abstract: As companies reported their latest quarterly earnings, their executives were frequently asked about their next moves on pricing.
lead_paragraph: Companies that sell food and other household staples — many of which have reported increased profits in their latest quarterly earnings — are weighing their next moves on prices as inflation cools.
headline: How Long Will Companies Keep Raising Prices on Consumer Goods?

abstract: Proposed new limits come as corporations may spend $1 trillion on stock repurchases this year.
lead_paragraph: When the Biden administration unveils its annual budget today, it will propose new ways to raise money from big companies and wealthy executives. One of these ideas could rewrite a fundamental practice in corporate America: stock buybacks.
headline: Biden Renews Pushback Against Stock Buybacks

abstract: The supposed link between buybacks and inequality is unproven.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in the news. This week, the financial journalist Roger Lowenstein weighs in on a plan by Senate Democrats to tax stock buybacks. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
headline: Why Taxing Stock Buybacks Is the Wrong Fix for Executive Pay

abstract: On his first day back in the top job, Howard Schultz made an abrupt change in policy at the company as it faces rising worker discontent.
lead_paragraph: As Starbucks faces a rising wave of employee unrest, its new chief executive is abruptly shifting how the coffee chain splits its profits between workers and shareholders.
headline: Starbucks’s new C.E.O. scraps stock buybacks to ‘invest more profit into our people.’

abstract: The job cuts, which amount to less than 5 percent of the company’s work force, are its largest in roughly eight years.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Wednesday became the latest addition to a growing list of big technology companies that have announced plans to lay off employees because of overhiring during the pandemic and worries about the economy.
headline: Microsoft to Lay Off 10,000 Workers as It Looks to Trim Costs

abstract: Microsoft also said it was negotiating changes to the deal to satisfy objections made by a British regulator, which could allow it to complete its purchase of the video game giant as soon as this month.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday ruled against the Federal Trade Commission’s attempt to delay Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, setting the stage for the tech giant and the video game publisher to merge as soon as this month.
headline: Judge Rejects F.T.C. Delay of $70 Billion Microsoft-Activision Deal

abstract: The fee will drop to 12 percent of revenue, from 30 percent, starting in August, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft will decrease the share of money it charges independent developers that publish PC games on its online store, starting in August, the company said on Thursday.
headline: Microsoft plans to take a smaller cut from developers in its games store.

abstract: The hackers appeared to be trying to learn what the company knew about them, a regulatory filing said.
lead_paragraph: An elite hacking group sponsored by Russian intelligence gained access to the emails of some of Microsoft’s senior executives beginning in late November, the company disclosed in a blog post and regulatory filing on Friday.
headline: Microsoft Executives’ Emails Hacked by Group Tied to Russian Intelligence

abstract: The company found a way to placate three of the most powerful regulatory bodies in the world, along with a federal judge in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: The first call that Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, made in early 2022 after his company announced a $69 billion deal to buy the video game publisher Activision Blizzard was to Kenichiro Yoshida, the chief executive of Sony.
headline: How Microsoft Turned the Tide in Its Regulatory Fight Over Activision

abstract: Microsoft said it would invest $1.5 billion in G42, an Emirati company with ties to China, as Washington and Beijing maneuver to secure tech influence in the Persian Gulf.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Tuesday that it would make a $1.5 billion investment in G42, an artificial intelligence giant in the United Arab Emirates, in a deal largely orchestrated by the Biden administration to box out China as Washington and Beijing battle over who will exercise technological influence in the Persian Gulf region and beyond.
headline: Microsoft Makes High-Stakes Play in Tech Cold War With Emirati A.I. Deal

abstract: The malware was revealed as Russian troops remained massed at the Ukrainian border, and after Ukrainian government agencies had their websites defaced.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Microsoft warned on Saturday evening that it had detected a highly destructive form of malware in dozens of government and private computer networks in Ukraine that appeared to be waiting to be triggered by an unknown actor.
headline: Microsoft Warns of Destructive Cyberattack on Ukrainian Computer Networks

abstract: They could save money if Activision’s titles are added to Xbox Game Pass, a monthly subscription service. But some are reserving judgment.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft announced that it was spending $69 billion to buy the video game maker Activision Blizzard in January last year, Justin Kats was stunned.
headline: As Microsoft Completes Activision Deal, Gamers Celebrate Cautiously

abstract: The extension is most likely a signal that the companies believe they will eventually receive needed approvals.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft and Activision Blizzard said on Wednesday that they were delaying a $69 billion merger as the two companies scrambled to get final approval from British antitrust regulators.
headline: Microsoft and Activision Delay Deal to Settle British Regulatory Issues

abstract: A mobile-inspired overhaul makes Microsoft’s newest operating system feel equally modern and unoriginal.
lead_paragraph: For tech reviewers, critiquing a new operating system is something of an absurd ritual.
headline: Taking Microsoft’s Windows 11 for a Test Drive

abstract: The tech giant and its partner OpenAI were accused of infringing on copyrights to train A.I. technologies like the online chatbot ChatGPT.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft filed a motion in federal court on Monday that seeks to dismiss parts of a lawsuit brought by The New York Times Company.
headline: Microsoft Seeks to Dismiss Parts of Suit Filed by The New York Times

abstract: Approval from British regulators for the $69 billion takeover was the last hurdle left for the tech giant, which saw off serious challenges to the transaction.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is poised to close its $69 billion takeover of the video game publisher Activision Blizzard, after British regulators signed off on the transaction on Friday.
headline: Microsoft Beats the Antitrust Odds on Its Activision Deal

abstract: “Digital adoption curves aren’t slowing down,” Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, said in a statement. “They’re accelerating.”
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Tuesday reported that its quarterly sales grew at one of its strongest rates in years, as the company was poised to cross $2 trillion in market value.
headline: Microsoft reports strongest quarterly growth in years, as profit also rises.

abstract: The pledge is unprecedented for Big Tech and makes it easier for roughly 100,000 workers to unionize.
lead_paragraph: Punctuating a year of major gains for organized labor, Microsoft has announced that it will stay neutral if any group of U.S.-based workers seeks to unionize.
headline: Microsoft Agrees to Remain Neutral in Union Campaigns

abstract: New artificial intelligence technology is roiling Silicon Valley. For now, the most obvious ways to use it are in software like Microsoft’s suite of products.
lead_paragraph: For all the talk about the transformative nature of new technology called generative artificial intelligence, some of the earlier commercial uses may be far more prosaic: formatting a PowerPoint slide, summarizing a call or writing to-do lists.
headline: Microsoft and Google Unveil A.I. Tools for Businesses

abstract: Corporate leaders are feeling emboldened by another legal defeat for the Federal Trade Commission, though the agency may still fight to block the takeover.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge’s decision to let Microsoft close its $70 billion takeover of the video game maker Activision Blizzard didn’t just represent a win for the tech giant. It’s also a major blow to the F.T.C., which had sought to block the transaction.
headline: What the Microsoft-Activision Ruling Means for the Future of Deal-Making

abstract: Brad Smith testified before a House committee a year after Chinese hackers infiltrated Microsoft’s technology and penetrated government networks.
lead_paragraph: Republican lawmakers questioned a senior Microsoft executive on Thursday about the company’s presence in China, about a year after Chinese hackers used the tech giant’s systems to launch a devastating hack of federal government networks.
headline: Lawmakers Question Microsoft’s President About Its Presence in China

abstract: An acquisition of Discord, a chat app for gamers, would buttress Microsoft’s gaming business.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Discord, a social media company popular with gamers, has held deal talks with Microsoft for a transaction that could top $10 billion, according to people briefed on the situation.
headline: Discord and Microsoft Said to Discuss Deal That Could Top $10 Billion

abstract: The hackers started their attack in January but escalated their efforts in recent weeks, security experts say. Business and government agencies were affected.
lead_paragraph: Businesses and government agencies in the United States that use a Microsoft email service have been compromised in an aggressive hacking campaign that was probably sponsored by the Chinese government, Microsoft said.
headline: Thousands of Microsoft Customers May Have Been Victims of Hack Tied to China

abstract: A former S.E.C. chief and a former White House economics chief on how progressive regulators are outsourcing U.S. regulatory policy to Europe.
lead_paragraph: Congress has given federal regulators broad authority over key areas of our society, and the actions of those regulators often have profound effects on our lives and on our future. We applaud the swift and decisive actions by financial regulators to prevent the run on Silicon Valley Bank from cascading through the regional banking system. But regulatory power is not absolute; it is granted by Congress and has strict limits, and its exercise requires due process.
headline: The Microsoft-Activision Mess Is a Blow to American Sovereignty

abstract: The blockbuster deal for the video game maker came together quickly and opportunistically.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s $68.7 billion deal to buy Activision Blizzard is a blockbuster bid to transform the tech giant’s present and its future. If completed, it would be Microsoft’s largest-ever deal and the biggest all-cash acquisition in history. For such a momentous deal, it came together relatively quickly, we can report.
headline: How Microsoft Bought Activision Blizzard

abstract: Chafing at their dependence, Amazon, Google, Meta and Microsoft are racing to cut into Nvidia’s dominant share of the market.
lead_paragraph: In September, Amazon said it would invest up to $4 billion in Anthropic, a San Francisco start-up working on artificial intelligence.
headline: Nvidia’s Big Tech Rivals Put Their Own A.I. Chips on the Table

abstract: Regulators are expected to give Microsoft’s proposed acquisition of Activision Blizzard — the largest in Microsoft’s history — a tough review.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Wednesday kicked off a charm offensive in Washington to gain government approval for its $70 billion deal to buy the video game company Activision Blizzard, saying it would not give preferential treatment to its own games in its app stores.
headline: Microsoft starts a charm offensive to push through its Activision deal.

abstract: Quarterly revenue was up 7 percent and profits were up 9 percent as the company embarked on an aggressive plan to embrace artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s cloud computing business drove a surprisingly strong quarter despite pressure from the slowing U.S. economy, the company said on Tuesday.
headline: Microsoft Beats Financial Expectations Despite Worries About Economy

abstract: The streaming giant hopes a less expensive offering will boost subscription numbers, which have dropped for the first time in a decade.
lead_paragraph: Netflix has selected Microsoft to help build its forthcoming ad-supported tier, the streaming giant said on Wednesday.
headline: Netflix turns to Microsoft to help build its new ad-supported service.

abstract: Until recently, antitrust regulators in Europe and the United States took different approaches. Now, they’re on the same page — which some experts say makes closing deals harder.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft announced its $70 billion acquisition of the video game maker Activision Blizzard last year, almost everyone involved expected antitrust inquiries from officials in the European Union and Britain, and many thought regulators there would try to block the deal. What U.S. enforcers would do, however, was less clear.
headline: Microsoft’s Activision Deal Tests a New Global Alignment on Antitrust

abstract: Officials said the social network had failed to block objectionable political content, a sign of the sacrifices it must make to remain in the vast but difficult market.
lead_paragraph: LinkedIn has been the lone major American social network allowed to operate in China. To do so, the Microsoft-owned service for professionals censors the posts made by its millions of Chinese users.
headline: China Punishes Microsoft’s LinkedIn Over Lax Censorship

abstract: Microsoft’s all-in moment on artificial intelligence has been defined by billions in spending and a C.E.O. counting on technology with huge potential and huge risks.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Satya Nadella hammered out a deal that surprised everyone outside his inner circle at Microsoft.
headline: How Microsoft’s Satya Nadella Became Tech’s Steely Eyed A.I. Gambler

abstract: As a new chatbot wows the world with its conversational talents, a resurgent tech giant is poised to reap the benefits while doubling down on a relationship with the start-up OpenAI.
lead_paragraph: When a chatbot called ChatGPT hit the internet late last year, executives at a number of Silicon Valley companies worried they were suddenly dealing with new artificial intelligence technology that could disrupt their businesses.
headline: Microsoft Bets Big on the Creator of ChatGPT in Race to Dominate A.I.

abstract: The reductions come three months after the tech giant completed its $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said Thursday that it would eliminate 1,900 roles in its video game division, including at Activision Blizzard, which it acquired for $69 billion three months ago.
headline: Microsoft Cuts 1,900 Jobs in Its Video Game Division

abstract: By launching Bing, Microsoft is abandoning the ethical principles it had carefully crafted around A.I.
lead_paragraph: The celebration that greeted Microsoft’s release of its A.I.-boosted search engine, Bing, to testers two weeks ago has lurched to alarm.
headline: History May Wonder Why Microsoft Let Its Principles Go for a Creepy, Clingy Bot

abstract: Activision has a lot of popular games that fit into Microsoft’s plans to build a vast library of titles that can be played on all sorts of devices. The metaverse can wait.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is inevitable now that when a big tech company makes a significant, strategic decision — like Microsoft’s plan to spend $70 billion on the video game giant Activision Blizzard — it invokes the metaverse.
headline: It’s Not Complicated. Microsoft Wants Activision for Its Games.

abstract: Revenue was up 18% in the latest quarter, the tech giant said, as investors look for signs that it’s beginning to profit from artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Microsoft topped Apple as the most valuable public company. Last week, it surpassed $3 trillion in market valuation. Next week, Satya Nadella will hit his 10th anniversary as the company’s chief executive.
headline: Microsoft Reports 33% Rise in Profit

abstract: The president of Microsoft says the company is focusing its PAC efforts on supporting democracy.
lead_paragraph: After the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Microsoft temporarily paused political contributions following revelations that the tech giant’s corporate PAC had previously made donations to members of Congress who voted to overturn the outcome of the 2020 presidential election. On Feb. 5, the company announced further changes to its approach to political contributions. While Microsoft’s president, Brad Smith, acknowledges that there is too much money in politics, he is not ready to pull the plug on donations entirely. “The future of technology increasingly is going to be decided in the world of politics,” he says.
headline: Microsoft’s Donations Got It in Trouble. But It’s Not Done With Politics.

abstract: Moscow also appears to be stepping up influence operations to weaken European and U.S. support for sending more aid to the Ukrainian government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A hacking group with ties to the Russian government appears to be preparing new cyberattacks on Ukraine’s infrastructure and government offices, Microsoft said in a report on Wednesday, suggesting that Russia’s long-anticipated spring offensive could include action in cyberspace, as well as on the ground.
headline: Russia’s Spring Offensive in Ukraine Could Include Cyberattacks, Microsoft Says

abstract: Revenue increased 13 percent in the latest quarter compared with a year earlier. Profit rose 27 percent.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Tuesday reported strong sales in its latest quarter, showing that its corporate customers have been shaking off jitters about spending heavily in the uncertain economy.
headline: Microsoft’s A.I. Investment Stabilizes Its Cloud Business

abstract: Video games have become weapons that tech titans wield to try to shape our future.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: With Activision, Microsoft Bets on the Future

abstract: Once again a juggernaut thanks to artificial intelligence, Microsoft has worked to shed its strong-arm image. Is there a catch?
lead_paragraph: The December day in 2021 that set off a revolution across the videogame industry appeared to start innocuously enough. Managers at a Wisconsin studio called Raven began meeting one by one with quality assurance testers, who vet video games for bugs, to announce that the company was overhauling their department. Going forward, managers said, the lucky testers would be permanent employees, not temps. They would earn an extra $1.50 an hour.
headline: Why Microsoft Has Accepted Unions, Unlike Its Rivals

abstract: The sale, which is expected to be the biggest in auction history for a private collection, will offer works from the Microsoft co-founder’s impressive cache that ranges from old masters to contemporary giants.
lead_paragraph: In the art world’s latest eye-popping development, Christie’s auction house announced on Thursday that it would sell the impressive art collection of Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft who died in 2018. The trove, which includes masterpieces by Renoir and Roy Lichtenstein, has an estimated valued of more than $1 billion.
headline: Christie’s to Sell Paul G. Allen’s $1 Billion Art Collection

abstract: Starting Feb. 28, “employees will have 30 days to make adjustments to their routines and adopt the working preferences they’ve agreed upon with their managers.”
lead_paragraph: Microsoft told employees that they will need to return to office next month, transitioning back to its corporate campus for the first time since the Omicron coronavirus variant tore through the nation.
headline: Microsoft tells workers to prepare to return to the office.

abstract: The tech giant aims to remain at the forefront of generative artificial intelligence with its partnership with OpenAI.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Monday that it was making a “multiyear, multibillion-dollar” investment in OpenAI, the San Francisco artificial intelligence lab behind the experimental online chatbot ChatGPT.
headline: Microsoft to Invest $10 Billion in OpenAI, the Creator of ChatGPT

abstract: The decision barring the takeover of a big video game publisher is a major victory for proponents of regulating tech giants, which have faced obstacles in the United States.
lead_paragraph: British antitrust regulators dealt a major setback on Wednesday to Microsoft’s plans to acquire the video game giant Activision Blizzard for $69 billion, blocking the proposed deal and handing a notable win to government enforcers around the world who want to rein in Big Tech.
headline: U.K. Blocks Microsoft’s $69 Billion Bid for Activision, a Blow for Tech Deals

abstract: Known for the Xbox, Microsoft has been diversifying away from boxy hardware in favor of reaching millions more new gamers.
lead_paragraph: In mid-2014, Satya Nadella, who had just become the chief executive of Microsoft, ushered the heads of the company’s gaming division into his fifth-floor office in Redmond, Wash.
headline: How Microsoft Is Ditching the Video Game Console Wars

abstract: Its president, Brad Smith, said companies needed to “step up” and governments needed to “move faster” as artificial intelligence progressed.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft endorsed a crop of regulations for artificial intelligence on Thursday, as the company navigates concerns from governments around the world about the risks of the rapidly evolving technology.
headline: Microsoft Calls for A.I. Rules to Minimize the Technology’s Risks

abstract: By acquiring a provider of artificial-intelligence software, the tech giant is hoping to bolster its offerings for the fast-growing field of medical computing.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Monday that it would buy Nuance Communications, a provider of artificial-intelligence and speech-recognition software, for about $16 billion, as it pushes to expand its health care technology services.
headline: Microsoft to Buy Nuance for $16 Billion to Focus on Health Care Tech

abstract: The bloc’s antitrust regulators could side with Microsoft on Monday, but the tech giant still faces an uphill battle to gaining full  approval.
lead_paragraph: European antitrust regulators are set to weigh in Monday on Microsoft’s $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard. In a twist, the European Commission is reportedly set to approve a video game megadeal that its American and British counterparts have already rejected.
headline: The $69 Billion Microsoft-Activision Deal Faces a Big E.U. Test

abstract: Mr. Gates, who at the time was Microsoft’s chairman, had asked a female employee out on a date, a Microsoft spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft executives warned Bill Gates in 2008 about inappropriate emails he had sent to a female employee, a Microsoft spokesman said on Monday.
headline: Microsoft leaders warned Bill Gates over ‘inappropriate’ emails.

abstract: The tech giant’s quarterly results included strong growth in cloud computing, fueled by its services in generative artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft gave more signs on Thursday that its hefty investments in artificial intelligence were beginning to bear fruit, as it reported a 17 percent jump in revenue and a 20 percent increase in profit for the first three months of the year.
headline: Microsoft Reports Rising Revenues as A.I. Investments Bear Fruit

abstract: The company had its first $5 billion quarter for its gaming business, as people looked for entertainment at home and Microsoft launched the long awaited new generation of its Xbox console.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft continued to benefit from the pandemic’s shift to remote computing and gaming, with revenue and profits reaching new heights in the latest quarter, the company said on Tuesday.
headline: Microsoft profits jump 33 percent as pandemic continues shift to cloud computing.

abstract: The tech giant has been accused of stifling competition by packaging its video conferencing app with other tools like Word and Excel.
lead_paragraph: European Union regulators on Tuesday charged Microsoft with breaking antitrust rules by bundling its Teams video conferencing and collaboration software with a suite of other productivity tools, giving it an unfair advantage over rivals.
headline: E.U. Charges Microsoft With Antitrust Violations Over Teams Bundling

abstract: In federal court, Satya Nadella and Bobby Kotick opposed an attempt by the F.T.C. to delay Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of a video game giant.
lead_paragraph: Satya Nadella, the chief executive of Microsoft, appeared in federal court on Wednesday to pledge his support for open platforms and consumer choice, underscoring the tech giant’s commitment to closing its $70 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard over regulators’ objections.
headline: Microsoft and Activision Chiefs Testify Merger Will Benefit Consumers

abstract: The arrangement is likely to create waves inside Microsoft, where some employees have objected to working with the Pentagon.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said Wednesday that it would begin producing more than 120,000 augmented reality headsets for Army soldiers under a contract that could be worth up to $21.9 billion.
headline: Microsoft will make augmented reality headsets for the Army in a $21.9 billion deal.

abstract: Robert Iger, brought back as Disney’s C.E.O., unveiled his vision for more austere operations. New inflation data is coming out.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s often-overlooked search engine, Bing, is mounting a comeback with ChatGPT, the suddenly ubiquitous chatbot capable of composing song lyrics, writing academic essays and answering all manner of questions. The new version of Bing was released to a limited group of users on Tuesday. The revamped product is part of Microsoft’s $13 billion investment in OpenAI, the artificial intelligence lab behind ChatGPT that Microsoft is betting on to stay competitive with its big tech rivals like Google, Apple and Meta. But those companies are also racing to incorporate the new technology into their own software. A day before the unveiling of the new Bing, Google announced that it would soon release an experimental chatbot called Bard for its own search engine, which is much more widely used than Bing. And Meta is fast-tracking the development of chatbot technology for its products.
headline: The Week in Business: Microsoft’s Big Bet on A.I.

abstract: Millions of articles from The New York Times were used to train chatbots that now compete with it, the lawsuit said.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times sued OpenAI and Microsoft for copyright infringement on Wednesday, opening a new front in the increasingly intense legal battle over the unauthorized use of published work to train artificial intelligence technologies.
headline: The Times Sues OpenAI and Microsoft Over A.I. Use of Copyrighted Work

abstract: The move by the commission signals an aggressive stance by federal regulators to thwart the expansion of the tech industry’s biggest companies.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission, in one of the most aggressive actions taken by federal regulators in decades to check the power of the tech industry’s giants, on Thursday sued to block Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of the video game maker Activision Blizzard.
headline: F.T.C. Sues to Block Microsoft’s $69 Billion Acquisition of Activision

abstract: The group will become the largest union at a video game company in the United States, while Microsoft pledged to stay neutral on the vote.
lead_paragraph: About 600 workers at Activision Publishing, the video game maker owned by Microsoft, are unionizing, forming the largest video game workers’ union in the United States, the Communications Workers of America said on Friday. Microsoft recognized the union after the vote count was finalized.
headline: About 600 Workers Unionize at Microsoft-Owned Activision

abstract: A five-day hearing over Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition, which the Federal Trade Commission hopes to block, began Thursday in federal court.
lead_paragraph: The first day of a weeklong hearing that could determine the outcome of Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of the video game giant Activision Blizzard opened Thursday with a promise from Microsoft: If a federal judge grants an injunction that would delay the deal’s closing, Microsoft could abandon the deal altogether.
headline: Microsoft Says It Could Abandon Activision Deal if Judge Delays It

abstract: A museum’s worth of masterworks from the Microsoft co-founder’s collection are offered in a two-part charity sale. Five topped $100 million.
lead_paragraph: Just when it seemed the high-flying art market couldn’t soar any higher, paintings and sculptures from the collection of the Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen hit the $1.5 billion mark at Christie’s New York on Wednesday night, making it the biggest sale in auction history.
headline: Paul G. Allen’s Art at Christie’s Tops $1.5 Billion, Cracking Records

abstract: It plans to remove restrictions only once the virus acts “more like an endemic virus such as the seasonal flu,” an executive wrote.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has joined other corporate giants in assessing the best way to bring workers back to the office, a year after the pandemic sent home employees, who had to learn how to be productive on video conference calls while juggling interruptions from families, pets and the doorbell.
headline: Microsoft to Ease Workers Back to the Office Starting Next Week

abstract: The earnings were driven by success in the company’s Microsoft Cloud business, which includes Office 365 subscriptions and Azure.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft produced its most profitable quarter. Again.
headline: Microsoft profit soars 48%, to $20.5 billion.

abstract: The suit, which accuses the tech companies of copyright infringement, adds to the fight over the online data used to power artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Eight daily newspapers owned by Alden Global Capital sued OpenAI and Microsoft on Tuesday, accusing the tech companies of illegally using news articles to power their A.I. chatbots.
headline: 8 Daily Newspapers Sue OpenAI and Microsoft Over A.I.

abstract: In seeking to oppose the $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard, the agency is hoping to revamp the nation’s antitrust rules — even if it loses.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration yesterday took its boldest step yet in challenging the reach of tech giants when the F.T.C. sued to block Microsoft’s $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard.
headline: The Stakes Behind the F.T.C.’s Bid to Block Microsoft’s Big Deal

abstract: The government’s antitrust case against Google borrows heavily from the landmark lawsuit against Microsoft 25 years ago. But it lacks the same cultural impact.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department argues in a federal antitrust suit that Google is a dominant tech company that has abused its market power to bully industry partners, protect its monopoly and thwart competition.
headline: Microsoft, Google and Antitrust: Similar Legal Theories in a Different Era

abstract: A change in Microsoft Word’s default typeface, from Calibri to Aptos, didn’t register for everyone, but fans of typography got excited.
lead_paragraph: When you read — a book, a traffic sign, a billboard, this article — how much do you really notice the letters? If you’re like most people, the answer is probably not at all.
headline: Microsoft Word’s Subtle Typeface Change Affected Millions. Did You Notice?

abstract: In his lawsuit against OpenAI and its chief executive, Sam Altman, Mr. Musk relies on a provocative paper from the start-up’s closest partner.
lead_paragraph: When Elon Musk sued OpenAI and its chief executive, Sam Altman, for breach of contract on Thursday, he turned claims by the start-up’s closest partner, Microsoft, into a weapon.
headline: Why Elon Musk’s OpenAI Lawsuit Leans on A.I. Research From Microsoft

abstract: The company aims to be “carbon negative” by the end of the decade, but its emissions rose sharply in the most recent year measured.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has an ambitious plan to cut its carbon emissions. But on Thursday, the company reported a big increase in the greenhouse gases emanating from its operations and its products, a reminder of the challenges that companies face as they try to clean up their businesses.
headline: Microsoft’s Pursuit of Climate Goals Runs Into Headwinds

abstract: As regulatory scrutiny picks up, the tech giant says it is pleased with the progress OpenAI has made with governance and considers its oversight role unnecessary.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has given up its seat on OpenAI’s board, relinquishing a nonvoting position it gained late last year, as regulators intensify their scrutiny of the ties between the tech giant and the start-up behind the chatbot ChatGPT.
headline: Microsoft Surrenders OpenAI Board Position

abstract: Its sales of $49.4 billion in the first quarter were up 18 percent from a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Despite inflation and uncertainty over the war in Ukraine, Microsoft on Tuesday reported financial results that showed little threat to the fundamentals of its business.
headline: Microsoft reports rising revenue and profits, despite war and inflation.

abstract: The British antitrust watchdog blocked the takeover attempt, in a decision that will be closely watched in Washington and Brussels.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s mergers regulator on Wednesday blocked Microsoft’s $69 billion takeover bid for Activision Blizzard, ruling that buying the maker of “Call of Duty” would give the tech giant too much control of the thriving market for cloud-based video games.
headline: The U.K. Deals a Huge Blow to Microsoft’s $69 Billion Activision Bid

abstract: The move appears to be an olive branch to the Federal Trade Commission, which could vote to block the $69 billion acquisition in a closed-door session on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: In a last-minute attempt to placate antitrust regulators, Microsoft said on Tuesday night that it would bring the blockbuster video game franchise Call of Duty to Nintendo devices if its $69 billion acquisition of the game’s maker, Activision Blizzard, was completed.
headline: Microsoft to Offer Call of Duty on Nintendo Devices if Activision Deal Closes

abstract: Some players, unhappy with Activision in recent years, said the Microsoft deal could reverse a decline in quality.
lead_paragraph: When Drew Bienusa began playing Call of Duty, a first-person shooter game published by Activision Blizzard, he was immediately smitten. He loved how immersive having a digital avatar was, and the game was a favorite among his friends.
headline: ‘New Eyes’: Gamers Greet Microsoft’s Activision Deal With Guarded Optimism

abstract: Though interest in Halo has waned over the years, the company is banking on a new version to goose sales of its Xbox and subscription gaming service.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft released its first Xbox console 20 years ago, executives did not think that Halo, a new game set in a 26th-century galactic war pitting humans against alien invaders, would become the face of the tech giant’s gaming aspirations.
headline: With Halo Infinite, Microsoft Hopes to Rekindle Its Flagship Game

abstract: Amid U.S.-China tensions, the company has faced questions over whether operating an advanced research lab in Beijing is politically tenable.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft opened an advanced research lab in Beijing in 1998, it was a time of optimism about technology and China.
headline: Microsoft Debates What to Do With A.I. Lab in China

abstract: The technology giant will stop offering automated tools that predict a person’s gender, age and emotional state and will restrict the use of its facial recognition tool.
lead_paragraph: For years, activists and academics have been raising concerns that facial analysis software that claims to be able to identify a person’s age, gender and emotional state can be biased, unreliable or invasive — and shouldn’t be sold.
headline: Microsoft Plans to Eliminate Face Analysis Tools in Push for ‘Responsible A.I.’

abstract: The group was likely using the websites to install malware that helped it gather data from government agencies and other groups, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Monday that it had seized 42 websites from a Chinese hacking group in an effort to disrupt the group’s intelligence-gathering operations.
headline: Microsoft Seizes 42 Websites From a Chinese Hacking Group

abstract: A poll generated by artificial intelligence, embedded next to a Guardian article on Microsoft’s news aggregator platform, asked readers to speculate on the cause of a woman’s death.
lead_paragraph: An auto-generated poll that Microsoft embedded on its news aggregating platform alongside a Guardian article was “crass” and caused significant damage to The Guardian’s reputation, the newspaper said on Thursday.
headline: Microsoft Criticized for Embedding ‘Crass’ A.I. Poll Beside News Article

abstract: Plus, Argentina elects a far-right president and Rosalynn Carter dies at 96.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
headline: Microsoft Hires OpenAI’s Ousted C.E.O., and More

abstract: “Did you ever think we would have a literal Avenger fighting back against the relentless march of A.I.? Because that’s sort of what this story is about.”
lead_paragraph: This week, more drama at OpenAI: The company wanted Scarlett Johansson to be a voice of GPT-4o, she said no … but something got lost in translation. Then we talk with Noland Arbaugh, the first person to get Elon Musk’s Neuralink device implanted in his brain, about how his brain-computer interface has changed his life. And finally, the Times’s Karen Weise reports back from Microsoft’s developer conference, where the big buzz was that the company’s new line of A.I. PCs will record every single thing you do on the device.
headline: ScarJo vs. ChatGPT, Neuralink’s First Patient Opens Up, and Microsoft’s A.I. PCs

abstract: Shareholders called for action after evidence emerged that Bill Gates had sought romantic relationships with employees.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has selected a law firm to review its sexual harassment and gender discrimination policies, the company’s board announced on Thursday, after shareholders raised alarms about how Microsoft and Bill Gates, one of its founders, had treated employees, especially women.
headline: Microsoft opens a review of its sexual harassment policies.

abstract: The megadeal could strengthen Microsoft’s standing in the video game industry, after a year and a half of negotiations with regulators around the world.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Friday that it had closed its $69 billion purchase of the video game giant Activision Blizzard, overcoming significant regulatory hurdles in Britain and the United States and signaling that the tech industry’s giants are still free to use their cash hoards to get even bigger.
headline: Microsoft Closes $69 Billion Activision Deal, Overcoming Regulators’ Objections

abstract: Microsoft has remained neutral during a labor organizing bid as the Xbox maker seeks regulatory approval for its Activision acquisition.
lead_paragraph: A few months after Microsoft announced plans to acquire the video game maker Activision Blizzard, the tech giant said it would remain neutral if Activision workers sought to unionize once the deal went through. Now, a major union is testing Microsoft’s appetite for organizing at a company it already owns.
headline: Video Game Workers at Microsoft and Activision Take Steps to Unionize

abstract: The F.T.C. and D.O.J. are hampered by persistent underinvestment in regulatory oversight.
lead_paragraph: There’s been no shortage of excellent analyses on why Microsoft agreed to buy Activision Blizzard this week for a staggering $70 billion in cash. It could be a simple strategic fit in the fast-growing video games industry or an opportunistic acquisition in the midst of a sexual harassment investigation that’s dented Activision’s stock. Others surmised it filled a need for Microsoft to bulk up against other bigger competitors and, naturally, something about the metaverse, which feels like the justification for everything these days. But one reason sticks in my mind: Because Microsoft can.
headline: Microsoft and the Mania for Mergers

abstract: Technology companies were once leery of what some artificial intelligence could do. Now the priority is winning control of the industry’s next big thing.
lead_paragraph: In March, two Google employees, whose jobs are to review the company’s artificial intelligence products, tried to stop Google from launching an A.I. chatbot. They believed it generated inaccurate and dangerous statements.
headline: In A.I. Race, Microsoft and Google Choose Speed Over Caution

abstract: The new, A.I.-powered system was released to a small audience a week ago. Microsoft says it is working out its issues.
lead_paragraph: A week after it was released to a few thousand users, Microsoft’s new Bing search engine, which is powered by artificial intelligence, has been offering an array of inaccurate and at times bizarre responses to some users.
headline: Microsoft’s Bing Chatbot Offers Some Puzzling and Inaccurate Responses

abstract: The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission agreed to divide responsibility for investigating three major players in the artificial intelligence industry.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators have reached a deal that allows them to proceed with antitrust investigations into the dominant roles that Microsoft, OpenAI and Nvidia play in the artificial intelligence industry, in the strongest sign of how regulatory scrutiny into the powerful technology has escalated.
headline: U.S. Clears Way for Antitrust Inquiries of Nvidia, Microsoft and OpenAI

abstract: The Biden administration organized a broad group of allies to condemn Beijing for cyberattacks around the world, but stopped short of taking concrete punitive steps.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration for the first time on Monday accused the Chinese government of breaching Microsoft email systems used by many of the world’s largest companies, governments and military contractors, as the United States rallied a broad group of allies to condemn Beijing for cyberattacks around the world.
headline: U.S. Accuses China of Hacking Microsoft

abstract: The agency had sued to halt the blockbuster deal last year. Its latest move in federal court would prevent the acquisition from being completed.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission sued Microsoft on Monday to stop the company from closing its $69 billion purchase of the video game powerhouse Activision Blizzard, escalating the federal government’s efforts to stymie the largest consumer technology deal in decades.
headline: F.T.C. Sues to Stop Microsoft’s Activision Deal From Closing

abstract: A provocative paper from researchers at Microsoft claims A.I. technology shows the ability to understand the way people do. Critics say those scientists are kidding themselves.
lead_paragraph: When computer scientists at Microsoft started to experiment with a new artificial intelligence system last year, they asked it to solve a puzzle that should have required an intuitive understanding of the physical world.
headline: Microsoft Says New A.I. Shows Signs of Human Reasoning

abstract: A new study by Microsoft shows that Russian cyberattacks often happened within days or even hours of missile strikes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For weeks after the outbreak of the war in Ukraine, American officials wondered about the weapon that seemed to be missing: Russia’s mighty cyberarsenal, which most experts expected would be used in the opening hours of an invasion to bring down Ukraine’s power grid, fry its cellphone system and cut off President Volodymyr Zelensky from the world.
headline: Russia Uses Cyberattacks in Ukraine to Support Military Strikes, Report Finds

abstract: Researchers from the Citizen Lab, a cybersecurity research group, found that the most diligent censor in China is Microsoft’s search engine Bing, the only foreign search engine operating in the country.
lead_paragraph: China’s internet censorship is well known, but a report has quantified the extent of it, uncovering more than 66,000 rules controlling the content that is available to people using search engines.
headline: China’s Search Engines Have More Than 66,000 Rules Controlling Content, Report Says

abstract: The hack, by a Chinese group that the company said was intent on conducting espionage, went undetected for a month.
lead_paragraph: Chinese hackers intent on collecting intelligence on the United States gained access to government email accounts, Microsoft disclosed on Tuesday night.
headline: Chinese Hackers Breached Government Email Accounts, Microsoft Says

abstract: The company that has invested billions in generative A.I. pioneers like OpenAI says giant systems aren’t necessarily what everyone needs.
lead_paragraph: In the dizzying race to build generative A.I. systems, the tech industry’s mantra has been bigger is better, no matter the price tag.
headline: Microsoft Makes a New Push Into Smaller A.I. Systems

abstract: The entertainment industry is still grappling with the digital future.
lead_paragraph: Will the premiere of the 25th James Bond movie, “No Time to Die” — delayed since last year because of the Covid pandemic — result in big ticket sales for the much beleaguered movie theater industry? So far, demand for the film is tracking well in presales — and in excitement — which is in fitting with an overall upward trend in ticket sales since they sank at the start of the pandemic.
headline: Hollywood’s Recovery, Live Events in the Covid Era and Microsoft

abstract: Ms. Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, has staked an ambitious trustbusting agenda on a case that may be difficult to win.
lead_paragraph: Lina Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, has pledged to usher in a new era of trustbusting of America’s corporate giants, recently saying the agency plans to “enforce the antitrust laws to ensure maximal efficacy.”
headline: Lina Khan, Aiming to Block Microsoft’s Activision Deal, Faces a Challenge

abstract: With the completion of the blockbuster acquisition, the notion that tech giants can grow through “vertical transactions” remains intact.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s top antitrust officials have used novel arguments over the past few years to stop tech giants and other large companies from making deals, a strategy that has had mixed success.
headline: The Upshot of Microsoft’s Activision Deal: Big Tech Can Get Even Bigger

abstract: The $69 billion video game acquisition is expected to be finalized soon after the sign-off from British regulators.
lead_paragraph: British regulators on Friday gave final approval to Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of the video game publisher Activision Blizzard, the last major obstacle for a deal that at one point seemed to be falling apart because of government objections on both sides of the Atlantic.
headline: Microsoft Finally Closes In on Activision Deal After Key Approval

abstract: Prosecutors compare their new fight against Apple to the seminal case against Windows in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Impeding innovation. Reducing consumer choice. Extending dominance to other markets.
headline: The Second Coming of the Microsoft Antitrust Battle?

abstract: Britain’s antitrust regulator said the companies had addressed its main concerns about the $69 billion deal, though final approval is yet to come.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft came one step closer on Friday to completing its $69 billion purchase of the video game maker Activision Blizzard, in a deal that has become an example of how a company can successfully ride out stricter regulatory scrutiny of the power of tech giants.
headline: Microsoft Closes In on Activision Deal After Britain Signals Approval

abstract: The green light follows objections to the blockbuster deal by American and British regulators on the grounds that it would undercut competition.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s faltering $69 billion bid to buy the video game company Activision Blizzard received a glimmer of hope on Monday when European Union regulators approved what would be the largest consumer tech deal in two decades.
headline: E.U. Approves Microsoft’s $69 Billion Deal for Activision

abstract: The tech giant moved quickly to hire Sam Altman and others after their abrupt departures from OpenAI, a key Microsoft partner.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft, the technology giant that ranks as one of the world’s most valuable companies, was shaken by the upheaval at OpenAI, the small but influential artificial intelligence start-up that developed the ChatGPT chatbot, before it found a way out of the turmoil that propelled its shares to a new high.
headline: Microsoft’s Stock Hits Record High After Hiring OpenAI Outcasts

abstract: Microsoft made epic mistakes for years, but it’s again one of the tech world’s superstars.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Why Didn’t Microsoft Die?

abstract: The technology giant faced a strong U.S. dollar and weakening demand for personal computers in its latest financial results.
lead_paragraph: Facing a strong U.S. dollar and weakening personal computer sales, Microsoft on Tuesday reported its slowest growth in five years.
headline: Microsoft Reports Slowest Revenue Growth in Five Years

abstract: “People should be able to see these pictures, and enjoy them, and appreciate them,” the Microsoft co-founder said. Will Allen’s cache of science fiction objects have a different future from the masterpieces auctioned last week?
lead_paragraph: A van Gogh landscape to die for. A sacred scene by Botticelli that puts a lump in your throat. One of Jasper Johns’s stunningly subtle map paintings.
headline: Paul G. Allen and the Art He Didn’t Sell

abstract: Federal regulators have sued to block the $69 billion acquisition, but the company has settled on a path forward and is preparing to force the issue.
lead_paragraph: Early this month, Brad Smith, Microsoft’s president, met with Lina Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, to push for regulatory approval of Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of the video game company Activision Blizzard.
headline: Microsoft Gambles on ‘Nice Guy’ Strategy to Close Activision Megadeal

abstract: The accord could ease the path for thousands of workers to unionize at the game company, which Microsoft is acquiring, and addresses an antitrust objection.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft and the Communications Workers of America union announced an agreement on Monday that would make it easier for employees to unionize at the video game maker Activision Blizzard, which Microsoft is acquiring for $70 billion.
headline: Microsoft Pledges Neutrality in Union Campaigns at Activision

abstract: Hiring Mustafa Suleyman, the DeepMind co-founder, is a coup for the tech giant’s ambitions. But regulators may be skeptical.
lead_paragraph: The heavyweight fight to dominate artificial intelligence just entered a new round. Microsoft has poached an A.I. pioneer just as Apple and Google discuss forming a united front to make up lost ground.
headline: Is Microsoft Building an Unassailable Lead in A.I.?

abstract: With the deal, the largest in the software maker’s history, Microsoft will acquire Activision’s huge pool of users and access to some of the world’s most popular games.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft plans to buy the powerhouse but troubled video game company Activision Blizzard for nearly $70 billion, its biggest deal ever and one that places a major bet that people will be spending more and more time in the digital world.
headline: Microsoft will buy Activision Blizzard, betting $70 billion on the future of games.

abstract: The tech giant cited the strong U.S. dollar, falling consumer demand and production slowdowns of PCs for its performance.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The uncertainty and challenges in the global economy have hit Microsoft, which on Tuesday reported quarterly earnings that fell short of Wall Street’s and its own expectations.
headline: Microsoft reports earnings that fall short of already-reduced expectations.

abstract: In a letter to Microsoft’s chief executive, Satya Nadella, Twitter said the tech giant had violated a data agreement.
lead_paragraph: Twitter on Thursday sent a letter to Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, accusing the tech giant of improperly using the social media company’s data.
headline: Twitter Accuses Microsoft of Improperly Using Its Data

abstract: Amid the tech industry’s worst slump in decades, industry leaders are predicting an era built on new chatbots and other types of artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a rough few months for the tech industry. There have been tens of thousands of layoffs, hundreds of billions in value lost on Wall Street and a high-profile scandal at a crypto company that has shaken faith in that young market.
headline: A Tech Race Begins as Microsoft Adds A.I. to Its Search Engine

abstract: The decision puts an end to years of legal wrangling over the contract, for 10 years of cloud-computing services.
lead_paragraph: The Defense Department said on Tuesday that it would not go forward with a lucrative cloud-computing contract that had become the subject of a contentious legal battle amid claims of interference by the Trump administration.
headline: Pentagon Cancels a Disputed $10 Billion Technology Contract

abstract: Mustafa Suleyman is leaving a start-up called Inflection to take the senior position with Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: Mustafa Suleyman, a co-founder of Google’s DeepMind artificial intelligence lab, is leaving the start-up he was running to lead Microsoft’s consumer A.I. business, in another sign of Microsoft’s aggressive plans for the technology.
headline: Microsoft Hires DeepMind Co-Founder to Run Consumer A.I.

abstract: The announcement capped a tumultuous weekend for OpenAI, after Mr. Altman made a push to reclaim his job as C.E.O. of the artificial intelligence company.
lead_paragraph: The board of directors of OpenAI, the high-flying artificial intelligence start-up, said in a note to employees on Sunday night that its former chief, Sam Altman, would not be returning to his job, while naming his second interim replacement in two days.
headline: Microsoft Hires Sam Altman Hours After OpenAI Rejects His Return

abstract: Users outside China said the site had failed to call up videos and images of the iconic figure from the 1989 crackdown. The company blamed an “accidental human error.”
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s Bing search engine briefly blocked images and videos of the famous “tank man” of Tiananmen Square on Friday, the anniversary of China’s massacre of pro-democracy protesters in 1989, in what the company said was an error.
headline: Microsoft’s Bing Briefly Blocked ‘Tank Man’ on Tiananmen Anniversary

abstract: An acquisition that once faced long odds now appears to be on a path toward approval.
lead_paragraph: British antitrust officials said on Tuesday that they were reviewing a revised offer by Microsoft to win approval of its $69 billion merger with Activision Blizzard, an effort to clear the biggest remaining regulatory hurdle to the major video games deal.
headline: Microsoft Offers British Regulators Changes to Activision Deal

abstract: The chip maker’s stock price has jumped over the last year thanks to its stranglehold on the market for the chips needed to build A.I. systems.
lead_paragraph: Move over, Microsoft and Apple. The stock market has a new king.
headline: Nvidia Becomes Most Valuable Public Company, Topping Microsoft

abstract: The shift is indicative of the importance of new artificial intelligence technology to Silicon Valley and Wall Street investors.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Apple was the stock market’s undisputed king. It first overtook Exxon Mobil as the world’s most valuable public company in 2011 and held the title almost without interruption.
headline: Microsoft Tops Apple to Become Most Valuable Public Company

abstract: After years of talks about the need for public-private partnerships to combat cyberattacks, the war in Ukraine is stress-testing the system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last Wednesday, a few hours before Russian tanks began rolling into Ukraine, alarms went off inside Microsoft’s Threat Intelligence Center, warning of a never-before-seen piece of “wiper” malware that appeared aimed at the country’s government ministries and financial institutions.
headline: As Tanks Rolled Into Ukraine, So Did Malware. Then Microsoft Entered the War.

abstract: The new technology has gone down unusual, sometimes unnerving paths in lengthy conversations with some early users.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft will start limiting conversations with the new chatbot in its Bing search engine to five questions per session and 50 questions per day, the company said on Friday.
headline: Microsoft to Limit Length of Bing Chatbot Conversations

abstract: The company, which announced plans to lay off 10,000 workers last week, had warned that was facing a significant slowdown in the growth of its sales.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Tuesday reported its slowest growth in six years and cautioned that a broader slump will continue as both consumers and businesses put the brakes on spending.
headline: Microsoft Revenue Up 2 Percent, but Profit Drops 12 Percent

abstract: The tech giant is unbundling Teams from its Office software suite, as it faces mounting scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is separating Teams, its popular video and chat app, from its Office software suite in markets around the world, broadening a split that began in the European Union last fall.
headline: Regulators Force Another Microsoft Split

abstract: Why are so many major companies investing in this new digital world — and what is it, anyway?
lead_paragraph: Microsoft announced this week that it was acquiring Activision Blizzard, the maker of video games such as Call of Duty and Candy Crush, in a deal valued at nearly $70 billion.
headline: Microsoft and the Metaverse

abstract: The widely used Microsoft Teams and Outlook email services were unavailable for thousands of users early Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft restored access to its email and video conferencing tools on Wednesday after thousands of users were unable to connect to the services for hours.
headline: Microsoft Services Back Online After Morning Outages

abstract: The outcome, involving about 300 employees, is one of organized labor’s biggest victories at a major U.S. tech company.
lead_paragraph: Organized labor claimed one of its biggest victories at a U.S. tech company on Tuesday, gaining a foothold among about 300 employees at a video game maker owned by Microsoft.
headline: Video Game Workers Get a Union Foothold at Microsoft

abstract: The OpenAI fracas most likely cements control of one of the most powerful and promising technologies on the planet under one of this country’s tech titans.
lead_paragraph: There was the coup that hit the headlines: the OpenAI board’s abrupt ousting of its co-founder and chief executive, Sam Altman. Now we are on the verge of a second, even more critical coup, one that cements control of one of the most powerful and promising technologies on the planet under one of this country’s tech titans.
headline: The OpenAI Coup Is Great for Microsoft. What Does It Mean for Us?

abstract: Profit and sales at the tech giant, the first of the largest tech companies to report earnings for the three months ending in December, grew about 20 percent.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft announced record profit and sales on Tuesday despite investor fears that the pandemic-fueled tech boom may be over.
headline: Microsoft’s profit continues to climb.

abstract: Mr. Nadella moved fast to hire Sam Altman, who was pushed out of OpenAI on Friday, and asserted his company’s role in its partnership with the A.I. start-up.
lead_paragraph: Just two weeks ago, Microsoft’s Satya Nadella stood onstage next to OpenAI’s Sam Altman at the start-up’s conference in a former concert hall in San Francisco. Both wore black jeans, Mr. Altman in an army-green shirt and Mr. Nadella in navy casual.
headline: How Microsoft’s Satya Nadella Kept the ‘Best Bromance in Tech’ Alive

abstract: The company pushed back its reopening, which had been slated for Oct. 4.
headline: The latest: Microsoft delays its return to the office indefinitely.

abstract: The company’s profit topped $20 billion as it pointed to early interest in its artificial intelligence products.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft reported record sales and profits on Tuesday, as it shook off recession fears and began seeing the early impacts of its investments in generative artificial intelligence.
headline: Microsoft Revenue Up 8% to $56.2 Billion in Latest Quarter
Catch up: Google’s and Microsoft’s profits soar as pandemic benefits Big Tech.

abstract: Profits rose 47 percent to $16.5 billion, surpassing expectations.
lead_paragraph: With the pandemic accelerating the turn to cloud computing, Microsoft continued its string of strong financial results.
headline: Microsoft had its most profitable quarter.

abstract: The company knew the new technology had issues like occasional accuracy problems. But users have prodded surprising and unnerving interactions.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft introduced a new version of its Bing search engine that includes the artificial intelligence of a chatbot last week, company executives knew they were climbing out on a limb.
headline: Microsoft Considers More Limits for Its New A.I. Chatbot

abstract: Lawyers for the Justice Department and Google as well as the judge in a monthslong trial have invoked the landmark case against Microsoft from the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Antitrust trials are full of long stretches of detailed, often tedious testimony punctuated by telling moments. In the two-month Google antitrust trial that is nearing its conclusion, one of those moments came in a brief exchange in October.
headline: How Microsoft’s Legal Legacy Shapes the Antitrust Case Against Google

abstract: A British agency’s move to block the company’s $69 billion bid for the video games company reflects a new regulatory reality for corporate buyers.
lead_paragraph: A British regulator’s decision to reject Microsoft’s $69 billion takeover bid for Activision Blizzard stunned many who had expected the deal to go through. That’s especially because moves this month by the agency, the Competition and Markets Authority, suggested that the transaction might pass muster.
headline: What Microsoft’s Activision Setback Means for Deal Making

abstract: Satya Nadella, the chief executive of Microsoft, is the government’s biggest-name witness in its landmark antitrust case against Google.
lead_paragraph: Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, testified on Monday that Google’s power in online search was so ubiquitous that even his company found it difficult to compete on the internet, becoming the government’s highest-profile witness in its landmark antitrust trial against the search giant.
headline: Microsoft C.E.O. Testifies That Google’s Power in Search Is Ubiquitous

abstract: Microsoft’s $69 billion deal for Activision Blizzard, which is undergoing reviews in 16 countries, has become a test for whether tech giants can buy companies amid a backlash.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Microsoft has accused Sony, its chief video game rival, of misleading regulators. Its lawyers have showed off game consoles, including an Xbox, to British officials. And the president of a major union that Microsoft wooed has spoken up on the company’s behalf to the Federal Trade Commission.
headline: Can Big Tech Get Bigger? Microsoft Presses Governments to Say Yes.

abstract: Brad Smith, Microsoft’s president, told Congress he supports the Journalism Competition and Protection Act, which empowers news publishers to collectively bargain with online platforms like Facebook and Google.
lead_paragraph: Brad Smith, Microsoft’s president, told Congress he supports the Journalism Competition and Protection Act, which empowers news publishers to collectively bargain with online platforms like Facebook and Google.
headline: Microsoft Executive Says Tech Consolidation Threatens Journalism

abstract: Microsoft broke records with the announcement of its planned acquisition of the video game publisher Activision Blizzard, which has been battered by accusations of having a toxic work environment. The $68.7 billion purchase will undoubtedly upend the gaming industry, with the sale giving the tech giant access to top series like Call of Duty, Overwatch,...
snippet: Microsoft broke records with the announcement of its planned acquisition of the video game publisher Activision Blizzard, which has been battered by accusations of having a toxic work environment. The $68.7 billion purchase will undoubtedly upend ...
lead_paragraph: Microsoft broke records with the announcement of its planned acquisition of the video game publisher Activision Blizzard, which has been battered by accusations of having a toxic work environment. The $68.7 billion purchase will undoubtedly upend the gaming industry, with the sale giving the tech giant access to top series like Call of Duty, Overwatch,...
headline: How Microsoft Buying Activision Blizzard Might Affect You

abstract: A vote on whether to form a union at the e-commerce giant’s warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., has become a labor showdown, drawing the attention of N.F.L. players, and the White House.
lead_paragraph: Players from the National Football League were among the first to voice their support. Then came Stacey Abrams, the Democratic star who helped turn Georgia blue in the 2020 election.
headline: Amazon Workers’ Union Drive Reaches Far Beyond Alabama

abstract: Customers can start telling Jeff Bezos to treat his workers like human beings.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the ways that people who have worked inside Amazon’s warehouses describe the experience: “The job crushed my spirit and crippled my body.” “The lowest point in my life.” An “isolating colony of hell.” “They’re killing people mentally and physically.” “I began to hate my day-to-day life.” “The way Amazon pushes people is not moral.” “I had whole days where I didn’t talk to anyone.” “The systematic devaluing of human bodies.”
headline: The Force That Can Help Amazon’s Workers? Amazon’s Shoppers.

abstract: A new collaboration between the retailing giant and the food distribution service includes free restaurant delivery for Prime members.
lead_paragraph: Under earnings pressure after a big loss last year, the food distribution company Grubhub struck a deal with Amazon on Wednesday, offering restaurant delivery services without a fee for Amazon Prime members.
headline: What Amazon Prime’s Deal With Grubhub Means for Consumers

abstract: A Brazilian pilot working for wildcat miners escaped death when his plane went down in a remote area. He walked through the jungle for 36 days before being rescued.
lead_paragraph: This story was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center’s Rainforest Investigations Network.
headline: His Plane Crashed in the Amazon. Then Came the Hard Part.

abstract: The first detailed studies of the so-called P.1 variant show how it devastated a Brazilian city. Now scientists want to know what it will do elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: In just a matter of weeks, two variants of the coronavirus have become so familiar that you can hear their inscrutable alphanumeric names regularly uttered on television news.
headline: Virus Variant in Brazil Infected Many Who Had Already Recovered From Covid-19

abstract: The visual effects supervisor, hurt in one of three recent accidents on Amazon film sets, has sued, but the company says it is not to blame.
lead_paragraph: In March 2023, the producers of Amazon’s holiday movie “Candy Cane Lane,” starring Eddie Murphy, were determined to set a 15-foot fir aflame for a scene, according to court papers filed in a recent lawsuit.
headline: Film Crew Veteran, Injured in an Accident, Faults Amazon for His Pain

abstract: The company and its new union share the same problem.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday, Derrick Palmer clocked in for his 7:15 a.m. shift at Amazon’s giant warehouse on Staten Island and spent the day packing boxes with board games, iPhones and mini vacuum cleaners. The following morning, he boarded a train to Washington, D.C., where more experienced labor leaders hailed him and his best friend, Christian Smalls, for doing what had once seemed impossible: unionizing an Amazon facility.
headline: Amazon vs. the Union

abstract: Alabama is more than its shading on the electoral map.
lead_paragraph: The Deep South is not generally known for its labor agitation, which is why it might come as a surprise for some to learn that it is in Alabama where workers have mounted one of the largest and most aggressive efforts to unionize Amazon in recent memory.
headline: The Deep South Has a Rich History of Resistance, as Amazon Is Learning

abstract: Dom Phillips and Bruno Araújo Pereira were last seen Sunday morning traveling in a boat in the northern Brazilian state of Amazonas.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A British journalist and a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples have been reported missing deep inside the Amazon rainforest, after the expert’s organization said it had received threats for its work monitoring illegal mining and fishing in the area.
headline: British Journalist and Indigenous Expert Are Missing in Amazon After Threats

abstract: In this lesson, students will listen to an episode of “The Daily” to learn about Amazon warehouse workers trying to organize a union.
lead_paragraph: Featured Podcast: “A Union Drive at Amazon”
headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Union Drive at Amazon’

abstract: Amazon, which has its highest employment during the holiday shopping season, said the tornado formed at the site’s parking lot.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every day as Christmas nears, Amazon’s share of online sales typically rises, as customers turn to the e-commerce giant to quickly deliver packages. To make that happen, Amazon hires hundreds of thousands of additional workers, both full-time employees and contractors, and runs its operations at full tilt.
headline: At Amazon Site, Tornado Collided With Company’s Peak Delivery Season

abstract: Amazon said on Monday that it was removing products promoting QAnon, a baseless conspiracy, from its website, after QAnon supporters were prominent in the riot at the Capitol last week.
lead_paragraph: Amazon said on Monday that it was removing products promoting QAnon, a baseless conspiracy, from its website, after QAnon supporters were prominent in the riot at the Capitol last week.
headline: Amazon says it will remove QAnon products from its store.

abstract: The agreement’s national scope and its concessions to organizing go further than any previous settlement that the e-commerce giant has made.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon, which faces mounting scrutiny over worker rights, agreed to let its warehouse employees more easily organize in the workplace as part of a nationwide settlement with the National Labor Relations Board this month.
headline: Amazon Reaches Labor Deal, Giving Workers More Power to Organize

abstract: Labor and small business were once natural allies against big business. They should join forces again.
lead_paragraph: In a welcome joining of forces, labor unions and small-business advocacy groups this month supported an antitrust bill that would give New York State sweeping new authority to sue corporate titans like Amazon for abusing their market power in ways that harm competitors or workers.
headline: There’s a New Duo That Could Help Rein In Amazon

abstract: Deforestation is one of many problems Brazil’s new government will need to address.
lead_paragraph: When Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva is sworn in as president of Brazil for an unprecedented third term on Sunday, one of his most pressing problems will be an Amazon at a dangerous tipping point.
headline: For Lula and the World, the Tough Job of Saving the Amazon Begins

abstract: A hearing officer for the National Labor Relations Board found that Amazon illegally discouraged organizing at an Alabama warehouse. The company can appeal to block a new election.
lead_paragraph: A hearing officer of the National Labor Relations Board has recommended that the board throw out a union election at an Amazon warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., where results announced in early April showed workers rejecting a union by a more than two-to-one ratio.
headline: Labor Board Official Backs Union Challenge on Amazon Vote

abstract: A Norwegian group filed a complaint with regulators, saying Amazon had deliberately made it difficult to end memberships to its Prime service. Groups in Europe and the U.S. back the effort.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Those who have tried ending a membership in Amazon Prime, the technology giant’s digital subscription service, may be familiar with the multi-click process: warnings that cancellation will mean losing “exclusive benefits,” and prompts to reverse course, or switch to an annual membership instead.
headline: Consumer Groups Target Amazon Prime’s Cancellation Process

abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about one of the biggest victories for organized labor in a generation. Then, they will consider the role of unions in general, as well as the possibilities of a local student union.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How Two Best Friends Beat Amazon” by Jodi Kantor and Karen Weise
headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Two Best Friends Beat Amazon’

abstract: What this economic moment means for the company and the people who work there.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is constantly hiring. Data has shown that the company has had a turnover rate of about 150 percent a year.
headline: Amazon and the Labor Shortage

abstract: The new Halo Rise studies your body and breathing and rates your restfulness, from “Poor” to “Great.” Who needs this?
lead_paragraph: Is there any technology more ironic than sleep tracking? Tech companies say their wearables and apps that study your body as you snooze can help you get a better night’s rest. But many sleep experts, and the companies themselves, say technology itself is to blame when you don’t sleep well.
headline: Amazon Wants to Review Your Sleep. (No, Thanks.)

abstract: Workers overwhelmingly voted down a union last year, but labor regulators threw out the result, citing company misconduct.
lead_paragraph: During the first union election at Amazon’s Bessemer, Ala., warehouse early last year, organizers largely avoided visiting workers at home because Covid was raging and few Americans were vaccinated.
headline: Amazon Warehouse in Alabama Is Set to Begin Second Union Election

abstract: A unionizing campaign that had deliberately stayed under the radar for months has in recent days blossomed into a star-studded showdown to influence the workers.
lead_paragraph: A unionizing campaign that had deliberately stayed under the radar for months has in recent days blossomed into a star-studded showdown to influence the workers.
headline: A unionization vote at an Amazon warehouse in Alabama has become a labor showdown.

abstract: Is the retailer a monopoly? It depends on how you define its competition.
lead_paragraph: Americans buy a lot of stuff from Amazon. But Americans also just buy a lot of stuff. This presents a problem for anyone contending that Amazon acts as a monopoly: The company is huge, but depending on how you measure its place in the vastness of American retail, its presence isn’t necessarily overwhelming, let alone clearly illegally monopolistic.
headline: The Flaw in the Case Against Amazon

abstract: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, while diminished, commanded a premium price, with Amazon seeking to bolster its crucial Prime membership offering.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the ultimate symbol of one Hollywood era ending and another beginning, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, home to James Bond, “Thelma & Louise” and Rocky, finally found a buyer willing to pay retail: Amazon.
headline: James Bond, Meet Jeff Bezos: Amazon Makes $8.45 Billion Deal for MGM

abstract: Covid-19 has cemented the e-commerce giant’s hold on the economy — but it has also spurred employees all around the country to organize.
lead_paragraph: When Abdul Tokhi, a father of two small children, arrived in the United States from Afghanistan in 2017, a local church group helped him and his family find an apartment in Corona, a city in California’s Inland Empire — a 27,000-square-mile stretch of deserts, mountains, farmland and sprawling housing communities east of Los Angeles. The group collected furniture donations, bringing over sofas, tables and a bulky, outdated television. They also connected him to a hiring company, which landed him a job as a “picker” in an Amazon warehouse, a 12-mile drive from Corona in a town named Eastvale. He started at Amazon earning $12.25 an hour, while his wife stayed home to take care of the kids.
headline: Amazon’s Great Labor Awakening

abstract: “Genius:MLK/X,” a “Mr. & Mrs. Smith” series, a remake of “Shogun” and “Feud: Capote vs. the Swans” are among the new arrivals.
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of February’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, Disney+, Hulu, Max and More in February

abstract: They will receive 50 cents to $3 more an hour, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Amazon will increase pay between 50 cents and $3 an hour for half a million workers in its warehouses, delivery network and other fulfillment teams, the company said on Wednesday.
headline: Amazon to raise pay for 500,000 workers.

abstract: The timing of the vote coincides with an election at Amazon’s warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., outside Birmingham.
lead_paragraph: Amazon and a fledgling union of workers at its Staten Island warehouse agreed to terms of an election for late March, setting the stage for two major elections at Amazon warehouses at the same time.
