headline: A union election at the Amazon warehouse on Staten Island is set for March.

abstract: The judge said the worker was “unlawfully” fired two years ago after a pandemic safety protest at a company warehouse.
lead_paragraph: A judge ruled on Monday that Amazon must reinstate and pay lost wages to a worker the company “unlawfully” fired two years ago after a protest at its fulfillment center on Staten Island, the same warehouse that recently voted in a landmark election to unionize.
headline: A judge ruled that Amazon must reinstate a Staten Island worker who was fired.

abstract: The ruling, on charges brought by the National Labor Relations Board, involved actions at two Staten Island warehouses before union votes last year.
lead_paragraph: Amazon violated labor law in advance of unionization elections last year at two warehouses on Staten Island, a federal administrative judge has ruled.
headline: Judge Finds Amazon Broke Labor Law in Anti-Union Effort

abstract: Federal prosecutors said that Kayricka Wortham, a former operations manager at an Amazon warehouse in Georgia, was the leader of a group that stole money from the company.
lead_paragraph: In her role as an operations manager at an Amazon warehouse in Georgia, Kayricka Wortham had the authority to approve new vendors and their invoices.
headline: Ex-Amazon Manager Sentenced to 16 Years in Prison in $9 Million Theft Scheme

abstract: With the failure of the union campaign in Bessemer still fresh on their minds, labor organizers are looking to retool their strategy.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Prime Day, Amazon’s annual summer shopping bonanza, lasted not one but two days this June. The company advertised it incessantly on social media and especially to subscribers of Amazon Prime, a group that includes close to half of the U.S. population. In the many warehouses in and around the company’s hometown, thousands of workers showed up to their packing and sorting stations for a mandatory, extra-long shift.
headline: Amazon Transformed Seattle. Now, Its Workers Are Poised to Take It Back.

abstract: The online retail giant avoided a major fine but agreed to changes that have long been sought by merchants who depend on Amazon to reach customers.
lead_paragraph: Amazon has agreed to give merchants operating in the European Union more access to valuable real estate on its website, the European Commission said Tuesday, in a deal that ends antitrust investigations by regulators who said the company had used its size and power to stifle competition in the bloc.
headline: Amazon and E.U. Reach Deal to End Antitrust Investigation

abstract: Illegal mines have fueled a humanitarian crisis for the Yanomami Indigenous group. Brazil’s new president is trying to fight back.
lead_paragraph: The illegal tin mine was so remote that, for three years, the massive gash it cut into the Amazon rainforest had gone largely ignored.
headline: The Amazon’s Largest Isolated Tribe Is Dying

abstract: Included in the breach was a list that purportedly showed how much money each of the platform’s streamers had earned in the past two years.
lead_paragraph: Twitch, the live-video site popular with gamers, said on Wednesday that it had endured a data breach that security researchers believe may have provided sweeping insight into the platform’s computer code, security vulnerabilities and payments to its content creators.
headline: A ‘potentially disastrous’ data breach hits Twitch, the livestreaming site.

abstract: The administration isn’t letting the tech giants write the rules of global trade. Good.
lead_paragraph: One reason that the idea of free trade has fallen out of fashion in recent years is the perception that trade agreements reflect the wishes of big American corporations, at everybody else’s expense.
headline: How the Biden Administration Took the Pen Away From Meta, Google and Amazon

abstract: The police in Brazil said on Saturday that they had arrested another person connected to the deaths of Dom Phillips and Bruno Araújo Pereira, and said the men been shot to death.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A third person was arrested on Saturday in connection with the killings of a British journalist and a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples who went missing while deep in the Amazon nearly two weeks ago, the police said before sharing grisly details about how the pair was murdered.
headline: Third Man Arrested in Amazon Slayings of Journalist and Activist

abstract: It’s the biggest victory for organized labor in a generation. Was it a fluke or the start of a new era of labor activism?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
headline: Does the Amazon Union Win Portend a Comeback for Organized Labor?

abstract: The company’s rewiring of retail puts customers at risk.
lead_paragraph: When Carey Gartner ordered a TV remote on Amazon in 2017, it arrived promptly at his home in Texas, most likely in one of those standard brown boxes with the company’s logo: an arrow tilting up in a half-smile. A year later, the battery cover popped off the remote, exposing a lithium battery, and Gartner’s 19-month-old swallowed it, severely burning and permanently damaging her esophagus, according to allegations in a court filing. His wife, Morgan McMillan, sued Amazon on their daughter’s behalf.
headline: What You Don’t Know About Amazon

abstract: The company has held hundreds of meetings with workers to discourage them from supporting a union in two upcoming elections.
lead_paragraph: On Staten Island, Amazon supervisors often refer to them as “training.” At an Amazon warehouse in Alabama, supervisors refer to them ambiguously as “meetings.” Amazon says they’re officially “small group meetings.”
headline: Mandatory Meetings Reveal Amazon’s Approach to Resisting Unions

abstract: Affirm said it had reached an agreement with the online retail giant to provide its customers with monthly payment plans for purchases of $50 or more.
lead_paragraph: Amazon customers will soon have another payment option at checkout.
headline: Amazon strikes a deal with Affirm, the buy-now pay-later provider.

abstract: Amazon said that if Ms. Khan played a role in antitrust investigations of Amazon, it would violate federal ethics rules and the firm’s right to due process.
lead_paragraph: Amazon demanded on Wednesday that Lina Khan, the new chair of the Federal Trade Commission and an avowed critic of the company, recuse herself from any antitrust investigation into the e-commerce giant.
headline: Amazon says the new F.T.C. chair, Lina Khan, should recuse herself from investigations.

abstract: The F.T.C. chair, who published an influential law school paper on the e-commerce giant, is now fighting the company over its market dominance.
lead_paragraph: Lina Khan’s career has come full circle. The F.T.C., which she chairs, and 17 states sued Amazon on Tuesday, accusing the tech giant of using illegal practices to maintain its monopoly position in e-commerce.
headline: What to Watch as Lina Khan Finally Takes On Amazon

abstract: In “Amazon Unbound,” his second book about the company, Brad Stone focuses on its singular C.E.O.
lead_paragraph: AMAZON UNBOUNDJeff Bezos and the Invention of a Global EmpireBy Brad Stone
headline: To Understand Amazon, We Must Understand Jeff Bezos

abstract: The e-commerce giant added at least nine new warehouses in the city over the past year as 2.4 million packages a day strained the nation’s largest urban delivery system.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic gripped New York City, it propelled an enormous surge in online shopping that has not waned, even in a metropolis where stores are rarely far away. People who regularly bought online are now buying more, while those who started ordering to avoid exposure to the virus have been won over by the advantages.
headline: As Online Shopping Surged, Amazon Planned Its New York Takeover

abstract: Connecticut’s top law enforcement official said on Wednesday that he was conducting an antitrust investigation into how Amazon runs its e-books business.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut’s top law enforcement official said on Wednesday that he was conducting an antitrust investigation into how Amazon runs its e-books business.
headline: Connecticut is investigating Amazon’s practices in the e-books market.

abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks from May’s new titles.
lead_paragraph: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in May

abstract: An affiliation agreement between the Amazon Labor Union and the 1.3 million-member Teamsters signals an escalation in challenging the online retailer.
lead_paragraph: After years of organizing Amazon workers and pressuring the company to bargain over wages and working conditions, two prominent unions are teaming up to challenge the online retailer.
headline: How the Teamsters and a Homegrown Union Plan to Take On Amazon

abstract: Workers had accused the companies of unlawful behavior during recent union campaigns.
lead_paragraph: In a sign that federal labor officials are closely scrutinizing management behavior during union campaigns, the National Labor Relations Board said Friday that it had found merit in accusations that Amazon and Starbucks had violated labor law.
headline: Labor regulators find merit in accusations by unions at Amazon and Starbucks.

abstract: Revenue rose to a record $137.4 billion, just slightly under forecasts.
lead_paragraph: An improving economy and a persistent virus are beginning to weigh on Amazon’s retail business, even as its cloud computing business grew and an investment lifted profits.
headline: Amazon confronts pandemic costs and raises the price of Prime.

abstract: The successful organization of a warehouse in Staten Island offers a real glimmer of hope for the American working class.
lead_paragraph: Faced with an unexpectedly strong organizing campaign by workers at one of its Staten Island warehouses, Amazon initially turned to one of the oldest tricks in the anti-union playbook: a little bit of racism.
headline: Amazon Tried One of the Oldest Tricks in the Book, and It Backfired

abstract: Amazon was built on an underdog philosophy, but its workers are finding a voice. That presents a problem for the company that goes far beyond the union vote in Alabama.
lead_paragraph: It has been Day 1 at Amazon ever since the company began more than a quarter-century ago. Day 1 is Amazon shorthand for staying hungry, making bold decisions and never forgetting about the customer. This start-up mentality — underdogs against the world — has been extremely good for Amazon’s shoppers and shareholders.
headline: Amazon’s Clashes With Labor: Days of Conflict and Control

abstract: The companies’ latest earnings reports provide insight into the state of consumers and businesses, including where they’re willing to spend — and cut costs.
lead_paragraph: Earnings reports yesterday from Apple and Amazon covered some very different businesses: premium-priced smartphones and tablets versus the world’s “everything store” and a dominant cloud computing platform.
headline: Apple’s and Amazon’s Report Cards for the Global Economy

abstract: The labor agency wants a federal judge to order changes there in the case of a fired worker before a union election starts next week.
lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board sued Amazon in federal court on Thursday, asking a judge to force the company to swiftly rectify what it called “flagrant unfair labor practices” before workers at one of its Staten Island warehouses begin voting in a union election next week.
headline: N.L.R.B. sues Amazon over labor practices at a Staten Island facility.

abstract: The internet giant acquired One Medical, a national chain of primary care clinics, for $3.9 billion.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s shares fell after the social media platform, which is locked in a legal battle with Elon Musk over its future ownership, reported that it lost $270 million in the second quarter. Alphabet, Apple, Meta and Microsoft will report their earnings next week, with many forecasters expecting more disappointing results.
headline: Amazon Wants to Be Your Doctor, Too

abstract: The move comes as Amazon is laying off 18,000 workers, but a company spokesman said the decision to end the AmazonSmile program was not a cost-cutting measure.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is shutting down an in-house charity that gave customers the opportunity to direct a small amount of their purchases to a wide range of nonprofits, from large hospitals to modest horse farms, saying the impact “was often spread too thin.”
headline: Amazon Axes ‘Smile’ Charity Program, Citing Limited Impact

abstract: The Builders Association explores the world of turkers, workers performing thousands of weird, low-paying tasks for an online giant.
lead_paragraph: A place where “information is free” and “money isn’t everything”: That’s how Stewart Brand, the longtime editor of the Whole Earth Catalog, foresaw the future of the internet in 1985.
headline: Review: In ‘I Agree to the Terms,’ It’s Raining Pennies From Amazon

abstract: Andy Jassy, the successor to Jeff Bezos, was already running the company’s most profitable business.
lead_paragraph: In the popular imagination, Amazon is a big huge store run by Jeff Bezos, a smiling man with a clean-shaven head who is, sometimes, the richest person in the world. You order and Amazon delivers.
headline: What, Exactly, Is Amazon Web Services?

abstract: We’re interested in learning as much as possible about how Amazon manages its work force.
lead_paragraph: Amazon and its founder, Jeff Bezos, have pioneered news ways of mass-managing people through technology, relying on a maze of systems that minimized human contact to grow unconstrained.
headline: Are You a Current or Former Amazon Employee?

abstract: Over 700 workers in Coventry joined a union and are seeking recognition for it to negotiate with the company, known for its resistance to organized labor.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, as Britain’s inflation rate reached 10 percent, Amazon gave its workers there a pay raise. At a warehouse in Coventry, in the Midlands of England, the offer was for an extra 50 pence (about 63 cents) an hour, or about 5 percent.
headline: At a British Amazon Warehouse, a Union Bid Surges, Then Stalls

abstract: The company hopes a new interface — replacing a much-maligned predecessor — will make the streaming service easier and more inviting for viewers.
lead_paragraph: Amazon excels at making a seemingly infinite array of retail items feel organized and accessible. So why has its streaming service, Prime Video, long had such an ugly, clunky user interface? “Amazon Prime Video’s Library Is Now Genuinely Impossible to Browse,” the online entertainment magazine Paste declared in a headline last year. As the streaming business got more competitive, notably with the arrival of glossy entrants like Disney+ and HBO Max, the poorly designed Prime Video interface stood out even more.
headline: Amazon is giving Prime Video a face-lift.

abstract: Investors were closely watching business spending with the company’s cloud computing division, which grew 12 percent in the most recent quarter.
lead_paragraph: Amazon reported solid quarterly sales on Thursday, showing that corporations and consumers are spending as inflation has eased.
headline: Amazon Revenue Jumps as Consumer and Business Spending Improves

abstract: The outcome of a vote at a warehouse in Alabama could have far-ranging implications for both the company and the labor movement.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — By the end of Monday, thousands of yellow envelopes mailed to a squat brick building in Birmingham, Ala., will hold the fate of one of the most closely watched union elections in recent history, one that could alter the shape of the labor movement and one of America’s largest employers.
headline: Contentious Union Vote at Amazon Heads to a Count

abstract: A company known for audiobooks is mounting starry live productions — and recording them, too.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Marvel took off her shoes, stretched out her arms and started describing her horrible dreams. Ato Blankson-Wood offered thoughts on astrology. Bill Camp, cradling a guitar in his lap, asked if someone could go get coffee, while Jason Bowen adjusted his chair.
headline: Radio Drama for a Podcast Age: How Amazon’s Audible Moved Into Theater

abstract: Company officials said the terminations were the result of an internal review, while the fired managers saw it as a response to the recent union victory.
lead_paragraph: After Amazon employees at a massive warehouse on Staten Island scored an upset union victory last month, it turned the union’s leaders into celebrities, sent shock waves through the broader labor movement and prompted politicians around the country to rally behind Amazon workers. Now it also appears to have created fallout within Amazon’s management ranks.
headline: Amazon Abruptly Fires Senior Managers Tied to Unionized Warehouse

abstract: His film “Ferrari,” a big-budget indie from Michael Mann, is the kind of adult drama the major studios have shied away from.
lead_paragraph: The name placard on the dais said “A. Driver,” and if you’re making a Ferrari movie, you’d certainly better have one.
headline: Venice Film Festival: Adam Driver Calls Out Netflix and Amazon Amid Strikes

abstract: The Food and Drug Administration told the online retailer in a letter this week that the products were not approved for sale in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Amazon said on Wednesday that it was removing seven eyedrops products from its website after the Food and Drug Administration warned the company that the eyedrops had not been recognized as safe and effective.
headline: Amazon to Stop Selling Seven Eyedrops After F.D.A. Warning

abstract: The Amazon rainforest in Brazil has experienced sharply increasing levels of illegal deforestation and mining, violence against environmental activists and Indigenous people and a loosening of environmental enforcement under the administration of President Jair Bolsonaro.
lead_paragraph: The Amazon rainforest in Brazil has experienced sharply increasing levels of illegal deforestation and mining, violence against environmental activists and Indigenous people and a loosening of environmental enforcement under the administration of President Jair Bolsonaro.
headline: The winner of the election will likely play a major role in deciding the fate of the Amazon rainforest.

abstract: “Banzeiro Òkòtó,” by Eliane Brum, considers the devastating impacts of mass deforestation on Brazil and its people.
lead_paragraph: Among the past conscripts of land speculators in Brazil were live crickets. After a counterfeit title was drawn up to transfer public land into private hands, the document was placed in a box with one of the insects, whose excrement and nibbling gave the paper an appearance of authentic age. The virtual impunity granted by successive Brazilian governments to grileiros — “cricketers” — and their fellow land grabbers has worsened mass deforestation in the Amazon.
headline: A Manifesto for a New World, With the Amazon at Its Center

abstract: The retailer also swung to a profit in the second quarter.
lead_paragraph: All that cost-cutting at Amazon might be paying off. The company isn’t back to the torrid growth of bygone days but managed to beat Wall Street expectations on Thursday.
headline: Amazon Posts 11% Rise in Revenue as Growth Improves

abstract: The lawsuit is the first time that the Federal Trade Commission under its chair, Lina Khan, has taken Amazon to court.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission sued Amazon on Wednesday, accusing it of illegally inducing consumers to sign up for its Prime service and then hindering them from canceling the subscription, in the most aggressive action against the company to date by the agency’s chair, Lina Khan.
headline: F.T.C. Accuses Amazon of Tricking Users Into Subscribing to Prime

abstract: The count was much closer than another unionization vote taken at the facility last year.
lead_paragraph: Union supporters are narrowly trailing opponents in a union election at an Amazon warehouse in Alabama, the National Labor Relations Board said on Thursday. But the count was far closer than a vote at the same warehouse last year, when workers rejected the union by a more than 2-to-1 ratio.
headline: Union Trails in Amazon Vote in Alabama, With Challenges Pending

abstract: The deal, which will help expand distribution of its stationary bikes, comes in the middle of a turnaround effort by the company’s new chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Peloton said on Wednesday that it had reached a deal with Amazon to sell exercise equipment, accessories and apparel on the retailer’s U.S. website, as the maker of stationary bikes tries to reinvigorate sales.
headline: Peloton will sell fitness equipment and apparel on Amazon.

abstract: The layoffs will focus on human resources and its retail division, Amazon’s chief executive said in an email to employees.
lead_paragraph: Amazon plans to eliminate 18,000 corporate and technology jobs in a significant expansion of its cost-cutting plans, the company’s chief executive, Andy Jassy, said in a message to employees on Wednesday.
headline: Amazon Expands Corporate Layoffs to 18,000 Jobs

abstract: A novel idea to leave the country’s vast oil reserves in the ground fizzled for lack of international support. Now, struggling under painful debt, the government wants to expand drilling in the rainforest.
lead_paragraph: YASUNÍ NATIONAL PARK, Ecuador — In a swath of lush Amazon rainforest here, near some of the last Indigenous people on Earth living in isolation, workers recently finished building a new oil platform carved out of the wilderness.
headline: Ecuador Tried to Curb Drilling and Protect the Amazon. The Opposite Happened.

abstract: Chafing at their dependence, Amazon, Google, Meta and Microsoft are racing to cut into Nvidia’s dominant share of the market.
lead_paragraph: In September, Amazon said it would invest up to $4 billion in Anthropic, a San Francisco start-up working on artificial intelligence.
headline: Nvidia’s Big Tech Rivals Put Their Own A.I. Chips on the Table

abstract: A 2011 thriller was supposed to cost $15. One merchant listed it at $987, with a 17th-century publication date. That’s what happens in a marketplace where third-party sellers run wild.
lead_paragraph: John C. Boland was poking around the Amazon bookstore when he saw the science thriller “Hominid” for sale at dizzying prices. It was $907 from Sandy Dunes Surplus, $930 from Rocky Mountain Books and $987 from Open Range Media.
headline: What Happened to Amazon’s Bookstore?

abstract: Faced with boycotts and criminal complaints, the director of “Tandav” made the edits this week. But that did not appear to satisfy some of the show’s critics, who called for him to be jailed.
lead_paragraph: ARPORA, India — The director of a big-budget Amazon web series has bowed to pressure from Hindu nationalists and cut several scenes that they had deemed offensive, demonstrating the sway of a powerful political movement that strives to reshape Indian society.
headline: Director of Amazon India Drama Cuts Scenes Amid Outcry From Hindu Nationalists

abstract: A “Road House” remake, and the satires “Palm Royale” and “The Regime” start streaming.
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of March’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, Disney+, Hulu, Max and More in March

abstract: For years merchants have complained about transaction fees that eat into their revenue, but having Amazon take up the fight may ratchet up the pressure. The change will go into effect Jan. 19.
lead_paragraph: Amazon will stop accepting Visa credit cards issued in Britain from mid-January, the company said on Wednesday.
headline: Amazon, railing against high fees, will stop accepting Visa credit cards issued in Britain.

abstract: The F.T.C. accused the internet giant of protecting an online retail monopoly and forcing higher prices onto consumers.
lead_paragraph: In the two years since Andy Jassy replaced Jeff Bezos as Amazon’s chief executive, he has been cleaning up after his company’s aggressive pandemic expansion and after Mr. Bezos. Mr. Jassy has reined in Amazon’s voracious warehouse growth, culled from the company’s sprawl of products and laid off thousands of employees on several of Mr. Bezos’ pet projects.
headline: For Amazon’s Andy Jassy, a Cleanup Job Just Got a Lot Bigger

abstract: An unusual number of vice presidents are leaving for prominent jobs at public companies or high-growth start-ups.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Andy Jassy is elevated to chief executive of Amazon on Monday, taking the reins from its founder, Jeff Bezos, it will be one of the most closely watched executive handoffs in years.
headline: Bezos’ Exit Is One of Many Among Amazon’s Top Ranks

abstract: One of the world’s largest sustainable development agencies has worked with energy companies to quash opposition and keep oil flowing, even in sensitive areas.
lead_paragraph: RESGUARDO BUENAVISTA, Colombia — At the edge of the Colombian Amazon, in an Indigenous village surrounded by oil rigs, the Siona people faced a dilemma.
headline: In the Amazon, a U.N. Agency Has a Green Mission, but Dirty Partners

abstract: The series, “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power,” will take place thousands of years before the events of the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy.
lead_paragraph: Amazon Prime Video’s long-gestating “Lord of the Rings” series, which will make its debut on the streaming platform in September, officially has a name: “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power.”
headline: Amazon unveils the title for its big-budget ‘Lord of the Rings’ streaming series.

abstract: The tech giant deserves credit for taking on big issues, but what matters is that it follows through to the end.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Amazon Wants a Lot of New Laws

abstract: The company has hired a law firm to look into allegations at Amazon Web Services.
lead_paragraph: Amazon has hired a law firm to investigate claims of widespread gender discrimination in part of its cloud computing division, the company said in an email to employees late last week.
headline: Amazon will investigate gender bias claims in its cloud division.

abstract: Recent organizing campaigns in the South suggest the company’s wage scale may have left it vulnerable to a union.
lead_paragraph: In making the case against a union at its warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., Amazon has touted its compensation package. The company notes that base pay at the facility, around $15.50 an hour for most rank-and-file workers, is more than twice the local minimum wage, and that it offers comprehensive health insurance and retirement benefits.
headline: Amazon Says It Pays Alabama Workers Well; Other Local Employers Pay More

abstract: Corporate America keeps squeezing the humanity out of the workplace.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to imagine that Amazon executives popped champagne corks over the weekend after quashing the union drive in Bessemer, Ala. After a bruising fight, workers at the warehouse, in a suburb of Birmingham, rejected joining a union by more than a two-to-one ratio, chilling future union organizing efforts at the nation’s second-largest private employer.
headline: Amazon’s Big Win Over the Little Guy

abstract: Holiday fare arrives, with “Candy Cane Lane,” and “Dr. Who” and “Shape Island” specials. “Percy Jackson” and “Culprits” also land this month.
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of December’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, Disney+, Hulu and More in December

abstract: Nearly a year after its victory on Staten Island, the Amazon Labor Union is grappling with election losses and internal conflict.
lead_paragraph: One year after its surprise victory at a Staten Island warehouse, the only union in the country representing Amazon workers has endured a series of setbacks and conflicts that have caused longtime supporters to question if it will survive.
headline: Strains Emerge Inside the Union That Beat Amazon

abstract: How a small group of workers in Alabama are taking on one of the most powerful companies in the world.
lead_paragraph: Since its earliest days, Amazon has been anti-union, quashing any attempt by workers to organize.
headline: A Union Drive at Amazon

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Amazon, Prince Philip, DMX: Your Friday Evening Briefing

abstract: Outsiders see a business success story for the ages. Many insiders see an employment system under strain.
lead_paragraph: An Amazon worker tries to return from a Covid-related leave and is mistakenly fired. A wife panics as disability benefits halt for her gravely ill husband. An employee is fired for having a single underproductive day.
headline: Power and Peril: 5 Takeaways on Amazon’s Employment Machine

abstract: Amazon workers in Alabama voted down the biggest push for unionizing in the company’s history.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here are the top stories in business and tech to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
headline: The Week in Business: Amazon Defeats the Union

abstract: The agreement comes after a three-year deal the former president and first lady had with Spotify lapsed.
lead_paragraph: Higher Ground, the production entity led by former President Barack Obama and Michelle Obama, the former first lady, has signed an exclusive, multiyear production deal with Audible, the audio arm of Amazon, just two months after a similar agreement with Spotify ended.
headline: Higher Ground, the Obamas’ production company, signs multiyear deal with Amazon’s Audible.

abstract: The development, still under construction, sits on sacred land in Cape Town. But some Indigenous leaders have allied with the developers, prompting a debate over who speaks for First Nations people.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — On a swath of grassy land with an open view of Cape Town’s picturesque Table Mountain, a squad of yellow tractors cleared the lot for a new $300 million commercial and residential development that has stirred up debate in South Africa not just for its location, but also for its anchor tenant: the tech giant Amazon.
headline: New Amazon Headquarters Sparks Feud Among Indigenous South Africans

abstract: “The Idea of You,” “Scrublands,” “The Big Cigar” and “Hacks” are streaming.
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of May’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, Disney+, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in May

abstract: Michelle Gass, the chief executive of Kohl’s, is striking deals with Amazon and Sephora in a bid to stay relevant.
lead_paragraph: Brick-and-mortar retailers have been decimated in recent years. First came Amazon. Then the pandemic.
headline: Brick-and-Mortar Retail in the Age of Covid, and Amazon

abstract: “By the way, Amazon, here we come. Watch,” the president said. But the White House quickly said his remarks did not mean the government would get formally involved.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Days after warehouse workers on Staten Island defied Amazon and successfully formed a labor union, President Biden on Wednesday threw his support behind the workers and championed their cause.
headline: Biden Appears to Show Support for Amazon Workers Who Voted to Unionize

abstract: “The hardworking warehouse employees who have helped sustain us during these unprecedented times should not have to risk injury or face punishment,” Gov. Gavin Newsom said.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Wednesday signed a bill that restricts warehouse employers from setting productivity quotas that prevent workers from taking breaks or following health and safety laws. The new law could alter Amazon’s labor practices.
headline: California governor signs bill that could push Amazon to change labor practices.

abstract: The longtime lieutenant to Jeff Bezos has made more changes than many expected since becoming C.E.O.
lead_paragraph: The last of the nation’s biggest banks reported their second-quarter earnings this morning. Goldman Sachs beat expectations, as the firm’s traders were able to capitalize on volatile markets. Bank of America’s bottom line was in line with expectations, but its earnings still fell by a third from the same quarter a year ago.
headline: The Andy Jassy Way at Amazon

abstract: New firms are raising billions of dollars to buy up popular Amazon listings, minting millionaires along the way. Here’s how it works.
lead_paragraph: Eco-Baby, TrailBuddy, Quility and TapeKing aren’t exactly household names, but they’re working on it. Their products are among the most popular in their categories on Amazon, accounting for millions of dollars in yearly sales.
headline: The Great Amazon Flip-a-Thon

abstract: For his latest album, “Y’Y,” the Brazilian composer looked to inspirations in nature and experiments with prepared pianos.
lead_paragraph: In the northeastern Brazilian state of Pernambuco — a narrow, humid stretch of land where the South American coastline juts out into the Atlantic — fables endure the test of time. “There’s one about the Pajeú, the river which runs through the state,” the jazz composer and pianist Amaro Freitas said on a recent morning, video-calling from his sun-drenched living room in Recife. “It goes like this: Once upon a time, a Brazilian viola was buried in the riverbed. From that moment on, anyone who drank from the stream would become a poet.”
headline: The Pianist Amaro Freitas Takes His Jazz Somewhere New: The Amazon

abstract: Readers take two sides of the argument. Also: Affordable housing in SoHo; Native American food insecurity; the healing power of art.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
headline: The Union Defeat at an Amazon Warehouse

abstract: Dom Phillips, a British journalist, and Bruno Pereira, a Brazilian expert on Indigenous groups, have not been seen since Sunday. They faced threats before they disappeared.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Javari Valley in the Amazon rainforest is one of the most isolated places on the planet. It is a densely forested Indigenous reserve the size of Maine where there are virtually no roads, trips can take a week by boat and at least 19 Indigenous groups are believed to still live without outside contact.
headline: Threats, Then Guns: A Journalist and an Expert Vanish in the Amazon

abstract: Amazon walked away from the $1.7 billion acquisition of iRobot as it faces questions from regulators in the European Union and United States.
lead_paragraph: Amazon said on Monday that it was abandoning plans to buy iRobot, the maker of the self-driving Roomba vacuum, after regulators raised concerns the deal would hurt competition.
headline: Amazon Scraps Deal to Buy Maker of Roomba Amid Regulatory Scrutiny

abstract: A vote this week at a warehouse near Albany, N.Y., will help show whether the upstart union can win outside its home base on Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: The Amazon Labor Union has built momentum leading up to an election this week at an 800-person warehouse near Albany, N.Y.
headline: Amazon Labor Union, With Renewed Momentum, Faces Next Test

abstract: Newly released emails show particular praise of Amazon among top Defense Department officials during the Trump administration as technology firms competed for a $10 billion award.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Defense Department prepares to solicit bids for cloud-computing work that could yield billions of dollars for Amazon, members of Congress are raising new questions about the company’s efforts to win a $10 billion contract during the Trump administration.
headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Question Amazon’s Connections on Pentagon Contract

abstract: The nation’s largest police force recently joined the Ring Neighbors app and can now enlist the help of the city’s residents in investigations. Critics say it could lead to racial profiling.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department, which already relies on a high-tech toolbox that includes facial recognition software, drones and mobile X-ray vans, has joined Neighbors, a public neighborhood watch platform owned by Amazon’s Ring where video doorbell owners can post clips, and where precincts can enlist the help of the city’s residents in their investigations.
headline: What to Know Now That the N.Y.P.D. Is on Amazon’s Neighborhood Watch App

abstract: Americans should contemplate the human cost of speedy delivery.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s failed and divisive re-election campaign doesn’t immediately come to mind as a model for success in corporate America. Nonetheless, retail giant Amazon seems to have taken some lessons from the former president in its frantic effort to quash a unionization drive underway at one of its warehouses in Alabama.
headline: Don’t Look Away From Amazon Workers’ Latest Union Drive

abstract: BlackRock and Wells Fargo also delayed their mandatory returns until October. Both attributed the changes to new developments in the spread of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: More large corporations, including Amazon, BlackRock and Wells Fargo, announced on Thursday that they would delay their return-to-office plans as the spread of the Delta variant causes the number of coronavirus cases to climb.
headline: Amazon pushes its return to office to January.

abstract: Five questions for Alex Pritz about his documentary “The Territory,” about the fight to preserve the Amazon rainforest.
lead_paragraph: Alex Pritz’s documentary “The Territory” drops us right onto the front lines of the battle to preserve the Amazon rainforest in Brazil. Pritz embeds us with both an Indigenous community under threat, the Uru Eu Wau Wau, and the farmers who seize Indigenous lands with apparent impunity. That on-the-ground approach brings a visceral suspense to global environmental issues and gives a firsthand view of a local community (numbering less than 200) as they fight for survival in new ways.
headline: Community Filmmaking in the Amazon

abstract: A split over the stewardship of the union’s high-profile president, Christian Smalls, has led a rival faction to file a lawsuit seeking an election.
lead_paragraph: A dissident group within the Amazon Labor Union, the only certified union in the country representing Amazon employees, filed a complaint in federal court Monday seeking to force the union to hold a leadership election.
headline: Amazon Union Dissidents, in Challenge to Leader, Move to Force Vote

abstract: After an election defeat in Alabama, many in labor are shifting strategies, wary of the challenges and expense of winning votes site by site.
lead_paragraph: The lopsided vote against a union at Amazon’s warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., was a major disappointment to organized labor, which regards the fight with Amazon as central to labor’s survival. Yet the defeat doesn’t mark the end of the campaign against Amazon so much as a shift in strategy.
headline: Union Loss May Bring New Phase of Campaign Against Amazon

abstract: The findings, related to gold mining in Peru, provide new evidence of how people are altering ecosystems in dangerous ways around the world.
lead_paragraph: The protected old-growth forest in the Amazon of southeastern Peru appears pristine: Ancient trees with massive trunks grow alongside young, slender ones, forming a canopy so thick it sometimes feels to scientists like evening during the day.
headline: Alarming Levels of Mercury Are Found in Old Growth Amazon Forest

abstract: The company plans to open Amazon Style later this year in Glendale, Calif., that will incorporate customers’ physical browsing behavior and preferences on the Amazon Shopping app.
lead_paragraph: Amazon, which has posed formidable challenges to booksellers, big-box chains and grocers, has a new kind of retailer in its sights: physical clothing stores.
headline: Amazon plans a new rival for retailers: a physical clothing store.

abstract: Archaeologists, relying on laser technology and decades of research, mapped a cluster of ancient cities in eastern Ecuador. Their findings add to evidence of dense settlements in Amazonia.
lead_paragraph: The Amazon valley looked like so many others, with a muddy river snaking through dense forest, except that this one had earthen mounds rising at clear right angles and ditches carving long straight lines through the soil.
headline: Remnants of Sprawling Ancient Cities Are Found in the Amazon

abstract: The company said it was working with the Anti-Defamation League to potentially add language to the page that viewers see before buying or renting the film.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Nets and the Anti-Defamation League sent a letter to Amazon asking the company to address the “deeply and unequivocally antisemitic” documentary and related book at the heart of the Brooklyn Nets guard Kyrie Irving’s suspension. The company said it was working with the A.D.L. to explore adding a disclaimer to the film.
headline: Amazon Considers Disclaimer to Antisemitic Film Irving Shared Online

abstract: People are eager to return to grocery stores, but Amazon seems to be missing the opportunity.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Stores Still Matter. Where’s Amazon?

abstract: The announcement was a further retreat from the rigid stance the tech giant had taken earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: Amazon told employees on Monday that it was loosening its plans to force workers to return to their offices, further retreating from a more rigid approach it had taken earlier this year.
headline: Amazon expands flexibility for some employees to work from home indefinitely.

abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of October’s most promising new titles.
lead_paragraph: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in October

abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of December’s most promising new titles.
lead_paragraph: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in December

abstract: The online retailer’s size and sway affects the free exchange of ideas, the groups argue. The Biden administration has stepped up enforcement of antitrust policies.
lead_paragraph: With mounting signs that the Federal Trade Commission is preparing to file a lawsuit against Amazon for violating antitrust laws, a group of booksellers, authors and antitrust activists are urging the government to investigate the company’s domination of the book market.
headline: Authors and Booksellers Urge Justice Dept. to Investigate Amazon

abstract: The American company sees big potential in the country’s nascent e-commerce market. Both sides view a troubled grocery store chain as the key to success.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Amazon and one of the world’s richest men are engaged in a multibillion-dollar, politically fraught clash over Rani Pillai’s favorite place to buy groceries.
headline: Why Amazon Is Confronting the Richest Man in India

abstract: In off-the-cuff remarks on the sidelines of the NATO summit, the defense minister, Ben Wallace, derided Russia and suggested that Ukrainian officials tone down some of their demands for aid.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s counteroffensive may be progressing more slowly than hoped, but Russia’s forces have also been stymied — one of several signals that Britain’s defense minister on Wednesday said showed that “Russia is not as strong as you think it is.”
headline: ‘We’re Not Amazon’: Britain’s Defense Minister Says Ukrainian Officials Should Show More Gratitude

abstract: The Federal Trade Commission and 17 states sued Amazon, saying its conduct in its online store and services to merchants illegally stifled competition.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission and 17 states sued Amazon on Tuesday, setting up a long-awaited antitrust fight with the e-commerce giant that could alter the way Americans shop for everything from toilet paper to electronics online.
headline: U.S. Accuses Amazon of Illegally Protecting Monopoly in Online Retail

abstract: The company’s consumer and operations business has experienced a significant shake-up in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: Two of Amazon’s most senior Black executives are departing the company, according to four people familiar with the change, leaving Amazon without any Black leaders on its senior leadership team, which includes more than two dozen executives responsible for running the company.
headline: Senior Black Executives Depart Amazon as It Names New Consumer Boss

abstract: The disappearance of Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira signals another tipping point in the Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Monday began, for me, with a call that became a horror story. I discovered that Dom Phillips, a British journalist and friend, disappeared a day earlier in the Javari Valley, one of the Amazon’s most dangerous regions.
headline: Was a British Journalist the Latest Victim of Bolsonaro’s War on the Amazon?

abstract: Tree loss was down 20 percent from the previous year, the environment minister announced.
lead_paragraph: Deforestation in the Amazon rainforest in Brazil fell to a five-year low, the country’s National Institute of Space Research announced on Thursday, a sign that Brazil, which has the biggest share of tropical forest in the world, was making progress on its pledge to halt all deforestation by the end of the decade.
headline: Deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon Falls to a Five-Year Low

abstract: Our streaming picks for March, including ‘Biggie: I Got a Story to Tell,’ ‘Bill & Ted Face the Music’ and ‘Coming 2 America’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for March.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in March

abstract: Our streaming picks for April, including ‘Concrete Cowboy,’ ‘Made for Love’ and ‘Them’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for April.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in April

abstract: Our picks for November, including ‘tick, tick … BOOM!’, ‘The Great’ Season 2, and ‘Passing’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for November.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in November

abstract: Amazon relishes mastering the impossible. But it hasn’t put the same energy into managing its work force.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Amazon Is Brilliant. Why Not at H.R.?

abstract: Airports across the United States are devoting more space to freight shipments as online shopping surges in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: HEBRON, Ky. — Since the pandemic started nearly a year ago, 15,000 fewer people arrive and depart daily from the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport, known as CVG. Yet the 60 percent drop in passenger traffic is not so apparent on the airport’s four runways, which are handling a record amount of air cargo — nearly 4,000 tons a day.
headline: Air Cargo Construction Is Booming, Thanks to Amazon

abstract: The success of an independent drive has organized labor asking whether it should take more of a back seat.
lead_paragraph: After the stunning victory at Amazon by a little-known independent union that didn’t exist 18 months ago, organized labor has begun to ask itself an increasingly pressing question: Does the labor movement need to get more disorganized?
headline: Amazon Workers Who Won a Union Their Way Open Labor Leaders’ Eyes

abstract: In a secret settlement in Virginia, Amazon swore off threatening and intimidating workers. As the company confronts increased labor unrest, its tactics are under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Five years ago, Amazon was compelled to post a “notice to employees” on the break-room walls of a warehouse in east-central Virginia.
headline: How Amazon Crushes Unions

abstract: Jeff Bezos’ successor has set himself apart with a hands-on approach in Washington.
lead_paragraph: When Jeff Bezos was chief executive of Amazon, he took an arm’s-length stance toward the company’s affairs in Washington. He rarely lobbied lawmakers. He testified only once before Congress, under the threat of subpoena.
headline: Amazon C.E.O. Andy Jassy Breaks From the Bezos Way

abstract: Dave Clark, who was also the architect of the company’s sprawling warehouse operations, said he would depart after 23 years.
lead_paragraph: Dave Clark, the chief executive of Amazon’s consumer business, who was the architect of its massive warehouse operations, announced on Friday that he would leave the company after 23 years. He did not say what he would do next, and the company did not immediately name a successor.
headline: The chief executive of Amazon’s consumer business is leaving.

abstract: The delay is the latest reminder that the tech industry’s pandemic-fueled boom has slowed and another indicator of how remote work has changed office-space needs.
lead_paragraph: When Amazon said in 2018 that it planned to build a second headquarters in Virginia, along with a sister office complex in New York, it was a symbolic moment for the tech industry’s increasing importance to the American economy.
headline: Amazon Pauses Work on 2nd Headquarters in Virginia

abstract: An examination of Brazil’s immense tannery industry shows how hides from illegally deforested ranches can easily reach the global marketplace. In the United States, much of the demand for Brazilian leather comes from automakers.
lead_paragraph: BURITIS, Brazil — One morning this summer, Odilon Caetano Felipe, a rancher who raises cattle on illegally deforested land in the Amazon, met with a trader and signed over 72 newly fattened animals. With that stroke of the pen, Mr. Felipe gave his cattle a clean record: By selling them, he obscured their role in the destruction of the world’s largest rainforest.
headline: How Americans’ Appetite for Leather in Luxury SUVs Worsens Amazon Deforestation

abstract: The F.T.C. chair shot to fame six years ago after publishing an academic article that the company needed to be contained. Legal experts wonder if that time has come.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, Lina Khan, then a 29-year-old law student, shot to fame with an academic article about why Amazon should be contained. Cutting against prevailing trends in antitrust law, Khan argued that the e-commerce giant was unfairly dominating huge swaths of the American economy.
headline: Lina Khan Raises the Heat on Amazon

abstract: Paige Thompson’s lawyers said she had been looking for cracks so they could be fixed. A jury found her guilty of wire fraud and hacking charges.
lead_paragraph: A former Amazon engineer who was accused of stealing customers’ personal information from Capital One in one of the largest breaches in the United States was found guilty of wire fraud and hacking charges on Friday.
headline: Ex-Amazon Worker Convicted in Capital One Hacking

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “This idea of a kind of pristine, untouched Amazonian landscape was definitely not the case.”
headline: Quotation of the Day: Research Reveals Remnants of Sprawling Ancient Cities in the Amazon Rainforest

abstract: A conversation with the warehouse workers who created the e-commerce giant’s first union against all odds.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.
headline: How Two Friends Beat Amazon and Built a Union

abstract: For many Americans, it has become hard to imagine online shopping without Prime.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Amazon Prime: Loved at Almost Any Price

abstract: Hundreds of square miles of the rainforest have burned as countries in the region battle a record number of fires fueled by extreme weather.
lead_paragraph: By this time of the year, rain should be drenching large swaths of the Amazon rainforest. Instead, a punishing drought has kept the rains at bay, creating dry conditions for fires that have engulfed hundreds of square miles of the rainforest that do not usually burn.
headline: Rains Are Scarce in the Amazon. Instead, Megafires Are Raging.

abstract: Last month, the company said it planned to acquire One Medical, a much larger competitor to its own health care business.
lead_paragraph: Amazon told employees in an email on Wednesday that it is shutting down Amazon Care, its in-house foray into providing primary and urgent health care. The move comes a month after Amazon announced plans to buy a much larger competitor, One Medical, in a $3.9 billion deal.
headline: Amazon says it will shut down Amazon Care, its primary and urgent health care business.

abstract: Our streaming picks for January, including ‘Cobra Kai,’ ‘Bump’ and ‘One Night in Miami …’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for January.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in January

abstract: Why Lina Khan and the F.T.C. must prevail in their long-awaited lawsuit against Amazon.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission’s chair, Lina Khan, has brought her long-awaited, audacious case against Amazon, signaling the Biden administration’s determination to restore an approach to competition law that has been in decline since the Carter administration. This will doubtless draw fresh criticism about her supposed overreach. But Amazon is precisely the kind of company that Congress had in mind in enacting America’s many antitrust laws.
headline: Amazon Is the Apex Predator of Our Platform Era

abstract: The bill would curb production quotas at Amazon and other companies that critics say are excessive and force workers to forgo bathroom breaks.
lead_paragraph: In the latest sign of the growing scrutiny of Amazon’s labor practices, the California State Senate on Wednesday approved a bill that would place limits on production quotas for warehouse workers.
headline: California Senate Passes Bill Reining In Amazon Labor Model

abstract: The world’s richest man thanked Amazon employees and customers for making his flight to space possible.
lead_paragraph: From groceries and streaming subscriptions to web servers and Alexa, Amazon has become one of the most powerful economic forces in the world. And after Jeff Bezos returned from his brief flight to space on Tuesday in a rocket built by his private space company, Blue Origin, he made remarks that drew attention to the vast wealth the company had created for him.
headline: Bezos thanks Amazon workers and customers for his vast wealth, prompting backlash.

abstract: Some Brazilian scientists fear that the Amazon may become a grassy savanna — with profound effects on the climate worldwide.
lead_paragraph: In the past half-century, 17 percent of the Amazon — an area larger than Texas — has been converted to croplands or cattle pasture. Less forest means less recycled rain, less vapor to cool the air, less of a canopy to shield against sunlight. Under drier, hotter conditions, even the lushest of Amazonian trees will shed leaves to save water, inhibiting photosynthesis — a feedback loop that is only exacerbated by global warming.
headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Has the Amazon Reached Its “Tipping Point”?’

abstract: The online retailer said that a shadowy organization bribed Amazon employees to help carry out fraudulent returns of expensive electronics, luxury goods and gold.
lead_paragraph: Amazon has accused an international organization, including customers and several former employees, of conspiring to steal millions of dollars in online products through fraudulent refunds.
headline: Amazon Suit Claims International Ring Stole Millions in Fraudulent Refunds

abstract: The founder of the e-commerce giant steps down as C.E.O. in two days. Then what?
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos founded Amazon 27 years ago. He steps down as C.E.O. two days from now. His successor, Andy Jassy, will take over the e-commerce giant on July 5.
headline: Amazon After Bezos

abstract: The eight countries that comprise the Amazon River basin agreed on several initiatives to curtail deforestation in the world’s largest and most important rainforest.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the leaders of eight countries that are home to the Amazon River basin agreed to work together to conserve the world’s largest rainforest at a groundbreaking meeting convened by President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil.
headline: Amazon Countries, Led by Brazil, Sign a Rainforest Pact

abstract: The app icon, which shows a blue patch above Amazon’s signature smile-shaped arrow, was given smoother edges and a folded corner after claims that it bore a resemblance to the German dictator.
lead_paragraph: You might not have seen it until someone pointed it out. But an Amazon logo that was just quietly redesigned bore an unsettling resemblance to the face of Adolf Hitler — at least according to some on social media.
headline: Amazon Quietly Tweaks Logo Some Say Resembled Hitler’s Mustache

abstract: Why has the union campaign spread so much further at the coffee chain than at the e-commerce giant?
lead_paragraph: Roughly six weeks after successful union votes at two Buffalo-area Starbucks stores in December, workers had filed paperwork to hold union elections in at least 20 other Starbucks locations nationwide.
headline: A Union Blitzed Starbucks. At Amazon, It’s a Slog.

abstract: There is no technological miracle that will fix decades of bad policy.
lead_paragraph: What if you could get health care as quickly and easily as you order socks and cat litter? It sounds fanciful in a country where people die waiting to see a doctor, but Amazon believed it could do for health care what it had done for shopping. Hailed as “the future of medicine,” the Amazon Care telehealth and house-call service was pitched to employers as “high-quality care, convenience and peace of mind.”
headline: Amazon Really Believed It Could Sell You a Health Care Fantasy

abstract: The fate of Colombia’s rainforest may lay in the hands of a rebel group linked to drugs and illegal mining.
lead_paragraph: There’s a struggle for law and order in many of the world’s tropical forests, and nature is losing.
headline: ‘Narco-deforestation’ and the future of the Amazon

abstract: Artists say officials tied to the country’s ruling party use pressure to stem criticism. Streaming services hoping to tap the Indian market’s potential have been caught in the middle.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Bollywood once again has fallen into the cross hairs of India’s Hindu nationalist ruling party — and major Western streaming services like Amazon and Netflix increasingly find themselves caught in the middle.
headline: Amazon Web Drama Draws the Wrath of India’s Hindu Nationalists

abstract: Seeking to raise revenue, Amazon said that U.S. subscribers to its streaming service could opt for an ad-free version for an extra $2.99 per month.
lead_paragraph: Amazon will start featuring advertisements on content streamed on Prime Video, the company said on Friday, making it the latest streaming service to turn to commercials to raise revenue.
headline: Amazon Will Show Commercials on Prime Video Starting Next Year

abstract: The closures affect its bookstores and Amazon 4-Star locations, but not Whole Foods or Amazon Fresh.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is closing more than 50 of its physical retail stores, including two dozen bookstores and more than 30 Amazon 4-Star stores selling general merchandise, the company said Wednesday.
headline: Amazon plans to shut down more than 50 brick-and-mortar stores.

abstract: The Windsor Police Department said it was investigating what it called “potential hate crime incidents” after a seventh noose was found at a future fulfillment center.
lead_paragraph: Amazon said it had temporarily stopped construction of a new fulfillment center in Windsor, Conn., after seven ropes that appeared to be nooses were found on the site since April 27.
headline: Amazon Pauses Construction at Connecticut Site After Nooses Are Found

lead_paragraph: Every month, American streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of March’s most promising new titles. abstract: The dream was to sell directly to customers. Now Peloton is on Amazon, Casper is in a furniture shop, and it’s awkward.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, I bought an online mattress — in a boring, conventional store.
headline: Why Peloton Is Selling on Amazon

abstract: The company, reporting a 9 percent revenue increase for the first quarter, is the latest Big Tech company to top Wall Street’s financial expectations.
lead_paragraph: For much of its history, Amazon grew amazingly, unbelievably fast. Not so much anymore.
headline: Amazon’s Growth Is Slow but Good Enough

lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for December.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in December

abstract: An examination of Brazil’s tannery industry shows how leather seats in luxury SUVs are worsening forest destruction.
lead_paragraph: How do cow hides from illegal farms in the Amazon end up in American SUVs?
headline: A Times Investigation Into Amazon Deforestation

abstract: The tech giant has struggled to produce popular games, but a much-delayed title released this week could be the first step in a turnaround.
lead_paragraph: Amazon has been successful in nearly every industry it has entered, from books and grocery shopping to cloud computing and movie streaming. So it has been puzzling to many that success in the lucrative video game business has eluded the tech giant.
headline: For Flagging Amazon Games Unit, New World ‘Has to Be Our Breakthrough’

abstract: Amazon has reimagined entire industries. What happens next to the $1.7 trillion company?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Amazon Without Jeff Bezos

abstract: The social network, which had fast been gaining right-wing users, said that Amazon had conspired with Twitter, but did not provide any direct evidence.
lead_paragraph: Hours after it went offline on Monday, the social media start-up Parler filed a lawsuit in federal court accusing Amazon of violating antitrust law and asking for a temporary restraining order to prevent the tech giant from blocking access to cloud computing services.
headline: Parler Accuses Amazon of Breaking Antitrust Law in Suspending Hosting Services

abstract: United Airlines employees will be required to upload proof of vaccination within five weeks of the Food and Drug Administration’s fully approving a vaccine or by Oct. 25, whichever comes first.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines said on Friday that it would require all U.S. employees to be vaccinated against the coronavirus starting this fall. It was the first major airline to establish such a mandate and the latest in a small but growing number of businesses to do so.
headline: United Airlines will require vaccination, and Amazon revives mask mandates.

abstract: They’ll be replaced in North America with paper packing, eliminating some 15 billion pillows a year. Plastic film is a major pollutant.
lead_paragraph: They’re a familiar sight in Amazon packages: The plastic air pillows designed to keep products safe in transit, but that also end up in landfills by the billions.
headline: Amazon Says It Will Stop Using Puffy Plastic Shipping Pillows

abstract: The National Labor Relations Board has scheduled a mail-in election to start Feb. 4 for workers in Alabama after throwing out the results of a vote last year.
lead_paragraph: Amazon workers in Alabama will have another shot at voting to form a union this winter, as the National Labor Relations Board scheduled a mail-in election to start Feb. 4.
headline: A timeline is set for a new unionization vote at an Amazon warehouse.

abstract: Market size matters, but even small changes have an outsize ripple effect.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: How Big Is Amazon, Really?

abstract: The animals painted in ocher in Colombia may include giant ground sloths and other creatures that vanished from the Americas. But some researchers say the art has a more recent origin.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the last ice age, South America was home to strange animals that have since vanished into extinction: giant ground sloths, elephant-like herbivores and an ancient lineage of horses. A new study suggests that we can see these lost creatures in enchanting ocher paintings made by ice age humans on a rocky outcrop in the Colombian Amazon.
headline: Does This Amazon Rock Art Depict Extinct Ice Age Mammals?

abstract: The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union may be one of the most eclectic labor unions in the U.S. And it is on the cusp of pushing into the e-commerce behemoth.
lead_paragraph: A group of gravediggers in Columbus, Ohio, who just negotiated a 3 percent raise. The poultry plant that processes chicken nuggets for McDonald’s. The workers who make Cap’n Crunch in Iowa. The women’s shoe department at Saks Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.
headline: Organizing Gravediggers, Cereal Makers and, Maybe, Amazon Employees

abstract: The company has big plans to turn its delivery fleet green. But very few of the vehicles are made right now.
lead_paragraph: In the fall, Jeff Bezos tweeted praise for Rivian, a start-up under contract to make 100,000 electric delivery vans for Amazon, and its founder, R.J. Scaringe, calling him “one of the greatest entrepreneurs I’ve ever met.”
headline: Can Anyone Satisfy Amazon’s Craving for Electric Vans?

abstract: Netflix reports a drop in subscribers, but it could have been worse. The Fed announces its next rate increase. And we’ll hear how strong, or weak, the U.S. economy is.
lead_paragraph: It is theoretically possible to go through a day patronizing only Amazon-owned companies: You might buy groceries at Whole Foods, listen to a book on Audible on your commute, check your Goodreads account and then, of course, visit Amazon.com. Now, the e-commerce giant is making a new push into health care. Amazon announced on Thursday that it had reached a $3.9 billion deal to buy One Medical, a network of primary care clinics, as part of its quest to become a major player in the industry. The deal is the first acquisition under Andy Jassy, who became chief executive a year ago after Jeff Bezos stepped down. Mr. Jassy’s approach to the role has been much different from his predecessor’s, but on this decision, he hasn’t diverged too drastically from Mr. Bezos. One Medical is not the first health-care-related company Amazon has purchased. In 2018, it acquired PillPack, an online pharmacy.
headline: The Week in Business: Amazon’s Latest Acquisition

abstract: Delegates will vote on a resolution pledging “all resources necessary” for efforts to unionize the retail giant.
lead_paragraph: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents over one million workers in North America in industries including parcel delivery and freight, will vote on whether to make it a priority to organize Amazon workers and help them win a union contract.
headline: The Teamsters consider a new emphasis on organizing Amazon workers.

abstract: Workers at a warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., are to vote next month on whether to unionize, the largest and most viable effort of its kind involving the technology giant.
lead_paragraph: The largest, most viable effort to unionize Amazon in many years began last summer not in a union stronghold like New York or Michigan, but at a Fairfield Inn outside Birmingham, in the right-to-work state of Alabama.
headline: Amazon Union Drive Takes Hold in Unlikely Place

abstract: Amazon, racing to get products from factories to our homes, lures merchants with chartered cargo ships.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Amazon on the High Seas

abstract: A new study weighed a range of threats and variables in an effort to map out where the rainforest is most vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Up to half of the Amazon rainforest could transform into grasslands or weakened ecosystems in the coming decades, a new study found, as climate change, deforestation and severe droughts like the one the region is currently experiencing damage huge areas beyond their ability to recover.
headline: A Collapse of the Amazon Could Be Coming ‘Faster Than We Thought’

abstract: Unlike any other streamer, Amazon brings hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue and the power of a vast network of other lines of business to the fight.
lead_paragraph: In the 1930s and ’40s, five major Hollywood studios dominated the film industry and tried to lock up distribution and exhibition channels as well by taking over movie theaters across the country. Courts and regulators saw that allowing studios so much power up and down the film supply chain posed grave threats to the integrity of the industry and to viewer choice.
headline: Don’t Let Amazon Eat the Film Industry

abstract: A bipartisan group told the company that they were considering referring their concerns to the Justice Department for a potential criminal inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of lawmakers pressed Amazon’s chief executive on Monday to respond to allegations that its executives provided a congressional inquiry with false answers to questions about its house-brand products.
headline: Lawmakers question whether Amazon executives, including Jeff Bezos, misled Congress.

abstract: Our picks for September, including ‘Billions,’ ‘Goliath’ and ‘Worth’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for September.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in September

abstract: The tech giant introduced the Rufus chatbot. It has lagged behind others on introducing consumer-facing generative artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Amazon entered the consumer chatbot fray on Thursday, announcing a new artificial intelligence personal shopping assistant as the company races to catch up with other tech giants.
headline: Amazon Enters Chatbot Fray With Shopping Tool

abstract: America’s two largest private employers have converged in some ways, but each still has a leg up on the other.
lead_paragraph: When titans clash, the ground shakes and televisions get a lot cheaper. I’m referring, of course, to this week’s Christmas-in-July sales competition between Walmart and Amazon, the biggest and second-biggest private employers in the United States.
headline: Amazon Prime Day, Walmart Plus Week and the Battle of the Retail Giants

abstract: A knot of problems with Amazon’s system for handling paid and unpaid leaves has led to devastating consequences for workers.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Tara Jones, an Amazon warehouse worker in Oklahoma, cradled her newborn, glanced over her pay stub on her phone and noticed that she had been underpaid by a significant chunk: $90 out of $540.
headline: Inside Amazon’s Worst Human Resources Problem

abstract: Regional inequality has deepened across the country.
lead_paragraph: When I set out to report a book on the problem of growing regional inequality in America, I did not expect that it would involve spending several hours on a cold winter day standing inside a large dumpster.
headline: Amazon and the Breaking of Baltimore

abstract: “The Boys,” “Orphan Black: Echoes,” “The Bear” and “The Acolyte” will be streaming.
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of June’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, AMC+, Disney+, Hulu, and More in June

abstract: Even the big tech companies don’t have it all figured out.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Maybe Amazon Has No Master Plan

abstract: The Biden era has prompted Brazil to take steps to repair its record as an environmental scoundrel — for which it’s seeking billions of dollars from the international community.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center’s Rainforest Investigations Network.
headline: Bolsonaro’s Sudden Pledge to Protect the Amazon Is Met With Skepticism

abstract: As the pandemic gripped New York City, it propelled an enormous surge in online shopping. Amazon, the giant online retailer, went shopping too.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic gripped New York City, it propelled an enormous surge in online shopping. Amazon, the giant online retailer, went shopping too.
headline: In New York, as shoppers went online, Amazon went on a warehouse-buying spree.

abstract: In a lawsuit filed on Tuesday, the Federal Trade Commission said the internet giant used its monopoly power to stifle competition and raise prices.
lead_paragraph: In a long-awaited lawsuit, the Federal Trade Commission and 17 states sued Amazon on Tuesday, accusing the company of using illegal tactics to control online shopping in ways that stifled competition, and raised prices for consumers and costs to sellers.
headline: Here Are the 2 Tactics Amazon Used to Undermine Competition, the F.T.C. Says

abstract: Amazon Web Services began reporting increased “error rates” in its cloud operations on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon warehouses around the country stopped operating Tuesday as outages in the company’s cloud computing system took down the technology that powers the company’s logistics operations.
headline: Amazon’s cloud computing outage disrupts its warehouse operations.

abstract: A Times investigation married hourslong stakeouts with data reporting and found that it’s all too easy for hides from illegally deforested ranches to reach the global marketplace.
lead_paragraph: In July 2021, Manuela Andreoni, a Pulitzer Center reporting fellow at The New York Times, camped out for hours outside a slaughterhouse close to the Jaci-Paraná reserve in Brazil. She was tracking a truck that she suspected was delivering hides from cattle kept on illegally deforested ranches to a supplier of American automobile seat makers. A few days earlier, Victor Moriyama, a photographer working for The Times, nearly stepped on a poisonous snake.
headline: Tracing the Trail of Amazon Deforestation

abstract: Federal labor regulators said that Amazon had illegally barred off-duty employees from work sites and that the policy was aimed at union backers.
lead_paragraph: Federal labor regulators have concluded that Amazon’s policy of restricting the warehouse access of off-duty employees is illegal, backing a contention of the union that has represented workers at a Staten Island warehouse since winning an election there last year.
headline: Amazon Union Gets Favorable Finding on Warehouse Access for Organizing

abstract: Michael De Luca and Pamela Abdy, brought on to ready MGM for a sale, announced their departures one month after its acquisition by Amazon.
lead_paragraph: The two top executives at Metro Goldwyn Mayer — Michael De Luca and Pamela Abdy — announced their impending departures on Wednesday, one month after Amazon closed its $8.5 billion acquisition of the film studio.
headline: One month after Amazon takeover, two top MGM executives announce their departures.

abstract: Double-parked delivery trucks raise a political question about the use of our roadways.
lead_paragraph: Between 1961, when the social critic Jane Jacobs published “The Death and Life of Great American Cities,” and the Covid lockdowns of 2020, it seemed the residential neighborhoods of Washington, like those of certain other, mostly Eastern cities in the United States, had discovered the secret of happiness and safety in the automobile age: narrow streets.
headline: Something Has Changed on City Streets, and Amazon Is to Blame

abstract: A deal would add Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer’s 4,000 films to Amazon’s streaming library, including the James Bond, Rocky and “Legally Blonde” franchises.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has been in talks to sell itself to Amazon, according to three people briefed on the matter. If completed, a deal would turbocharge Amazon’s streaming ambitions by bringing James Bond, Rocky, RoboCop and other film and television properties into the e-commerce giant’s fold.
headline: MGM Looks to Amazon as the Hollywood Studio Tries to Find a Buyer

abstract: A website called Not Amazon was created to drive sales to more than 4,000 independent stores in four cities. The initiative aims to keep expanding.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The snow was falling outside Ali Haberstroh’s apartment in late November when the idea came to her.
headline: A Canadian ‘Buy Local’ Effort Fights Amazon on Its Own Turf

abstract: Galena, a 6-year-old shorthair, was found in an Amazon warehouse a week after she climbed into a 3-by-3-foot cardboard box at her owner’s home.
