lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — An 18th-century turban ornament glistening with diamonds, emeralds and pearls has a fascinating back story, yet almost none of it appeared on the placard that once accompanied the piece in the Museum of Islamic Art.
headline: Museums Find Value in Sharing Jewels’ History

abstract: Three states and the District of Columbia allege that the tech giant misled consumers by continuing to track those who had changed their privacy settings to prevent data collection.
lead_paragraph: The District of Columbia and three states sued Google on Monday, claiming that the tech giant deceived consumers to gain access to their location data.
headline: Four Attorneys General Claim Google Secretly Tracked People

abstract: The case could reshape the rules of how other businesses can make money on the Android operating system.
lead_paragraph: A jury ruled on Monday that Google had violated antitrust laws to extract fees and limit competition from Epic Games and other developers on its Play mobile app store, in a case that could rewrite the rules on how thousands of businesses make money on Google’s smartphone operating system, Android.
headline: Google Loses Antitrust Court Battle With Makers of Fortnite Video Game

abstract: Hardcore business travelers have no intention of going back to the old ways. The workers who cater to their needs don’t have as many choices.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I served on my building’s co-op board with someone whose daily logistical demands made me realize I was just coasting.
headline: How the Pandemic Has Made the Creative Class Feel Free

abstract: The [DATE] episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Agnes Callard. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Agnes Callard

abstract: For more than a decade, a sweeping nondisclosure agreement with Tiger Woods, brokered by Gloria Allred, has ruled her life. Now she’s ready to rip it up.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Uchitel was sitting at a table in her Upper East Side apartment not long ago, alternately stoic and tearful, surrounded by hundreds of pages of legal documents. For more than a decade these have been familiar company: the wallpaper of a room she can’t seem to leave.
headline: This Is Rachel Uchitel, Representing Herself

abstract: The search giant’s negotiations to buy Wiz, a cybersecurity start-up, for $23 billion, come as the Biden administration has taken a hard line against consolidation in tech and other industries.
lead_paragraph: Google, which became one of the world’s most valuable companies through its search engine and other consumer internet services, is nearing its largest-ever acquisition to improve what it can offer to business customers.
headline: Google Close to Its Biggest Acquisition Ever, Despite Antitrust Scrutiny

abstract: Some are nostalgic for the silence they had at home, especially since in-office perks, aimed at luring people back, can make it harder to concentrate.
lead_paragraph: Marjorie Roberts, who runs a nonprofit in the Florida Keys, started out a recent morning with a list of tasks that ideally she would have raced right through. Figure out coverage for someone going on summer vacation. (Easy.) Look at the accountant’s recent audit. (Blah.) Redo a reimbursement request that the county finance department turned down. (Why?!) All simple enough.
headline: So You Wanted to Get Work Done at the Office?

abstract: OpenAI’s chief executive, Sam Altman, and Microsoft’s chief technology officer, Kevin Scott, on an A.I.-powered Bing.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s release of a ChatGPT-powered Bing signifies a new era in search. Then, a disastrous preview of Bard — Google’s answer to ChatGPT — caused the company’s stocks to slide 7 percent. The A.I. arms race is on.
headline: Bing’s Revenge and Google’s A.I. Face-Plant

abstract: Chafing at their dependence, Amazon, Google, Meta and Microsoft are racing to cut into Nvidia’s dominant share of the market.
lead_paragraph: In September, Amazon said it would invest up to $4 billion in Anthropic, a San Francisco start-up working on artificial intelligence.
headline: Nvidia’s Big Tech Rivals Put Their Own A.I. Chips on the Table

abstract: The explosion of the e-commerce economy has created an opportunity for thieves — and a conundrum for the railways.
lead_paragraph: Of all the dozens of suspected thieves questioned by the detectives of the Train Burglary Task Force at the Los Angeles Police Department during the months they spent investigating the rise in theft from the city’s freight trains, one man stood out. What made Victor Llamas memorable wasn’t his criminality so much as his giddy enthusiasm for trespassing. He was a self-taught expert of the supply chain, a connoisseur of shipping containers. Even in custody, as the detectives interrogated him numerous times, after multiple arrests, in a windowless police-station room in the spring of 2022, a kind of nostalgia would sweep over the man. “He said that was the best feeling he’d ever had, jumping on the train while it was moving,” Joe Chavez, who supervised the task force’s detectives, told me. “It was euphoric for him.”
headline: The Great Freight-Train Heists of the 21st Century

abstract: The tech giant is sprinting to protect its core business with a flurry of projects, including updates to its search engine and plans for an all-new one.
lead_paragraph: Google’s employees were shocked when they learned in March that the South Korean consumer electronics giant Samsung was considering replacing Google with Microsoft’s Bing as the default search engine on its devices.
headline: Google Devising Radical Search Changes to Beat Back A.I. Rivals

abstract: The Justice Department’s antitrust lawsuit, which a group of states joined, was the fifth by U.S. officials against the company since 2020.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department and a group of eight states sued Google on Tuesday, accusing it of illegally abusing a monopoly over the technology that powers online advertising, in the agency’s first antitrust lawsuit against a tech giant under President Biden and an escalation in legal pressure on one of the world’s biggest internet companies.
headline: U.S. Accuses Google of Abusing Monopoly in Ad Technology

abstract: A new Canadian law will require technology companies to license news content. Facebook’s owner said it would drop news from the platform.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Parliament has passed a law that will require technology companies to pay domestic news outlets for linking to their articles, prompting the owner of Facebook and Instagram to say that it would pull news articles from both platforms in the country.
headline: Canada Forces Google and Facebook to Pay News Outlets for Linking to Articles

abstract: Eddy Cue, a longtime executive at the company, said Apple’s multibillion-dollar deals with Google were driven by quality, not money.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s top deal maker on Tuesday defended his company’s favoritism of Google on iPhones, a pivotal collaboration that has shaped the modern tech industry and is at the center of a federal antitrust trial against the search giant.
headline: Top Apple Executive Defends Favoring Google on iPhones

abstract: The tech giant intends to start gradually blocking trackers, or cookies, from Chrome in mid-2023 and eliminate them altogether later that year.
lead_paragraph: Google pushed back plans to phase out a widely used technology to track the web activity of users, in an effort to address growing concerns from regulators and digital advertising industry rivals.
headline: Google delays a privacy change to its Chrome web browser.

abstract: Google has released a new chatbot to a limited number of people in the U.S. and Britain. How does it compare with what is already out there?
lead_paragraph: Google has released a new chatbot, Bard, and has shared the experimental technology with a limited number of people in the United States and Britain.
headline: What Google Bard Can Do (and What It Can’t)

abstract: Long-awaited tech like A.I., 3-D telepresence and driverless cars is finally reaching the public.
lead_paragraph: At its biggest event of the year, Google announced an avalanche of A.I. product releases: A.I. in search, A.I. that writes emails and A.I. that generates slides. Is Google pulling ahead in the A.I. arms race?
headline: Google’s A.I. Bonanza and Driverless Car Talk With Cruise C.E.O. Kyle Vogt

abstract: The layoffs amount to about 6 percent of the global work force at the company, the latest tech giant to make cuts after a pandemic hiring spree.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, said on Friday that it planned to cut 12,000 jobs, becoming the latest technology company to reduce its work force because of concerns about a broader economic slowdown, after a hiring spree during the pandemic.
headline: Google Parent Alphabet to Cut 12,000 Jobs

abstract: In opening statements for the government’s first monopoly trial of the modern internet era, Google defended itself and said people had many choices for online search.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department and 38 states and territories on Tuesday laid out how Google had systematically wielded its power in online search to cow competitors, as the internet giant fiercely parried back, in the opening of the most consequential trial over tech power in the modern internet era.
headline: ‘A Monopolist Flexing’: U.S. Blasts Google’s Tactics as Antitrust Trial Opens

abstract: The government claims that Google illegally stifles rivals, while the company says its practices are legal and mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from Google’s antitrust trial
headline: Google Goes on Trial Over Justice Dept. Claims That It Has Monopoly Power

abstract: The company abandoned work on an earlier military program after employees revolted.
lead_paragraph: Google executives told employees last week in a companywide meeting that it is interested in a Pentagon contract for cloud computing and that working for the military would not necessarily conflict with principles created by the company for how its artificial intelligence technology would be used.
headline: Google executives tell employees it can compete for Pentagon contracts without violating its principles.

abstract: Google said that starting July 1, it would take 15 percent of the first $1 million developers take in from certain app sales, down from 30 percent.
lead_paragraph: Google is cutting in half its commission on developers’ first $1 million in app sales, following a similar move by Apple that is aimed at appeasing developers and regulators who accuse the companies of abusing their dominance of the smartphone industry.
headline: Google reduces some app-store fees amid criticism.

abstract: In toasters and in life, the top-rated anything will never be good enough.
lead_paragraph: Let me tell you about my friend Dan Symons. There is a kind of person who finds the idea of seeking out “the best” incredibly enticing, on an almost spiritual level. The kind of person who genuinely enjoys perusing articles like “the nine best hair dryers of 2023,” who is overcome with clammy dread at the idea of drinking in a bar with only a four-star rating on Google, who, in order to plan a weekend getaway, requires a prolonged and extensive operation that involves several spreadsheets. You know the type. Maybe you even are the type.
headline: The Tyranny of ‘the Best’

abstract: The designer Olympia Le-Tan has created a home goods line with the kind of stuff you’d steal (or want to steal) from a hotel.
lead_paragraph: During the early days of the pandemic, the designer Olympia Le-Tan missed traveling. Or rather, she missed hotels.
headline: Hotel Life Without the Hotel

abstract: The company that helped popularize open office plans and lavish employee perks is trying to reinvent office spaces to cope with workplace sensibilities changed by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Google’s first office was a cluttered Silicon Valley garage crammed with desks resting on sawhorses.
headline: Google’s Plan for the Future of Work: Privacy Robots and Balloon Walls

abstract: Described by its showrunner as “definitely a fantasy,” the hit series relies on a team of historical consultants. Does the show take their advice? Mostly.
lead_paragraph: When the first season of the Netflix series “Bridgerton” premiered on Christmas Day, Amanda Vickery sat at home with her three daughters and watched every episode. This was in 2020, in the midst of England’s lockdown, and Vickery remembers thinking, “Thank goodness for this escape.”
headline: How ‘Bridgerton’ Makes History

abstract: The internet giant, planning on employees returning to the office for a few days a week, is building another $1 billion office less than two miles away.
lead_paragraph: Google said Friday that it would spend $1 billion to purchase a London office building, making it the owner of another high-priced piece of real estate as the internet giant bets on an eventual return to office for its employees around the world.
headline: Google pays $1 billion for a London office building.

abstract: He’s now one of the most consumed media products on the planet. His Spotify deal, estimated at $100 million, speaks to the allure of making audiences feel they’re in on something subversive.
lead_paragraph: The other comics called him “Little Ball of Anger” — semi-affectionately, never to his face — a man flammable by bearing and branding, it seemed, with his taekwondo muscles and a scorching conviction that the Bible had some holes.
headline: Joe Rogan Is Too Big to Cancel

abstract: Appointments for mammograms and other tests to detect potential cancers were canceled during lockdowns, possibly leading to undiagnosed malignancies. In some cases, the delay has come at a great cost.
lead_paragraph: Yvette Lowery usually gets her annual mammogram around March. But last year, just as the pandemic was gaining a foothold and medical facilities were shutting down, the center where she goes canceled her appointment. No one could tell her when to reschedule.
headline: Advanced Cancers Are Emerging, Doctors Warn, Citing Pandemic Drop in Screenings

abstract: The app, created by allies of the opposition leader Aleksei Navalny, vanished from online stores, reflecting a new level of pressure against U.S. technology companies in the country.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Apple and Google removed an app meant to coordinate protest voting in this weekend’s Russian elections from the country on Friday, a blow to the opponents of President Vladimir V. Putin and a display of Silicon Valley’s limits when it comes to resisting crackdowns on dissent around the world.
headline: Google and Apple, Under Pressure From Russia, Remove Voting App

abstract: The new Hulu movie is the rare Hollywood production that portrays the struggles to conceive as women actually experience them.
lead_paragraph: As millions of women know, fertility treatments can be a nightmare. The painful, sterile procedures, the loss of control over your own body, the never-ending blood tests and experiments and strange medications that take over your refrigerator shelves and your life.
headline: ‘False Positive’ and the Horror-Filled Truth About Fertility Treatments

abstract: Workers will have the option to return in April but can continue to work from home until September.
lead_paragraph: Google employees in the United States will likely be allowed to return to the office next month, the company said on Wednesday.
headline: Google to welcome some employees back to office in April.

abstract: Sridhar Ramaswamy ran the tech giant’s lucrative ad machine. Now he’s betting on a new business model for search.
lead_paragraph: Call it a redemption narrative: After working to grow Google’s lucrative advertising business for 15 years, Sridhar Ramaswamy left the Silicon Valley Goliath to co-found Neeva, a subscription-based search engine that promises not to profit off its customers’ search data. It sounds good in theory; many companies have exploited user data under the guise of their free services. But whether Neeva can get users to care enough about their data to pay for privacy is a whole other story.
headline: Meet the Man Who Wants You to Give Up Google

abstract: A court rejected Google’s appeal of a record-setting antitrust fine related to Android and online search.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Global efforts to crimp the power of the world’s largest technology companies scored an important legal victory on Wednesday when a European Union court gave its blessing to a record multibillion-dollar fine issued against Google in 2018.
headline: E.U. Scores Major Legal Victory Against Google

abstract: Artificial intelligence is being woven into an array of the company’s products. But the change — for now — is subtle.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — There was a time when Google offered a wondrous vision of the future, with driverless cars, augmented-reality eyewear, unlimited storage of emails and photos, and predictive texts to complete sentences in progress.
headline: Google Offers a More Modest Vision of the Future

abstract: A cascading series of failures, from the central government on down, left hospitals across India without medical oxygen, killing hundreds. One tragic night in Delhi shows how it happened.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At 9:45 p.m., alarms blared across the intensive care unit of Jaipur Golden Hospital. Over two dozen patients on ventilators couldn’t breathe. Some flailed their arms and legs. Others cried for help, choking sounds coming from their throats as if they were being strangled.
headline: The Night the Oxygen Ran Out

abstract: The tech giant admitted no wrongdoing as it resolved four women’s claims of widespread pay biases. The company will also allow an outside monitor to review its practices.
lead_paragraph: Google has settled a class-action lawsuit that accused it of systematically underpaying women, promising to provide $118 million in monetary relief and invite outsiders to review its pay practices.
headline: Google Agrees to Pay $118 Million to Settle Pay Discrimination Case

abstract: Google says its goals for carbon-free power are impeded by state-regulated utilities, particularly in the Southeast, that lack a competitive market.
lead_paragraph: It was the sort of dry panel discussion that occurs at hundreds of industry conferences every year — until a Google representative decided it was time to unleash.
headline: Clean Energy Quest Pits Google Against Utilities

abstract: A video producer claims he was fired after he complained that an obscure group based in the Sierra foothills dominated a business unit at Google.
lead_paragraph: OREGON HOUSE, Calif. — In a tiny town in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, a religious organization called the Fellowship of Friends has established an elaborate, 1,200-acre compound full of art and ornate architecture.
headline: How a Religious Sect Landed Google in a Lawsuit

abstract: The “Crime Junkie” co-host, who oversees a network of popular podcasts, has a new podcast aimed at heating up the “coldest of cases.”
lead_paragraph: Late last month, Ashley Flowers, 33, the producer of more than a dozen true crime podcasts, was racing between her home and her office in Indianapolis, preparing for the arrival of two babies. The first, her daughter Josie, was born Jan. 28. The second, due this week, is a new podcast she’s hosting called “The Deck.”
headline: Ashley Flowers Wants to Up the Ante of True Crime

abstract: Silicon Valley is wondering whether ChatGPT will replace Google as the internet’s main source of information. For many topics, YouTube already has.
lead_paragraph: Will ChatGPT kill Google?
headline: There’s Already a Better Search Engine Than Google. It’s YouTube.

abstract: Under pressure from employees and supporters of reproductive rights, the company announced privacy changes for the post-Roe era.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google said on Friday that it would delete abortion clinic visits from the location history of its users, in the company’s first effort to address how it will handle sensitive data in the wake of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade.
headline: Google Says It Will Delete Location Data When Users Visit Abortion Clinics

abstract: Tim Sweeney, who runs the company that created Fortnite, testified in a case that, if he wins, could allow competing payment systems on the Play Store.
lead_paragraph: It was a long-awaited day in court for Epic Games’ chief executive, Tim Sweeney, who testified in a San Francisco federal courthouse on Monday in the company’s legal battle against Google.
headline: Epic Games C.E.O. Says Google Has ‘De Facto Control’ on Android App

abstract: “Our research shows that publishers’ revenue increases when they use our tools — that’s why they choose to use them!” a Google official writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
headline: From Google, on Its Advertising Tech Business

abstract: Outrageous lies destroyed Guy Babcock’s online reputation. When he went hunting for their source, what he discovered was worse than he could have imagined.
lead_paragraph: Guy Babcock vividly remembers the chilly Saturday evening when he discovered the stain on his family. It was September 2018. He, his wife and their young son had just returned to their home in Beckley, an English village outside of Oxford. Mr. Babcock still had his coat on when he got a frantic call from his father.
headline: A Vast Web of Vengeance

abstract: Amid a crisis in affordable housing, the century-old ideas of Henry George have gained a new currency.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Mike Duggan talks about his accomplishments in Detroit, the list is both impressive and sad. He had the streetlights turned back on, and reopened closed parks. In the decade since he took office, the city has demolished some 25,000 blighted homes whose rusty debris and incubation of crime drag down neighborhoods.
headline: The ‘Georgists’ Are Out There, and They Want to Tax Your Land

abstract: Gustie Owens, a member of the inaugural class of The New York Times Diverse Crossword Constructor Fellowship, makes her debut.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE —  Once, in middle school, Gustie Owens’s teacher announced to her from across the room that “12-Across is ALLIGATOR.” Gustie realized that the crossword puzzle she was working on was reflected in the lenses of her glasses.
headline: Gossip Session

abstract: In her “A Good Girl’s Guide to Murder” series and “Five Survive,” this British author makes herself at home on the East Coast.
lead_paragraph: How does a London-based novelist concoct a convincing story set in the United States? Some might splurge for a temporary relocation in the name of research, but Holly Jackson opts for a virtual visit via Google Maps. Navigating from street views to real estate listings — and even, eventually, to electoral records — she’ll piece together a universe for her characters.
headline: Holly Jackson’s Maximization of Google Maps

abstract: The Oscar-winning actress has found therapeutic refuge on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Brie Larson was not at last week’s Oscars, though she won one for her acting in “Room,” about a mother in captivity, five years ago.
headline: Brie Larson Pivoted to Video

abstract: The results were below analysts’ expectations for a net profit of $17.33 billion on revenue of $68.05 billion.
lead_paragraph: Google’s pandemic boom may finally be slowing.
headline: Alphabet’s profit drops 8% as Google’s pandemic boom shows signs of slowing.

abstract: Fly through David Rockow’s New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
headline: Wide-Eyed Wonderment

abstract: Efrain Guerrero and James Jones had an instant chemistry after meeting three years ago, though each had a different way of expressing love for each other.
lead_paragraph: Establishing a joint Google calendar may not be a standard marker of a flourishing romance, but for Efrain Guerrero and James Jones, it stood in just fine for a more customary expression of commitment.
headline: Their Future Was Written on the Calendar

abstract: The mind behind DeepMind.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode is a conversation with Demis Hassabis, the head of Google’s artificial intelligence division. We talk about Google’s latest A.I. models, Gemini and Gemma; the existential risks of artificial intelligence; his timelines for artificial general intelligence; and what he thinks the world will look like post-A.G.I.
headline: Google DeepMind C.E.O. Demis Hassabis on the Path From Chatbots to A.G.I.

abstract: The absence of stringent regulation has allowed the search giant to dominate the powerful market for online advertising. Here's how to fix it.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Gary Gensler, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, asked Congress to consider the idea of regulating cryptocurrency exchanges the way the federal government has long regulated stock exchanges. While his comments drew fresh attention to the unregulated markets for cryptocurrency, they reminded me of another long unregulated exchange marketplace: the market for digital advertising.
headline: Google Is Dominating This Hidden Market With No Rules

abstract: The Justice Department for more than a year has investigated whether Google abuses its dominance over the interlocking technologies that deliver ads online.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has in recent weeks conducted new interviews for its investigation into Google’s ad technology, a sign it may be moving closer to filing its second antitrust case against the company, said three people with knowledge of the matter.
headline: Justice Dept. Said to Conduct New Interviews in Inquiry Into Google’s Ad Tech

abstract: The company, which has been working to trim expenses, laid off employees who worked on core engineering, the Google Assistant product and hardware such as the Pixel phone.
lead_paragraph: Google laid off hundreds of workers in several divisions Wednesday night, seeking to lower expenses as it focuses on artificial intelligence and joining a wave of other companies cutting tech jobs this year.
headline: Google Cuts Hundreds of Jobs in Engineering and Other Divisions

abstract: Genzaburo Yoshino’s novel “How Do You Live?” may be the basis for the award-winning animator’s final film.
lead_paragraph: HOW DO YOU LIVE?By Genzaburo YoshinoTranslated by Bruno NavaskyForeword by Neil Gaiman
headline: The First English Translation of Hayao Miyazaki’s Favorite Childhood Book

abstract: Rhaenyra receives some surprising news, and Viserys likely sets into motion the thing he’s been trying to avoid.
lead_paragraph: A couple of centuries in Westeros’s future, in the same garden (I think) where King Viserys went on a blind date with a child on Sunday, Cersei Lannister will tell the soon-to-be-splooshed Oberyn Martell one of the saddest things anyone has ever heard.
headline: ‘House of the Dragon,’ Season 1, Episode 2: A Happy Announcement

abstract: At the center of an antitrust lawsuit filed by 10 state attorneys general last month is a deal Google extended to Facebook to be a partner in the digital advertising space, according to court documents.
lead_paragraph: At the center of an antitrust lawsuit filed by 10 state attorneys general last month is a deal Google extended to Facebook to be a partner in the digital advertising space, according to court documents.
headline: Behind the Google-Facebook deal that is the focus of an antitrust suit.

abstract: And soon after, I told both of my parents who I really am.
lead_paragraph: After I came home from the hospital, my mother and father took turns sitting on my bed every night to make sure I was still breathing. My mother would rest her head on my chest and say a prayer. My father would whisper, “I love you,” and touch my cheek.
headline: When My Heart Broke, My Father Used Google to Save Me

abstract: Job cuts, which could continue throughout the year, have created a glum mood at what was arguably Silicon Valley’s most exuberant workplace.
lead_paragraph: When Diane Hirsh Theriault’s co-worker returned from lunch to Google’s Cambridge, Mass., office one afternoon in October, his work badge couldn’t open a turnstile. He quickly realized it was a sign that he had been laid off.
headline: Google’s Once Happy Offices Feel the Chill of Layoffs

abstract: This week’s episode focused on the immediate aftermath of the king’s death and on the misunderstanding that helped shape the consequences.
lead_paragraph: Before we get started this week, let us have a moment of silence for Lord Beesbury.
headline: ‘House of the Dragon’ Season 1, Episode 9 Recap: A Convenient Mistake

abstract: The subject is one of the gravest topics in art history. I came for the lost stories of Jewish collectors. Where were they?
lead_paragraph: Some headlines from the last few months. March: the French government agrees to return a major landscape by Gustav Klimt to the heirs of Nora Stiasny, a Jewish woman from Vienna, forced to sell it before being sent to her death in 1942.
headline: In ‘Afterlives,’ About Looted Art, Why Are the Victims an Afterthought?

abstract: Single again in midlife, I am learning how to embrace reality over fantasy in a new relationship.
lead_paragraph: A prompt on the Hinge dating app asks for two truths and a lie. I could say: I was in a cult as a teenager. I got engaged after only two months of dating. I had a stroke at 44, after ending my 19-year marriage.
headline: When a Breakup Is an Act of Love

abstract: Experts say the new feature may offer dubious advice in response to personal health queries.
lead_paragraph: Do you have a headache or is it a sinus infection? What does a stress fracture feel like? Should you be worried about the pain in your chest? If you Google those questions now, the answers may be written by artificial intelligence.
headline: Google Is Using A.I. to Answer Your Health Questions. Should You Trust It?

abstract: Maybe at another time in human history I would have cared about the health benefits, but at this point, I’m like, what does “good for you” even mean?
lead_paragraph: I’m standing with two friends in the 39-degree air on the edge of a lake in northeastern California in just our bathing suits. A lone fisherman in several layers of outerwear stares, drinks from a bottle of Racer Ale and says, “Tell me you ladies aren’t going in that water.”
headline: Swimming in Very Cold Water Keeps Me Sane

abstract: The tech giant will pay $700 million and allow app makers to collect payments directly from consumers in a settlement it hopes will help resolve other legal challenges.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Monday that it would allow developers on its Play app store to offer direct payment options to users and would pay $700 million to settle an antitrust suit brought by state attorneys general, in the company’s latest move to navigate increased regulatory scrutiny of its power.
headline: Google Allows More App Payment Options in Antitrust Deal With States

abstract: With long battery life and nice cameras, the new Google devices excel at what popular phones have done for years. Is that enough?
lead_paragraph: For half a decade, Google, the maker of Android, the world’s most widely used phone software, has had a dream to make a best-selling phone that rivals the gold standard, the iPhone.
headline: Google Pixel 6 Review: Playing Catch-Up With the iPhone

abstract: Google’s latest entry-level phone, which costs $500, is just as good as devices nearly double its price.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, there were plenty of compelling reasons to spend upward of $900 on a smartphone. Nowadays, you’ll have to come up with an excuse to pay that much.
headline: Pixel 7A Review: We’re Running Out of Reasons to Splurge on a ‘Pro’ Phone

abstract: Jennifer Weber has two shows opening on Broadway, “&Juliet” and “KPOP,” and her “Hip-Hop Nutcracker” is coming to Disney+.
lead_paragraph: Among the movement challenges that the choreographer Jennifer Weber has been facing lately: dodging tourists on the sidewalks around Times Square as she runs between theaters. Her first Broadway show opens on Thursday. Her second opens Sunday.
headline: A Genre-Spanning Choreographer Who Says Yes to the Unknown

abstract: The popular drug discount app deceptively shared details on users’ illnesses and medicines with ad firms, regulators said in a legal complaint.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans have used GoodRx, a drug discount app, to search for lower prices on prescriptions like antidepressants, H.I.V. medications and treatments for sexually transmitted diseases at their local drugstores. But U.S. regulators say the app’s coupons and convenience came at a high cost for users: wrongful disclosure of their intimate health information.
headline: GoodRx Leaked User Health Data to Facebook and Google, F.T.C. Says

abstract: In Allyson Shaw’s “Ashes and Stones” and Diana Helmuth’s “The Witching Year,” authors confront ancient stereotypes through modern eyes.
lead_paragraph: From “Macbeth”’s weird sisters to Snow White’s evil stepmother, witches have long enchanted our collective imagination. They are dangerously seductive; they are old hags; deceitful; estranged from society; unmarried and childless. Almost always, they are women.
headline: Two Books Explore the Lives of Witches

abstract: Some people are resigned to another season of restrictions and plan to forge ahead with celebrations. Others are trying to overcome a sense of perpetual fear.
lead_paragraph: A single mother of two girls, Katherine Sargent is accustomed to working hard to ensure Christmas is a wonderful time, baking cookies and shopping with her children to find new ornaments for the tree.
headline: Family Stress Intensifies as Omicron Invades the Holidays

abstract: Google says a change takes just a few steps, but a panel of designers found otherwise. The issue is at the heart of a federal antitrust trial.
lead_paragraph: Imagine if every time you went to the supermarket, your shopping cart came loaded with the same box of cereal.
headline: Google Says Switching Away From Its Search Engine Is Easy. It’s Not.

abstract: Kim France and Paul Green agreed to Google each other before meeting. By the end of their first date, the creators of Lucky magazine and the School of Rock knew enough to make it official.
lead_paragraph: Just after Kimberly Lauren France and Paul Richard Green met on Tinder in early April 2021, Mr. Green floated an idea. Instead of getting to know each other through the app, they should set up a first date and, in the meantime, Google each other.
headline: Exclusive After the First Date. Living Together Three Days Later.

abstract: After nearly three years, Google has decided to winnow its video game ambitions because Stadia was less popular than it had anticipated.
lead_paragraph: Google said it would shutter the video game streaming service Stadia, its answer to Microsoft’s Xbox and Sony’s PlayStation video game consoles, in another sign of Google’s drive to be leaner amid fears of an economic slowdown.
headline: Google to Shut Down Stadia Video Game Streaming Service

abstract: As medical practices owned by private equity firms fuel overbilling, a payment tool also backed by such investors helps insurers boost their profits.
lead_paragraph: Insurance companies have long blamed private-equity-owned hospitals and physician groups for exorbitant billing that drives up health care costs. But a tool backed by private equity is helping insurers make billions of dollars and shift costs to patients.
headline: In Battle Over Health Care Costs, Private Equity Plays Both Sides

abstract: The lawsuit echoes many of the complaints Black employees have expressed over the years about working at the company.
lead_paragraph: A former employee at Google sued the company on Friday, claiming it systematically discriminated against Black workers by placing them in lower-level jobs, underpaying them and denying them opportunities to advance.
headline: Lawsuit Accuses Google of Bias Against Black Employees

abstract: The Sep. 12, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Tressie McMillan Cottom, with Emily Drabinski. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Tressie McMillan Cottom Interviews Emily Drabinski

abstract: Brendan Carr, a Republican member of the Federal Communications Commission, said he was concerned that the Chinese-owned app could provide Beijing with access to the data of Americans.
lead_paragraph: A member of the Federal Communications Commission has asked Google and Apple to remove TikTok from their app stores, citing concerns that the popular Chinese-owned video app could send American data back to Beijing.
headline: An F.C.C. commissioner pushes Apple and Google to remove TikTok from their app stores.

abstract: At the start of its antitrust defense, Google attributed its success to relentless investment, countering government claims that it broke the law to stay ahead.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has spent weeks arguing in a federal antitrust trial that Google has built an impenetrable barrier around its search business with strong-arm tactics and multibillion-dollar deals.
headline: Google Search Boss Says Company Invests to Avoid Becoming ‘Roadkill’

abstract: How long can Google hold on to its jackpot of business models?
lead_paragraph: The antitrust trial against Google has led to some of tech’s biggest players testifying in court, and things have gotten spicy. The New York Times reporter Cecilia Kang tells us the wildest moments in the trial so far.
headline: Google’s Trial Heats Up + How to Wear A.I. + It’s Our Birthday!

abstract: Google has worried for years that Apple would one day expand its internet search technology, and has been working on ways to prevent that from happening.
lead_paragraph: For years, Google watched with increasing concern as Apple improved its search technology, not knowing whether its longtime partner and sometimes competitor would eventually build its own search engine.
headline: Inside Google’s Plan to Stop Apple From Getting Serious About Search

abstract: Alphabet posted revenue of $55.31 billion, up 34 percent from a year earlier, and net profit more than doubled to $17.93 billion in the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: Google’s parent company, Alphabet, said on Tuesday that revenue in its most recent quarter increased sharply from the same period a year ago, boosted by strong demand for online advertising on its search results and YouTube videos and by continued growth at its cloud computing arm.
headline: Alphabet’s profit more than doubled last quarter as Google’s advertising business rebounded.

abstract: Despite computer shortages, controversies and lawsuits, A.I. continues to improve at a rapid pace.
lead_paragraph: The high-profile A.I. start-up Anthropic released a new version of its Claude chatbot on Monday, saying it outperforms other leading chatbots on a range of standard benchmark tests, including systems from Google and OpenAI.
headline: A.I. Start-Up Anthropic Challenges OpenAI and Google With New Chatbot

abstract: Interest has been building in the works of Nikolai Kapustin, who wrote in classical styles, with a jazzy spin.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1936, savvy listeners may have sensed that the novelty tune “Rhythm Saved the World” wasn’t only about its nominal subject: the drummer boys who motivated Revolutionary War soldiers at the Battle of Bunker Hill. No, as played by Louis Armstrong, it was clear that the song’s real subject was jazz itself, and its ability to conquer foreign lands — and other genres — with ease.
headline: A Composer Shows the Way to Give Classical Music Swing

abstract: What the Big Tech meltdown can teach all workers.
lead_paragraph: The tech giants’ offices were once heralded as the workplaces of the future. Their employees enjoyed previously unheard-of perks, like free farm-to-table lunches, on-site laundry and weekly massages, all lavished on them as they set about designing the technologies transforming the world.
headline: Google Changed Work Culture. Its Former Hype Woman Has Regrets.

abstract: The test program is likely to whittle away at the lucrative commissions that Google has charged app developers for money made on its platform.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Wednesday that it would allow some apps, such as Spotify, to offer their own billing system within the Google Play store as part of a pilot program.
headline: Google, facing antitrust scrutiny, says it will let apps like Spotify offer alternate billing systems.

abstract: The internet giant said it would begin testing its new chatbot, Bard, with a small, private group before releasing it to the public in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Monday that it would soon release an experimental chatbot called Bard as it races to respond to ChatGPT, which has wowed millions of people since it was unveiled at the end of November.
headline: Racing to Catch Up With ChatGPT, Google Plans Release of Its Own Chatbot

abstract: When Toni-Ann Craft created Friends with Rings, a membership network for engaged and married couples, it was a lifeline for her own marriage.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, a year into their marriage, Toni-Ann Craft, 37, and Kenneth Craft Jr., 42, moved from their spacious two-bedroom condominium in Washington to a smaller, two-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn, where Mrs. Craft grew up.
headline: Her Members-Only Couples Network Is Also Group Therapy

abstract: Pundits have likened the president to Lear, to Hamlet, to Macbeth, to Coriolanus. That may have been four years of wishful thinking.
lead_paragraph: As we say farewell to President Trump, why is no one discussing Timon?
headline: It’s Time to Turn the Page on the Trump-Shakespeare Comparisons

abstract: Google and Apple told Parler, a social network popular with far-right conservatives, that it must better police its users if it wants a place in their app stores.
lead_paragraph: Parler is one of the hottest apps in the world, a social network that has attracted millions of far-right conservatives over the past year with its hands-off approach to policing users’ posts. And with the news that President Trump had been kicked off Twitter and Facebook, Parler was the odds-on bet to be his next soapbox.
headline: Parler Pitched Itself as Twitter Without Rules. Not Anymore, Apple and Google Said.

abstract: Caroline Crampton shares her own worries in “A Body Made of Glass,” a history of hypochondria that wonders whether newfangled technology drives us crazier.
lead_paragraph: British national identity is built on the stiff upper lip, but the author Caroline Crampton, who lives in Merseyside, has allowed hers to quaver and curl, and it’s a relief.
headline: Does a Small Cough Make You Think the Worst? Here’s a Book for You.

abstract: A start-up called Perplexity shows what’s possible for a search engine built from scratch with artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: For my entire adult life, whenever I’ve had a question about the world or needed to track down something online, I’ve gone to Google for answers.
headline: Can This A.I.-Powered Search Engine Replace Google? It Has for Me.

abstract: The law, the first of its kind in the world, deals a blow to the market dominance of the tech giants, which opposed the bill.
lead_paragraph: South Korea legislators on Tuesday approved the first law in the world that requires app stores to let users pay for in-app purchases through multiple payment systems, a blow to the market dominance of Apple and Google, which opposed the bill.
headline: South Korea forces Google and Apple to allow third-party in-app payments.

abstract: If current polling holds, it’s not running an alternative to Biden that seems most likely to put Trump back in the presidency.
lead_paragraph: In the emotional life of the liberal mediasphere, there was so little space between the release of the New York Times/Siena poll showing President Biden losing to Donald Trump handily across a range of swing states (doom! doom!) and the Democratic overperformance in Tuesday’s elections (sweet relief!) that one of the striking features of the polling passed with relatively little comment.
headline: Should Joe Manchin Run for President?

abstract: Like Meta, the company opened access to its technology to outside programmers, but kept its most powerful system under wraps.
lead_paragraph: When Meta shared the raw computer code needed to build a chatbot last year, rival companies said Meta was releasing poorly understood and perhaps even dangerous technology into the world.
headline: Google Is Giving Away Some of the A.I. That Powers Chatbots

abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to tell your father your sister is recording him without his knowledge — and more.
lead_paragraph: My sister revealed that she often records phone conversations that she has with our father without his knowledge. She says she does it because he is so “funny,” i.e., eccentric, but I get the impression that she is laughing more at him than with him. I find his conversations less humorous than distressing, since he is often, at the best of times, in a state of heightened psychological dysregulation and anxiety, and the pandemic has just made things worse. Because of my sister’s behavior, my niece has grown up thinking there’s nothing wrong or unethical with recording conversations without the other person’s knowledge or consent and has herself started to do this.
headline: Is It OK That My Sister Secretly Records Our Dad for Laughs?

abstract: Researchers found ads placed by Google on sites that falsely call global warming a hoax. The revenue those sites earn from the ads can fund further misinformation.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of last month’s United Nations global climate summit, Google, the world’s biggest provider of ads online, made a big announcement: It would stop placing ads on sites that deny the scientific consensus on climate change.
headline: Google Pledged to Remove Ads From Climate Denial Sites, but Many Still Run

abstract: The federal government’s first monopoly trial this century will feature top tech executives, experienced litigators and an Obama-appointed judge.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from Google’s antitrust trial
headline: Who’s Who in the Google Monopoly Trial

abstract: Entries for the week of May 2, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic

abstract: People who upload images of children that Google flags as potentially illegal will be able to provide more context to appeal bans.
lead_paragraph: When Google informed a mother in Colorado that her account had been disabled, it felt as if her house had burned down, she said. In an instant, she lost access to her wedding photos, videos of her son growing up, her emails going back a decade, her tax documents and everything else she had kept in what she thought would be the safest place. She had no idea why.
headline: Her Child’s Naked Dance Killed Her Google Account. New Appeals Path Restored It.

abstract: The first applications for the Shuttered Venue Operators Grant program, offering $16 billion in federal aid, were approved.
lead_paragraph: As the emails finally started arriving late last week, some business owners got the good news they had been long awaiting: They would be awarded a piece of a $16 billion federal grant fund intended to preserve music clubs, theaters and other live-event businesses devastated by the pandemic.
headline: Some Venue Owners Get a Federal Lifeline. Others Are Told They’re Dead.

abstract: Success came relatively easy — until he tried acting. For a moment, journalism seemed more viable. But now he’s the lead in “Shortcomings.”
lead_paragraph: Five years after Justin H. Min began pursuing acting by Googling “how to pursue acting,” he thought he was getting the hang of it. He had made a viral commercial, and he was in contention for three major roles.
headline: Justin H. Min, Travel Writer? The Path Not Taken for a Rising Star

abstract: In Meghan Gilliss’s debut novel, “Lungfish,” a young family maroons itself on a deserted island where sustenance is whatever you can get your hands on.
lead_paragraph: “Lungfish can go three and a half years without food,” we learn late in Meghan Gilliss’s debut novel. This information has practical use for Tuck, the protagonist, who is obsessed with food — specifically with the act of buying and preparing it. But for Tuck — an unemployed new mother with a husband going through opioid withdrawal — food is not about pleasure; it is only sustenance. In between looking for a job and selling bumper stickers, she feeds both herself and her 2-year-old daughter, Agnes, just enough to keep them both alive.
headline: For Squatters in the Gulf of Maine, Life Is Only Survival

abstract: Bess Wohl sees “Camp Siegfried,” which opens Off Broadway in November, as a “deeply American play” about seduction.
lead_paragraph: YAPHANK, N.Y. — On a Sunday afternoon earlier this month, the playwright Bess Wohl stood on the shores of a lake in this Long Island hamlet about 60 miles from Manhattan. She admired the surface pleasures of the scene — the water, the leaves, a sky the blue of a faded Tiffany’s box, an obliging swan.
headline: How a Pro-Nazi Camp on Long Island Inspired a New Play

abstract: The company has suspended Gemini’s ability to generate human images while it vowed to fix the issue.
lead_paragraph: Images showing people of color in German military uniforms from World War II that were created with Google’s Gemini chatbot have amplified concerns that artificial intelligence could add to the internet’s already vast pools of misinformation as the technology struggles with issues around race.
headline: Google Chatbot’s A.I. Images Put People of Color in Nazi-Era Uniforms

abstract: A North Dakota bill that an Apple executive had warned “threatens to destroy iPhone as you know it” died in a vote on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A North Dakota bill that an Apple executive had warned “threatens to destroy iPhone as you know it” died in a vote on Tuesday.
headline: North Dakota lawmakers vote down a bill that threatened Apple’s and Google’s revenues.

abstract: Why Google thought twice about restoring your privacy.
lead_paragraph: There is a saying in Silicon Valley that when a product is free, the user is the product.
headline: Google’s Privacy Backpedal Shows Why It’s So Hard Not to Be Evil

abstract: A Canadian search-and-rescue group said it had conducted two missions recently after hikers “may have sought to follow” a nonexistent trail on Google Maps.
lead_paragraph: A search-and-rescue group in British Columbia advised hikers to use a paper map and compass instead of street map programs after it said two hikers had been rescued by helicopter after likely following a trail that did not exist but that appeared on Google Maps.
headline: Hikers Rescued After Following Nonexistent Trail on Google Maps

abstract: Judge Amit P. Mehta tried poking holes in the closing arguments of a landmark monopoly case as he weighs a ruling that could reshape tech.
lead_paragraph: The judge overseeing a landmark U.S. antitrust challenge to Google tried to poke holes in both sides’ cases during closing arguments Thursday as he weighed a ruling that could reshape the technology industry.
headline: Judge Grills U.S. and Google on Antitrust Claims

abstract: The tech giant, which is facing similar scrutiny in the U.S., also said it would make changes to increase transparency of its online ad systems.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Google agreed to pay roughly $270 million in fines and change some of its business practices as part of a settlement announced on Monday with French antitrust regulators who had accused the company of abusing its dominance of the online advertising market.
headline: Google to Pay $270 Million to Settle Antitrust Charges in France

abstract: The platform’s tolerance of white supremacist, pro-Nazi and conspiracy theory content pushes the boundaries of the medium.
lead_paragraph: He had already been banned from Twitter, but on his podcast he could give full voice to his hateful conspiracy theories.
headline: On Google Podcasts, a Buffet of Hate

abstract: Advice from an army of very busy exterminators.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not gentle with them anymore,” said Laura Love. “I see one and I’m like, ‘I’m coming for you.’”
headline: Moths Have Been Partying in Your Dark Closet. What Now?

abstract: In a game called GeoGuessr, competitors try to pinpoint where in the world a Google Street View image has been taken. Some can do it in seconds.
lead_paragraph: An unremarkable stretch of highway and trees, as seen on Google Maps’ Street View, appeared on the screen. It could have been anywhere from Tasmania to Texas.
headline: Siberia or Japan? Expert Google Maps Players Can Tell at a Glimpse.

abstract: The first tech monopoly trial of the modern internet era is concluding. The judge’s ruling is likely to set a precedent for other attempts to rein in the tech giants that hold sway over information, social interaction and commerce.
lead_paragraph: The biggest U.S. challenge so far to the vast power of today’s tech giants is nearing its conclusion.
headline: Strongest U.S. Challenge to Big Tech’s Power Nears Climax in Google Trial

abstract: Critical thinking, as we’re taught to do it, isn’t helping in the fight against misinformation.
lead_paragraph: For an academic, Michael Caulfield has an odd request: Stop overthinking what you see online.
headline: Don’t Go Down the Rabbit Hole

abstract: Google’s new $1,800 gadget proves that phones with bendable screens are something people might want. Now they just need to get cheaper.
lead_paragraph: When I recently turned on Google’s new Pixel Fold smartphone and unfolded it as if it were a book, it transformed into a miniature tablet, similar to an iPad Mini or an Amazon Fire. Then something unexpected happened.
headline: Google Pixel Fold Review: Foldable Phones Are Improving

abstract: The pathbreaking company plans to replace its Harlem home with a 21-story building with apartments, retail and a new theater.
lead_paragraph: It was more than 50 years ago that Barbara Ann Teer rented space in a building at 125th Street and Fifth Avenue in Harlem that would serve as the home of a nascent organization called National Black Theater.
headline: National Black Theater Plans Next Act in a New Harlem High-Rise

abstract: The government’s antitrust case against Google borrows heavily from the landmark lawsuit against Microsoft 25 years ago. But it lacks the same cultural impact.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department argues in a federal antitrust suit that Google is a dominant tech company that has abused its market power to bully industry partners, protect its monopoly and thwart competition.
headline: Microsoft, Google and Antitrust: Similar Legal Theories in a Different Era

abstract: The tech giant, which is wrapping up its arguments in the federal monopoly trial, has framed itself as a good corporate citizen that has pushed innovation and helped consumers.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two and a half weeks, Google has called a dozen witnesses to defend itself against claims by the Justice Department and a group of state attorneys general that it illegally maintained a search and advertising monopoly, in a landmark antitrust case that could reshape tech power.
headline: What Google Argued to Defend Itself in Landmark Antitrust Trial

abstract: Nearly 8,000 Puzzlemania solvers submitted for a chance to win $1,000
lead_paragraph: When we planned December’s “Super Mega” crossword contest, we wondered, “Would solvers want to do a puzzle that’s a giant, wall-size, Brobdingnagian 67x41 grid, with almost 800 answers? And would they enjoy it?”
headline: And the ‘Super Mega’ Crossword Contest Winners Are…

abstract: Efforts to seal testimony have increasingly raised questions as the federal antitrust case enters its third week in court.
lead_paragraph: In a court filing last month, Google argued that it needed its privacy in an antitrust trial that would spotlight its dominance in online search.
headline: ‘Unprecedented’ Secrecy in Google Trial as Tech Giants Push to Limit Disclosures

abstract: As it races to compete with OpenAI’s ChatGPT, Google has retired its Bard chatbot and released a more powerful app.
lead_paragraph: First, there were talking digital assistants like Siri, Alexa and Google Assistant. Then there were online chatbots like ChatGPT and Google Bard. Now, the two are merging.
headline: Google Releases Gemini, an A.I.-Driven Chatbot and Voice Assistant

abstract: The country’s largest newspaper chain said Google’s power over ad technology has contributed to the decline of local news.
lead_paragraph: Gannett, the country’s largest newspaper chain, filed a lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, accusing the tech giant of violating federal antitrust laws by illegally abusing a monopoly over the technology used by publishers to buy and sell online ads.
headline: Gannett Sues Google, Accusing It of Dominating the Ad Market

abstract: Amit P. Mehta, a judge in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, will issue a landmark antitrust ruling.
lead_paragraph: One of Amit P. Mehta’s first cases after becoming a federal judge in late 2014 proved to be a crash course in antitrust.
headline: The Judge Deciding Google’s Fate

abstract: Philip Paxson’s family said in a lawsuit that he was following Google Maps directions last year when he drove off a collapsed bridge in Hickory, N.C., plunged into a creek and drowned.
lead_paragraph: The family of a North Carolina man who drowned last year after he drove off a collapsed bridge while following Google Maps directions has sued Google for negligence, saying that the company’s failure to update its maps led directly to his death.
headline: He Drove Into a Creek and Died. His Family Blames Google Maps.

abstract: The chatbot now pulls information from a user’s Gmail, Google Docs and Google Drive accounts. The feature leaves a lot to be desired.
lead_paragraph: This week, Bard — Google’s competitor to ChatGPT — got an upgrade.
headline: Google’s Bard Just Got More Powerful. It’s Still Erratic.

abstract: The product, pitched as a helpmate for journalists, has been demonstrated for executives at The New York Times, The Washington Post and News Corp, which owns The Wall Street Journal.
lead_paragraph: Google is testing a product that uses artificial intelligence technology to produce news stories, pitching it to news organizations including The New York Times, The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal’s owner, News Corp, according to three people familiar with the matter.
headline: Google Tests A.I. Tool That Is Able to Write News Articles

abstract: Developed with Fitbit, Google’s first smart watch takes a page from Apple’s playbook by requiring loyalty to its brand.
lead_paragraph: It’s 2022, and Google finally has a response to the Apple Watch. It’s the Pixel Watch, which is essentially a Fitbit designed to work only with Android phones and seemingly a direct counterattack to Apple’s wearable that works only with iPhones.
headline: The Google Watch Is Here. But You’d Better Love Android.

abstract: The move is a concession to regulators and lawmakers, who are challenging whether the company has overcharged developers.
lead_paragraph: Google said it planned to lower the cut it takes on subscription-based apps in its Play Store for devices running its Android software, in the latest concession to regulatory pressure challenging whether the company has overcharged developers.
headline: Google plans to lower the cut it takes in its app store to 15 percent.

abstract: Engineers at the tech giants built tools years ago that could put a name to any face but, for once, Silicon Valley did not want to move fast and break things.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in early 2017, at Facebook’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif., an engineer named Tommer Leyvand sat in a conference room with a smartphone standing on the brim of his baseball cap. Rubber bands helped anchor it in place with the camera facing out. The absurd hat-phone, a particularly uncool version of the future, contained a secret tool known only to a small group of employees. What it could do was remarkable.
headline: The Technology Facebook and Google Didn’t Dare Release

abstract: In “This Bird Has Flown,” the Bangles frontwoman Susanna Hoffs demonstrates her range.
lead_paragraph: My husband was the one who freaked out when the review copy of “This Bird Has Flown” arrived on our doorstep. “Susanna Hoffs? Of the Bangles? Wrote a book?”
headline: The Smart, Ferocious Rock-Star Redemption Romance You Didn’t Know You Needed

abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
headline: Today’s Wordle Review

abstract: Red Ventures has turned very specific advice into very big business.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN LAND, S.C. — Lindsey Turrentine first heard of Red Ventures last fall, when it bought the venerable tech news site CNET, where she is the senior vice president in charge of content. She sat down at her kitchen table in Berkeley, Calif., and frantically started Googling to find out what it was.
headline: You’ve Never Heard of the Biggest Digital Media Company in America

abstract: Publishers have long worried that artificial intelligence would drive readers away from their sites. They’re about to find out if those fears are warranted.
lead_paragraph: For the past year and a half since ChatGPT was released, a scary question has hovered over the heads of major online publishers: What if Google decides to overhaul its core search engine to feature generative artificial intelligence more prominently — and breaks our business in the process?
headline: Can Google Give A.I. Answers Without Breaking the Web?

abstract: Linwei Ding, a Chinese national, was arrested in California and accused of uploading hundreds of files to the cloud.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese citizen who recently quit his job as a software engineer for Google in California has been charged with trying to transfer artificial intelligence technology to a Beijing-based company that paid him secretly, according to a federal indictment unsealed on Wednesday.
headline: Ex-Google Engineer Charged With Stealing A.I. Secrets for Chinese Firm

abstract: The company is scrapping another plan that would have blocked so-called cookies after privacy groups and regulators complained that Google needed to do more to ensure privacy.
lead_paragraph: When Google announced a plan to block digital tracking cookies from its Chrome web browser two years ago, the advertising industry and regulators worried that the proposal would further entrench the search giant’s dominance over online ads.
headline: Google introduces a new system for tracking Chrome browser users.

abstract: Fourteen years and one Apple App of the Year award in, AllTrails has become something rare: a tool that works for both experts and newbies.
lead_paragraph: Close your eyes and imagine a stereotypical hiker. Do the words “rugged” and “built Ford tough” come to mind? Are they wearing khaki shorts? Is a tube attached to a CamelBak hanging from their mouth?
headline: Boots, Backpack and a Ubiquitous App

abstract: Google said in 2021 that it would stop running ads alongside videos and other content that denied the existence and causes of climate change.
lead_paragraph: In October 2021, Google promised to stop placing ads alongside content that denied the existence and causes of climate change, so that purveyors of the false claims could no longer make money on its platforms, including YouTube.
headline: Google Promised to Defund Climate Lies, but the Ads Keep Coming

abstract: His inflated sense of his fitness to lead isn’t just delusional. It’s dangerous.
lead_paragraph: The hubris. The narcissism. The convenient and fraudulent anti-elitism. The out-of-his-mind theories presented as out-of-the-box thinking.
headline: The High-I.Q. Nonsense of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

abstract: Despite concerns of a shaky ad market and growing competition in A.I., Google’s bounce forward in the second quarter was aided by accelerating revenue from its search engine and the video platform YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, gained ground in its most recent quarter against several of its lingering challenges, according to financial results released on Tuesday.
headline: Alphabet Steams Past Ad Worries, Fueled by Google’s Search Engine

abstract: His death helped awaken the nation to a rise in anti-Asian violence. For his grieving family, the reckoning hasn’t gone far enough.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Monthanus Ratanapakdee urged her parents to please. stay inside. An uneasiness had hung over her ever since a mob descended on the Capitol early that month, though really, people had been acting crazy for a year. Throughout 2020, multiple strangers had come at her seemingly out of nowhere. That January, an old man yelled at her in Golden Gate Park — something about a virus and going back to her country — while she watched her sons, then 10 and 7, run in a playground. In February, two joggers, women, yelled something about germs at her older son as he played on a dock with a friend. In March, just before the country went into lockdown, a woman swung at Monthanus outside a hospital; she ducked the punch before running across the street. In November, another old man spat in her direction as her sons rode their scooters by the bay.
headline: Why Was Vicha Ratanapakdee Killed?

abstract: Alex Trebek projected impartiality. Bialik has questioned vaccines, endorsed a disputed brain supplement and weighed in on hot-button issues.
lead_paragraph: After the succession debacle at “Jeopardy!” turned one of television’s most respected game shows into a punchline on late-night talk shows and at the Emmy Awards, Mayim Bialik took over as a temporary host this season with a simple goal: not to draw too much attention to herself.
headline: Mayim Bialik Wants the ‘Jeopardy!’ Job. Is She ‘Neutral’ Enough?

abstract: Will Smith and Aunjanue Ellis play the parents of Venus and Serena Williams in a warm, exuberant, old-fashioned sports drama.
lead_paragraph: The climactic scenes in “King Richard” take place in 1994, as Venus Williams, 14 years old and in her second professional tennis match, faces Arantxa Sánchez-Vicario, at the time the top-ranked player in the world. If you don’t know the outcome, you might want to refrain from Googling. And even if you remember the match perfectly, you might find yourself holding your breath and full of conflicting emotion as you watch the director Reinaldo Marcus Green’s skillful and suspenseful restaging.
headline: ‘King Richard’ Review: Father Holds Court

abstract: Eight years after a controversy over Black people being mislabeled as gorillas by image analysis software — and despite big advances in computer vision — tech giants still fear repeating the mistake.
lead_paragraph: When Google released its stand-alone Photos app in May 2015, people were wowed by what it could do: analyze images to label the people, places and things in them, an astounding consumer offering at the time. But a couple of months after the release, a software developer, Jacky Alciné, discovered that Google had labeled photos of him and a friend, who are both Black, as “gorillas,” a term that is particularly offensive because it echoes centuries of racist tropes.
headline: Google’s Photo App Still Can’t Find Gorillas. And Neither Can Apple’s.

abstract: Personal Google accounts that have not been used in at least two years could be removed starting in December as part of an effort to address security threats, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Starting in December, Google will begin deleting accounts that have not been used in at least two years as part of an effort to address security risks, the company said on Tuesday.
headline: Haven’t Checked Your Gmail in a While? Google May Delete Your Account.

abstract: You won’t crack Blake Slonecker’s puzzle right away, and that’s good.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
headline: For Real

abstract: For half a century, Geoffrey Hinton nurtured the technology at the heart of chatbots like ChatGPT. Now he worries it will cause serious harm.
lead_paragraph: Geoffrey Hinton was an artificial intelligence pioneer. In 2012, Dr. Hinton and two of his graduate students at the University of Toronto created technology that became the intellectual foundation for the A.I. systems that the tech industry’s biggest companies believe is a key to their future.
headline: ‘The Godfather of A.I.’ Leaves Google and Warns of Danger Ahead

abstract: The tech giant has recently spent more than $1 billion to resolve several legal claims as more battles with the Justice Department loom.
lead_paragraph: In December, Google spent $700 million to resolve states’ claims that its Play Store had strong-armed app makers into high fees and tough terms. About six weeks after that, Google paid $350 million to end a lawsuit accusing it of improperly sharing users’ private information.
headline: Google Settles Smaller Lawsuits as It Prepares for More Antitrust Fights

abstract: Like the Cybertruck, this podcast is bulletproof.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains strong language.
headline: Google’s Next Top Model, Will the Cybertruck Crash? and This Week in A.I.

abstract: The work of Michaelina Wautier, a 17th-century artist, was long overlooked. She is belatedly gaining recognition as an old master, as the first U.S. show of her work opens in Boston.
lead_paragraph: Katlijne Van der Stighelen, a professor of art history at the University of Leuven in Belgium, first encountered the work of Michaelina Wautier, a 17th-century painter, in 1993 in the storage area of a Vienna museum.
headline: For Centuries, Her Art Was Forgotten, or Credited to Men. No More.

abstract: Newly revealed memos show that government investigators saw red flags in Google’s behavior nearly a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: What the U.S. Missed With Google

abstract: A $2.1 billion purchase of a Hudson Square building is a shot in the arm for the ailing New York office market.
lead_paragraph: It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at one of the largest office-space deals, not just in New York City but in the United States.
headline: Google’s Big Bet on Manhattan Office Space

abstract: Christina Iverson and a new constructor, Katie Hale, give little kids (and the rest of us) a mwah! of a Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This post might be a little bit short and sweet because here in rural Queens, N.Y., where the internet tubes get flooded from time to time, I am tethered to my phone like a pioneer with a rope tied to the barn during a blizzard. Anyway! I’m lucky that our two constructors have a back story that’s as charming as their collaboration; this grid is really lighthearted and lovely, not too easy but great for a range of Sunday solvers.
headline: Toddler Talk

abstract: “Time for all you doobie-lovin’ potheads to get up to your usual smoky high jinks: folding laundry and hoping half a gummy will help you fall asleep,” Stephen Colbert joked.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
headline: Late Night Celebrates 4/20

abstract: The move came after a Russian regulator demanded that the company stop showing ads with what the regulator claimed was false information about the invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Thursday night that it had suspended all advertising in Russia after the country’s internet regulator demanded that the company stop showing what it considered ads displaying false information about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
headline: Google Suspends Advertising in Russia

abstract: The pop megastar’s first of three shows at MetLife Stadium featured an appearance from the rising rapper Ice Spice, a fan-favorite song and loads of sequins.
lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoon, a seemingly endless parade of Taylor Swift fans wearing flowery dresses, sparkly cowboy boots, sequined T-shirts and handmade friendship bracelets made their way to East Rutherford, N.J., turning the vast asphalt parking lot at MetLife Stadium into a pop-up performance space, a fashion runway and a meeting ground for friends, old and new.
headline: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Touches Down in New Jersey

abstract: Sonos is seeking to ban the import of several Google products that are made in China. The preliminary finding will now be reviewed by the full United States International Trade Commission.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google infringed on speaker-technology patents held by Sonos and should not be allowed to import products that violate Sonos’s intellectual property, a judge said in a preliminary finding by the United States International Trade Commission that was released on Friday.
headline: Google Infringed on Patents Owned by Sonos, a Trade Judge Says

abstract: Ken Paxton, the state attorney general, said products like Google Photos and the Nest camera had violated Texans’ privacy rights.
lead_paragraph: The Texas attorney general filed a privacy lawsuit against Google on Thursday, accusing the internet company of collecting Texans’ facial and voice recognition information without their explicit consent.
headline: Texas Sues Google for Collecting Biometric Data Without Consent

abstract: In designing warehouse-size data centers that behaved like a single computer, he changed the fabric of the internet.
lead_paragraph: When Google arrived in the late 1990s, hundreds of thousands of people were instantly captivated by its knack for taking them wherever they wanted to go on the internet. Developed by the company’s founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin, the algorithm that drove the site seemed to work like magic.
headline: Luiz Barroso, Who Supercharged Google’s Reach, Dies at 59

abstract: In response to Times articles, the search giant is changing its algorithm, part of a major shift in how Google polices harmful content.
lead_paragraph: For many years, the vicious cycle has spun: Websites solicit lurid, unverified complaints about supposed cheaters, sexual predators, deadbeats and scammers. People slander their enemies. The anonymous posts appear high in Google results for the names of victims. Then the websites charge the victims thousands of dollars to take the posts down.
headline: Google Seeks to Break Vicious Cycle of Online Slander

abstract: The social media app is not available on Google’s app store, and the former president’s company and Google are publicly disagreeing about why.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Tuesday that it would not distribute Truth Social on its Play app store until Truth Social, the social media platform founded by former President Donald J. Trump, removed content that incites violence.
headline: Google Says Trump’s Truth Social Must Scrub Violent Content to Join Play Store

abstract: It’s been a bumpy ride for the most important players in tech.
lead_paragraph: Is Google allowed to spend billions of dollars to make its search product the default browser? That is the question at the center of U.S. et al. v. Google — the most important tech trial of the modern internet era — and Kevin and Casey disagree on the answer.
headline: Casey v. Kevin on U.S. v. Google + Walter Isaacson on Two Years With Elon Musk

abstract: When I covered my first movie premiere for The Times, I learned that there’s a casual art to a good carpet question.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I found myself awake in the wee morning hours, anxiously Googling things like “what to wear to cover a movie premiere” and “red carpet question ideas.”
headline: Making My Red (Well, Blue) Carpet Reporting Debut

abstract: The big tech platforms are facing a challenge unlike any other as Australia moves to make them pay for news.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — In a major escalation, Google threatened on Friday to make its search engine unavailable in Australia if the government approved legislation that would force tech companies to pay for journalism shared on their platforms.
headline: An Australia With No Google? The Bitter Fight Behind a Drastic Threat

abstract: Despite record profits, a number of them are worried that the company is suffering from both its size and leadership from its C.E.O., Sundar Pichai.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The seeds of a company’s downfall, it is often said in the business world, are sown when everything is going great.
headline: Google Executives See Cracks in Their Company’s Success

abstract: If you saved me and my sister on a cold, rainy night in Alaska 34 years ago, I would like to thank you.
lead_paragraph: There’s a story I tell my sons to remind them that, despite much evidence to the contrary, humans have the capacity to be amazingly kind.
headline: Sending Out an S.O.S.

abstract: In an extended interview, Mr. Pichai expressed both optimism and worry about the state of the A.I. race.
lead_paragraph: Sundar Pichai has been trying to start an A.I. revolution for a very long time.
headline: Google C.E.O. Sundar Pichai on the A.I. Moment: ‘You Will See Us Be Bold’

abstract: The tech giant joins other companies that have readjusted their plans as the more contagious Delta variant of the coronavirus sweeps through the country.
lead_paragraph: Google said Wednesday that it would require employees who returned to the company’s offices to be vaccinated against the coronavirus. It also said it would push back its official return-to-office date to mid-October from September, joining a host of other companies whose plans have been scrambled in recent days by the spread of the highly contagious Delta variant.
headline: Google mandates vaccines for employees and delays its return to the office to October.

abstract: The company is making changes to a popular message board called Memegen that some employees say sounds a lot like censorship.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 14 years, an online message board called Memegen has served as a virtual water cooler for Google employees.
headline: Google to Tone Down Message Board After Employees Feud Over War in Gaza

abstract: A proposal in the South Korean legislature is an early test of how forcefully the Biden administration will defend the companies abroad while trying to trim their power at home.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, Apple and Google have been fighting a bill in the South Korean legislature that they say could imperil their lucrative app store businesses.
