The companies have appealed directly to South Korean lawmakers, government officials and the public to try to block the legislation, which is expected to face a crucial vote this week.
headline: Apple and Google’s Fight in Seoul Tests Biden in Washington

abstract: The internet giant will grant users access to a chatbot after years of cautious development, chasing splashy debuts from rivals OpenAI and Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: For more than three months, Google executives have watched as projects at Microsoft and a San Francisco start-up called OpenAI have stoked the public’s imagination with the potential for artificial intelligence.
headline: Google Releases Bard, Its Competitor in the Race to Create A.I. Chatbots

abstract: Lawrence Osborne’s new novel, “On Java Road,” is a mystery set amid political tensions.
lead_paragraph: No one else writes “thrillers” as languid as Lawrence Osborne’s. His novels tend to be leisurely, slow-burn mysteries that could be mistaken for impeccably observed travel memoirs, except for the fact that usually there’s a dead body that needs hiding, finding or explaining. For Osborne, who has set stories in Bangkok, Morocco, Cambodia and Mexico, geography may be the most important character. “If you don’t know where you are, you probably don’t know who you are,” Ralph Ellison wrote in “Invisible Man,” and that could easily apply to Osborne’s writing, fiction and nonfiction alike.
headline: As Hong Kong Protests, a Woman Tied to Powerful People Vanishes

abstract: For years, gay male performers were left out of the comedy landscape or tokenized within it. Now, a new wave of entertainers are succeeding by playing to themselves.
lead_paragraph: WHEN DEWAYNE PERKINS was a teenager growing up on the South Side of Chicago, he would occasionally turn to Google in search of, if not himself, somebody who at least came close. What he found was a void. “I remember Googling gay comics and nothing coming up, especially gay Black comics,” says Perkins, whose blazingly funny stand-up work ranges from sweet to goofy to raunchy. “I am not a fan of being a token. I don’t think it’s fun to be ‘the first.’”
headline: The Queer Young Comics Redefining American Humor

abstract: Our critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Hello, readers.
headline: Foxes, Lawyers and Londoners

abstract: The embrace by some conservative influencers and conspiracy theorists is part of a broader effort to shift people away from Big Tech.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
headline: Fed Up With Google, Conspiracy Theorists Turn to DuckDuckGo

abstract: Silver mining may have disappeared, but Creede Repertory Theater has been an economic and cultural boon to its community for 50 years.
lead_paragraph: CREEDE, Colo. — Perched at 8,900 feet in the San Juan Mountains, five hours from the nearest major airport and near the Rio Grande headwaters, Creede is a town of around 350 full-time residents, with one grocery store, one gas station and a fast-rushing flume. A traffic light? Now you’re asking for a lot.
headline: Friday Night Footlights: How Theater Bonds a Colorado Town

abstract: Since Google overhauled its search engine, publishers have tried to assess the danger to their brittle business models while calling for government intervention.
lead_paragraph: When Frank Pine searched Google for a link to a news article two months ago, he encountered paragraphs generated by artificial intelligence about the topic at the top of his results. To see what he wanted, he had to scroll past them.
headline: Google’s A.I. Search Leaves Publishers Scrambling

abstract: The store, on the ground floor of the company’s Manhattan headquarters, will feature Google gadgets and branded gear, such as T-shirts, hats and dog toys.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Google started making its own smartphones and voice-assisted speakers. Now, Google has a store to sell them in.
headline: Google is ready to open its first store, in New York.

abstract: Few people are better than Trevor Rainbolt at identifying  obscure locations online — but there’s even more joy in watching him visit them IRL.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2021, a 22-year-old from Arkansas named Trevor Rainbolt shuttered himself in his Los Angeles apartment to memorize the world. For months, he spent his time studying Google Street View from his desk chair. Delivery drivers handed over his meals; a barber came to style his hair. After a while, his memory grew planetary. When you see cabbage-like plants thriving along the sides of a Russian country road, he learned, you’re most likely looking at Sakhalin Island. On a bridge lined with pea-green pavement? You’re above a river in Indonesia’s Central Kalimantan province. If your vista, but for the sweep of golden grasslands, screams South Africa, you’ll be in Eswatini.
headline: He Memorized the World With Google Maps. Now He’s Exploring It.

abstract: Slaughter’s “Renewal” looks at how a personal transformation can lead to broader social change.
lead_paragraph: RENEWAL
headline: Anne-Marie Slaughter Explains What She Has Learned From a Long Career of Public Service

abstract: Natalie Murphy makes her New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Natalie Murphy, who is making her constructing debut in the New York Times Crossword! Ms. Murphy is the 14th constructor to debut in 2022. I did the math, and we are averaging a constructor debut  every 3.7 days — that’s a pretty stellar start to the year.
headline: Love Your Work!

abstract: The company says it will start purging accounts, including services like Gmail and YouTube, that have been idle for two years or more.
lead_paragraph: If you have not used one of your Google accounts for a long time, you might want to this week. Inactive accounts will start vanishing on Dec. 1.
headline: Make Sure Your Google Accounts Are Active, or They Might Be Deleted

abstract: Software developers have accused the company of harsh policies and taking a large cut of financial transactions in their apps.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of 36 states and the District of Columbia sued Google on Wednesday over claims that its mobile app store abuses its market power and forces aggressive terms on software developers, expanding the legal challenges facing the internet search giant.
headline: Dozens of States Sue Google Over App Store Fees

abstract: Technology companies were once leery of what some artificial intelligence could do. Now the priority is winning control of the industry’s next big thing.
lead_paragraph: In March, two Google employees, whose jobs are to review the company’s artificial intelligence products, tried to stop Google from launching an A.I. chatbot. They believed it generated inaccurate and dangerous statements.
headline: In A.I. Race, Microsoft and Google Choose Speed Over Caution

abstract: Epic Games’s victory over the search giant could let app developers keep more money, and marks a fresh blow against Big Tech.
lead_paragraph: Epic Games on Monday finally achieved one of its longstanding goals: weakening one of the two major companies behind the modern mobile app ecosystem. A jury found that Google violated antitrust laws by maintaining tight control of its app store, harming the Fortnite maker and other developers.
headline: Google’s Antitrust Setback Could Remake the App Economy, and More

abstract: Looks like Google is on the naughty list this year.
lead_paragraph: A jury decided the Google Play store unfairly stifles competition and maintains a monopoly. Kevin and Casey discuss how the ruling could reshape the digital economy. Then, a growing movement of developers and enthusiasts of artificial intelligence want the technology developed as quickly as possible, even if it has negative consequences for humanity. And, finally, why the internet of the future could look totally different.
headline: Google’s Epic Loss, Silicon Valley’s Curious New Subculture and How 2023 Changed the Internet

abstract: Alex Zhou and Eddie Kay met on a plane heading to Boston from Los Angeles. After going their separate ways, the two reconnected on social media.
lead_paragraph: Boarding a flight to Boston from Los Angeles in January 2018, Alex Zhou noticed a cute guy helping someone with their bag. The guy, Eddie Lin Kay, turned out to be her seatmate.
headline: When the Cute Guy on Your Flight Turns Out to be Your Seatmate

abstract: Gabriel Weinberg of the search engine DuckDuckGo was the first competitor to testify in the Justice Department’s antitrust trial against Google.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of DuckDuckGo on Thursday described Google as a monopoly that has hurt competition and consumers through its scale and command over the tech industry, in the first testimony of a rival in the federal trial of the Justice Department’s antitrust lawsuit against the search giant.
headline: C.E.O. of Google Rival Describes Obstacles to Efforts to Compete

abstract: After the tech giant threatened to take its search engine offline in Australia, I’ve been looking into some alternatives.
lead_paragraph: It’s the first port of call for any random question that pops into our heads. The repository of basically all knowledge on the internet. The search engine so ubiquitous it’s a verb.
headline: My Attempt to Prepare for a Future Without Google

abstract: We may be witnessing a major realignment of the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: I was Googling around the other day for a factoid: how many Israelis had visited the United Arab Emirates since the signing of their normalization agreement, known as the Abraham Accords. Answer: more than 130,000.
headline: Jumping Jehoshaphat! Have You Seen How Many Israelis Just Visited the U.A.E.?

abstract: Our critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: I was leafing through an old Terence Conran book on home décor and encountered an interesting opinion. Conran asserts that a single lamp or task light is superior for reading than an overhead light, because “a pool of light gives a pleasant sense of intimacy and encourages concentration.” If this is true, I wonder if the concentration impact might be heightened by using an extremely localized light source, such as a flashlight or headlamp. (I know several people who swear by headlamps when reading — and, of course, any child who has read furtively beneath a blanket can testify to the efficacy of the flashlight.)
headline: A Stylish Art Dealer and a Trip to Italy

abstract: If your idea of a good summer read involves abject terror, we’ve got some recommendations for you.
lead_paragraph: Buried artifacts, lost treasures, ancient puzzles — archaeological excavations make for frightening fiction, especially when their unearthings wreak havoc on those living in the present. It’s easy to forget that Pazuzu — the demon who caused so much mischief in “The Exorcist” — emerged from an archaeological dig in Iraq.
headline: Gothic Whodunits and Exploding Heads: Summer’s New Horror Books

abstract: The company also said it would restore many of its famed office perks.
lead_paragraph: As Google prepares to bring workers back to its offices, the company is relaxing some of its Covid-19 workplace policies, including a rule requiring U.S. employees to be vaccinated. But workers will still have to be vaccinated if they plan to use the company’s offices.
headline: Google eases pandemic rules for employees in the U.S.

abstract: Four were dismissed, and two were disciplined. Google has said its actions had nothing to do with trying to combat unionization efforts.
lead_paragraph: Google has agreed to settle a National Labor Relations Board case filed by six former and current employees who said the company had illegally fired or disciplined them because of their unionization efforts.
headline: Google settles with six employees who worked on unionization efforts.

abstract: Facebook was going to compete with Google for some advertising sales but backed away from the plan after the companies cut a preferential deal, according to court documents.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, Facebook said it was testing a new way of selling online advertising that would threaten Google’s control of the digital ad market. But less than two years later, Facebook did an about-face and said it was joining an alliance of companies backing a similar effort by Google.
headline: Behind a Secret Deal Between Google and Facebook

abstract: These outbreaks should be getting less significant as more Australians get vaccinated. But that has been a slow, ungainly process.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent the past 24 hours jumping at phone alerts and periodically Googling “NSW covid” and “Victoria border restrictions.”
headline: Here We Go Again: Another Covid Case Brings More Uncertainty

abstract: Wildlife officials had been seeking the elk since it was first spotted in 2019. On Saturday, they tranquilized the animal and slid the tire off after removing its antlers.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, Patrick Hemstreet was in his home office in Pine, Colo., checking his email when his wife called to him from upstairs, telling him to look out the front window. Among the pine trees and aspen, Mr. Hemstreet saw a herd of about 40 elk, including a large bull crowned with a bristling rack of antlers.
headline: After 2 Years, a Tire Is Removed From an Elk’s Neck in Colorado

abstract: With the help of Google Cloud, scientists churned through hundreds of thousands of images of the night sky to reveal that the solar system is filled with unseen objects.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, a team of researchers dedicated to finding killer asteroids before they kill us came up with a neat trick.
headline: Killer Asteroid Hunters Spot 27,500 Overlooked Space Rocks

abstract: This word has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word soiree has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 24 in “How Do You Party — Barbie Style?” by Alyson Krueger:
headline: Word of the Day: soiree

abstract: The 10-week trial, set to begin Tuesday, amps up efforts to rein in Big Tech by targeting the core search business that turned Google into a $1.7 trillion behemoth.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from Google’s antitrust trial
headline: In Its First Monopoly Trial of Modern Internet Era, U.S. Sets Sights on Google

abstract: Alexandra Andrews’s debut novel follows a Machiavellian aspiring writer who becomes entangled in her work for a best-selling fiction writer.
lead_paragraph: How dismaying would it be to get a dream job working for a famous writer, only to discover that her new novel in progress seemed off somehow — remote and uninspiring? This is what happens to Florence Darrow in Alexandra Andrews’s “Who Is Maud Dixon?,” and at first it throws Florence for a loop.
headline: In ‘Who Is Maud Dixon?,’ a Dream Job Leads to a Twisty Nightmare

abstract: At least five telecommunications companies have blocked the service, which aggregates news from various sources, according to an analysis from NetBlocks, an internet observatory.
lead_paragraph: Several Russian internet service providers are preventing users inside the country from accessing Google News after Russian generals accused a mercenary leader, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, of attempting a coup.
headline: Google News Blocked in Russia as Feud With Mercenary Leader Intensifies

abstract: Who can explain the success of the skin care brand Augustinus Bader?
lead_paragraph: What can explain the level of extreme devotion, on the part of Augustinus Bader skin care users, to 50 milliliter bottles of creams that cost $280 each — and now an expanded offering of everything from body creams to hair vitamins?
headline: A Mysterious Professor, a Financier and a Beauty Phenomenon

abstract: The government states that data is “oxygen for a search engine” and that Google’s anticompetitive behavior has given it a data fortress. Google says innovation explains its success.
lead_paragraph: The federal government’s first monopoly trial of the modern internet era is less than a week old, but already a central character has emerged: data. Its role, its use and its power are key issues in the Justice Department’s case against Google.
headline: A Key Question in Google’s Trial: How Formidable Is Its Data Advantage?

abstract: Lean into longer recipes (if you dare), or roast canned or frozen artichokes for a flavorful lemon spaghetti.
lead_paragraph: Hello there. By now you’ve heard from Melissa Clark, Priya Krishna and Genevieve Ko instead of Sam Sifton, who’s been traveling. (It takes a village to cover for Sam.) And now, you’ve got me. I’m the Food and Cooking editor of The New York Times, and I’m tickled to be your host on this summer Monday morning.
headline: What to Cook Right Now

abstract: A trio of antitrust cases on the docket threaten to reshape Google’s business and sap its profits.
lead_paragraph: Google’s loss was swift after a monthlong antitrust trial in a San Francisco federal court. A little more than three hours after a jury had begun deliberating on Monday, they returned with their verdict.
headline: Google’s Antitrust Loss to Epic Could Preview Its Legal Fate in 2024

abstract: It says it will give other companies plenty of time to adapt to changes to its Android software. Similar changes made by Apple affected big internet companies.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Wednesday that it was working on privacy measures meant to limit the sharing of data on smartphones running its Android software. But the company promised those changes would not be as disruptive as a similar move by Apple last year.
headline: Google Plans Privacy Changes, but Promises to Not Be Disruptive

abstract: Our sneak peek into Google’s new robotics model, RT-2, which melds artificial intelligence technology with robots.
lead_paragraph: A one-armed robot stood in front of a table. On the table sat three plastic figurines: a lion, a whale and a dinosaur.
headline: Aided by A.I. Language Models, Google’s Robots Are Getting Smart

abstract: Jared Goudsmit finds a shortcut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
headline: Tours de Force

abstract: The engineer, Blake Lemoine, contends that the company’s language model has a soul. The company denies that and says he violated its security policies.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google fired one of its engineers, Blake Lemoine, on Friday, more than a month after he raised ethical concerns about how the company was testing an artificial intelligence chatbot that he believes has achieved consciousness.
headline: Google Fires Engineer Who Claims Its A.I. Is Conscious

abstract: Sundar Pichai, the chief executive of Google, said he never discussed a potential acquisition of the digital media start-up.
lead_paragraph: Sundar Pichai, the chief executive of Google, said in a New York courtroom on Friday that he never discussed a possible takeover of Ozy Media.
headline: Google C.E.O. Testifies in Ozy Media Founder’s Fraud Trial

abstract: As the government wraps up its case in the landmark monopoly trial, it has built a picture of how Google became dominant in online search — and the harms that it says resulted.
lead_paragraph: Since Sept. 12., the Department of Justice and a group of state attorneys general have questioned more than 30 witnesses as they try to prove that Google broke antitrust laws, in a landmark monopoly trial that may affect the power of the technology industry.
headline: What the U.S. Has Argued in the Google Antitrust Trial

abstract: With Australia moving to make the tech companies pay for news, Facebook took a hard line, while Google has struck deals to pay publishers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, Facebook and Google have been locked in a stare-down with news publishers and lawmakers in Australia.
headline: Facebook Blocks News in Australia, Diverging With Google on Proposed Law

abstract: Three years ago, the company walked away from a Defense Department project after employees objected to it. Now the company is working on a new proposal for the Pentagon.
lead_paragraph: Three years after an employee revolt forced Google to abandon work on a Pentagon program that used artificial intelligence, the company is aggressively pursuing a major contract to provide its technology to the military.
headline: Google Wants to Work With the Pentagon Again, Despite Employee Concerns

abstract: This thriller, about a teenage girl whose mother disappears, plays out on a computer screen.
lead_paragraph: The gimmick behind “Missing,” a strenuous techno-thriller about a teen girl named June (Storm Reid) who takes to the internet to track down her mother (Nia Long), is that the directors and screenwriters, Will Merrick and Nick Johnson, frame the action on computer screens. All of June’s sleuthing is cloistered to apps which she opens in increasing panic. She’s a web-weaned child who barely bothered to speak to her mom even before the parent’s disappearance. Initially, June celebrates having the house to herself by Googling “How to throw a rager.” Her friends dutifully post her drunkenness to Instagram so that we, the viewer, can witness it.
headline: ‘Missing’ Review: Mom’s Lost in the Matrix

abstract: French officials said Google had ignored a 2020 order from regulators to negotiate a licensing deal with publishers to use short blurbs from articles in search results.
lead_paragraph: Google was fined 500 million euros, or $593 million, by French antitrust authorities on Tuesday for failing to negotiate a deal in “good faith” with publishers to carry news on its platform, a victory for media companies that have been fighting to make up for a drop in advertising revenue that they attribute to the Silicon Valley giant.
headline: France fines Google $593 million for not negotiating ‘in good faith’ with news publishers.

abstract: Important information is getting drowned out online by a lot of trollish junk.
lead_paragraph: The internet is the most comprehensive compendium of human knowledge ever assembled, but is its size a feature or a bug? Does its very immensity undermine its utility as a source of information? How often is it burying valuable data under lots of junk? Say you search for some famous or semifamous person — a celebrity, influencer, politician or pundit. Are you getting an accurate picture of that person’s life or a false, manipulated one?
headline: We Might Never Know How Much the Internet Is Hiding From Us

abstract: The tech giant is facing the greatest legal threat in its history, and hopes the stolid approach of Kent Walker, its top lawyer, will once again prevail.
lead_paragraph: When the government started an antitrust investigation into Google, one of the company’s top lawyers, Kent Walker, said the solution was not a charm offensive. Google just needed to explain how its business functioned.
headline: Google Turns to a Steady Old Hand to Fight Antitrust Charges

abstract: The companies pulled support for the “free speech” social network, all but killing the service just as many conservatives are seeking alternatives to Facebook and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Parler, a social network that pitches itself as a “free speech” alternative to Twitter and Facebook, is suffering from whiplash.
headline: Amazon, Apple and Google Cut Off Parler, an App That Drew Trump Supporters

abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners makes some impressive logical leaps.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — When you’re eight years old, the height of comedy is telling your friends, your parents and your teachers that it isn’t opposite day. I remember giddily going through the logical twists and turns of “wait … I mean … it is synonym night? Or is it … not opposite not day?” and so on, ad infinitum.
headline: Just for the Fun of It

abstract: For when you want the lightness of a salad but the comfort carb-iness of rice.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Mia again, filling in for Melissa Clark today. She’ll be back with us next week.
headline: Dreamy, Creamy Coconut-Lime Rice With Peanuts

abstract: The women, backed by an abortion-rights group, say they were denied abortions under state law despite risks to themselves and their fetuses that made the procedure a medical necessity.
lead_paragraph: Five women who say they were denied abortions despite grave risks to their lives or their fetuses sued the State of Texas on Monday, apparently the first time that pregnant women themselves have taken legal action against the bans that have shut down access to abortion across the country since the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.
headline: Five Women Sue Texas Over the State’s Abortion Ban

abstract: Many teenagers are back in school for the first time since March 2020. Whether they’re happy to be there or not, most agree nothing feels “normal.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the first edition of Current Events Conversation for the 2021-2022 school year. Every Thursday we editors round up some of the best teenage comments posted to our recent writing prompts, both to give those students and their schools a shout-out and to offer a snapshot of what young people around the country — and, often, around the world — are thinking about issues in the news.
headline: What Students Are Saying About What It’s Like to Be Back in School

abstract: “Solid Ivory” is a scrapbook of memories about Ivory’s childhood, his mentors and his filmmaking and romantic partner Ismail Merchant.
lead_paragraph: The movie director James Ivory is most closely associated with decorous period pieces, paeans to inhibition like “Howards End” and “The Remains of the Day,” so I wasn’t expecting his memoirs to be quite such a “Remembrance of Penises Past.”
headline: James Ivory, Famous for Buttoned-Up Films, Is Frank About Sex and Much Else in His Memoir

abstract: The tech company’s plan is similar to one announced two days earlier by Meta, another Silicon Valley giant.
lead_paragraph: Google, whose work in artificial intelligence helped make A.I.-generated content far easier to create and spread, now wants to ensure that such content is traceable as well.
headline: Google Joins Effort to Help Spot Content Made With A.I.

abstract: Google appears to have turned off its new A.I. Overviews for a number of searches as it works to minimize errors.
lead_paragraph: When Sundar Pichai, Google’s chief executive, introduced a generative artificial intelligence feature for the company’s search engine last month, he and his colleagues demonstrated the new capability with six text-based queries that the public could try out.
headline: Google Rolls Back A.I. Search Feature After Flubs and Flaws

abstract: Houston Grand Opera, known for innovation, unveils Jake Heggie’s “Intelligence,” directed by Jawole Willa Jo Zollar and featuring Urban Bush Women.
lead_paragraph: In a theater at the Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan one recent afternoon, a rehearsal for the coming opera “Intelligence,” about Civil War-era spies, was about to begin.
headline: In an Opera About Civil War Spies, Dancers Help Drive the Drama

abstract: Two undocumented immigrants from opposite sides of the world connect in Brooklyn — and over their shared trauma relating to apparent alien abductions.
lead_paragraph: Do you want to believe? Solomon (Jorge Antonio Guerrero) does — he already believes that his own mother was abducted by space aliens — which is probably easier than accepting what may be her truer and grizzlier fate.
headline: ‘We Are Living Things’ Review: The Truth Is Out There

abstract: As the Justice Department’s case against Google nears an end, the federal government has more suits in the pipeline trying to rein in Big Tech.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government’s landmark antitrust trial against Google’s search business is nearing its conclusion. But the parade of major federal cases challenging Big Tech’s power is just getting going.
headline: U.S. Antitrust Case Against Google Is Just the Start

abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
headline: Today’s Top News: The Google Monopoly Trial, and More

abstract: At home in California, Streisand talks about her new memoir, exploring the movies and men of her life, and her determination to control her own art.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s her grandkids, maybe it’s being 81, but Barbra Streisand is open to new stuff. Take sharing. Well, take sharing herself. “My Name Is Barbra,” her first memoir, is upon us. It’s 970 pages and billows with doubt, anger, ardor, hurt, pride, persuasion, glory and Yiddish. I don’t know that any artist has done more sharing.
headline: Barbra Streisand Is Ready to Tell All. Pull Up a Seat.

abstract: The Chinese-owned video app is dealing with a flood of war videos and the question of whether it is spreading unverified information.
lead_paragraph: Bre Hernandez used to scan TikTok for videos of makeup tutorials and taco truck reviews. Since Russia invaded Ukraine, the 19-year-old has spent hours each day scrolling the app for war videos, watching graphic footage of Ukrainian tanks firing on Russian troops and civilians running away from enemy gunfire.
headline: TikTok Is Gripped by the Violence and Misinformation of Ukraine War

abstract: Google hopes that giving its chatbot more capabilities and improving its accuracy will give more users a reason to use it.
lead_paragraph: In March, Google released an artificial intelligence chatbot called Bard. It was Google’s answer to OpenAI’s hugely popular ChatGPT.
headline: Google Connects A.I. Chatbot Bard to YouTube, Gmail and More Facts

abstract: Larry Kosilla, one of the top car detailers in the country, gives Ferraris, Lamborghinis and old barn finds the beauty treatment.
lead_paragraph: The 1969 Pontiac Le Mans had been sitting in a garage in Greenwich, Conn., undriven and, by the look of it, untouched for two decades. Wood piled against the body had scratched the blue paint. Mice had crawled into the engine and burrowed into the cabin, leaving behind toxic urine and droppings. Splotches of mold covered the white vinyl seats, black carpet, armrest and dash.
headline: Primp Your Ride

abstract: Investors see Wednesday’s Consumer Price Index report as a pivotal report card on inflation and the Federal Reserve’s next move.
lead_paragraph: The mood music on rate cuts has changed again. Inflation hasn’t fallen as quickly as expected and the economy is performing strongly. All eyes now are focused on the upcoming Consumer Price Index data for clues on when the Fed might finally start cutting interest rates.
headline: How Low Will They Go? Wall Street’s Big Rethink on Interest Rate Cuts

abstract: These prosecutions typically spark innovation in unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: The Google antitrust trial, which began last week, is ostensibly focused on the past — on a series of deals that Google made with other companies over the past two decades. The prosecution in the case, U.S. et al. v. Google, contends that Google illegally spent billions of dollars paying off Samsung and Apple to prevent anyone else from gaining a foothold in the market for online search.
headline: The Google Trial Is Going to Rewrite Our Future

abstract: When the police can’t afford to solve cold cases using DNA databases, deep-pocketed donors can.
lead_paragraph: Last January, Carla Davis was on LinkedIn when she saw an intriguing post: “Identify the Victim of 1978 Tennessee Murder.”
headline: The True Crime-Obsessed Philanthropists Paying to Catch Killers

abstract: The virtual assistants had more than a decade to become indispensable. But they were hampered by clunky design and miscalculations, leaving room for chatbots to rise.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy Tuesday in San Francisco, Apple executives took the stage in a crowded auditorium to unveil the fifth-generation iPhone. The phone, which looked identical to the previous version, had a new feature that the audience was soon buzzing about: Siri, a virtual assistant.
headline: How Siri, Alexa and Google Assistant Lost the A.I. Race

abstract: European Union regulators filed new antitrust charges against Google, which could lead to fines and orders for the company to change its business practices.
lead_paragraph: Google was charged on Wednesday with violating European Union antitrust laws by using its dominance in online advertising to undercut rivals, the latest in a string of cases around the world that strike at the core of the internet giant’s business model.
headline: Google’s Online Advertising Practices Violate Antitrust Laws, E.U. Says

abstract: Male players as young as 16 have many options to play high-level basketball before the N.B.A. without going to college — and get paid big money to do it.
lead_paragraph: In February, Ramses Melendez, who goes by RJ, announced his college decision in a video posted to his social media accounts. A 4-star forward in the class of 2021, Melendez followed a typical formula for the video: a highlight reel and then a jersey reveal. He strayed from the script for a moment, though, when he acknowledged in a voice-over that “it wasn’t easy to make this decision.”
headline: Teenage Ballers Can Cash in Earlier Than Ever. But at What Cost?

abstract: The country has been hit hard by wildfires and other climate disasters, but it’s also making tons of money from fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: What do you do when your country feels some of the worst calamities of climate change but also enriches itself from the very fossil fuels that are responsible for climate change?
headline: There’s an election in Australia. Here’s how climate fits in.

abstract: Its campaign is part of a global wave of actions by governments that are testing how far they can go to control online speech.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Russia is increasingly pressuring Google, Twitter and Facebook to fall in line with Kremlin internet crackdown orders or risk restrictions inside the country, as more governments around the world challenge the companies’ principles on online freedom.
headline: Russia Raises Heat on Twitter, Google and Facebook in Online Crackdown

abstract: The author dissects the anxieties and discontents of living in a world wrought by tech giants.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a world in which Google and Amazon join together to form an all-knowing corporate juggernaut that could program our every movement. Author Dave Eggers has contemplated such a future in his latest dystopian novel “The Every.” Eggers, who limits his own use of technology to the bare minimum, says he was inspired by the limitless choice of our digital world and the idea of a data-driven tech monopoly that would use “your preferences and algorithmic-determined personality” to help you “become the better version of yourself and the ultimate version of yourself.”
headline: Dave Eggers Created the Google-Amazon Mash-Up of Your Nightmares

abstract: The singer-songwriter Ethel Cain has an elaborate vision of becoming a different kind of pop star. She’s doing it from rural Alabama.
lead_paragraph: DALEVILLE, Ala. — About 25 minutes north of the Florida border, near the mouth of a U.S. Army post and not much else, sits a simple brick home with wood paneling, open windows and a silver pickup truck out front.
headline: The Most Famous Girl at the Waffle House

abstract: Default settings on devices allow the tech industry to keep collecting and using data as it wants.
lead_paragraph: A report in The Guardian in August that lawyers who had had business before the Supreme Court gave money to an aide to Justice Clarence Thomas for a Christmas party was surprising. Just as surprising was the way the publication learned about it: from the aide’s public Venmo records. Brian X. Chen, the consumer technology writer for The Times, wrote that even he was surprised that such records of money transfers could be public.
headline: This Is Why Google Paid Billions for Apple to Change a Single Setting

abstract: After more than eight months of research and development, Google has unveiled its most powerful A.I. so far. But only parts of it are widely available.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, Google has raced to build technology that could match ChatGPT, the eye-opening chatbot offered by the San Francisco artificial intelligence start-up OpenAI.
headline: Google Updates Bard Chatbot With ‘Gemini’ A.I. as It Chases ChatGPT

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 1, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like saying to the world, ‘look, here we are!’”
headline: Quotation of the Day: Allinllachu, World: Quechua Joins Google Translate

abstract: While some indulged in baking through lockdown, a husband-and-wife team discovered an exceptionally large and well-preserved group of Jurassic starfish.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Millions of years before the Cotswolds, in western England, became a popular vacation destination, romanticized for its ancient woodlands, honey-colored stone villages and medieval abbeys, it was a shallow, warm sea, home to a Jurassic marine ecosystem.
headline: Amateur Fossil Hunters Make Rare Find in U.K. Using Google Earth

abstract: Google presents itself to independent sellers as cheaper and less restrictive. But it is not clear whether it can change people’s habits of going straight to Amazon.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google tried to copy Amazon’s playbook to become the shopping hub of the internet, with little success. Now it is trying something different: the anti-Amazon strategy.
headline: Google Aims to Be the Anti-Amazon of E-Commerce. It Has a Long Way to Go.

abstract: The antitrust backlash against Big Tech is playing out in places not known as regulatory hotbeds.
lead_paragraph: Type “running shoes,” “best laptop” or “camping equipment” into Google from just about anywhere in the world and the top of the screen will show a carousel of ads from websites promoting products to browse and compare.
headline: Why Turkey’s Regulators Became Such a Problem for Google

abstract: If Google were declared a so-called common carrier like a utility company, it would prevent the company from prioritizing its own products, services and websites in search results.
lead_paragraph: Ohio’s attorney general, Dave Yost, filed a lawsuit on Tuesday in pursuit of a novel effort to have Google declared a public utility and subject to government regulation.
headline: Ohio’s attorney general wants Google to be declared a public utility.

abstract: Gemini, Google’s new chatbot, has provoked a fierce debate about social values and artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: When Google released Gemini, a new chatbot powered by artificial intelligence, it quickly faced a backlash — and unleashed a fierce debate about whether A.I. should be guided by social values, and if so, whose values they should be.
headline: The Miseducation of Google’s A.I.

abstract: Google plans to experiment with new office configurations and more flexibility. Will others follow?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Back to Work the Google Way

abstract: It isn’t too late to start a constructive conversation about aging and leadership.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and I have something in common: We were born on Nov. 20, 1942 — he in Scranton, Pa., I in Providence, R.I.
headline: I Share a Birthday With President Biden. Ask Me About Our Age.

abstract: The April 4, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Chris Miller. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Chris Miller

abstract: Rachel Honig had been on hundreds of dates. Grad Conn could barely muster the courage to go on one. But after canceling four times, the fifth time was a charm.
lead_paragraph: Wilson Grad Conn wasn’t going to let his dating inexperience become a liability when he started seeing Rachel Lyn Honig in the fall of 2019.
headline: On the Fifth Try, a First Date to Remember

abstract: The virus-tracing effort raises questions about the power of Big Tech to set global standards for public health tools.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Cavey, a real estate agent in Denver, was thrilled last fall when Colorado introduced an app to warn people of possible coronavirus exposures.
headline: Why Apple and Google’s Virus Alert Apps Had Limited Success

abstract: Infusing themes, characters and — of course — the color pink, people used the movie to inspire their own celebrations.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, Shallon Lester, 36, a YouTuber, saw “Barbie” with 20 girlfriends and then headed back to her house in Bozeman, Mont., for a “Barbiecue.”
headline: How Do You Party — Barbie Style?

abstract: Google has an automated tool to detect abusive images of children. But the system can get it wrong, and the consequences are serious.
lead_paragraph: Mark noticed something amiss with his toddler. His son’s penis looked swollen and was hurting him. Mark, a stay-at-home dad in San Francisco, grabbed his Android smartphone and took photos to document the problem so he could track its progression.
headline: A Dad Took Photos of His Naked Toddler for the Doctor. Google Flagged Him as a Criminal.

abstract: The administration’s vaccine plan isn’t ambitious enough.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s administration overpromised on coronavirus vaccines. In November, his secretary of health and human services said there would be 40 million doses available by the end of the 2020; he was off by about a month. Trump himself promised 100 million doses in that same period. Everything he and his team said was a sales pitch, designed to foster the false impression that the pandemic they let burn out of control was on the cusp of ending.
headline: Please, Biden, Try for 2 Million Shots a Day

abstract: Emails sent to dozens of restaurants, including those with Michelin stars, threaten a barrage of one-star reviews unless owners pay.
lead_paragraph: In a new scam targeting restaurants, criminals are leaving negative ratings on restaurants’ Google pages as a bargaining chip to extort digital gift cards.
headline: Restaurants Face an Extortion Threat: A Bad Rating on Google

abstract: Outdated textbooks, not enough teachers, no ventilation — for millions of kids like Harvey Ellington, the public-education system has failed them their whole lives.
lead_paragraph: One Saturday afternoon in late May, a few days before the end of his junior year, Harvey Ellington plopped onto his queen-size bed, held up his phone and searched for a signal. The 17-year-old lived in a three-bedroom trailer on an acre lot surrounded by oak trees, too far into the country for broadband, but eventually his cell found the hot spot his high school had lent him for the year. He opened his email and began to type.
headline: The Tragedy of America’s Rural Schools

abstract: The government has set its sights on the internet behemoth in the first monopoly trial of the modern internet era.
lead_paragraph: For years, the government has been trying to rein in Big Tech, pursuing some of the largest and most powerful companies on the internet. This week, the government takes on Google in the first monopoly trial of the modern internet era.
headline: U.S. v. Google

abstract: The states argue that Google reached a deal with Facebook to have the social network join its effort in an effort to “kill” a competing ad network.
lead_paragraph: Google’s chief executive approved an agreement with Facebook at the heart of an antitrust lawsuit that 16 states and Puerto Rico have lodged against the search giant, according to a portion of the complaint revealed on Friday.
headline: Google’s chief executive signed off on deal at center of antitrust case, states say.

abstract: The newest painting by Jasper Johns was inspired by a fan letter from an astrophysicist. Here’s a first look.
lead_paragraph: At 91, Jasper Johns is turning out impressive and touchingly personal work. During the solitary months of the pandemic, he completed a painting titled “Slice,” and a group of related drawings and prints. Likely to be a standout of his upcoming show, “Jasper Johns: Mind/Mirror,” a two-venue retrospective opening Sept. 29 at the Whitney Museum of American Art and the Philadelphia Museum of Art, “Slice” is a large, horizontal and predominantly black oil painting that combines unrelated images of a map of outer space and a human knee.
headline: All the World in a ‘Slice’ of Art

abstract: Isomorphic Labs is a spinoff of the London-based artificial intelligence lab DeepMind.
lead_paragraph: Google’s parent company, Alphabet, is launching an operation dedicated to drug discovery.
headline: Google’s parent launches a company dedicated to drug discovery.

abstract: Our company’s motto used to be “Don’t be evil.” An organized work force will help us live up to it.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 1, 2018, at 11:10 a.m., some 20,000 Google employees, along with employees of Waymo, Verily and other Alphabet companies, stopped working and walked off the job in cities around the world. A week earlier, The New York Times reported that the company had paid tens of millions of dollars to two executives who had been accused of sexual misconduct toward our co-workers, staying silent about the alleged abuse and letting them walk away with no consequences.
headline: We Built Google. This Is Not the Company We Want to Work For.

abstract: Under the agreement, which state attorneys general said was the largest U.S. internet privacy settlement, Google must also make its location-tracking practices clearer to users.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Google agreed to a record $391.5 million privacy settlement with a 40-state coalition of attorneys general on Monday for charges that it misled users into thinking they had turned off location tracking in their account settings even as the company continued collecting that information.
headline: Google Agrees to $392 Million Privacy Settlement With 40 States

abstract: A member of a powerful publishing family, he drove his Pennsylvania newspaper’s Pulitzer Prize-winning coverage of the child sex abuse scandal at Penn State.
lead_paragraph: David Newhouse, who as the editor guided The Patriot-News in Harrisburg, Pa., to a Pulitzer Prize for breaking the story that led to the conviction of the Penn State assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky for sexually abusing young boys, and to the firing of Joe Paterno, the school’s revered head football coach, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 65.
headline: David Newhouse, 65, Dies; His Paper Broke the Sandusky Story

abstract: The Supreme Court, Congress, even the White House — the reverberations are everywhere.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Hope you had a nice Fourth of July. Politically speaking, most of the fireworks seemed to be coming from the Supreme Court. Any thoughts on how the term ended?
headline: Trump Is Gone, Sort of. The Fireworks Are Still Going Off.

abstract: Who is he?
lead_paragraph: Matt Gaetz’s gamble appears to have paid off.
headline: House Speaker Mike Johnson

abstract: The company realized months ago that it could be running afoul of pay laws in a number of countries but has been slow to fix the problem, according to internal documents.
lead_paragraph: In December, a group of Google managers responsible for overseeing thousands of its temporary staff members discovered the company had been underpaying some of those workers for years.
headline: Google Could Be Violating Labor Laws With Pay for Temp Workers

abstract: The project is a big bet on scaling up programs that have proved effective in lifting low-income workers into middle-class jobs and careers.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Thursday that it was creating a $100 million fund to sponsor an ambitious project to expand effective skills training and job placement programs for low-income Americans.
headline: Google Creates $100 Million Fund for Skills Training Program

abstract: A conversation with the author of ‘Stolen Focus.’
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Johann Hari. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Johann Hari

abstract: Many doulas, relied upon for pregnancy and childbirth support, have started offering their services over text and video. Experts say that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Kanwal Haq, a New York-based doula, was on a plane home from a vacation last September when she received a text from her client: “It’s game day here.”
headline: You Can Now Get Virtual Doula Care for Pregnancy. Does It Work?

abstract: When Mrinal Kalakrishnan and Preeti Talwai first met at work, neither of them was looking for romance. Several months later, they went on their first date.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2017, Mrinal Kalakrishnan and Preeti Murali Talwai arrived at a crossroads.
headline: Not Searching for Love, They Found It at Google

abstract: Before the pandemic, Google’s sprawling campus of airy, open offices and whimsical common spaces set a standard for what an innovative workplace was supposed to look like.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic, Google’s sprawling campus of airy, open offices and whimsical common spaces set a standard for what an innovative workplace was supposed to look like.
headline: Ikea meets Lego: Google redesigns its office space.

abstract: Is the mania for subscriptions a choice, or the only path in an ad system dominated by giants?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Google and Facebook Killed Free

abstract: The tech giants talk a lot about the “metaverse” and cloud computing. What really powers them is selling us socks.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Google and Facebook’s Ad Empires

abstract: The tech giant becomes the latest to adopt tougher standards as the industry comes under fire for not doing enough to protect children.
lead_paragraph: Google says it plans additional privacy measures to protect teenage users on YouTube and its search engine, becoming the latest technology giant to adopt tougher standards in the face of criticism that companies are not doing enough to protect children.
headline: Google will add privacy steps for teenagers on its search engine and YouTube.

abstract: “Dispatches From the Gilded Age” is a collection of essays by the journalist Julia Reed, who died at 59 in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Julia Reed, a journalist and ambassador of Southern hospitality who died of cancer at 59 in 2020, was a great generator of maxims, especially about the little things. A sampler, from her posthumous collection of career-spanning essays, “Dispatches From the Gilded Age”:
headline: The Essays of a Beloved Bon Vivant

abstract: A rival chatbot has shaken Google out of its routine, with the founders who left three years ago re-engaging and more than 20 A.I. projects in the works.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, Google’s founders, held several meetings with company executives. The topic: a rival’s new chatbot, a clever A.I. product that looked as if it could be the first notable threat in decades to Google’s $149 billion search business.
headline: Google Calls In Help From Larry Page and Sergey Brin for A.I. Fight

abstract: TikTok skeptics now have a smoking gun.
lead_paragraph: Calls to ban TikTok or force its sell-off from its parent company ByteDance are gaining momentum, especially after reports of ByteDance’s surveillance of several U.S. journalists. And could Microsoft’s investment in OpenAI mark the end of Google’s search monopoly?
headline: TikTok’s Spying Scandal and ChatGPT’s Challenge to Google

abstract: European Union and British regulators are investigating an agreement between the internet giants that a U.S. antitrust inquiry uncovered.
lead_paragraph: A secret deal struck between Google and Meta, the parent company of Facebook, is being investigated by antitrust regulators in the European Union and Britain for potentially undermining competition in the multibillion-dollar digital advertising market.
headline: A secret ad deal between Google and Meta is under scrutiny in Europe.

abstract: Pathbreaking legislation showed that even a small nation can get the tech giant to bend. But the United States seems unlikely to follow.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Just a few weeks after Google threatened to leave Australia if the government forced tech platforms to pay for news, the search giant is suddenly showering money on its most demanding critics.
headline: Google Is Suddenly Paying for News in Australia. What About Everywhere Else?

abstract: A special Valentine’s Day look back.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, a chatbot tried to break up Kevin Roose’s marriage. Ever since, chatbots haven’t been the same. We’ll tell you how. Then, we’ll talk through the latest ways the world is adapting to artificial intelligence. And finally, Aravind Srinivas, the chief executive of Perplexity, will discuss his company’s “answer engine,” a challenger to Google’s search engine that could reshape the web as we know it.
headline: The State of A.I., and Will Perplexity Beat Google or Destroy the Web?

abstract: In the first full day of testimony in the U.S. monopoly trial against Google, the Justice Department sought to show that the company had long tried to cut out search competitors.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department used its first full day of questioning in its antitrust trial against Google on Wednesday to establish that the internet giant had long sought agreements to be the default search engine on mobile devices, which the government argues were used to illegally maintain the company’s hold over online search.
headline: In Antitrust Trial, Former Google Employee Details History of Search Deals

abstract: Even as gender and masculinity are more fluid than ever, it can still rankle when male stars co-opt traditionally gay codes and styles.
lead_paragraph: IF YOU ARE a fan of Harry Styles, you’ve probably had a complicated couple of years. Styles contains multitudes, or at least he contains multiple narratives: At 29, he is the British reality-competition star made good, the style icon, the now-solo boy-band supernova, the “Saturday Night Live” host, the burgeoning movie star, the burgeoning movie actor (different thing) and the pop-cultural shape-shifter for whom everything is a lark, a laugh, a pose, an interesting new outfit to try on. This makes Styles the ideal choose-your-own-adventure celebrity for the first generation of fans to have grown up fluent in the syntax of the multiverse. You don’t have to love all the iterations of him, just the ones that resonate with you.
headline: Is Celebrity ‘Queer Baiting’ Really Such a Crime?

abstract: The moves may result in a second antitrust lawsuit against Google before the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Justice has accelerated an investigation into Google’s digital advertising practices and may file an antitrust lawsuit against the internet giant before the end of the year, two people with knowledge of the government’s thinking said on Wednesday.
headline: Justice Dept. Is Said to Accelerate Google Advertising Inquiry

abstract: The owner of the dating services Tinder and OkCupid claims Google violated antitrust laws.
lead_paragraph: Match Group, which owns dating services like Tinder and OkCupid, sued Google on Monday, claiming that it broke antitrust laws with the rules it set for its smartphone app store.
headline: Match Group sues Google over its app store rules.

abstract: The effort is the first time the tech giant has tried to get a government case against it tossed out.
lead_paragraph: Google asked a federal court on Friday to dismiss an antitrust lawsuit led by the State of Texas, the first time it has sought to have one of the government competition cases against it thrown out in the United States.
headline: Google asks court to dismiss Texas antitrust case.

abstract: Begun nearly a decade ago, Loon was one of the company’s high-profile, cutting-edge efforts. But it was difficult to turn into a business.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google’s parent company Alphabet is shutting down Loon, a high-profile subsidiary spun out from its research labs that used high-altitude helium balloons to deliver cellular connectivity from the stratosphere.
headline: Google-Linked Balloon Project to Provide Cell Service Will Close

abstract: Ohio’s attorney general has asked for a judicial declaration that Google has evolved into a common carrier. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: American law recognizes that some critically important businesses must accept all customers and treat everyone fairly because they are not easily or economically efficient to duplicate — think railroads, electricity providers and telephone companies.
headline: Let’s Make Google a Public Good

abstract: The tech giant has so far taken steps to streamline without mass layoffs, but employees are girding for deeper cuts.
lead_paragraph: Google workers in Switzerland sent a letter this month to the company’s vice president of human resources, outlining their worries that a new employee evaluation system could be used to cull the work force.
headline: Google Employees Brace for a Cost-Cutting Drive as Anxiety Mounts

abstract: Google is charging some small businesses for email and other apps after more than a decade of free use. Business owners say Google is being callous.
lead_paragraph: When Google told some small businesses in January that they would no longer be able to use a customized email service and other workplace apps for free, it felt like a broken promise for Richard J. Dalton Jr., a longtime user who operates a scholastic test-prep company in Vancouver, British Columbia.
headline: Google Says It’s Time for Longtime Small-Business Users to Pay Up

abstract: Adam Vincent gives the hard sell.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Adam Vincent, for whom this puzzle marks a second appearance in the New York Times Crossword!
headline: Discover Unexpectedly

abstract: A small search engine company in the Czech Republic helped inspire a law that is poised to put major limits on tech giants like Google.
lead_paragraph: As Google extended its dominance as a search engine over the past two decades, the Czech Republic stood out as a surprising holdout.
headline: Google Vanquished a Rival in Prague. Payback Could Hurt.

abstract: A Russian court fined Google about $360 million (21.1 billion rubles) on Monday for failing to remove content the country deems illegal, including coverage of the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A Russian court fined Google about $360 million (21.1 billion rubles) on Monday for failing to remove content the country deems illegal, including coverage of the war in Ukraine.
headline: Russia fines Google for failing to remove news it calls ‘fake.’

abstract: Sneha Medappa Maruvanda grew up in India, and Dr. Mark Ross Edelstein, in Virginia. But in getting to know one another, they discovered their backgrounds were strikingly similar.
lead_paragraph: By the time Sneha Medappa Maruvanda met Dr. Mark Ross Edelstein in person, she feared they might not have anything left to say to each other.
headline: In Their Different Cultures, They Found Common Denominators

abstract: The new details came in an unredacted version of a lawsuit filed by Texas and 11 other states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Google said in an internal document that it had successfully “slowed down” European privacy rules in collaboration with other tech companies, according to a legal filing released on Friday.
headline: Google said it had successfully ‘slowed down’ European privacy rules, according to lawsuit.

abstract: Blake Lemoine, the engineer, says that Google’s language model has a soul. The company disagrees.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google placed an engineer on paid leave recently after dismissing his claim that its artificial intelligence is sentient, surfacing yet another fracas about the company’s most advanced technology.
headline: Google Sidelines Engineer Who Claims Its A.I. Is Sentient

abstract: The tech giant is evaluating tools that would use artificial intelligence to perform tasks that some of its researchers have said should be avoided.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Google, locked in an accelerating competition with rivals like Microsoft and OpenAI to develop A.I. technology, was looking for ways to put a charge into its artificial intelligence research.
headline: Google Tests an A.I. Assistant That Offers Life Advice

abstract: The tech giant has sought to trim expenses to pay for artificial intelligence investments; it had earlier cut 12,000 jobs in January.
lead_paragraph: Google conducted another round of layoffs on Wednesday, telling its recruiters that by the end of the day hundreds of them would be losing their jobs, three people with knowledge of the layoffs said.
headline: Google Sheds Hundreds of Recruiters in Another Round of Layoffs

abstract: In “The Secret Battle of Evan Pao,” a Chinese American boy and his family feel as if they’re refighting the U.S. Civil War.
lead_paragraph: In 1860, there were approximately 35,000 Chinese people in the United States, about 200 of whom lived in the Eastern part of the country. Of these, 50-60 would go on to fight in the American Civil War. Most were Union soldiers, but there were exceptions, like the two eldest sons of the famous conjoined twins Chang and Eng Bunker — Christopher Bunker, the son of Chang, and Stephen Bunker, the son of Eng, who were both enslavers (like their fathers) and Confederate soldiers.
headline: Soldiering On

abstract: The contract workers are resisting a plan to resume in-person work, citing health concerns and commuting costs.
lead_paragraph: Google Maps contract employees who are required to return to their office in Washington State recently circulated a petition to keep working from home since some cannot afford their commutes, presenting another challenge to Google’s plan to refill offices and restore campus life.
headline: Google Maps Workers Say They Can’t Afford the Trip Back to the Office

abstract: Entries for the week of Feb. 13, 2023.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic

abstract: The company has teamed up with Ray-Ban to create glasses that can take photos, record video, answer phone calls and play podcasts.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last Saturday, after a three-mile hike through the Presidio, I stood in a throng of tourists looking at the Golden Gate Bridge. As the crowd snapped photos of the landmark, I decided to join in.
headline: Smart Glasses Made Google Look Dumb. Now Facebook Is Giving Them a Try.

abstract: At the company’s annual conference, Google demonstrated dozens of products and features that work with artificial intelligence, along with new phones.
lead_paragraph: When the San Francisco start-up OpenAI released ChatGPT late last year, the A.I. chatbot looked like the first significant threat in decades to Google. One day, tech insiders thought, it could make Google’s internet search engine look old and stodgy.
headline: Google Builds on Tech’s Latest Craze With Its Own A.I. Products

abstract: The latest tranche totals about 200. They are among more than 1,000 that the company, accused of firing union organizers, claimed were protected by attorney-client privilege.
lead_paragraph: Google wrongly claimed attorney-client privilege to protect documents subpoenaed in a National Labor Relations Board case filed by former employees who say the company fired them because of their unionization efforts, a labor judge has ruled.
headline: Google must turn over more documents in a labor case, a judge rules.

abstract: From women’s soccer to college sports, athletes have lost faith in leagues and organizations handling abuse and other complaints.
lead_paragraph: As revelation after devastating revelation emerged last month about soccer executives ignoring reports of male coaches sexually abusing or harassing female players, the National Women’s Soccer League Players Association hired an outside company to provide an anonymous online platform for athletes to report abuse and other concerns.
headline: Outside Hotlines for Athletes Are a Sign of Strained Trust in Sports

abstract: X marks the spot where Twitter died.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, a crane arrived in downtown San Francisco to take down the Twitter sign from the company’s office building. The crane’s arrival marked the death of Twitter, the brand, and the start of X, Elon Musk’s everything app. Today, why Elon’s acquisition feels more and more like cultural vandalism and what, if anything, will replace the global town square.
headline: Elon’s X Machina, Crypto Orbs and a Visit to Google’s Robot Lab

abstract: Asking elected officials to keep silent  is bad for democracy.
lead_paragraph: In March, when the City Council of Fort Wayne, Ind., voted 7 to 2 to approve $16 million in tax breaks for a corporation to open a distribution center in the city, it was something of a shot in the dark: Four of the Council members — including two who voted in favor of the deal — didn’t know which corporation they were considering.
headline: How Amazon, Google and Other Companies Exploit NDAs

abstract: A partnership would extend the long relationship between the companies that has helped deliver everything from maps to search on Apple’s devices.
lead_paragraph: Apple is in discussions with Google about using the search giant’s generative artificial intelligence model called Gemini for its next iPhone, as the company races to embrace a technology that has upended the tech industry.
headline: Apple and Google Are Discussing a Deal to Bring Generative A.I. to iPhones

abstract: The ruling did not affect some central parts of the antitrust cases about Google search, which are scheduled to go to trial next month.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge said this week that the Justice Department and a group of states could not move forward with some claims in antitrust complaints against Google, narrowing the scope of what is set to be the most significant federal monopoly trial against a tech giant in decades.
headline: Judge Narrows Scope of Coming Trial Over Google Monopoly Claims

abstract: The decision is in response to a proposed law in the country that would require tech companies to pay publishers for linking to stories across their platforms.
lead_paragraph: Facebook said on Wednesday that it would restrict people and publishers from sharing links to news articles in Australia, in response to a proposed law in the country that requires tech companies to pay publishers for linking to articles across their platforms.
headline: Facebook restricts the sharing of news in Australia as Google says it will pay some publishers.

abstract: It’s been a week of A.I. vertigo — the feeling that we’ve been dragged five years into the future and aren’t sure what to do about it.
lead_paragraph: This week, OpenAI unveiled GPT-4o, its newest A.I. model. It has an uncannily emotive voice that everybody is talking about. Then, we break down the biggest announcements from Google IO, including the launch of A.I. overviews, a major change to search that threatens the way the entire web functions. And finally, Kevin and Casey discuss the weirdest headlines from the week in another round of HatGPT.
headline: OpenAI’s Flirty New Assistant, Google Guts the Web and We Play HatGPT

abstract: British researchers and a team from Google found that teaching people how to spot misinformation made people more skeptical of it.
lead_paragraph: In the fight against online misinformation, falsehoods have key advantages: They crop up fast and spread at the speed of electrons, and there is a lag period before fact checkers can debunk them.
headline: Google Finds ‘Inoculating’ People Against Misinformation Helps Blunt Its Power

abstract: Seth A. Abel weaves some tasty long entries together.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When constructors make a puzzle, they are faced with a choice: They can use an already established grid design — some puzzle-making programs come with a library of premade grids — and fill around it, or they can choose to design the grid themselves.
headline: The End of Time

abstract: The tech giant showed off how it would enmesh A.I. more deeply into its products and users’ lives, from search to so-called agents that perform tasks.
lead_paragraph: Last May, Sundar Pichai, Google’s chief executive, said the company would use artificial intelligence to reimagine all of its products.
headline: Google Takes the Next Step in Its A.I. Evolution

abstract: How we look matters as much as what we see.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, I read a book I’d been ignoring for 10 years, Nicholas Carr’s “The Shallows: What the Internet Is Doing to Our Brains.” It was a finalist for a Pulitzer Prize in 2011 and was much loved among people who seemed to hate the internet.
headline: I Didn’t Want It to Be True, but the Medium Really Is the Message

abstract: Can you tell the difference between a $10,000 Chanel bag and a $200 knockoff? Almost nobody can, and it’s turning luxury fashion upside down.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, the legend goes, Theseus slew the Minotaur and sailed triumphantly home to Athens on a wooden ship. The vessel was preserved by Athenian citizens, who continually replaced its rotting planks with strong, fresh timber so a pilgrimage to Delos could be made each year in their hero’s name. Fascinated by this mythical tale, the philosopher Plutarch found it to embody a “logical question of things that grow”: After Theseus’s ship had been stripped of all its original material, could it still be considered the same ship? His question has caromed through centuries of Western thought. What if, Thomas Hobbes wondered, someone rustled up a second boat out of the discarded planks; would you now have two original vessels? And what about our own era of machine-made duplication — does replication strip away the soul of creation?
headline: Inside the Delirious Rise of ‘Superfake’ Handbags

abstract: Judge Amit P. Mehta must now decide whether Google violated the law, potentially setting a precedent for a series of tech monopoly cases.
lead_paragraph: A landmark antitrust trial against Google concluded on Friday after a federal judge heard final arguments, setting the stage for a ruling that could fundamentally shift the tech industry’s power.
headline: Final Arguments in Google Antitrust Trial Conclude, Setting Up Landmark Ruling

abstract: Shares of the SPAC trying to merge with Donald Trump’s social media company rose on Thursday after the decision.
lead_paragraph: The shares of the cash-rich special purpose acquisition company that seeks to merge with former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company surged on Thursday after Google said it would allow Trump Media & Technology Group’s flagship product to appear in its app store.
headline: Google’s Move to Include Truth Social in App Store Buoys Investor Confidence

abstract: When a Google staffing agency reneged on a promise to pay an attendance bonus, temps who are part of the company’s union organized and forced it to backtrack.
lead_paragraph: Ned McNally, a temp worker at Google’s data center in Council Bluffs, Iowa, received notice in August that he would get a $200 weekly bonus until the end of the year for working a full week. It was a nod to the labor shortages ravaging businesses during the pandemic.
headline: Google Temps Fought Loss of Pandemic Bonus. And Won.

abstract: I like workouts that burn, workouts that sear, workouts that leave me on the ground gasping for air.
lead_paragraph: I am not a person who tends toward extremes. I shy away from skydiving or deep sea exploration (too high; too low). I don’t like incredibly spicy food. I prefer my drinking water at room temperature. I do not like horror movies or very sad movies or even movies when a sad part lasts longer than necessary. Suffice it to say, in a vast majority of my life, I enjoy the comfort and safety of the moderate middle.
headline: Why I Can’t Quit Extreme Workouts

abstract: Set off by a scene in a movie, a critic reflects on cultural baggage: “The things you loved when you were young will never be able to make you young again.”
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of other people, I enjoyed Joachim Trier’s “The Worst Person in the World,” a young woman’s coming-of-age story that’s also a spiky romantic comedy of sorts. But the reason I can’t stop thinking about this movie (which I can’t discuss further without risking spoilers, so be warned) has to do with its status as a Gen X midlife cri de coeur.
headline: Shelf Life: Our Collections and the Passage of Time

abstract: “Am I concerned? Yes. Am I optimistic and excited about all the potential of this technology? Incredibly.”
lead_paragraph: For years, Google was seen as one of the most cutting-edge developers of A.I. But, with OpenAI’s release of ChatGPT, and other chatbots beating Google to market, is that distinction still the case? Google’s chief executive is in an unenviable position: Scramble to catch up or, in the face of potentially harmful technology, move slowly.
headline: Google C.E.O. Sundar Pichai on Bard, A.I. ‘Whiplash’ and Competing With ChatGPT

abstract: A new wave of chat bots like ChatGPT use artificial intelligence that could reinvent or even replace the traditional internet search engine.
lead_paragraph: Over the past three decades, a handful of products like Netscape’s web browser, Google’s search engine and Apple’s iPhone have truly upended the tech industry and made what came before them look like lumbering dinosaurs.
headline: A New Chat Bot Is a ‘Code Red’ for Google’s Search Business

abstract: In “Luckenbooth,” Jenni Fagan traces the strange, fantastical stories of artists, vagabonds, dreamers and mystics in a single tenement.
lead_paragraph: LUCKENBOOTHBy Jenni Fagan
headline: A Gothic Novel Haunted by Nine Lives Over Nine Decades

abstract: When Apple and Google collaborated last year on a smartphone-based system to track the spread of the coronavirus, the news was seen as a game changer. The software uses Bluetooth signals to detect app users who come into close contact. If a user later tests positive, the person can anonymously notify other app users whom the person may have crossed paths with in restaurants, on trains or elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: When Apple and Google collaborated last year on a smartphone-based system to track the spread of the coronavirus, the news was seen as a game changer. The software uses Bluetooth signals to detect app users who come into close contact. If a user later tests positive, the person can anonymously notify other app users whom the person may have crossed paths with in restaurants, on trains or elsewhere.
headline: Virus alert apps powered by Apple and Google have had limited success.

abstract: “We’ve heard directly from a growing number of our advertising and publisher partners who have expressed concerns about ads that run alongside or promote inaccurate claims about climate change,” the company said.
lead_paragraph: Google said it will no longer display advertisements on YouTube videos and other content that promote inaccurate claims about climate change.
headline: Google bans ads on content, including YouTube videos, with false claims about climate change.

abstract: They shrugged off concerns about the company’s fate ahead of closing arguments in the Justice Department’s lawsuit this week.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Google’s employees gathered for an all-hands meeting named T.G.I.F. These companywide meetings are rarely held on Fridays these days, but the name has stuck.
headline: Google Employees Tune Out Antitrust Threat as Trial Comes to a Head

abstract: Jonathan Kanter, the head of the Justice Department’s antitrust division, made his boldest move on Thursday by accusing Apple of antitrust violations.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Jonathan Kanter took over the Justice Department’s antitrust division in November 2021, the agency secured an additional $50 million to investigate monopolies, bust criminal cartels and block mergers.
headline: The Trustbuster Who Has Apple and Google in His Sights

abstract: Two new lawsuits filed by the victims’ families are the most recent attempt to hold social media companies responsible when men steeped in violent ideologies on those platforms open fire.
lead_paragraph: Ask the families of the victims of last year’s racist massacre in Buffalo what they want and one goal comes up again and again.
headline: Are Google and Meta to Blame for the Racist Massacre in Buffalo?

abstract: The barriers that keep contractors from getting hired for parties are an open secret in the events industry.
lead_paragraph: Until it’s time to plan a major event like a wedding, there is little reason for most people to know about the existence of vendor lists: the directories of caterers, florists, event planners, D.J.s and others who work with venues to put on events.
headline: Hidden Bias in the Wedding Industrial Complex

abstract: Jonathan Kanter, who was confirmed by the Senate earlier this week as the assistant attorney general for antitrust, has been a longtime behind-the-scenes player in building arguments against tech giants.
lead_paragraph: Google asked the Justice Department on Friday to investigate whether its new top antitrust official, who has represented Google rivals, needs to step back from inquiries and lawsuits against the company.
headline: Google questions if the new Justice Department antitrust boss can be impartial.
Catch up: Google’s and Microsoft’s profits soar as pandemic benefits Big Tech.

abstract: Michael F. Bennet, a Colorado Democrat, cited national security, adding to bipartisan pressure on the Chinese-owned video app.
lead_paragraph: Senator Michael Bennet, Democrat of Colorado, called on Apple and Google Thursday to remove TikTok from their app stores because of national security concerns, as bipartisan pressure on the Chinese-owned company escalates.
headline: Senator Calls on Apple and Google to Ban TikTok in App Stores

abstract: The suit claimed that the Fellowship of Friends, an obscure group based in the Sierra Nevada foothills, gained influence inside Google.
lead_paragraph: A former video producer for Google has settled a lawsuit that claimed he was fired after he complained that a religious sect had gained a foothold inside a business unit of the company.
headline: Ex-Google Contractor Settles Lawsuit Over Religious Sect

abstract: Lawyers for the Justice Department and Google as well as the judge in a monthslong trial have invoked the landmark case against Microsoft from the 1990s.
