abstract: Instagram, Facebook, Snapchat and several newcomers are betting on artificial intelligence to rejuvenate the fun, interactivity and whimsy of creating and sharing images.
lead_paragraph: Myuri Thiruna, a freelance photographer in Toronto, used to post frequently on Instagram and discuss photography with other users. But she said she had stopped two years ago, feeling “drained” by the demands of social media and the pursuit of followers and trends.
headline: To Bring Socializing Back to Social Networks, Apps Try A.I. Imagery

abstract: “LinkedIn Is Cool Now,” Businessweek declared this week. It’s also a dating app, according to Hypebae. Oh, and dating apps are for networking, The Wall Street Journal says.
lead_paragraph: “LinkedIn Is Cool Now,” Businessweek declared this week. It’s also a dating app, according to Hypebae. Oh, and dating apps are for networking, The Wall Street Journal says.
headline: What Even Is a Social Network Anymore?

abstract: Lawmakers interrogated Shou Chew over the video app’s ties to the Chinese government in a hearing that suggests the company’s problems are far from over.
lead_paragraph: The C.E.O. of TikTok was grilled for nearly five hours in Congress on Thursday about his company’s ties to China, and his testimony did little to suggest the video platform’s problems are over. The aggressive questioning of Shou Chew has only added fuel to fiery U.S.-China relations and highlighted TikTok’s awkward position as a battleground between Washington and Beijing. The Biden administration wants TikTok’s Chinese owner ByteDance to sell the company or face a ban, but hours before Mr. Chew testified, China said it opposed a sale.
headline: TikTok’s C.E.O. Struggles to Make His Case in Washington

abstract: A TikTok trend says so, but experts aren’t so sure.
lead_paragraph: In a TikTok video from May, a 21-year-old woman in London shoves a clump of lettuce leaves into a Superman mug, steeps them in hot water (with a peppermint tea bag, for taste) and drinks it. “Update, I do feel slightly drowsy,” she records herself saying from a reclined position later on. “Another update, lettuce has crack because your sis is gone,” she adds again, looking like she’s on the verge of falling asleep.
headline: Is ‘Lettuce Water’ Really the Sleep Aid of Your Dreams?

abstract: Antsy executives have a message for their employees: Plans to return to in-person work are real this time.
lead_paragraph: Executives at the investment firm TIAA are especially proud of one aspect of their back-to-work plans: The company is on only its second round of setting a return-to-office date. They first hoped to bring employees back in January, but were derailed by the Omicron variant. Now the firm is targeting March 7.
headline: Say Hello Again to the Office, Fingers Crossed

abstract: The May 21, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with James Pethokoukis. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews James Pethokoukis

abstract: Meta introduced artificially intelligent characters based on Jane Austen, Snoop Dogg and others into Instagram, Facebook and WhatsApp, as the race to lead the technology heats up.
lead_paragraph: In a WhatsApp text conversation this week, we asked Jane Austen — yes, the 19th-century British author — how she felt about Mr. Darcy, a character from one of her most famous works, “Pride and Prejudice.”
headline: Meet the A.I. Jane Austen: Meta Weaves A.I. Throughout Its Apps

abstract: An agreement at the U.N. climate summit.
lead_paragraph: After two weeks of furious debate, diplomats from nearly 200 countries at the U.N. climate summit in Dubai reached a sweeping agreement that explicitly called for “transitioning away from fossil fuels.”
headline: Thursday Briefing

abstract: In her new book, Sarah Stodola tours seaside resorts and catalogs some of the damage they can do.
lead_paragraph: Publishing a book about beaches in the season of the “beach read” is a bold and meta move, like when Kramer made a coffee-table book about coffee tables on “Seinfeld.”
headline: ‘The Last Resort’ Interrogates the Beach While Enjoying It

abstract: Why has Brazil united in rejecting last year’s insurrection, while the United States remains deeply divided over Jan. 6?
lead_paragraph: Monday marks one year since thousands of right-wing protesters draped in the colors of the Brazilian flag stormed into Brazil’s Congress, Supreme Court and presidential offices with a violent fury and the goal of overturning an election.
headline: Two Capitol Riots. Two Very Different Results.

abstract: With the slang term beating out “metaverse” and “#IStandWith,” has the publisher behind the Oxford English Dictionary lost it like the rest of us?
lead_paragraph: A year ago, the lexicographic grandees at Oxford Languages dutifully stuck out their arms and chose “vax” as the 2021 Word of the Year.
headline: The Word of the Year Goes Goblin Mode

abstract: We’ve rounded up the best of what’s leaving this month, which includes a lot of favorites, among them two Oscar winners. Catch them while you can.
lead_paragraph: Two recent (and worthy) Oscar winners lead the list of titles exiting Netflix in the United States this month, alongside two horror favorites, two action extravaganzas and one of the most beloved romantic comedies of its time. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)
headline: Stream These 10 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in August

abstract: The Wall Street giant is likely to be paid more than $100 million for its role in a bond purchase that ultimately failed to save the California bank from collapse.
lead_paragraph: As an adviser to Silicon Valley Bank, Goldman Sachs last week tried to pull off a last-minute capital raise to save the firm from collapse. But the Wall Street giant also had another role in the bank’s final days, for which it’s expected to collect a massive fee: It bought a cache of the bank’s debt in a deal that ultimately led to concerns about the bank’s viability.
headline: Goldman Sachs Eyes a Big Payout From Silicon Valley Bank Deal

abstract: The rapper, who now goes by Ye, made antisemitic remarks on Instagram and Twitter that were widely criticized. They came after he wore a “White Lives Matter” shirt at Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Ye, the rapper formerly known as Kanye West, has set off one controversy after another in the last week, first at his fashion show and then on social media, prompting accusations of racism and antisemitism.
headline: Kanye West’s Posts Land Him in Trouble on Social Media

abstract: Blocking the popular app isn’t the solution.
lead_paragraph: There’s been an average of more than one school shooting per week in the United States so far in 2023, so it’s great to see lawmakers from both parties finally reaching consensus on how to protect America’s children: Ban TikTok.
headline: There’s a Much Smarter Way to Take On TikTok

abstract: Brad Smith testified before a House committee a year after Chinese hackers infiltrated Microsoft’s technology and penetrated government networks.
lead_paragraph: Republican lawmakers questioned a senior Microsoft executive on Thursday about the company’s presence in China, about a year after Chinese hackers used the tech giant’s systems to launch a devastating hack of federal government networks.
headline: Lawmakers Question Microsoft’s President About Its Presence in China

abstract: As part of a legal settlement, Google agreed to pay $23 million to users who clicked on a search link from 2006 to 2013. Individual payments are estimated to be less than $8.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who clicked on a Google search result link from October 2006 to September 2013 is entitled to a piece — however small — of a $23 million settlement that the tech giant has agreed to pay to resolve a class-action lawsuit.
headline: Google Might Owe You Money. Here’s How to Get It.

abstract: With his plans for a virtual reality metaverse, the Facebook founder pitches himself as a cultural impresario of the internet’s future.
lead_paragraph: What do you get for the man who has everything? How about a vivid fantasy world of his own design?
headline: The Mark Zuckerberg Aesthetic

abstract: Six cryptocurrency chiefs will testify about the promises and perils of their industry.
lead_paragraph: Today, the chiefs of six cryptocurrency companies will testify before the House Financial Services Committee about the promises and perils of crypto assets. It’s the first time crypto executives have been summoned by lawmakers in this way, a sign of the industry’s maturity — and the risks that regulators see in its rise.
headline: Crypto Moguls Prepare for Capitol Hill

abstract: The world’s most complete triceratops skeleton ever found will go on display next year, displacing a beloved, if quirky, exhibit of taxidermy.
lead_paragraph: In a long corridor at the back of the Melbourne Museum, Tim Ziegler slides open one of many metal drawers. Ziegler, the collections manager of palaeontology, pulls out a pristine white box, and out of that box he deposits into his palm something that looks like a lump of shiny coal about the size of a standard green grape.
headline: The Giant Who Lives in the Melbourne Museum

abstract: Ruangrupa, an Indonesian group of collaborators, turns social experiences into art. How will they leave their mark on Documenta, which unfolds over 100 days?
lead_paragraph: For four out of every five years, Kassel is a relatively humdrum town. Its population of 217,796 inhabits a central German valley, hundreds of miles from Berlin or Munich. Its parks and palaces are Teutonic-prim. People eat their lunchtime kebabs on a plaza opposite the squat, sober Fridericianum, one of Europe’s oldest public art museums. The local football team, KSV Hessen Kassel, languishes in the fourth tier of the German league. But on the half-decade, when Kassel hosts Documenta, arguably the world’s largest exhibition of contemporary art, nearly a million visitors pour in over 100 summer days. The Fridericianum is the nucleus, but Documenta annexes the entire town — shops, gardens, warehouses, streets — leaving relics behind. A wanderer may be art-struck without warning. Once, walking by the Fulda River, I encountered a Claes Oldenburg sculpture, from a Documenta in 1982: a tremendous blue pickax planted bit-first into the soil.
headline: A Radical Collective Takes Over One of the World’s Biggest Art Shows

abstract: The iPhone maker is the first U.S. tech giant charged with breaching the European Union’s Digital Markets Act, potentially exposing it to huge fines.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s feud with global regulators escalated after the European Union on Monday charged the iPhone maker with stifling competition on its App Store, a breach that carries potentially big penalties and could upend a hugely profitable area of the tech giant’s business.
headline: Apple’s European Headache

abstract: People who study social media say the conflict between Israel and Hamas has underscored the need for better data transparency from platforms.
lead_paragraph: As the Israel-Hamas war flooded social media with violent content, false information and a seemingly limitless swell of opinions, lawmakers and users have accused platforms like TikTok and Facebook of promoting biased posts.
headline: How Bad Is Antisemitism Online? It’s Increasingly Hard to Know.

abstract: Vivek Murthy, the U.S. surgeon general, wants warning labels on the tech platforms, arguing that they are fueling a mental health crisis among teens.
lead_paragraph: Just in: The U.S. surgeon general, Vivek Murthy, called for a warning label for social media platforms in a Times Guest Essay, advising parents that the technology may be helping fuel a mental health crisis among adolescents.
headline: Is Social Media the New Tobacco?

abstract: These five novels go well with sand, sunscreen and hot afternoons. (Landlocked on a rainy day? That works, too.)
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene around the halfway mark of the latest novel by the perennial best seller Elin Hilderbrand, THE FIVE-STAR WEEKEND (Little, Brown, 384 pp., $30), in which five women engage in a sacred ritual of beach vacations: shopping. The connection between them is the recently widowed Hollis Shaw, who invited four women from different eras of her life (high school, college, minivan life and midlife) to her fabulous Nantucket summer home to celebrate friendship and, ultimately, to help Hollis, the food influencer, move into the next phase of life.
headline: To Be Enjoyed in a State of Repose, Preferably Near Water

abstract: How were you and the people you know affected when Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp were inaccessible for hours this week?
lead_paragraph: “Facebook and its family of apps, including Instagram and WhatsApp, were inaccessible for hours on Monday, taking out a vital communications platform used by billions and showcasing just how dependent the world has become on a company that is under intense scrutiny,” writes The Times.
headline: Facebook Outage

abstract: Women generally have long hours of housework and care duties on top of a job, while men have less time-sensitive chores like lawn mowing.
lead_paragraph: In countries around the world, women do more unpaid labor — housework, child and elder care, and the mental load of managing a family — than men. New research suggests it takes a health toll on many of them.
headline: Why Unpaid Labor Is More Likely to Hurt Women’s Mental Health Than Men’s

abstract: The message board site, founded in 2005, detailed its financial performance in a filing. It is the last of an early generation of social media companies to aim for a public offering.
lead_paragraph: Reddit, the community-focused message board site, filed to go public on Thursday, paving the way for it to be the first major social media company to debut on the stock market in years and a test for private companies after a drought in initial public offerings.
headline: Reddit Files to Go Public, in First Social Media I.P.O. in Years

abstract: The S&P 500 plunged nearly 9 percent in April, its worst monthly decline since March 2020, as rising interest rates and high inflation raised concerns about consumer sentiment.
lead_paragraph: April wound up being the worst month for Wall Street since the March 2020 panic over the coronavirus, capped by a plunge in stocks on Friday.
headline: Wall Street Is Battered by Rising Fear About the Economy

abstract: Social circles were shrinking even before the pandemic. Here’s what the science says about the number of close friendships we should have.
lead_paragraph: An ongoing argument my husband and I have —  which has become more contentious during the pandemic — is about how many friends we should have.
headline: How Many Friends Do You Really Need?

abstract: Shares in Netflix and Peloton soared in the early part of the pandemic. Now they’re tumbling.
lead_paragraph: The future path of the pandemic is uncertain, but investors may have already made up their minds about the prospects for companies that had prospered months earlier. Netflix and Peloton plunged late in the day yesterday, on signs that “stay at home” stocks, which were already under pressure, could take a turn for the worse as people begin to venture out again.
headline: When Pandemic Stars’ Shines Dim

abstract: Social media didn’t cause my mental illness, but it exacerbated it. Now I have found a way to quiet the noise.
lead_paragraph: I was speaking in tongues. I was lying on my side on a plastic-covered couch, my neck craned over its arm, my mother beside me consulting with a doctor, and I was speaking in tongues. Some spirit was moving through me, causing me to regurgitate all that I had seen in the years leading to this moment. This spirit was not the Lord or any other celestial being. I knew exactly what I was referring to with each word and could envision the source material as my lips pinballed through my memory. It was, to my surprise and dismay, months and months of quotes and quips I had read since the inception of the Facebook News Feed, now bubbling up from my subconscious in an inscrutable cacophony of youthspeak.
headline: When Facebook Actually Broke My Brain

abstract: The agreement calls for phasing out fossil fuels. But it also lets oil producers keep drilling and gives few specifics on how to fund a shift to greener energy.
lead_paragraph: The COP28 climate summit wrapped up a few hours ago with a compromise agreement that calls on nations to move away from fossil fuels.
headline: What’s Missing From the COP28 Climate Deal

abstract: Google, Apple and others were warned that they must comply with a new law, which would make them more vulnerable to the Kremlin’s censorship demands.
lead_paragraph: As Russia attacks Ukraine, the authorities in Moscow are intensifying a censorship campaign at home by squeezing some of the world’s biggest tech companies.
headline: Russia Intensifies Censorship Campaign, Pressuring Tech Giants

abstract: Christine Wilson, the sole Republican commissioner at the F.T.C., criticized Lina Khan, the Democratic chair of the agency, accusing her of an “abuse of power.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Christine Wilson, the sole Republican commissioner on the Federal Trade Commission, said on Tuesday that she would soon resign and criticized Lina Khan, the Democratic chair of the agency, accusing her of an “abuse of power.”
headline: Republican F.T.C. Commissioner Says She Plans to Resign

abstract: The market for selling goods in real time online is relatively small, but a number of start-ups and big tech names are betting American consumers will catch on.
lead_paragraph: On a warm spring evening in New York, dozens of people gathered on a rooftop in Midtown Manhattan to sip fruity cocktails and chat. Shortly after the happy hour began, a woman stepped away from the crowd and went to work.
headline: The Companies Trying to Make Live Shopping a Thing in the U.S.

abstract: Hear tracks by Bad Bunny, Sparks, Anohni and the Johnsons and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
headline: Blur Surprises With a Reflection on Fame, and 9 More New Songs

abstract: Where we’re heading tomorrow, next year and beyond.
lead_paragraph: In today’s A.I. newsletter, the last in our five-part series, I look at where artificial intelligence may be headed in the years to come.
headline: What’s the Future for A.I.?

abstract: The social media app known for its short-form videos will now allow users to create posts that contain only words, competing with Threads and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: TikTok users can now post text-only content, a departure for the social media app known for its short videos.
headline: TikTok Introduces Text-Only Posts

abstract: Andrew J. Ries disarms us with an inventive variety crossword.
lead_paragraph: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Everyone who enjoys Thursday themes and Saturday puns in daily puzzles should be delving into Sunday variety puzzles, especially cryptic crosswords and puns and anagrams, or “Pandas.” This grid is a perfect example: It’s by a reliably excellent constructor of daily puzzles, and it’s full of inventive wordplay draped on a structure of anagrams that helps us fill in the blanks on the really tough stuff.
headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams

abstract: Regulators are examining whether X violated a new European law that requires large social media companies to stop the spread of illegal content, disinformation and other harmful material.
lead_paragraph: European Union regulators on Thursday opened an inquiry into X, the social media platform owned by Elon Musk, over the prevalence of gory videos and images, terrorism content and other illicit material it is carrying related to the Israel-Hamas war.
headline: E.U. Probes Elon Musk’s X Platform Over Violent Israel-Hamas War Content

abstract: The past decade has been one long party for tech. Where we go from here isn’t so clear.
lead_paragraph: We are in an odd moment for technology. Can you feel it? The powerful forces of unstoppable change and tech wealth are rolling along, but mixed in there is a shred of something else: doubt.
headline: An Unsteady Moment for Tech

abstract: The social network wrongly bowed to government demands to take down content in the countries, employees said, in more signs of internal dissent.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When India’s government ordered Facebook and other tech companies to take down posts critical of its handling of the coronavirus pandemic in April, the social network complied on some posts.
headline: India and Israel Inflame Facebook’s Fights With Its Own Employees

abstract: On Instagram, Snapchat and Tiktok, researchers were able to find graphic posts, even with the apps’ sensitivity features turned on.
lead_paragraph: Violent, distressing imagery related to the conflict between Hamas and Israel, including graphic posts showing dead children and adults, are easily accessible to young users on platforms such as Instagram, researchers have found.
headline: A New Report Documents How Easily Children Can Access Graphic Images of the War

abstract: WilmerHale, the law firm investigating Sam Altman, could present its findings to the company’s board as soon as next month. Mr. Altman was reinstated as chief executive.
lead_paragraph: WilmerHale, a prominent U.S. law firm, is close to wrapping up a detailed review of OpenAI’s chief executive, Sam Altman, and his ouster from the artificial intelligence start-up late last year, two people with knowledge of the proceedings said.
headline: Inquiry Into Ouster of OpenAI’s Chief Executive Nears End

abstract: Less isolation didn’t mean a return to normalcy. Albums with big feelings and room for catharsis made the most powerful connections.
lead_paragraph: The past year was awash in recorded music — not only the stuck-at-home recordings that musicians occupied themselves with when touring evaporated during the pandemic, but also many albums that had been made before the lockdowns but had been shelved in hopes of some return to normalcy. The albums that resonated most with me during 2021 were songs of reflection and revelation, often dealing with traumas and crises, transfigured through music.
headline: Best Albums of 2021

abstract: Hollywood is about to get even more phony!
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the 2002 movie “Simone,” Al Pacino plays a director whose star, played by Winona Ryder, walks out on him after saying her trailer on set isn’t grand enough.
headline: Watch Out for the Fake Tom Cruise

abstract: In partnership with his longtime collaborator, Dave Free, the greatest rapper of his generation is pushing himself — commercially and creatively — onto unexpected terrain.
lead_paragraph: Showtime. A bright light illumes an ethereal white curtain, and what sounds like a chorus of angels sings: “I hope you find some peace of mind in this lifetime/I hope you find some paradise.” A troupe of black-and-white-clad dancers march in formation on a catwalk. The dancers swing their arms, clapping in time to a string-heavy prelude. Quick-fast, thousands pull out their cellphones, transforming London’s O2 Arena into a starry cosmos.
headline: Kendrick Lamar’s New Chapter: Raw, Intimate and Unconstrained

abstract: After months of talks, the activist investor Nelson Peltz is jockeying for a director position at the entertainment giant as he pushes for a series of changes.
lead_paragraph: Disney already faces enormous challenges, including ballooning costs at its streaming service and unclear C.E.O. succession plans. Now it faces a proxy fight from Nelson Peltz’s Trian, the activist investment firm known for taking on blue-chip companies like Procter & Gamble.
headline: Disney Braces for a Fight Over Its Board

abstract: Christophe Honoré’s latest work, for the Paris stage, is part of a recent wave of stories in France about the complex aftereffects of social mobility.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French director Christophe Honoré, best known for films including “Love Songs” and “Sorry Angel,” has been making exceptional work in recent years — and international audiences have been missing out on it. The reason? It’s happening on theater stages in his home country.
headline: A Director Returns (Uncomfortably) to His Working-Class Roots

abstract: The Feb. 28, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Stephan J. Guyenet. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Stephan J. Guyenet

abstract: Part 1 of our weeklong series.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that will teach you about artificial intelligence, especially the new breed of chatbots like ChatGPT — all in only five days.
headline: How to Become an Expert on A.I.

abstract: A board member who was part of Sam Altman’s ouster as chief executive joined a majority of the company’s staff in calling for the decision’s reversal.
lead_paragraph: The future of OpenAI is in jeopardy after more than 700 of its 770 employees signed a letter on Monday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled at the high-profile artificial intelligence start-up.
headline: OpenAI Staff Threatens Exodus, Jeopardizing Company’s Future

abstract: Is Illumina, a gene-sequencing powerhouse, trying to speed innovation in the field of cancer blood tests or thwart it with an acquisition?
lead_paragraph: Illumina, the leading maker of gene-sequencing machines, is tiny compared with the tech giants of Silicon Valley. But like Google and Facebook, Illumina now finds itself in the cross hairs of antitrust enforcers in the United States and Europe.
headline: A Gene Sequencing Pioneer Battles Over What It Can Buy

abstract: In a season of layoffs and cutbacks, techies seized on the second installment of the Denis Villeneuve-directed science-fiction epic by taking over movie theaters.
lead_paragraph: In a top-floor atrium in downtown San Francisco on Thursday evening, tech workers from Google, Slack, X and Mozilla mingled next to a pair of cardboard cutouts of Timothée Chalamet and Zendaya.
headline: ‘Dune: Part Two’ Gives Sci-Fi-Obsessed Silicon Valley a Reason to Party

abstract: The culture of medicine means no crying, no sleeping, no making mistakes. And no getting help.
lead_paragraph: Certain memories are seared into physicians’ psyches. The chirp of the pager. Driving home half asleep in a postcall haze. The strangest objects found in human orifices (cockroach in the ear). The most hours we continuously stayed awake. Delivering our first baby, watching our first patient die. These are all rites of passage. I’ve found it’s easy to discuss the funny memories, but the disturbing ones are harder. Even with the closest of friends, recounting the tough moments feels like passing on a burden.
headline: Why So Many Doctors Treat Their Mental Health in Secret

abstract: The Art Dealers Association of America fair at the Park Avenue Armory offers 78 international galleries with blue-chip booths, along with artisans rescued from the margins.
lead_paragraph: The world is in tumult but for the moment, the business of art marches on. Artists go to their studios, museums keep their doors open and art critics try to make sense of it all. Meanwhile, the Art Dealers Association of America (ADAA), a members-only organization known for its blue-chip brands, has assembled for its annual fair.
headline: The Art Show Highlights Masters — and Artists Under the Radar

abstract: Idalia is barreling toward Florida.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Idalia intensified overnight and is now a Category 4 storm heading toward Florida’s Gulf Coast. It has wind speeds of 130 miles an hour and is expected to make landfall around 8 a.m Eastern, bringing catastrophic waves and potentially submerging the coast in up to 16 feet of flooding. You can track the storm’s path here.
headline: A Category 4 Hurricane

abstract: Truth Social, the social network started by former President Donald J. Trump, has struggled to attract large brands.
lead_paragraph: Between posts about conspiracy theories and right-wing grievances was an unusual advertisement: a photo of former President Donald J. Trump holding a $1,000 bill made of gold, which he was apparently offering free to supporters.
headline: On Trump’s Social Network: Ads for Miracle Cures, Scams and Fake Merchandise

abstract: More than three dozen states have come together in a lawsuit against Meta, the company behind Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp.
lead_paragraph: A historic set of new lawsuits, filed by more than three dozen states, accuses Meta, the country’s largest social media company, of illegally luring children onto its platforms and hooking them on its products.
headline: A Strategy to Treat Big Tech Like Big Tobacco

abstract: Tracking what may be planned in the coming days could become even more difficult as the groups take to lesser-known networks and apps that can’t be easily monitored.
lead_paragraph: On the Telegram messaging app, there were calls for armed marches on state capitols and the offices of tech companies like Google, Facebook and Twitter, starting on Jan. 16.
headline: Fringe Groups Splinter Online After Facebook and Twitter Bans

abstract: After a year of pandemic life, the superhero show’s inventive premise — television as both escape and prison — is all too relatable.
lead_paragraph: Even allowing for the pop culture invincibility of anything Marvel, Disney+’s “WandaVision” is an odd sort of superhero show to become a phenomenon. Why, of all the comic-book premises, would America in 2021 be captivated by a story about someone escaping inside classic TV as a refuge from trauma?
headline: ‘WandaVision’ Lives Inside TV. Just Like We Do.

abstract: In the newly created role, Meredith Whittaker will guide policy and strategy for the messaging app and work to expand its business.
lead_paragraph: Signal, the encrypted messaging app, has tapped Meredith Whittaker, a former adviser to the Federal Trade Commission chair and an artificial intelligence expert who protested Google’s use of the technology for military projects, as its president.
headline: Signal, the Encrypted Messaging App, Appoints a President

abstract: The nonprofit helped make the Berkshires a destination for culture lovers under Julianne Boyd, who is retiring.
lead_paragraph: The Barrington Stage Company announced Wednesday that Alan Paul, the associate artistic director of the Shakespeare Theater Company in Washington, will become its new artistic director, taking over the nonprofit theater company in Western Massachusetts known for producing notable new musicals and popular revivals and helping turn the Berkshires into a cultural oasis.
headline: Barrington Stage Company Names Alan Paul as Artistic Director

abstract: After a judge slammed the F.T.C.’s original lawsuit, regulators returned with a more detailed case accusing the platform of being a monopoly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission took new aim at Facebook on Thursday, beefing up its accusations that the company was a monopoly that illegally crushed competition, in an attempt to overcome the skepticism of a federal judge who threw out the agency’s original case two months ago.
headline: U.S. Revives Facebook Suit, Adding Details to Back Claim of a Monopoly

abstract: Saying it wants “to find the right balance” with the technology, the social network will delete the face scan data of more than one billion users.
lead_paragraph: Facebook plans to shut down its decade-old facial recognition system this month, deleting the face scan data of more than one billion users and effectively eliminating a feature that has fueled privacy concerns, government investigations, a class-action lawsuit and regulatory woes.
headline: Facebook, Citing Societal Concerns, Plans to Shut Down Facial Recognition System

abstract: The company will not be allowed to import products that infringe on Sonos patents, including smart speakers, video streaming devices, and some computers and phones.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google infringed on five audio technology patents held by the speaker manufacturer Sonos and is not allowed to import products that violate Sonos’s intellectual property into the United States, a trade court ruled on Thursday.
headline: Google Infringed on Sonos Speaker Technology, Trade Court Rules

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing

abstract: Over 800 people were arrested in France after a fresh wave of nighttime protests over the fatal police shooting of a 17-year-old. Many protesters were teenagers, too, officials said.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France urgently appealed to parents on Friday as the country braced for another night of unrest over the fatal police shooting of a 17-year-old, with French officials saying that the protests were driven mostly by angry young people and coordinated on social media.
headline: Bracing for New Night of Unrest, Macron Urges Parents to Keep Teenagers Home

abstract: Those who can go viral do. And they may also teach a class or two while they’re at it.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Loren sat down in front of a camera, blue and pink lights glowing behind her. From her living room to the screens of more than 8,300 students, she started to explain what a “meme mentality” was. This lesson, on cultivating a relatable online image, was part of Ms. Loren’s class on how to master — or even just understand — TikTok, currently the most downloaded app in the world.
headline: TikTok Class Is in Session

abstract: Why is British inflation so high?
lead_paragraph: Last month, the White House Council of Economic Advisers released a note comparing inflation rates among the Group of 7 — the major advanced economies. This is trickier than it might seem, because different countries measure consumer prices in different ways. In particular, the U.S. Consumer Price Index treats housing differently from the corresponding official measures of European nations, in ways that have caused U.S. inflation to seem more persistent than in some sense it really is. When the C.E.A. produced comparable numbers, they looked like this:
headline: This Green and Expensive Land

abstract: There were always two competing major theories about the 2022 midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: There were always two competing major theories about the 2022 midterm elections.
headline: Looking Back at Who Was Right About This Weird Election

abstract: Most legal experts say Twitter has the upper hand. But Musk revels in brinkmanship.
lead_paragraph: Now that Elon Musk has signaled his intent to walk away from his $44 billion offer to buy Twitter, the fate of the influential social media network will be determined by what may be an epic court battle, involving months of expensive litigation and high-stakes negotiations by elite lawyers on both sides.
headline: What’s Next in the Elon Musk-Twitter Saga? A Court Battle

abstract: The site asks its oversight body to rule on Trump. But its justice system doesn’t work for everyone.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Facebook Invokes Its ‘Supreme Court’

abstract: In a new book, Clare Carlisle considers the powerful partnership between the Victorian novelist and the de facto husband who tended her career.
lead_paragraph: We could all use a hype man like George Henry Lewes.
headline: George Eliot’s Scandalous Answer to ‘The Marriage Question’

abstract: And he has some ideas about what we should wear.
lead_paragraph: Having mixed feelings about return to office? Not sure what to wear? Ralph Lauren has a solution for that.
headline: Ralph Lauren Invites Everyone to Return to (His) Office

abstract: As Mr. Musk takes over Twitter, he is emulating some of the actions of Mr. Zuckerberg, who leads Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has positioned himself as an unconventional businessman. When he agreed to buy Twitter this year, he declared he would make the social media service a place for unfettered free speech, reversing many of its rules and allowing banned users like former President Donald J. Trump to return.
headline: Elon Musk Takes a Page Out of Mark Zuckerberg’s Social Media Playbook

abstract: Guy Ritchie’s latest action-comedy puts Jason Statham and Aubrey Plaza in the middle of a rote heist story.
lead_paragraph: The running joke of Jason Statham’s remarkably sturdy stardom — his bankability as an action lead has been running for over two decades — is that he always plays the same character: a stoic, unbreakable enforcer who offers the occasional gravel-toned wisecrack. The director Guy Ritchie’s own trademark, the stylized British crime comedy, has found its most frequent muse in this archetype, which Ritchie has helped shape in Statham ever since they both broke out with “Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels” (1999).
headline: ‘Operation Fortune: Ruse de Guerre’ Review: The Getaway Car Is Stuck on Cruise

abstract: This month’s picks include two disturbing looks at domestic dysfunction, and — on a brighter note — a portrait of a brilliant Leonard Bernstein protégée.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
headline: Three Great Documentaries to Stream

abstract: The Adani Group, the Indian conglomerate run by Asia’s wealthiest man, has gone on the offensive to fight fraud allegations by an American investor.
lead_paragraph: The Adani Group, one of India’s most powerful and prominent industrial conglomerates, is continuing to reel from accusations by a short seller that it had perpetrated stock manipulation and fraud in “the largest con in corporate history.”
headline: A Short Seller Costs an Indian Giant Billions

abstract: The outage disrupted the digital lives of small-business owners, politicians, aid workers and others. But for some, it was a welcome reprieve.
lead_paragraph: For more than five hours on Monday, the world got a taste of life without Facebook and its apps.
headline: Facebook’s Apps Went Down. The World Saw How Much It Runs on Them.

abstract: Accused of violating antitrust laws, Live Nation Entertainment faces a fight that could reshape the multibillion-dollar live music industry.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Thursday sued Live Nation Entertainment, the concert giant that owns Ticketmaster, asking a court to break up the company over claims it illegally maintained a monopoly in the live entertainment industry.
headline: U.S. Calls for Breakup of Ticketmaster Owner

abstract: As tech companies cut costs and move to remote work, their left-behind office furniture has become part of a booming trade.
lead_paragraph: Brandi Susewitz touched the curved stitching on a pair of bright red Arne Jacobsen Egg Chairs and announced they were worth around $5,000 each. The chairs were in pristine condition, perched in the reception area of the software company Sitecore’s office in downtown San Francisco.
headline: The Furniture Hustlers of Silicon Valley

abstract: Once an anti-vaccine stronghold, Marin County has become an unlikely champion of Covid-19 shots. But will it last?
lead_paragraph: The pocket of California that has emerged as a leader in Covid-19 vaccinations may come as a surprise.
headline: The Highest Vaccination Rate in California

abstract: Meta’s $300 smart glasses look cool but lack a killer app, and they offer a glimpse into a future with even less privacy and more distraction.
lead_paragraph: For the past two weeks, I’ve been using a new camera to secretly snap photos and record videos of strangers in parks, on trains, inside stores and at restaurants. (I promise it was all in the name of journalism.) I wasn’t hiding the camera, but I was wearing it, and no one noticed.
headline: How Meta’s New Face Camera Heralds a New Age of Surveillance

abstract: In an internal memo meant to pre-empt a “60 Minutes” interview, Facebook defended itself and said that social media was not a primary cause of polarization.
lead_paragraph: [Watch the Facebook hearing live.]
headline: Whistle-Blower to Accuse Facebook of Contributing to Jan. 6 Riot, Memo Says

abstract: As more and more workplaces pause or end the expectation of three days a week in the office, a large-scale return may never be on the horizon.
lead_paragraph: The conundrum facing executives nationwide these days is one familiar to anyone who has ever planned a birthday gathering: “It’s really hard to get anybody to come to a party if everybody R.S.V.P.s maybe,” said Zach Dunn, an expert on hybrid work and founder of the workplace management company Robin.
headline: The Rules for Hybrid Work Were Always Made Up

abstract: Live Nation Entertainment, the concert giant that owns Ticketmaster, faces a fight that could reshape the multibillion-dollar live music industry.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department and a group of states plan to sue Live Nation Entertainment, the concert giant that owns Ticketmaster, as soon as Thursday, accusing it of illegally maintaining a monopoly in the live entertainment industry, said three people familiar with the matter.
headline: U.S. Plans to Sue Ticketmaster Owner, Accusing It of Defending a Monopoly

abstract: The world has made real progress on climate change.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the journalist David Wallace-Wells explored a worst-case scenario for climate change: one in which the planet warmed by as much as 5 degrees Celsius by 2100 — causing widespread extreme weather, economic collapse, famine and war.
headline: The Climate’s Improved Future

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Boosters, 1619 Project, Thanksgiving: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing

abstract: The prominent A.I. start-up is also joining an industrywide effort to spot content made with artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: As experts warn that images, audio and video generated by artificial intelligence could influence the fall elections, OpenAI is releasing a tool designed to detect content created by its own popular image generator, DALL-E. But the prominent A.I. start-up acknowledges that this tool is only a small part of what will be needed to fight so-called deepfakes in the months and years to come.
headline: OpenAI Releases ‘Deepfake’ Detector to Disinformation Researchers

abstract: Agendar una actividad como pasear con algún viejo amigo, o un almuerzo con excolegas es una buena oportunidad para reconectar y mejorar la comunicación.
lead_paragraph: Esta es la sexta entrega del Reto de la felicidad en siete días de la sección Well. Para empezar este reto puedes visitar el siguiente enlace.
headline: Día 6: No canceles esos planes

abstract: Also, Biden said NATO’s support for Ukraine “will not waver.” Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Price Index — the most widely used measure of inflation in the U.S. economy — climbed 3 percent in the year through June, according to new government data. That is sharply lower than the 9 percent rate at its peak a year ago, offering hope for both consumers and businesses that the recent era of inflated prices will soon be over.
headline: Inflation Has Cooled Significantly

abstract: It is also disabling features in its maps app “as a safety and precautionary measure for Ukrainian citizens.”
lead_paragraph: Apple said on Tuesday that it had paused the sales of its products in Russia and taken several other steps in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
headline: Apple pauses sales of its products in Russia.

abstract: Western technology companies, recently freed from sanctions, should grant full access to Iranians.
lead_paragraph: Mahsa Amini died, but the hashtag #MahsaAmini lives on.
headline: Big Tech Should Support the Iranian People, Not the Regime

abstract: Nick Clegg, a former deputy prime minister, has shaped the company’s handling of Donald Trump at every turn.
lead_paragraph: When Facebook barred President Donald J. Trump from its service in January, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive, defended the decision in a Facebook post the morning after the siege of the Capitol. But the first draft was written the night before by Nick Clegg, a former British deputy prime minister who leads the company’s public affairs.
headline: British Political Veteran Steers Facebook’s Trump Decision

abstract: Gala-goers, start thinking green.
lead_paragraph: After the pop culture bonanza of this summer’s “Barbie,” the hoo-ha surrounding the live action remake of “The Little Mermaid” and the attention paid to anything in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, observers could be forgiven for hearing the title of the next Costume Institute blockbuster at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and think they were in for a Disney spectacle. After all, it is called “Sleeping Beauties: Reawakening Fashion.” And those princess costumes have been very influential.
headline: The Next Costume Institute Fashion Blockbuster Is Revealed

abstract: Many businesses have adopted policies to diversify hiring but the Supreme Court’s ruling to end the policy in universities endangers those efforts.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision on Thursday to strike down affirmative action at colleges and universities sent shock waves throughout higher education. But the effects of the 6-3 ruling, which found that race-conscious admissions programs were unlawful, promise to go much wider.
headline: Why Corporate America Is Worried About Affirmative Action

abstract: Downtown lunch spots that rely on catering to white-collar professionals are rethinking their business model as more employees work from home.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tough time for companies that cater to the needs of office workers. For some, like downtown lunch spots that rely on servicing white-collar professionals, remote work options could pose an existential risk.
headline: Shift to Remote Work Puts Pressure on Chains Like Sweetgreen

abstract: James Ijames’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play, set at a Southern barbecue, gets its first in-person production at the Public Theater.
lead_paragraph: I could begin with the ghost. Or the famous existential question.
headline: ‘Fat Ham’ Review: Dismantling Shakespeare to Liberate a Gay Black ‘Hamlet’

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing

abstract: The meta-musical, which won the Tony Award this year and the Pulitzer Prize in 2020, announced it would close on Jan. 15.
lead_paragraph: “A Strange Loop,” the winner of this year’s Tony Award for best musical, will close on Broadway on Jan. 15, after a short run that reflects the industry’s ongoing pandemic-related struggles and the challenges of marketing an unconventional musical that wrestles with complex themes.
headline: ‘A Strange Loop,’ Which Won Best Musical, Will End Broadway Run

abstract: As “Some Like It Hot” and “Ain’t No Mo’” head to Broadway, following runs of “Tootsie” and “Mrs. Doubtfire,” 10 artists reflect on an enduring trope and how it works, or doesn’t, today.
lead_paragraph: Men in dresses are in vogue on Broadway. Just before the pandemic, there was “Tootsie,” and just after the shutdown, “Mrs. Doubtfire.” Now comes “Some Like It Hot,” a musical adaptation of the classic caper comedy about two men who dress as women to escape the mob.
headline: Some Like It Not: Are Men in Dresses Still Funny?

abstract: Silicon Valley is losing one of its most visible, outspoken and powerful women. Any gains have been incremental at best.
lead_paragraph: When Sheryl Sandberg said this week that she was resigning as chief operating officer of Meta, she also reflected on her legacy as a woman in tech.
headline: What Sheryl Sandberg’s Exit Reveals About Women’s Progress in Tech

abstract: Countries and companies are in a fight between those that want to excavate minerals used in electric vehicles and others that warn the cost is too high.
lead_paragraph: Surging demand for metals used in electric vehicle batteries has kicked off an international race to mine the deep seas. And there are no rules.
headline: Why Deep-Sea Mining Is the Next Battleground in the Energy Transition

abstract: Citadel Securities is taking its first outside investment from the Silicon Valley firms Sequoia and Paradigm.
lead_paragraph: Citadel Securities, the huge market maker founded by Ken Griffin, announced today that it had sold a stake to the venture capital firms Sequoia and Paradigm for $1.15 billion. The deal, which values Citadel Securities at about $22 billion, will unite an established financial player with two top Silicon Valley growth investors. It’s the first outside investment in Griffin’s firm.
headline: Ken Griffin’s Trading Powerhouse Gains New Partners

abstract: This word has appeared in 39 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word adieu has appeared in 39 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 2, 2023, in “One Last Chance to Be Lazy” by Steven Kurutz:
headline: Word of the Day: adieu

abstract: The fall of Sam Bankman-Fried helps us see the movement’s vices, but that shouldn’t blind us to its virtues, either.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Times Opinion’s Holiday Giving Guide 2022. Read more about the guide in a note from Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.
headline: The Big Thing Effective Altruism (Still) Gets Right

abstract: After my partner was brutally beaten on the street, I became one of the many thousands of Americans caring for someone with post-traumatic stress disorder — and our relationship changed forever.
lead_paragraph: The night our world changed, I was in a copper baron’s palatial Adirondack home, writing about the history of the poorhouse. That afternoon, with the stained-glass reflections of autumn colors blazing through my window, I pored over an 1832 vendue contract auctioning the care of three female paupers to the lowest bidder in Sandown, N.H.
headline: His PTSD, and My Struggle to Live With It

abstract: The blockbuster deal for the video game maker came together quickly and opportunistically.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s $68.7 billion deal to buy Activision Blizzard is a blockbuster bid to transform the tech giant’s present and its future. If completed, it would be Microsoft’s largest-ever deal and the biggest all-cash acquisition in history. For such a momentous deal, it came together relatively quickly, we can report.
headline: How Microsoft Bought Activision Blizzard

abstract: YouTube and Facebook fared better in the experiment.
lead_paragraph: TikTok failed to catch 90 percent of ads featuring false and misleading messages about elections, while YouTube and Facebook identified and blocked most of them, according to an experiment run by misinformation researchers, the results of which were released on Friday.
headline: TikTok failed to stop most misleading political ads in a test run by researchers.

abstract: How a routine-looking software update became a major confrontation in the long-running conflict between two of the world’s largest tech companies.
lead_paragraph: Recently, Apple released a seemingly innocuous software update: a new privacy feature that would explicitly ask iPhone users whether an app should be allowed to track them across the other apps and sites that they use.
headline: Apple vs. Facebook

abstract: Pills and suppositories that promise to balance the vaginal microbiome are lining drugstore shelves and online marketplaces. But are they backed by science?
lead_paragraph: Before there were vaginal probiotics, there was the yogurt douche. In the 1970s, a common home remedy for yeast infections and other irritating ailments was to soak a tampon in plain, unsweetened yogurt and insert it into the vagina. The same live bacteria that make yogurt beneficial for the gut, the thinking went, might also be good for the vagina.
headline: Can Probiotics Boost Vaginal Health?

abstract: The lawsuit is the first time that the Federal Trade Commission under its chair, Lina Khan, has taken Amazon to court.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission sued Amazon on Wednesday, accusing it of illegally inducing consumers to sign up for its Prime service and then hindering them from canceling the subscription, in the most aggressive action against the company to date by the agency’s chair, Lina Khan.
headline: F.T.C. Accuses Amazon of Tricking Users Into Subscribing to Prime

abstract: Figuring out the root cause of our lack of inspiration can help us make better choices in how we spend our time, experts say.
lead_paragraph: At least once every weekend, one of my kids — ages 8 and 11 — lumbers over to me and moans, “I’m boooooored. There’s nothing to do.” When I remind them of all the things they could try (read a book, make an art project, play the piano) they glare at me as if I’ve just asked them to do 150 burpees and then lope off again, shoulders slumped.
headline: How to Be Bored, and What You Can Learn From It

abstract: Climate change’s effects are already unequal.
lead_paragraph: India has contributed little to climate change: Home to 18 percent of the world’s population, it has emitted just 3 percent of planet-warming greenhouse gases.
headline: A Hotter World

abstract: The lending giant’s shares jumped on the news that it is buying First Republic. But investors are watching to see if the deal ends the regional banking crisis.
lead_paragraph: First Republic is no more: Regulators seized the embattled lender overnight and sold it to JPMorgan Chase. What is now America’s second-biggest bank failure, after the 2008 collapse of Washington Mutual, means that 84 bank branches that closed as First Republic locations on Friday will reopen on Monday as Chase branches.
headline: JPMorgan Chase Returns to a Familiar Role: Bank Rescuer

abstract: Then, Mark Zuckerberg rethinks Meta’s strategy.
lead_paragraph: It’s acing standardized tests, building websites and hiring TaskRabbits — GPT-4 is “equal parts fascinating and terrifying.” OpenAI has released its latest model, alongside A.I. announcements from Meta, Google and other industry players. The A.I. arms race is only accelerating.
headline: GPT-4 Is Here, and the Group Chat Bank Run

abstract: It’s a big job being asked to symbolize an entire nation’s ideals, as the new Captain America is about to find out. But is he the best person for the job?
lead_paragraph: If you’ve encountered Captain America only in the Marvel movies, it may surprise you to learn that in the comic books, Steve Rogers isn’t the only person who has picked up the shield and called himself (or herself) “Captain America.” There have been dozens of reboots, retcons and alternate universes in Marvel Comics’ publishing history, and along the way over a dozen heroes have donned the red, white and blue. More often than not, the stories about these characters weigh one big issue: What does it take to symbolize an entire nation’s ideals?
headline: ‘The Falcon and the Winter Soldier’ Season 1, Episode 2 Recap: Freedom Isn’t Free

abstract: Kimmel reminisced about the days when the social media app was “just a safe place to lose your house in a pyramid scheme.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
headline: Jimmy Kimmel Misses the Old Facebook

abstract: The decision could give the government power to force Google and other tech companies to limit access to “Glory to Hong Kong,” an anthem of 2019 protests.
lead_paragraph: A Hong Kong court on Wednesday granted a government request to ban a popular pro-democracy anthem, raising further concerns about free speech in the city.
headline: Hong Kong Court Bans Democracy Song, Calling It a ‘Weapon’

abstract: President Yoweri Museveni accused the company of “arrogance” after it removed fake accounts and pages linked to his re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda has blocked Facebook from operating in his country, just days after the social media company removed fake accounts linked to his government ahead of a hotly contested general election set to take place on Thursday.
headline: Uganda Blocks Facebook Ahead of Contentious Election

abstract: This year’s super mega has 782 entries.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Puzzlemania features the largest crossword we’ve ever done — a 67 by 41 grid with a whopping 782 entries. While the print issue provides a slip sheet with all the clues, we’ve reproduced it in digital form in case you lose it or want another way to solve. We suggest ctrl + f the number of the clue you need for ease of use.
headline: Super Mega 2022: Clues

abstract: Even as more companies have become outspoken on social causes, the reaction by corporate America on Friday after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade was relatively muted.
lead_paragraph: Even as more companies have become outspoken on social causes, the reaction by corporate America on Friday after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade was relatively muted.
headline: Here’s how companies are reacting to the Supreme Court decision on abortion.

abstract: Investors will listen to the Federal Reserve chair’s speech on Thursday for clues on interest-rate moves, as the Israel-Hamas conflict drives up oil prices.
lead_paragraph: The Middle East crisis has put markets on edge, pushing up oil prices and driving demand for safe havens, like gold. A day after President Biden’s whirlwind trip to Israel, investors are focused again on their chief concern: whether stubbornly elevated inflation will force central banks to keep interest rates higher for even longer.
headline: Markets Look to Powell Amid Rising Tensions in the Middle East

abstract: Beijing unveiled an annual economic target in line with last year’s, as it looks to refocus on strategically important sectors.
lead_paragraph: China announced an official growth target of about 5 percent on Tuesday that’s already looking hard to pull off. The world’s second-biggest economy is facing headwinds, from a consumer slowdown to weak investor confidence and a trade war with the West.
headline: Is China’s Era of High Growth Over?

abstract: Lawyers for the failed crypto exchange told a bankruptcy judge they expected to pay creditors in full.
lead_paragraph: When the cryptocurrency exchange FTX declared bankruptcy about 15 months ago, it seemed few customers would recover much money or crypto from the platform. As John Ray III, who took over as chief executive during the bankruptcy, put it, “At the end of the day, we’re not going to be able to recover all the losses here.” He was countering Sam Bankman-Fried’s repeated claims that he could get every customer their money back.
headline: What Happens to FTX Clawback Cases if the Company Repays Its Creditors?

abstract: Brace yourself for an onslaught of devices that connect your eyes to the digital world.
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to avoid sounding vulgar, somehow, when discussing the future of facial computing. There is something inescapably crude, isn’t there, about the prospect of everyone walking around with computers on our faces?
headline: Apple and Facebook Are Coming for Your Face Next

abstract: Social media users voiced worries about a move by Meta to use information from public Instagram and Facebook posts to train its A.I. But the scraping has already begun. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Meta announced that it was going to expand its artificial intelligence services around the world, and the company let users in Europe know that it would use their public information to train its A.I. services starting on June 26.
headline: Can I Opt Out of Meta’s A.I. Scraping on Instagram and Facebook? Sort Of.

abstract: The [DATE] episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Agnes Callard. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Agnes Callard

abstract: Since President Vladimir V. Putin launched his attack on Ukraine, many Russians have taken to social media to express their anger.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian government said it was partially limiting access to Facebook for restricting some pro-Kremlin news media accounts, a move that could make it harder for Russians to share their anger over their country’s invasion of Ukraine.
headline: Russia says it will limit access to Facebook, a major platform for dissent.

abstract: But many of them know how not to get burned.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, when researchers at Boston College and Harvard set out to review all of the existing research on educational apps for kids in preschool through third grade, they were surprised to find that even though there are hundreds of thousands of apps out there that are categorized as educational, there were only 36 studies of educational apps in the databases they searched. “That is not a strong evidence base on which to completely redesign an entire schooling system,” Josh Gilbert, one of the co-authors of the study, told me over the phone.
headline: Most Teachers Know They’re Playing With Fire When They Use Tech in the Classroom

abstract: The situation serves as a reminder that partisan polarization in Washington is not symmetrical.
lead_paragraph: Two basic facts are central to understanding why the federal government may shut down on Sunday morning:
headline: A Government Shutdown Looms

abstract: By asking the singer Bertrand Cantat to contribute to his latest show, the director Wajdi Mouawad has overshadowed his own production.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Traumatized individuals reach a standoff. They talk past each other; the more powerful party is too hurt to mitigate the pain they inflict. Ultimately, no one wins.
headline: A Play With Music by a Convicted Murderer: Was It Worth It?

abstract: A new kind of corporate supercourt is looking for legitimacy.
lead_paragraph: They meet mostly on Zoom, but I prefer to picture the members of this court, or council, or whatever it is, wearing reflective suits and hovering via hologram around a glowing table. The members include two people who were reportedly on presidential shortlists for the U.S. Supreme Court, along with a Yemeni Nobel Peace Prize laureate, a British Pulitzer winner, Colombia’s leading human rights lawyer and a former prime minister of Denmark. The 20 of them come, in all, from 18 countries on six continents, and speak 27 languages among them.
headline: Trump Wants Back on Facebook. This Star-Studded Jury Might Let Him.

abstract: Arvind Krishna is trying to stay in touch with the company’s roots as he confronts today’s challenges.
lead_paragraph: In a tech industry dominated by Apple, Alphabet, Meta and Microsoft, it can be easy to forget that much of the humdrum work that makes screens flicker, servers hum and businesses run is performed by companies that rarely make the headlines, companies that have been gradually shaping the computer business for decades, companies like IBM.
headline: An Optimist at the Helm of IBM

abstract: Lawmakers should proceed cautiously when altering the rules governing the internet.
lead_paragraph: The nicest thing you can say about the Health Misinformation Act, proposed in July by the Democratic senators Amy Klobuchar and Ben Ray Luján, is that it means well. The internet has been a key accelerant of widespread myths, misunderstandings and lies related to Covid-19; Klobuchar and Luján’s bill would force online companies like Facebook to crack down on false information during public health emergencies, or lose immunity from lawsuits if they don’t.
headline: Facebook Is Bad. Fixing It Rashly Could Make It Much Worse.

abstract: Some influential tech executives said Mr. Lee’s death reflected a city overrun by crime, but few have reversed course since the arrest of a man who knew the victim.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After the stabbing death last week of Bob Lee, an entrepreneur and creator of Cash App, in a San Francisco neighborhood popular among technology workers, prominent tech executives including Elon Musk tore into the city’s leaders.
headline: Tech Leaders Blamed San Francisco for Bob Lee’s Killing. Then Came the Arrest.

abstract: The company said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Monday said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with the murder of George Floyd, to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.
headline: Facebook, preparing for Chauvin verdict, to limit posts that might incite violence.

abstract: A stock sell-off driven by a since-debunked picture underscored fears about how artificial intelligence could be used for nefarious purposes with big consequences.
lead_paragraph: For a few minutes on Monday, an ominous image of black smoke billowing from what appeared to be a government building near the Pentagon set off investor fears, sending stocks tumbling.
headline: An A.I.-Generated Spoof Rattles the Markets

abstract: His most famous finding was the “Pygmalion effect,” in which teachers’ high expectations of students can subconsciously make them better students.
lead_paragraph: Robert Rosenthal, a psychologist renowned as an expert in nonverbal communication, and in particular what he called the “self-fulfilling prophecies” in which subtle, often unconscious, gestures can influence behavior, died on Jan. 5 in Riverside, Calif. He was 90.
headline: Robert Rosenthal, Who Linked Subtle Cues to Behavior, Dies at 90

abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on responding to infidelity.
lead_paragraph: I am a retired but active woman in my 60s. I started dating a gentleman, also retired, some months ago after meeting him at a party. He said that he had just ended a long-distance relationship with someone but that she had told him to go ahead and start seeing other women.
headline: Should I Tell a Facebook Friend I Had an Affair With Her Partner?

abstract: The new corporate minimum tax is not law yet and is already rife with exceptions for the businesses that might have to pay it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An hour after Democrats released the text of their climate and tax legislation, Washington lobbyists for the private equity industry sprang into action.
headline: How a Last-Minute Lobbying Blitz Watered Down a Climate Bill Tax

abstract: The maker of Snapchat has been struggling with a sharp slowdown in its advertising business.
lead_paragraph: For years, Snap, the maker of the ephemeral messaging app Snapchat, steadily grew its advertising business. That changed last year after Apple enacted privacy changes that made it harder for apps to target advertising to their users.
headline: Snap Reports Slowest-Ever Quarterly Growth but Adds New Users

abstract: The layoffs will focus on human resources and its retail division, Amazon’s chief executive said in an email to employees.
lead_paragraph: Amazon plans to eliminate 18,000 corporate and technology jobs in a significant expansion of its cost-cutting plans, the company’s chief executive, Andy Jassy, said in a message to employees on Wednesday.
headline: Amazon Expands Corporate Layoffs to 18,000 Jobs

abstract: Top social media apps are struggling after a decade of dominance.
lead_paragraph: For years, most of the conversation about social media companies was about how powerful and dominant they were.
headline: A Social Media Status Update

abstract: Despite Mark Zuckerberg’s hope for the chatbot to be the smartest, it struggles with facts, numbers and web search.
lead_paragraph: In the last few days, you may have noticed something new inside Meta’s apps, including Instagram, Messenger and WhatsApp: an artificially intelligent chatbot.
headline: Meta’s A.I. Assistant Is Fun to Use, but It Can’t Be Trusted

abstract: An accusation against some A.I. companies that they are using the “open source” label too loosely.
lead_paragraph: There’s a big debate in the tech world over whether artificial intelligence models should be “open source.” Elon Musk, who helped found OpenAI in 2015, sued the startup and its chief executive, Sam Altman, on claims that the company had diverged from its mission of openness. The Biden administration is investigating the risks and benefits of open source models.
headline: Openwashing

abstract: Investors await Friday’s inflation report for clues on what the Fed will do next on rates. But it is not the only data point Wall Street is watching.
lead_paragraph: The final big test of the year for investors is set to arrive on Friday with the release at 8:30 a.m. Eastern of the Personal Consumption Expenditures report, the Fed’s preferred inflation gauge.
headline: The Eye-Popping Numbers Driving the Markets

abstract: In recent months, robberies have been more visible, with several involving large groups rushing into stores and coming out with armloads of goods.
lead_paragraph: “Flash mobs” swarm through a Nordstrom in Northern California and two Best Buy stores in Minnesota, running out with armfuls of merchandise. Five thieves steal $20,000 in products from an Ulta Beauty store in Pennsylvania in just 40 seconds. A security guard is fatally shot in Oakland, Calif., while working with a local television news crew reporting about a recent retail robbery by a group of thieves.
headline: Thefts, Always an Issue for Retailers, Become More Brazen

abstract: Shares opened at $42 on Tuesday before declining, valuing the grocery delivery company at $11.1 billion.
lead_paragraph: Initial public offerings are back, warts and all.
headline: Instacart Rises 12% on First Day of Trading, an Encouraging Sign for Tech I.P.O.s

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing

abstract: Meredith Davis and Elliott Poppel connected on the dating app the League, but did not meet in person until after a comedy show where the actor Aziz Ansari read their messages on the app aloud.
lead_paragraph: Not long after joining the dating app the League, Elliott Poppel attended a show at the Comedy Cellar club in Manhattan, where the actor Aziz Ansari performed as a surprise guest.
headline: After a Nudge from Aziz Ansari, a First Date

abstract: Max Fisher’s “The Chaos Machine” examines the psychological impacts of technology.
lead_paragraph: In Max Fisher’s authoritative and devastating account of the impacts of social media, “The Chaos Machine,” he repeatedly invokes Stanley Kubrick’s masterpiece “2001: A Space Odyssey.” The 1968 movie, in which a supercomputer coldly kills astronauts on a ship bound for Jupiter, was in Fisher’s thoughts as he researched the book. Its stark, ambiguous aesthetic is perfectly poised between the utopian and the dystopian. And as a story about trying to fix a wayward technology as it hurtles out of control, it is beautifully apt.
headline: How Social Media Influences Our Behavior, and Vice Versa

abstract: Beth Rubin and Trent H. Evans keep it all inside.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Thank you to Beth Rubin and Trent H. Evans for including the word “giraffe” in one of the clues for this puzzle so that I could use the picture above. Oh, and thank you for this fun puzzle, too!
headline: If You Drop It

abstract: Big tech is staring down the future.
lead_paragraph: Meta is in the fight of its life — and Mark Zuckerberg hopes VR is the answer. Hmmm. Plus, an existential threat to the gig economy and the wildest news in artificial intelligence.
headline: Legs Are Coming + $36 Burritos + Shocking AI News

abstract: Amid rising inflation and the threat of recession, corporate earnings are coming under pressure.
lead_paragraph: Streams of freshly minted quarterly earnings reports are beginning to arrive from corporate America, promising a fuller picture of how important segments of the economy fared as the stock market fell in the spring and early summer.
headline: Why You Should Be Wary of Wall Street’s Upbeat Stock Forecasts

abstract: Chafing at their dependence, Amazon, Google, Meta and Microsoft are racing to cut into Nvidia’s dominant share of the market.
lead_paragraph: In September, Amazon said it would invest up to $4 billion in Anthropic, a San Francisco start-up working on artificial intelligence.
headline: Nvidia’s Big Tech Rivals Put Their Own A.I. Chips on the Table

abstract: Plus Russia says it is retreating from Kherson City and markets try to parse China’s “zero Covid.”
lead_paragraph: In the critical midterm elections, Democrats defied the historical odds as well as an anticipated “red wave” that could have given the Republican Party a substantial majority in the House and a narrower one in the Senate.
headline: Your Thursday Briefing: No ‘Red Wave’ in U.S. Midterms

abstract: A company-appointed panel ruled that the ban was justified at the time but added that the company should reassess its action and make a final decision in six months.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A Facebook-appointed panel of journalists, activists and lawyers on Wednesday upheld the social network’s ban of former President Donald J. Trump, ending any immediate return by Mr. Trump to mainstream social media and renewing a debate about tech power over online speech.
headline: Facebook Oversight Board Upholds Social Network’s Ban of Trump

abstract: The justices are set to hear a case challenging Section 230, a law that protects Google, Facebook and others from lawsuits over what their users post online.
lead_paragraph: Nohemi Gonzalez, a 23-year-old California college student, was studying abroad in Paris in November 2015 when she was among the 130 people killed in a coordinated series of terrorist attacks throughout the city.
headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case That Targets a Legal Shield of Tech Giants

abstract: The government in Dublin has a big budget surplus, thanks to a boom in tax revenue from multinational companies. Build more housing? Or a subway? Sock it away? Whatever the case, someone will be unhappy.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years after a collapsed housing bubble forced Ireland to borrow tens of billions of dollars or risk going bust, the country is discovering that having too much money can also be a problem.
headline: Ireland’s Latest Fiscal Headache: What to Do With 10 Billion Euros

abstract: The Justice Department’s antitrust lawsuit, which a group of states joined, was the fifth by U.S. officials against the company since 2020.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department and a group of eight states sued Google on Tuesday, accusing it of illegally abusing a monopoly over the technology that powers online advertising, in the agency’s first antitrust lawsuit against a tech giant under President Biden and an escalation in legal pressure on one of the world’s biggest internet companies.
headline: U.S. Accuses Google of Abusing Monopoly in Ad Technology

abstract: Facebook, TikTok and Twitter seem to be increasingly connecting users with brands and influencers. To restore a sense of community, some users are trying smaller social networks.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two decades ago, Facebook exploded on college campuses as a site for students to stay in touch. Then came Twitter, where people posted about what they had for breakfast, and Instagram, where friends shared photos to keep up with one another.
headline: The Future of Social Media Is a Lot Less Social

abstract: A new Canadian law will require technology companies to license news content. Facebook’s owner said it would drop news from the platform.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Parliament has passed a law that will require technology companies to pay domestic news outlets for linking to their articles, prompting the owner of Facebook and Instagram to say that it would pull news articles from both platforms in the country.
headline: Canada Forces Google and Facebook to Pay News Outlets for Linking to Articles

abstract: Regulators are expected to give Microsoft’s proposed acquisition of Activision Blizzard — the largest in Microsoft’s history — a tough review.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Wednesday kicked off a charm offensive in Washington to gain government approval for its $70 billion deal to buy the video game company Activision Blizzard, saying it would not give preferential treatment to its own games in its app stores.
headline: Microsoft starts a charm offensive to push through its Activision deal.

abstract: The layoffs will affect 274 people, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Dotdash Meredith, the publishing giant that owns publications including People, InStyle and Better Homes & Gardens, said on Thursday that it would cut 7 percent of its staff, the latest media and tech company to do layoffs.
headline: Dotdash Meredith, Publisher of People and InStyle, Cuts 7% of Staff

abstract: The cases could significantly affect the power and responsibilities of social media platforms.
lead_paragraph: For years, giant social networks like Facebook, Twitter and Instagram have operated under two crucial tenets.
headline: Supreme Court Poised to Reconsider Key Tenets of Online Speech

abstract: Tech companies have been making subtle and not-so-subtle changes to their rules for better access to data for building A.I. We took a look at some of them.
lead_paragraph: Last July, Google made an eight-word change to its privacy policy that represented a significant step in its race to build the next generation of artificial intelligence.
headline: When the Terms of Service Change to Make Way for A.I. Training

abstract: The writer Jeanette Winterson explores the wild world unfolding alongside the rise of artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: As Tesla develops its humanoid robot and Facebook — sorry, now Meta — rebrands to signal its focus on the metaverse and an even more virtual world, some might continue to wonder whether an Armageddon that will have artificial intelligence overpowering humans is a possibility. But the novelist Jeanette Winterson is more optimistic.
