Her more utopian view of an A.I.-enabled future depends on more compassionate technologies and the diversification of the leaders driving innovation, who she says are currently “rich guys with a lot of power, and we can’t depend on their benevolence.”
headline: Sex Bots, Religion and the Wild World of A.I.

abstract: The groups say they are increasingly confused and frustrated by how major technology platforms moderate posts about abortion services.
lead_paragraph: TikTok has briefly suspended the account of Hey Jane, a prominent telemedicine abortion service, four times without explanation. Instagram has suspended Mayday Health, a nonprofit that provides information about abortion pill access, without explanation as well. And the search engine Bing has erroneously flagged the website for Aid Access, a major seller of abortion pills online, as unsafe.
headline: Abortion Groups Say Tech Companies Suppress Posts and Accounts

abstract: Regulators said the subscription service introduced last year is a “pay or consent” method to collect personal data and bolster advertising.
lead_paragraph: When Meta introduced a subscription option last year that would allow users in the European Union to pay for an advertising-free experience of Instagram and Facebook, it was meant to fix regulatory problems the company faced in the region.
headline: Meta’s Ad-Free Subscription Violates Competition Law, E.U. Says

abstract: To comply with European regulations, Apple has proposed reducing its commission on app sales while adding new fees and hurdles.
lead_paragraph: After 15 years of dictating how apps are distributed on iPhones, Apple has been forced to take marching orders from European regulators. A new law to bolster tech competition has demanded that Apple open its devices to competing app stores and payment alternatives.
headline: Apple Has a New Plan for Its App Store. Many Developers Hate It.

abstract: Budget watchdogs warn that temporary changes to the tax code that are being debated on Capitol Hill will lead to more deficits in the long run.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers on the House Ways and Means Committee achieved a feat on Friday after debating something that rarely comes together in an election year: bipartisan tax legislation.
headline: What’s in the New Tax Deal?

abstract: Seventy-one tracks that asked big questions, found new kinship between genres and helped us see the good in Ken.
lead_paragraph: The album may be imperiled; people have been saying so for decades, even though the form has resisted extinction. Meanwhile, songs flourish, whether or not they’re destined for albums, and are ever more flexible. Some maintain the pop conventions of verse-chorus-verse; others distill themselves down to TikTok-ready hooks or sprawl across digital time frames. Here are 30 of my favorite songs from 2023 — less a ranking than a playlist, a tribute to creative abundance.
headline: Best Songs of 2023

abstract: The new headset teaches a valuable lesson about the cost of tech products: The upsells and add-ons will get you.
lead_paragraph: When Apple unveiled the Vision Pro virtual reality goggles last year at a technology conference, many in the audience gasped at the price: $3,500. That’s more than quadruple the cost of a new iPhone and 14 times the cost of a competing headset from Meta.
headline: The True Price of Apple’s $3,500 Vision Pro Is Closer to $4,600

abstract: “Without a doubt, this is a dangerous idea that risks the safety of our children and puts them directly in harm’s way,” Letitia James, New York’s attorney general said in a statement.
lead_paragraph: Attorneys general for 44 states and jurisdictions called on Facebook to halt plans to create a version of Instagram for young children, citing concerns over mental and emotional well-being, exposure to online predators and cyberbullying.
headline: Dozens of state prosecutors tell Facebook to stop its plans for a children’s version of Instagram.

abstract: Adam Wagner’s puzzle will pull you in.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I am delighted to welcome Adam Wagner back to the New York Times Crossword for his seventh appearance in just under a year — that’s a pretty impressive track record! Mr. Wagner’s puzzles never fail to make me smile, and there’s always something fresh or novel about them.
headline: Likely Not Made by a Tyrannosaurus Rex

abstract: Microsoft and Alphabet will report results on Tuesday, as investors look for signs that a rally in stocks tied to artificial intelligence is justified.
lead_paragraph: Nasdaq futures are up on Tuesday morning, ahead of a Big Tech earnings bonanza that kicks off when Microsoft and Alphabet report second-quarter results after the closing bell. One question is at the top of many investors’ minds: Is the hype around artificial intelligence, which has propelled tech giants’ stock prices sky-high in recent months, justified, or is it another bubble in the making?
headline: Big Tech Earnings Will Test Investors’ Fervor for A.I.

abstract: One of the world’s largest sustainable development agencies has worked with energy companies to quash opposition and keep oil flowing, even in sensitive areas.
lead_paragraph: RESGUARDO BUENAVISTA, Colombia — At the edge of the Colombian Amazon, in an Indigenous village surrounded by oil rigs, the Siona people faced a dilemma.
headline: In the Amazon, a U.N. Agency Has a Green Mission, but Dirty Partners

abstract: College students need a taste of the monk’s life.
lead_paragraph: Nery Rodriguez just graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a major in economics, but one of the most significant courses she took there had nothing to do with marginal utility or game theory. When she registered last fall for the seminar known around campus as the monk class, she wasn’t sure what to expect.
headline: Why Universities Should Be More Like Monasteries

abstract: Eddy Cue, a longtime executive at the company, said Apple’s multibillion-dollar deals with Google were driven by quality, not money.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s top deal maker on Tuesday defended his company’s favoritism of Google on iPhones, a pivotal collaboration that has shaped the modern tech industry and is at the center of a federal antitrust trial against the search giant.
headline: Top Apple Executive Defends Favoring Google on iPhones

abstract: The April 7, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode in which Ezra answers listener questions. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Answers Listener Questions on A.I.

abstract: Many companies, particularly in the beauty and fashion industries, have boosted sales through the platform. They don’t really have a backup plan.
lead_paragraph: Amid debate in Washington over whether TikTok should be banned if its Chinese owner doesn’t sell it, one group is watching with particular interest: the many brands — particularly in the beauty, skin care, fashion, and health and wellness industries — that have used the video app to boost their sales.
headline: With TikTok Under Fire, Brands That Rely on It Worry

abstract: Free links to over 75 pieces about young people that have appeared across sections of NYTimes.com since September.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to a mammoth edition of our Teenagers in The Times feature.
headline: Teenagers in The Times: Fall 2023

abstract: Meta has cautioned that some content might be temporarily suppressed or suspended as it sifts through millions of posts spreading across its platforms.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Palestinian supporters say their posts have been suppressed or removed from Facebook and Instagram, even if the messages do not break the platforms’ rules.
headline: Social Media Users Accuse Facebook and Instagram of Suppressing Pro-Palestinian Posts

abstract: The Turing test used to be the gold standard for proving machine intelligence. This generation of bots is racing past it.
lead_paragraph: Franz Broseph seemed like any other Diplomacy player to Claes de Graaff. The handle was a joke — the Austrian emperor Franz Joseph I reborn as an online bro — but that was the kind of humor that people who play Diplomacy tend to enjoy. The game is a classic, beloved by the likes of John F. Kennedy and Henry Kissinger, combining military strategy with political intrigue as it recreates the First World War: Players negotiate with allies, enemies and everyone in between as they plan how their armies will move across 20th-century Europe.
headline: How Smart Are the Robots Getting?

abstract: Pitches for the future of the internet are banking on an old trick: FOMO.
lead_paragraph: If you have an internet connection, you’re probably familiar with the feeling. Something new starts happening online. People seem really excited about it. Suddenly you’re curious. (Sure, I’ll join TikTok.) Or maybe you feel dread. (Am I too late to buy crypto?) Everyone at some point fears missing out on something.
headline: Are You Missing Out on the Metaverse?

abstract: Russian spy agencies and new technologies could be used to push conspiracy theories, U.S. officials say.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s strategy to win the war in Ukraine is to outlast the West.
headline: Putin’s Next Target: U.S. Support for Ukraine, Officials Say

abstract: The former “Bachelor” star has (almost) left the franchise behind as he doles out advice on his podcast and on paper.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In 2014, during “After the Final Rose,” a live TV special that followed “The Bachelorette” finale, the season’s runner-up Nick Viall turned to the bachelorette, Andi Dorfman, and said: “If you weren’t in love with me, I’m just not sure why you made love with me?”
headline: Nick Viall Gets His Roses

abstract: Age, innovation, antitrust and the metaverse.
lead_paragraph: In October of last year, my colleague Kevin Roose wrote a column titled, “Facebook Is Weaker Than We Knew.” His hook was a series of stories in The Wall Street Journal, based on internal company documents, which revealed the company’s failure to stop content that damaged teen mental health, spread vaccine misinformation and more.
headline: Facebook’s Four Problems

abstract: Starting in November, subscriptions will cost between 9.99 euros and 12.99 euros per month, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Meta said on Monday that it will introduce an advertisement-free subscription option for Facebook and Instagram for the first time beginning next month for users in Europe, a sign of how government pressure is leading large tech companies to change their core products.
headline: In Europe, Meta Offers Ad-Free Versions of Facebook and Instagram for First Time

abstract: Dozens of companies have committed to helping their employees get access to reproductive care.
lead_paragraph: After the Supreme Court’s ruling on Friday that ended federal abortion rights, several companies released statements reaffirming their commitment to helping employees gain access to health care services they may not be able to obtain in their state.
headline: These Companies Will Cover Travel Expenses for Employee Abortions

abstract: NetChoice, whose members include Amazon, Google, Meta and TikTok, said the new law could cause online services to limit important content for minors.
lead_paragraph: A tech industry trade association sued the State of California on Wednesday in an effort to halt a new children’s online safety law, a legal challenge that comes at a moment of intensified public concern over the risks that content on popular platforms like Instagram and TikTok could pose to younger users.
headline: Tech Trade Group Sues California to Halt Children’s Online Safety Law

abstract: The emergency order was issued late Friday as wildfires threatened Yellowknife, in the Northwest Territories, and Kelowna, in British Columbia.
lead_paragraph: The western Canadian province of British Columbia was under a state of emergency order early Saturday, hours after most residents of Yellowknife, a city farther north, had fled ahead of a deadline to evacuate because of a dangerous wildfire.
headline: British Columbia Under State of Emergency as Wildfires Rage in Canada

abstract: A recent letter calling for a moratorium on A.I. development blends real threats with speculation. But concern is growing among experts.
lead_paragraph: In late March, more than 1,000 technology leaders, researchers and other pundits working in and around artificial intelligence signed an open letter warning that A.I. technologies present “profound risks to society and humanity.”
headline: What Exactly Are the Dangers Posed by A.I.?

abstract: Ecological disaster ties together the three strands of Matt Bell’s stark yet hopeful “Appleseed.”
lead_paragraph: APPLESEEDBy Matt Bell
headline: A Novel Charts Earth’s Path From Lush Eden to Barren Hellscape

abstract: The social media company posted rising sales after two quarters of declines, but added that the ad market remains unpredictable.
lead_paragraph: Snap, the parent company of Snapchat, on Tuesday reported that its revenue rose 5 percent in the latest quarter after two straight quarters of declines, as the digital advertising market rebounded.
headline: Snap Reports 5% Revenue Increase, Reversing Declines in Growth

abstract: We’re in a golden age of progress in artificial intelligence. It’s time to start taking its potential and risks seriously.
lead_paragraph: For the past few days, I’ve been playing around with DALL-E 2, an app developed by the San Francisco company OpenAI that turns text descriptions into hyper-realistic images.
headline: We Need to Talk About How Good A.I. Is Getting

abstract: A chat with Will Shortz, who has been editing The Times’s puzzle for 30 years.
lead_paragraph: Will Shortz celebrated his 30th anniversary as The Times’s Crossword editor this week. He is one of only four Crossword editors since 1942, when the paper began publishing puzzles as a way to offer relief to readers overwhelmed by war news. “It is possible there will now be bleak blackout hours — or if not that then certainly a need for relaxation of some kind or other,” Lester Markel, the paper’s Sunday editor, wrote to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, the publisher, two weeks after the attack on Pearl Harbor.
headline: A Crossword Anniversary

abstract: Billy Eichner plays a moody podcaster who has sworn off relationships, but just might find himself in one anyway, in this gay romantic comedy.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Billy Eichner is not a person you’d approach for love advice. Fans of his long-running viral videos, “Billy on the Street,” in which Eichner accosts New Yorkers to scream about pop culture, would not leap to list listening, empathy, communication or patience among his skills. Even his gentler sitcom was titled, justly, “Difficult People.”
headline: ‘Bros’ Review: Boy Meets Boy Meets Multiplex

abstract: Until recently, antitrust regulators in Europe and the United States took different approaches. Now, they’re on the same page — which some experts say makes closing deals harder.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft announced its $70 billion acquisition of the video game maker Activision Blizzard last year, almost everyone involved expected antitrust inquiries from officials in the European Union and Britain, and many thought regulators there would try to block the deal. What U.S. enforcers would do, however, was less clear.
headline: Microsoft’s Activision Deal Tests a New Global Alignment on Antitrust

abstract: The states’ central claim is that Facebook acquired competitors — particularly Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014 — in a predatory manner, by crushing competition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly four dozen states on Friday asked a federal appeals court to reconsider an antitrust lawsuit against Facebook that a judge threw out last year.
headline: States appeal a judge’s decision to throw out their Facebook antitrust case.

abstract: In David Adjmi’s new play, with songs by Will Butler, a ’70s band’s success breeds tension, and punches up the volume on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Peering behind the mystique of rock ’n’ roll has undeniable voyeuristic appeal. So there is an immediate thrill to seeing the mahogany-paneled control room and glassed-in sound booth that fill the Golden Theater stage, where “Stereophonic” opened on Friday. But David Adjmi’s astonishing new play, with songs by the former Arcade Fire member Will Butler, delivers more than a dishy glimpse inside the recording studio during rock’s golden age.
headline: ‘Stereophonic’ Review: Hitmakers Rendered in Sublime Detail

abstract: Ghostface and meta commentary are back in this sequel, yet the weight of obligations to the dictates of the franchise ultimately drags it down.
lead_paragraph: It was not surprising when Quentin Tarantino, an auteur unusually willing to criticize the work of his peers in public, told an interviewer that he didn’t like the original “Scream,” calling its director, Wes Craven, “the iron chain attached to its ankle.”
headline: ‘Scream VI’ Review: Yes, Another Scary Movie

abstract: Investors in the S&P 500 are highly dependent on the fate of Microsoft, Apple and other big technology stocks. A rally in March showed how this can mask turmoil in the rest of the market.
lead_paragraph: The fate of the S&P 500 index — used by investors as a barometer for the health of corporate America, and cited by presidents as a measure of their handling of the economy — often comes down to just two companies: Apple and Microsoft.
headline: How Big Tech Camouflaged Wall Street’s Crisis

abstract: A dispute over photos of bare chests with the nipples covered, posted on Instagram by a transgender and nonbinary couple, has prompted a call for the platform to clarify its content guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Content creators have long criticized Facebook and Instagram for their content moderation policies relating to photos that show partial nudity, arguing that their practices are inconsistent and often biased against women and L.G.B.T.Q. people.
headline: Instagram and Facebook Should Update Nude Photo Rules, Meta Board Says

abstract: When relationship dramas heated up this summer, she saw an opportunity.
lead_paragraph: For a particular corner of the internet, the world ended this summer. Several internet-famous WLW couples — an abbreviation for “women-loving women” — had made online announcements that they had split up, leading their followers to speculate about a so-called breakup curse. Followers of the drama called it the “lesbian breakup apocalypse,” and NBC News reported on it in August.
headline: The Lesbian Perez Hilton of TikTok

abstract: Creative professionals have been cut off from Western clients and from the products and services they use to make, market and get paid for their work.
lead_paragraph: In a call from his car on Sunday, a photographer from Moscow explained why he was driving to Tbilisi, Georgia, having left his apartment and essentially his whole life behind.
headline: Russian Artists Lose the Tools of Their Trades as Companies Pull Out

abstract: The jobs numbers were better than expected. But Meta’s earnings were weaker, sending its stock plunging. CNN’s top executive resigned. And the Olympics have begun.
lead_paragraph: The economy added 467,000 jobs in January despite record levels of coronavirus cases, the Department of Labor reported on Friday. Employers continued to add jobs at roughly the same rate as they did in December. Data quirks make the jobs numbers particularly difficult to accurately interpret in January, and the labor force shrank, suggesting that Omicron may have kept some people from looking for work. But economists said that the strong jobs report was a good sign. “Clearly something is different about this surge,” said Julia Pollak, chief economist for the career site ZipRecruiter.
headline: The Week in Business: A Strong Jobs Report

abstract: Wall Street investors were hoping the social media giant would regain its footing after more than a year of problems, including slumping ad sales.
lead_paragraph: Long before it was called Meta, Facebook was a Wall Street darling because of its breakneck growth and big profits. But the company had lost its luster with investors over the past 18 months thanks to a slump in ad sales and what some saw as self-inflicted wounds.
headline: Meta Profit Is Up 16% to $7.8 Billion in Recent Quarter

abstract: Roughly 3,000 educators are walking off the job on Thursday in one of the state’s largest school districts.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Oakland public school educators are walking off the job on Thursday as they call for improved working conditions and wages that would better keep pace with inflation and the high cost of living in the Bay Area.
headline: Oakland Teachers Go on Strike

abstract: The former president, now free to post again on Facebook and Twitter, has increasingly amplified far-right accounts on Truth Social. Experts on extremism worry that he will bring this approach to a far wider audience.
lead_paragraph: In September, former President Donald J. Trump went on Truth Social, his social network, and shared an image of himself wearing a lapel pin in the form of the letter Q, along with a phrase closely associated with the QAnon conspiracy theory movement: “The storm is coming.”
headline: Trump’s Evolution in Social-Media Exile: More QAnon, More Extremes

abstract: The creator and stars of the new Netflix series said they accepted David Choe’s contention that he had fabricated the detailed story he told on a 2014 podcast about coercing a masseuse into sex.
lead_paragraph: The creator and two stars of the new Netflix series “Beef” addressed a brewing controversy on Friday about another actor on the show who said on a podcast in 2014 that he had sexually assaulted a masseuse, comments now recirculating on social media.
headline: ‘Beef’ Stars Call Actor’s Story About Sexual Assault ‘Undeniably Hurtful’

abstract: Originally published on Sep. 1, 2018
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that exercise is one of the best things you can do for your health. But most people ignore one crucial component of it: resistance training. According to federal researchers, only 6 percent of adults do the recommended minimum amount of at least two muscle-strengthening workouts each week. Neglecting resistance training — any type of workout that builds strength and muscle — is a big mistake. It increases your metabolism, lowers your body fat and protects you from some of the leading causes of early death and disability. You don’t have to lift like a bodybuilder (or look like one) to benefit from resistance training. And it’s never too late to get started. Here is everything you need to know about resistance training, along with some simple, expert-approved workouts you can do at the gym or at home with minimal equipment.
headline: How to Get Strong

abstract: The company has enlisted Hollywood directors like Jon Favreau to help its effort to create products that blend the physical and virtual worlds.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 15 years after the iPhone set off the smartphone revolution, Apple is assembling the pieces for what it hopes will become its next business-altering device: a headset that blends the digital world with the real one.
headline: Apple Starts Connecting the Dots for Its Next Big Thing

abstract: Two dozen major Wall Street firms sent a letter to top law schools to crack down on discrimination and harassment amid an escalation in incidents targeting Jewish students.
lead_paragraph: With universities across the United States grappling with a rise in antisemitism since the start of the Israel-Hamas war, elite law firms are putting schools on notice. In a letter to some of the nation’s top law schools obtained by DealBook, about two dozen major Wall Street firms warned that what happens on campus could have corporate consequences.
headline: Law Firms Warn Universities About Antisemitism on Campus

abstract: Keeping its head down has not paid off for the company, which now faces regulatory pressure on many fronts. So it is starting to speak out.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last week, TikTok’s chief executive, Shou Zi Chew, met with several influential think tanks and public interest groups in Washington, sharing details on how his company plans to prevent data on American users from ever leaving the United States. And the company’s lobbyists swarmed the offices of lawmakers who have introduced bills to ban the app, telling them that TikTok can be trusted to protect the information.
headline: TikTok’s New Defense in Washington: Going on the Offense

abstract: Fewer children are attending school, across rich and poor districts.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, a troubling phenomenon began to spread in U.S. education: Students were not showing up to school.
headline: A Crisis of School Absences

abstract: In the web browser used within the TikTok app, supplementary code lets the company track every character typed by users. The company said the capability was for troubleshooting.
lead_paragraph: The web browser used within the TikTok app can track every keystroke made by its users, according to new research that is surfacing as the Chinese-owned video app grapples with U.S. lawmakers’ concerns over its data practices.
headline: TikTok Browser Can Track Users’ Keystrokes, According to New Research

abstract: Leaked internal documents show that the world’s dependency on Facebook and its family of apps comes at a great cost.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
headline: Facebook Was Down for a Few Hours. Should It Go Away Forever?

abstract: With the exception of Apple, eight tech giants are no longer “pure growth” stocks, while Exxon and Chevron are, a new study says. Our columnist says: Buyer, beware.
lead_paragraph: It is impossible even to talk about the long bull market that ended in January 2022 without saying high-growth tech stocks propelled the market higher.
headline: Value Stocks? Growth Stocks? Markets Last Year Turned Everything Topsy-Turvy.

abstract: Facebook said on Thursday that it was rebranding as Meta, taking a step to distance itself from the controversies it faces. How has this corporate strategy worked for other companies?
lead_paragraph: Rebranding a company amid a crisis or as a way to signal a shift in focus has been a popular corporate strategy for decades. But does it really help companies shed their image issues, or do customers see a name change as window dressing?
headline: 8 Companies That Changed Their Names to Signal a Strategy Shift

abstract: Digital currency’s hype men try to flip the script as Terra, Bitcoin and others fall off a cliff.
lead_paragraph: The cryptocurrency market is in a complete meltdown — which many are calling a “crypto winter.” But it’s more like an ice age, given that the market was roaring hot as recently as November, when the price of Bitcoin nearly hit $69,000. Today it’s hovering around $20,000.
headline: Crypto Meltdown Forces a Rebranding

abstract: A new play by Simon Stephens has hearty performances but a nearly undetectable pulse.
lead_paragraph: Making the best of the little you’ve got may or may not be the theme of “Morning Sun,” the pianissimo new play by Simon Stephens that opened Off Broadway on Wednesday. But it’s certainly the problem.
headline: Review: Edie Falco Shines as an Everywoman in ‘Morning Sun’

abstract: Facebook’s little mistakes have big consequences, too. (But only for us.)
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Facebook’s Unglamorous Mistakes

abstract: Signs suggest that Israel will likely invade Rafah.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of delays, negotiations and distractions, Israel appeared to hint this week that its assault of Rafah was all but inevitable.
headline: Thursday Briefing

abstract: Investors are assessing the consequences of the intensifying conflict, from sanctions to shortages and price surges.
lead_paragraph: The markets have been unsettled for many reasons this year, but the escalating conflict between Ukraine and Russia pushed them past a symbolic milestone yesterday. The S&P 500 slipped into a so-called correction, defined as a decline of least 10 percent from the most recent high.
headline: How Markets Are Thinking About the Ukraine Battle Lines

abstract: Doctors are exasperated by the persistence of false and misleading claims about the virus.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years into the pandemic, Covid-19 remains stubbornly persistent. So, too, does misinformation about the virus.
headline: As Covid-19 Continues to Spread, So Does Misinformation About It

abstract: Conor Sefkow coins a neologism.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to today’s constructor, Conor Sefkow, for making his New York Times Crossword debut! This puzzle is built around a term that Mr. Sefkow coined himself and just knew he had to build a puzzle around. I love hearing the origin stories of creative themes like this one (described in more detail below), and I am particularly fond of clever portmanteaus, which, as far as I’m concerned, are the height of wit.
headline: Cause for a Correction

abstract: Also, the Fed is not quite ready to cut borrowing rates. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Five of the country’s most prominent tech executives appeared at a hearing today on Capitol Hill, where they were berated by lawmakers for creating “a crisis in America” by ignoring the spread of child sexual abuse material on their platforms.
headline: Senators Grilled Tech Executives on Child Safety

abstract: The layoffs amount to about 6 percent of the global work force at the company, the latest tech giant to make cuts after a pandemic hiring spree.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, said on Friday that it planned to cut 12,000 jobs, becoming the latest technology company to reduce its work force because of concerns about a broader economic slowdown, after a hiring spree during the pandemic.
headline: Google Parent Alphabet to Cut 12,000 Jobs

abstract: Regulators in Ireland, where many tech giants have their European headquarters, have been criticized for not enforcing Europe’s data-protection law, once heralded as a global standard.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s WhatsApp messaging service was fined nearly $270 million by Irish authorities on Thursday for not being transparent about how it uses data collected from people on the service, in a case that represents a big test of Europe’s ability to enforce its landmark data privacy law.
headline: Facebook’s WhatsApp is fined for breaking the E.U.’s data privacy law.

abstract: Andrew Garfield stars as Jonathan Larson, the composer and lyricist of “Rent,” in this meta-musical directed by Lin-Manuel Miranda.
lead_paragraph: For his feature directing debut, the “Hamilton” honcho Lin-Manuel Miranda points his spotlight at the composer who inspired his own creative awakening: Jonathan Larson.
headline: ‘Tick, Tick … Boom!’ Review: A Bohemian’s Rhapsodies

abstract: The future of our news ecosystem depends on the outcome of a bitter battle.
lead_paragraph: A bitter battle is taking place between Big Tech and the free press over how to share in the income that news content generates for technology giants. The future of our news ecosystem, a linchpin of democracy, depends on the outcome.
headline: News Publishers Are Fighting Big Tech Over Peanuts. They Could Be Owed Billions.

abstract: The U.N. calls for a cease-fire in Israel and Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, called yesterday for a humanitarian cease-fire in Israel and Gaza in an address to the U.N. Security Council. He said that the attacks by Hamas that had left 1,400 people dead in Israel on Oct. 7 were “appalling” but that they did not justify the “collective punishment” of civilians in the Gaza Strip, where the Israeli military significantly stepped up its bombardment.
headline: Wednesday Briefing

abstract: The Times’s staff critics talk with one another about the reading they did this year, on and off the job.
lead_paragraph: Each year around now, The New York Times’s book critics choose their favorite books from among those they reviewed over the previous 12 months. We also ask them to gather to discuss their years in reading in broader detail. This time we welcome our newest critics, Molly Young and Alexandra Jacobs, to the conversation. Below, Dwight Garner, Jennifer Szalai, Young and Jacobs talk about older books they read for the first time, authors who inspired and disappointed them, and more. — John Williams
headline: Times Critics Discuss 2021 in Books, From Breakout Stars to Cover Blobs

abstract: Shakespeare’s tragedy becomes a girl-power romp in a cotton candy jukebox musical, featuring songs by the Swedish hitmaker Max Martin.
lead_paragraph: They don’t even bother to hide the jukebox. It’s right there, out in the open, before the show starts: a chrome Cyclops glowering at you from the stage of the Stephen Sondheim Theater, of all places.
headline: Review: On Broadway, ‘& Juliet’ (& Britney & Katy & Pink)

abstract: Facebook has been used as a tool for violence and abuse in country after country. Maybe it shouldn’t be everywhere.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Shrink Facebook to Save the World

abstract: He doesn’t own the company yet, but Elon Musk’s criticisms of Twitter executives are making waves.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk doesn’t own Twitter yet, but he’s already making his presence felt there. Musk took aim at Twitter employees and others this week in a round of tweets that raised new concerns about the company’s future under his freewheeling approach to content moderation. (He also said — with tongue presumably in cheek — that he would buy Coca-Cola next, “to put the cocaine back in.”)
headline: Musk Is Already Shaking Up Twitter

abstract: The former employee says the company hides behind flat offices and metrics to shirk its responsibility.
lead_paragraph: The Facebook whistle-blower Frances Haugen leaked a treasure trove of internal documents to the press and testified before Congress about the extent to which the tech giant fuels political polarization and erodes the mental health of teenagers. In this conversation with Kara Swisher, Haugen contemplates how Facebook has gotten away with it for so long. She discusses the company’s focus on seemingly objective metrics, the fixation with free speech and censorship debates and a general “fetishization of flatness” most clearly seen in the company’s large open-floor offices. All of this, says Haugen, allows Mark Zuckerberg to shirk responsibility: “When you refuse to acknowledge that power exists, you actually end up reinforcing the fact that power isn’t flat in the world.”
headline: Why Facebook Whistle-Blower Frances Haugen Thinks She’ll Outlast Mark Zuckerberg

abstract: Mike Schroepfer, who leads the company’s artificial intelligence and other technical efforts, said he planned to transition into a role as a senior fellow.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a rare change to Facebook’s top ranks, Mike Schroepfer, the chief technology officer and a longtime executive, plans to step down from his position next year, the company said on Wednesday.
headline: Facebook’s Chief Technology Officer to Step Down in 2022

abstract: A huge sell-off wiped billions of dollars from the electric carmaker’s market capitalization on Tuesday. Analysts see more trouble ahead.
lead_paragraph: With its stock in free fall and competition mounting on all sides, Tesla appears to be losing its most bullish supporters on a daily basis.
headline: Tesla Bulls Brace for a Rough Year Ahead

abstract: The fight between the two tech giants might remodel the internet as we know it.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: What’s Behind the Apple-Facebook Feud?

abstract: Despite the implosion of FTX and projections of a cryptocurrency winter, the metaverse real estate market is expected to grow by $5.37 billion by 2026.
lead_paragraph: In March, Gabe Sierra, a contractor whose family has been in the construction business for more than 30 years, will take offers for his latest creation: an 11,000-square-foot mansion with seven bedrooms and a pool in Pinecrest, Miami.
headline: The Next Hot Housing Market Is Out of This World. It’s in the Metaverse.

abstract: The actors’ strike effectively ended the “Barbie” film’s press tour. But Margot Robbie’s pink-carpet outfits are worth remembering.
lead_paragraph: The actors’ strike has hit the brakes on the hot pink convertible that is the “Barbie” film’s press tour.
headline: This Barbie Is Now on Strike

abstract: This week, Holland Cotter covers the Studio Museum in Harlem’s residency results, Sarah Grilo’s little-seen paintings and Mary Lucier’s experimental and heartfelt video art.
lead_paragraph: This week in Newly Reviewed, Max Lakin covers Christopher Wool’s sculptures in a dilapidated setting, Paa Joe’s reimagined New York icons and C’naan Hamburger’s contemporary vanitas paintings.
headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in March

abstract: In opening statements for the government’s first monopoly trial of the modern internet era, Google defended itself and said people had many choices for online search.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department and 38 states and territories on Tuesday laid out how Google had systematically wielded its power in online search to cow competitors, as the internet giant fiercely parried back, in the opening of the most consequential trial over tech power in the modern internet era.
headline: ‘A Monopolist Flexing’: U.S. Blasts Google’s Tactics as Antitrust Trial Opens

abstract: The government claims that Google illegally stifles rivals, while the company says its practices are legal and mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from Google’s antitrust trial
headline: Google Goes on Trial Over Justice Dept. Claims That It Has Monopoly Power

abstract: A conversation with the co-founder of GiveWell
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Holden Karnofsky. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Holden Karnofsky

abstract: “Radical Islamists” attacked Moscow, Vladimir Putin acknowledges.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin of Russia acknowledged for the first time that “radical Islamists” had carried out the attack on a concert hall near Moscow, while insisting that Ukraine could still have played a role.
headline: Tuesday Briefing

abstract: Elon Musk is back at the negotiating table. This time Twitter wants guarantees he won’t walk away – again.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk dropped a bombshell when he put his original $44 billion offer to buy Twitter back on the table, days ahead of a court battle over his monthslong effort to walk away from that very agreement.
headline: Twitter Wants Assurances from Musk

abstract: As a new chatbot wows the world with its conversational talents, a resurgent tech giant is poised to reap the benefits while doubling down on a relationship with the start-up OpenAI.
lead_paragraph: When a chatbot called ChatGPT hit the internet late last year, executives at a number of Silicon Valley companies worried they were suddenly dealing with new artificial intelligence technology that could disrupt their businesses.
headline: Microsoft Bets Big on the Creator of ChatGPT in Race to Dominate A.I.

abstract: But don’t expect Congress to get its act together on tech legislation.
lead_paragraph: I know, I know: “Not another prediction list …” But stick with me. After all, my first forecast from last year came true — although the Capitol siege moved the timetable forward considerably.
headline: Trump’s Social Media Return and What Else to Expect in 2022

abstract: A political fight is again putting the economy at risk.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government hit the legal limit on how much money it can borrow yesterday, prompting fears that the country soon may not be able to pay its bills.
headline: Routine Crisis

abstract: Adam Simon Levine’s debut puzzle speaks to us, in words we can’t pronounce.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Capping off a week of daily grids from brand- or almost-new constructors is this debut poser from Adam Simon Levine, with a dramatic centerpiece. I really needed the success jingle to know that I’d finished, at which point I unapologetically went to the internet to learn something new. When this happens on a Saturday, I consider the knowledge gained to be value added, especially when it’s something fascinating and important that slipped through the cracks of my experience and education.
headline: Greek Goddess of Memory

abstract: In “The Dating Show,” the British comedian and ventriloquist initiates close encounters of the potentially romantic kind. Laughs will definitely ensue.
lead_paragraph: Meaningful, long-lasting connections can take a while to form, but when Nina Conti met her future partner-in-crime, she knew they were simpatico right away.
headline: Dating Woes? Nina Conti Has the Answer, or at Least Some Jokes

abstract: Tony Leung stars as a spy chief during a shadowy period in midcentury China, when nationalists, communists and imperialists vied for power and souls.
lead_paragraph: History’s shadow is long; so is the shadow of Tony Leung’s cigarette, which few other images in modern Chinese (Hong Kong) cinema can rival for iconographic force. To picture him smoking is to conjure an entire world of feeling — the aesthetic ecstasy of Wong Kar-wai distilled into a single vision. Perhaps only Bruce Lee’s fist or the Cheongsam sway of another Wong favorite, Maggie Cheung, compare.
headline: ‘Hidden Blade’ Review: Smoke Gets in Your Eyes

abstract: The regional lender said it is weighing its options, after its shares fell despite assertions by the Federal Reserve that the recent bank crisis is contained.
lead_paragraph: The regional banking sector is teetering again, with PacWest’s stock plummeting more than 35 percent in premarket trading, despite the Fed chair Jay Powell’s assessment that the worst is over.
headline: PacWest’s Stock Plunge Reignites Banking Sector Fears

abstract: Reports suggest that screenwriters won concessions from Hollywood studios on key issues. That reflects the strength of unions’ hands in the current moment.
lead_paragraph: One of the longest-running strikes of 2023 is near an end: The Writers Guild of America reached a tentative agreement on Sunday with Hollywood studios on a new contract, 146 days after its more than 11,000 screenwriters walked out of movie and television productions.
headline: How the Writers Guild Deal Reflects Organized Labor’s Power

abstract: New revelations about how the merger came to be could complicate efforts to take the former president’s media company public.
lead_paragraph: Digital World, the special purpose acquisition company that struck a deal to merge with former President Donald Trump’s media venture, revealed yesterday that it was under investigation by the S.E.C. The disclosure came as the SPAC filed to raise as much as $1 billion in a deal that would be completed shortly after it combined with Trump Media & Technology Group.
headline: The S.E.C. Turns Up the Heat on Trump’s SPAC Deal

abstract: Schools have financial incentives to favor the relatives of alumni.
lead_paragraph: If colleges do away with legacy admissions, will it cost them financially? That’s the big question being whispered among university provosts and trustees across the country as the practice of giving children of alumni an edge in admissions comes under fire and there is increasing pressure to end it.
headline: After Affirmative Action Ruling, Legacy Admissions Take Center Stage

abstract: A report on direct messages sent to five women found that “abuse and harmful content is allowed to thrive” on Instagram. The platform’s parent company, Meta, said it disagreed with the report’s conclusions.
lead_paragraph: A look into the private direct messages of five prominent women on Instagram found a torrent of harassment, including pornographic images and threats of physical and sexual violence, while the perpetrators typically faced little to no consequences, according to a new report released Wednesday.
headline: For Prominent Women on Instagram, DMs Can Be a Cesspool of Misogyny

abstract: Though not at the very adorable winner, fortunately.
lead_paragraph: Kelsey O’Hagan first heard about the Gerber Photo Search from a nurse at a doctor’s appointment for her now-12-month-old son, Everett.
headline: There’s a New Gerber Baby and Some Parents Are Mad

abstract: Or do you still eagerly await the latest film release in the genre?
lead_paragraph: Are you a fan of comic books and superhero movies? Have you seen every film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe? Do you eagerly mark your calendar when the latest release date is announced? Or are you growing a little tired of the genre?
headline: Are You Growing Tired of Superhero Movies?

abstract: In this rugged wedge of northwestern Canada, winter means shimmering northern lights as well as hot soaks, dog sleds and hair-freezing contests.
lead_paragraph: Frozen hair is a nuisance in most places, but at the Eclipse Nordic Hot Springs in Whitehorse, Yukon, it’s a higher calling. Every winter, hundreds of people try to freeze their hair into a troll-doll-like coif for a chance to win cash prizes of 2,000 Canadian dollars, or nearly $1,500.
headline: In the Yukon, Minus 35 Is Perfect Weather to Get Outside

abstract: Stocks are swinging all over the place. It’s a good time to take your hands off the wheel — here’s how to let go.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you’ve lost some money betting on stocks, like MetaZuckerbook, and you feel you ought to do something in the face of a wildly swinging market where a giant company can soar or lose a quarter of its value in a day.
headline: Don’t Touch. Don’t Even Look. Invest Like Your Senators Should.

abstract: Caitlin Reid’s puzzle clues are a master class in misdirection.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Let’s talk about misdirection. It’s one of my favorite tactics in crossword puzzle cluing but can be confusing to those who are not used to thinking about what else a clue can mean.
headline: That’s the Spirit!

abstract: Ad buyers will no longer be able to use topics such as health, race or sexual orientation to target people with unwanted ads on Facebook or other Meta apps.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Meta, the social media company formerly known as Facebook, said on Tuesday that it planned to eliminate advertisers’ ability to target people with promotions based on their interactions with content related to health, race and ethnicity, political affiliation, religion, sexual orientation and thousands of other topics.
headline: Meta plans to remove thousands of sensitive ad-targeting categories.

abstract: The leaders of Google, OpenAI, Microsoft and others are meeting with lawmakers on Sept. 13 to kick off listening sessions that may shape A.I. rules in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York, plans to kick off a series of listening sessions next month on the regulation of artificial intelligence with Elon Musk of Tesla, Sundar Pichai of Google, Sam Altman of OpenAI and Satya Nadella of Microsoft.
headline: Tech Chiefs to Gather in Washington Next Month on A.I. Regulations

abstract: The final tally of the damage will be higher, officials said, although no buildings have been destroyed over the past 24 hours as the fires ease.
lead_paragraph: At least 50 buildings were consumed by wildfires in and around Kelowna, British Columbia, over the past few days, officials said on Monday, warning that the final tally will be higher as their survey of the damage continues.
headline: At Least 50 Buildings Have Burned in British Columbia Wildfires

abstract: “The 1619 Project” continues to provoke national debate about race and history.
lead_paragraph: Three and a half years ago, The New York Times Magazine published The 1619 Project. It argued that 1619, the year the first slave ship is widely believed to have arrived in what is now the U.S., was as foundational to America as the year 1776, and that the legacy of chattel slavery still shapes our society. Essays from historians, scholars and others covered issues including capitalism, criminal justice and music, and sparked a national debate about race and history that is still raging.
headline: A Lasting Impact

abstract: Legislation would require parental consent for anyone under 18 to access the algorithm-based feeds on TikTok, Instagram and other platforms.
lead_paragraph: Social media platforms like TikTok and Instagram have harnessed powerful algorithms to captivate millions of users with endless streams of entertaining videos and content, transforming the way new generations scroll through their screens.
headline: New York Seeks to Limit Social Media’s Grip on Children’s Attention

abstract: Stocks and bonds have tumbled worldwide, with the 30-year Treasury bill hitting a 16-year high. Investors are worried about the economy’s health.
lead_paragraph: A far-right mutiny on Capitol Hill has sent markets into a tailspin. Skittish investors have dumped stocks and bonds this morning on fears that chaos in the Republican Party will cause a government shutdown next month and all but squash the fleeting hopes of a soft-landing economic recovery heading into an election year.
headline: Chaos in Washington Adds to Market Jitters

abstract: As he grapples with Parkinson’s and considers what’s next, the director continues to provoke in “The Kingdom Exodus,” the final season of his haunted-hospital drama.
lead_paragraph: In the first two seasons of Lars von Trier’s haunted-hospital drama “The Kingdom,” hailed since the 1990s as Denmark’s “Twin Peaks,” von Trier appears in a tuxedo at the end of each episode to offer a droll recap and wish viewers a pleasant evening. With an impish grin and an appeal to “take the good with the evil,” he ends with a devil-horn salute.
headline: Lars von Trier Had the Key to the End of ‘The Kingdom’ All Along

abstract: Photographers and illustrators who once eagerly shared images of their work on Instagram are moving away from the site as it emphasizes video.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Deb JJ Lee built a career in illustration on Instagram, one colorful comic at a time.
headline: A New Refrain From Artists: We ‘Almost Gave Up on Instagram’

abstract: Meme-makers and misinformation peddlers are embracing artificial intelligence tools to create convincing fake videos on the cheap.
lead_paragraph: It wouldn’t be completely out of character for Joe Rogan, the comedian turned podcaster, to endorse a “libido-boosting” coffee brand for men.
headline: Making Deepfakes Gets Cheaper and Easier Thanks to A.I.

abstract: Starting with Google Glass, all have been plagued with the same issues, even as Apple plunges into the market with its Vision Pro.
lead_paragraph: After years of anticipation, Apple’s first major new product in nearly a decade has arrived. The $3,500 Vision Pro, a face computer that resembles ski goggles, will be released next week.
headline: Why Making Face Computers Cool Isn’t Easy

abstract: Deciding the future of the climate.
lead_paragraph: Presidents and prime ministers are gathering in Glasgow this week for the 12-day U.N. global warming conference, often referred to as COP26, to discuss global climate policies, which are likely to determine the future of the planet.
headline: Your Monday Briefing

abstract: The company said Covid-19 restrictions were slowing production of the company’s new phones ahead of the holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after expressing optimism about the global economy and its business, Apple on Sunday warned that its sales would fall short of expectations because a key iPhone factory in China had been shut down by a coronavirus outbreak.
headline: Apple Could Be Short of iPhones Because of Factory Disruptions in China

abstract: With its TikTok bill, Congress sent a message to the world: You cannot disregard basic internet norms and expect to be treated like any other country.
lead_paragraph: China’s violations of human rights and the basic norms of internet freedom are blatant and obvious. This month, with little fanfare, the country ordered Apple to block downloads of WhatsApp, Threads and Signal within its borders. It already prevents citizens from connecting to dozens of other providers of information, including this newspaper and Wikipedia, and for years, it has aggressively surveilled journalists and dissidents.
headline: When It Comes to TikTok, the World’s Democracies Have Played the Sucker for Far Too Long

abstract: The president’s blunt statement capped weeks of frustration in the White House over the spread of vaccine disinformation on Facebook and other platforms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden unleashed his growing frustration with social media on Friday, saying that platforms like Facebook were “killing people” by allowing disinformation about the coronavirus vaccine to spread online.
headline: ‘They’re Killing People’: Biden Denounces Social Media for Virus Disinformation

abstract: So far, 2023 has been a relatively mild fire year for the state, but the final few months on the calendar have often proved to be dangerous ones.
lead_paragraph: Anyone looking at data from California’s fire season this year may be tempted to breathe a sigh of relief.
headline: Is California’s Fire Season Over?

abstract: YouTube’s advertising practices on kids’ channels could have resulted in companies tracking children across the web, a report said.
lead_paragraph: This year, BMO, a Canadian bank, was looking for Canadian adults to apply for a credit card. So the bank’s advertising agency ran a YouTube campaign using an ad-targeting system from Google that employs artificial intelligence to pinpoint ideal customers.
headline: YouTube Ads May Have Led to Online Tracking of Children, Research Says

abstract: Siri, Google Search, online marketing and your child’s homework will never be the same. Then there’s the misinformation problem.
lead_paragraph: This month, Jeremy Howard, an artificial intelligence researcher, introduced an online chatbot called ChatGPT to his 7-year-old daughter. It had been released a few days earlier by OpenAI, one of the world’s most ambitious A.I. labs.
headline: The New Chatbots Could Change the World. Can You Trust Them?

abstract: Even as they allow some employees to change how often they come into the office, tech companies are rapidly buying and leasing properties around the country.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — Early in the pandemic, when shops along Mill Avenue in downtown Tempe closed their doors and students at nearby Arizona State University were asked to go home, the roar of construction continued to fill the air. Now, gleaming in the sunlight and stuffed with amenities, towering glass office buildings have sprouted up all over the Phoenix metropolitan area.
headline: Big Tech Makes a Big Bet: Offices Are Still the Future

abstract: Trevor Noah said the excision of family leave meant that “America will remain the only nation in the world where women try to give birth during their lunch break.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
headline: Late Night Savors What’s Left of Biden’s ‘Build Back Better’ Plan

abstract: Auto insurers try to make it easy to sign up for a policy. Those efforts have given an opening to scammers.
lead_paragraph: The first sign of trouble was the arrival of envelopes from the New York State Department of Labor, all about my wife’s previous earnings and recent unemployment filing. The second was the cheery “Welcome to Progressive” package, telling her how great it was to have her with the company now that she had bought her new auto insurance policy.
headline: How Identity Thieves Took My Wife for a Ride

abstract: The longtime chief operating officer of Facebook’s parent company, Ms. Sandberg has had a lower profile during Mark Zuckerberg’s pursuit of the so-called metaverse.
lead_paragraph: When Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, recruited a Google executive named Sheryl Sandberg to his social network in 2008, he said he had hired her because “she has just about the most relevant industry experience for Facebook, especially since we need to scale our operations and scale them globally.”
headline: Sheryl Sandberg Is Stepping Down From Meta

abstract: Investors are re-pricing the risks of the latest coronavirus variant.
lead_paragraph: Scientists, doctors and public health officials are still assessing the danger posed by the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, but markets are already jumping to conclusions. On Friday, markets fell on fears that the fast-spreading strain of the coronavirus first detected in South Africa, and which has now been found in more than a dozen countries, could throw the global economic recovery into reverse. Many countries have banned travel from countries in Southern Africa, while Israel, Japan and Morocco closed their borders to all outside travelers.
headline: Markets Aren’t That Spooked by Omicron

abstract: The internet giant, planning on employees returning to the office for a few days a week, is building another $1 billion office less than two miles away.
lead_paragraph: Google said Friday that it would spend $1 billion to purchase a London office building, making it the owner of another high-priced piece of real estate as the internet giant bets on an eventual return to office for its employees around the world.
headline: Google pays $1 billion for a London office building.

abstract: The inquiry predates the botched presale of Taylor Swift tickets this week and is said to focus on whether Live Nation has abused its power in the live music industry.
lead_paragraph: Follow for live updates on the Ticketmaster Senate hearing.
headline: Justice Dept. Is Said to Investigate Ticketmaster’s Parent Company

abstract: Crypto fans have argued that code can be a better arbitrator than traditional regulators.
lead_paragraph: The first time the Harvard law professor Lawrence Lessig told computer scientists they were the unwitting regulators of the digital age — about 20 years ago — he made a coder cry. “I am not a politician. I’m a programmer,” Mr. Lessig recalls her protesting, horrified by the idea.
headline: For Rules in Technology, the Challenge is to Balance Code and Law

abstract: Hoang-Kim Vu and Jessica Zetzman play their cards right.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — What makes a Monday puzzle great? Is it the theme’s wordplay? The liveliness of the fill entries? Some other intangible X factor? After solving today’s undeniably great crossword puzzle from the husband-and-wife constructing team Hoang-Kim Vu and Jessica Zetzman, I posed this question to the puzzle editors Sam Ezersky and Wyna Liu.
headline: You’re Reading One Right Now

abstract: Meta’s chief executive made a rare court appearance as the Federal Trade Commission tries to block his company’s purchase of the virtual reality start-up Within.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, was asked a series of questions in federal court on Tuesday about his aspirations for the immersive online world of the metaverse.
headline: Mark Zuckerberg Testifies About Meta’s Virtual Reality Ambitions

abstract: The April 2, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ethan Mollick. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ethan Mollick

abstract: As we trade sweatpants for formality and fun, corsets are one of the things to reign supreme.
lead_paragraph: After two years of ditching bras and languishing in leggings, many are welcoming structure back into their lives — and, for some, that extends to their clothing choices.
headline: The Corset Keeps Coming Back

abstract: The city’s addiction crisis has worsened quickly — and culture is a big factor.
lead_paragraph: For some San Franciscans, a drug crisis is just part of city living. They see people shooting up in front of their homes and businesses. They often find someone dozing on a sidewalk, high. Sometimes, they check for a pulse. “That’s how I found my first dead body,” said Adam Mesnick, owner of a local deli.
headline: San Francisco’s “Pro-Drug Culture”

abstract: New treatments are changing once deadly forms of the disease into manageable long-term illnesses. But not all patients are benefiting.
lead_paragraph: Carol MacKenzie had just finished playing a round of golf when she noticed some swelling and pain in her neck. It was 2014, and 18 years had passed since Ms. MacKenzie finished treatment for breast cancer. But it had returned. This time the cancer was growing inside several lymph nodes around her neck, plunging her back into treatment long after she thought that was all behind her.
headline: Is a Revolution in Cancer Treatment Within Reach?

abstract: Gina Moxley’s punchy, punk-rock play counters a woman’s betrayal by her therapists, exposing the sexism in her treatment.
lead_paragraph: I demand justice for Gloria.
headline: ‘The Patient Gloria’ Review: A Theatrical Remedy for Toxic Therapy

abstract: The agency will be the first in the federal government to roll out a comprehensive plan to integrate the technology into a variety of uses, from fighting crime to helping disaster survivors.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security has seen the opportunities and risks of artificial intelligence firsthand. It found a trafficking victim years later using an A.I. tool that conjured an image of the child a decade older. But it has also been tricked into investigations by deep fake images created by A.I.
headline: The Department of Homeland Security Is Embracing A.I.

abstract: California legislators have made the biggest push to pass new laws to rein in the technology. Colorado passed one protecting consumers.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in California last month advanced about 30 new measures on artificial intelligence aimed at protecting consumers and jobs, one of the biggest efforts yet to regulate the new technology.
headline: States Take Up A.I. Regulation Amid Federal Standstill

abstract: The playwright behind “Ohio State Murders,” opening this month, has a theory as to why: “It’s because I’m a Black woman.”
lead_paragraph: THE PLAYWRIGHT ADRIENNE Kennedy will make her Broadway debut this month at the age of 91, with “Ohio State Murders” (1992), a play she tried for years to commit to paper. “I couldn’t do it,” she recalls. It was 1989, and she’d been commissioned by the Great Lakes Theater in Cleveland, her hometown, to write about her experience as an undergraduate, decades ago, at Ohio State University. She was about to return her advance. And then, she says, “I just happened to be in the earthquake.”
headline: At 91, Adrienne Kennedy Is Finally on Broadway. What Took So Long?

abstract: Liz Kingsman plays a messy attention-seeker grasping at relevance in a sharp satire of the trend of female comics playing chaotic train wrecks.
lead_paragraph: Liz Kingsman’s stupendously silly spoof “One Woman Show” arrives in New York with enough buzz for an apiary. The rare solo comedy that moved from small theaters to the West End in London, it has received gushing reviews, topped year-end best-of lists and inspired more than one profile proclaiming its star the “queen of comedy.”
headline: ‘One Woman Show’ Review: Unlikable for Laughs

abstract: Shares of Meta, the parent company of Facebook, fell more than 26 percent, a loss that wiped more than $230 billion off its market value.
lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street tumbled on Thursday, with Meta, the parent company of Facebook, leading the way with a drop of 26.4 percent, its worst one-day loss ever and one that erased more than $230 billion off its market value.
headline: Meta plunges and sets off Wall Street’s worst drop in nearly a year.

abstract: Activision has a lot of popular games that fit into Microsoft’s plans to build a vast library of titles that can be played on all sorts of devices. The metaverse can wait.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is inevitable now that when a big tech company makes a significant, strategic decision — like Microsoft’s plan to spend $70 billion on the video game giant Activision Blizzard — it invokes the metaverse.
headline: It’s Not Complicated. Microsoft Wants Activision for Its Games.

abstract: The new $500 headset lets people see the outside world while immersed in virtual reality. The benefits are to be determined.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I spent several hours trying Meta’s latest goggles, the Quest 3. They ship next month. The headset runs virtual reality games with a novel twist: While shooting a blaster gun, snatching bats from midair and controlling a robot, I could see the real world through built-in cameras.
headline: With Meta’s Quest 3, Mixed Reality Is Here. So Now What?

abstract: In a movie extrapolated from one of his stand-up bits, Bert Kreischer is dragged to Russia to face a gory but still comedic reckoning.
lead_paragraph: The star of this picture, Bert Kreischer, is one of those popular stand-up comedians who’s not zeitgeist-adjacent enough to generate much in the way of think pieces or buzz. But in the late 1990s, as a student at Florida State University, he was the subject of a Rolling Stone magazine profile that named him “the top partyer at the Number One Party School in the country.”
headline: ‘The Machine’ Review: A Hard-Partying Comedian Pays for His Sins

abstract: Truong Huy San was accused of “abusing democratic freedoms,” a charge that rights groups say has been frequently used against critics of the government.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Vietnam have arrested one of the country’s most prominent journalists and accused him of “abusing democratic freedoms” by posting articles on Facebook that “infringed on the interests of the state and the legitimate rights and interests of organizations and individuals.”
headline: Vietnam Arrests Prominent Journalist for Facebook Posts

abstract: Revelations aside, there’s only one thing that will get the company to change its ways.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has endured one of the most punishing stretches of corporate coverage in recent memory, exposing its immense power and blithe disregard for its deleterious impacts.
headline: Face It, Facebook Won’t Change Unless Advertisers Demand It

abstract: Now that people of all genders have embraced the rituals of beauty, once seemingly reserved only for women, what does it mean to adorn our faces?
lead_paragraph: THE FIRST TIME I remember ever seeing a man wearing makeup was at a nightclub in midtown Kansas City, Mo., that allowed in under-21s one night a month. It must have been 1991 or ’92; he was out front with his friends, smoking; I, in my favorite blue-and-white star-print maxi dress and thrift store velveteen Mary Janes, was arriving with my brother and his girlfriend.
headline: Makeup Is for Everyone

abstract: In ancient Greece the great playwrights helped to plant and nurture the seeds of representative government through their characters and plots.
lead_paragraph: In the Sophocles play “Antigone,” King Creon, after ordering the execution of his niece for betraying him, asks, “Am I to rule for others, or myself?”
headline: For Early Democracy, Theater Was a Catalyst

abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Mysteries can help a plot gallop along even when the book you’re reading isn’t strictly speaking a “mystery,” plucked from the crime shelves of your local library. That’s certainly the case for three of the novels on this week’s list: In one, an immigrant searches for her missing husband, in another the return of a prodigal daughter brings buried family secrets to light, and in the third a hard-boiled Sam Spade-ish cryptozoologist stalks mystical creatures through the streets of a Chinese city.
headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week

abstract: Say hello to new-and-improved A.I. assistants, and move over to brands like Twitter and Tesla.
lead_paragraph: Each year, I look ahead at what’s new in technology to predict the tech that may affect your life in a big way — and the tech that will most likely be a fad.
headline: The Tech That Will Invade Our Lives in 2023

abstract: A.I. fervor has rocketed the chip company’s share price upward. Our columnist asked A.I. chatbots how big Nvidia would become if it kept growing as fast as it had over the past year.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a household name quite yet, but anyone who follows the stock market knows at least a little about Nvidia.
headline: If Nvidia Keeps Rising Like This, It Will Be Bigger Than the Global Economy

abstract: It’s been a tough run for Meta, and the boss seems to be getting out some aggression with military-style endurance routines and Brazilian jujitsu.
lead_paragraph: Close your eyes. Picture Mark Zuckerberg. What do you see?
headline: Mark Zuckerberg Would Like You to Know About His Workouts

abstract: From gross to grisly, this month’s horror movie picks coat the globe in gore.
lead_paragraph: Each month, we’re recommending five recent horror movies available to stream. Find more genre suggestions and other ways to navigate the streaming services at What to Watch.
headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Covid, Kentucky, Gymnasts: Your Monday Evening Briefing

abstract: “It’s the kind of week you normally post about on Facebook,” Meyers said on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
headline: Seth Meyers Breaks Down Facebook’s Very Bad Week

abstract: The May 31, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with D. Graham Burnett. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews D. Graham Burnett

abstract: Disappointing earnings from Microsoft, Alphabet and Texas Instruments reveal the big challenges facing technology giants.
lead_paragraph: The recent rally in technology stocks could come to a screeching halt at the opening bell on Wednesday. Overnight, investors dumped portions of their tech portfolios after disappointing results from Alphabet, Microsoft and Texas Instruments, with the trio reporting that a slowing global economy continues to batter demand for digital advertising, cloud computing and chips.
headline: Tech Stocks Tumble as Growth Falters

abstract: Jack Dorsey, who is stepping down after six years as Twitter’s chief executive, is one of the tech leaders who seem to have grown tired of managing their empires.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, when Jack Dorsey rejoined Twitter as its interim chief executive, he raved about the app with quasi-religious fervor, calling it “the closest thing we have to a global consciousness.”
headline: Dorsey’s Twitter Departure Hints at Tech Moguls’ Restlessness

abstract: Shares in Elon Musk’s electric vehicle maker fell sharply after the company delivered lackluster quarterly results and declined to give full-year guidance.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk and Tesla shareholders are at a crossroads.
headline: Tesla Tumbles as Growth Slows

abstract: The former president targeted the platform while in office, but has now come out against a bill that could ban the short video app in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: TikTok users have continued to flood the social media platform — and lawmakers’ inboxes — with pleas to halt a bill that would force its Chinese owners to divest or face a ban in the U.S.
headline: Could Trump Save TikTok?

abstract: What if technology companies seriously considered the problems of older customers?
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley isn’t just consumed by youth; often, it’s blinded.
headline: What Mark Zuckerberg Doesn’t Understand About Old People

abstract: The 27th annual U.N. climate talks opened yesterday in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Developing countries face irreversible damage from climate change but have done little to cause the crisis. And they are demanding compensation from the parties they see as responsible: wealthier nations that have emitted half of all heat-trapping gases since 1850 and created pollution that is dangerously heating the planet.
headline: Your Monday Briefing

abstract: Efforts to ban “Glory to Hong Kong,” a song popularized during pro-democracy protests in 2019, could set up a legal battle between tech giants and Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: After “Glory to Hong Kong” emerged as the unofficial anthem of pro-democracy demonstrators in 2019, the government of Hong Kong has tried to stifle its use. It has banned the song from schools. When it was played in error last year instead of the Chinese national anthem at a rugby match in South Korea, the Hong Kong government demanded an investigation.
headline: Hong Kong Asks Court to Stop Protest Anthem From Circulating Online

abstract: In “A Thread of Violence,” Mark O’Connell investigates an infamous Irish murder case that eludes explanation, refusing to cohere into a single narrative.
lead_paragraph: In “The Silent Woman” (1994), her merciless dissection of literary biography (that genre in which “the remaining secrets of the famous dead are taken from them and dumped out in full view of the world”), Janet Malcolm identified a version of biographical narrative — the kind she herself preferred — that doesn’t mesh with readers’ expectations of authorial certainty. “What the reader has usually heard in the text,” she writes, “is the sound of doubt, the sound of a crack opening in the wall of the biographer’s self-assurance.”
headline: A Literary Take on a Notorious Crime Finds More Doubt Than Truth

abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
headline: Today’s Top News: Key Takeaways From the G.O.P. Debate, and More

abstract: It may seem impossible to feel upbeat about the future, especially now. But there are common traits optimists share that can help improve anyone’s outlook.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re back in high school — fluorescent lights humming, hard plastic chairs, a classroom stuffy with hormones and anxiety — and you’ve just aced a test. Do you think to yourself, “I guess I got lucky today?” Or does your internal monologue say, “Damn, I’m good!”?
headline: Are You (Still) an Optimist? These Questions Might Help Explain Why

abstract: Our time and attention are valuable resources, and we’re in control of how — and on whom — we spend them.
lead_paragraph: I got together this week with an old friend I hadn’t seen since before the pandemic. Before meeting up, I was seized with a now-familiar apprehension. Would we find our old dynamic? Or would we sit across from one another awkwardly, unable to reclaim the rhythms and repartee that used to come so easily?
headline: The Friends We Keep

abstract: The move is part of an effort to make the app more like WhatsApp and iMessage. Law enforcement authorities say the privacy makes it harder to track criminals.
lead_paragraph: Meta said on Wednesday that it planned to turn Messenger, its global chat and voice messaging app, into a fully encrypted service, a move that is set to rekindle a debate about privacy and security in communications.
headline: Meta Plans to Add Encryption to Messenger, Stoking a Privacy Debate

abstract: The sitcom, about to become American TV’s longest-running live-action comedy, isn’t everyone’s kind of humor. These episodes capture the show’s brand of boundary-pushing satire.
lead_paragraph: “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” is one of the most successful comedies in TV history, but it isn’t for everyone.
headline: New to ‘It’s Always Sunny’? Watch These 5 Episodes (at Your Own Risk)

abstract: Two survivors of pandemic parenting needed a relationship tuneup. Could a new virtual therapy module called Ours do the trick?
lead_paragraph: On a recent sticky summer evening, Andrew and I assumed our trademark marital position: hovered over the iPad in bed.
headline: Honey, I Shrunk the Couples Counselor

abstract: The use of content from news and information providers to train artificial intelligence systems may force a reassessment of where to draw legal lines.
lead_paragraph: The boom in artificial intelligence tools that draw on troves of content from across the internet has begun to test the bounds of copyright law.
headline: Boom in A.I. Prompts a Test of Copyright Law

abstract: Bigger is still better, as the largest tech firms keep gobbling up weakened rivals.
lead_paragraph: It feels like another turbulent time in tech, another paradigm shift, like what happened with the move to mobile. In this case, it is a move away from the internet as we know it (Web2) — a soft-touch regulatory environment — to what’s being called Web3, where actual guardrails might be erected.
headline: The Pandemic Culls the Big Tech Herd

abstract: The Justice Department had accused Meta’s housing advertising system of discriminating against Facebook users based on their race, gender, religion and other characteristics.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Meta on Tuesday agreed to alter its ad technology and pay a penalty of $115,054, in a settlement with the Justice Department over claims that the company’s ad systems had discriminated against Facebook users by restricting who was able to see housing ads on the platform based on their race, gender and ZIP code.
headline: Meta Agrees to Alter Ad Technology in Settlement With U.S.

abstract: The start of a new Russian offensive.
lead_paragraph: With hundreds of thousands of Russian troops now in Ukraine, officials are warning that a new Russian offensive that could rival the start of the war is underway, with the Kremlin seeking to reshape the battlefield and seize the momentum.
headline: Your Thursday Briefing

abstract: The company is intensifying formal partnerships with faith groups across the United States and shaping the future of religious experience.
lead_paragraph: Months before the megachurch Hillsong opened its new outpost in Atlanta, its pastor sought advice on how to build a church in a pandemic.
headline: Facebook’s Next Target: The Religious Experience

abstract: Robert Kraft, an alumnus of Columbia, suggested he would withhold donations to the school. Other alumni are keeping quiet.
