abstract: New Mexico’s attorney general has accused Meta of not protecting children from sexual predators on its platforms. He now wants to know how it polices subscribers to accounts featuring children.
lead_paragraph: The New Mexico attorney general, who last year sued Meta alleging that it did not protect children from sexual predators and had made false claims about its platforms’ safety, announced Monday that his office would examine how the company’s paid-subscription services attract predators.
headline: Instagram and Facebook Subscriptions Get New Scrutiny in Child Safety Suit

abstract: Jobs growth continued to be strong. OPEC Plus announced that it would increase oil production. And a report on inflation in May is coming.
lead_paragraph: Sheryl Sandberg announced Wednesday that she was stepping down as chief operating officer of Meta after 14 years with the company. In that time, Facebook, as it was formerly known, grew into a behemoth, acquiring dozens of companies and extending its influence across the internet. Ms. Sandberg built her personal brand alongside the company, publishing “Lean In,” her best-selling 2013 book about how to succeed as a woman in the workplace. But Ms. Sandberg’s reputation suffered as Facebook faced backlash for its role in the spread of misinformation during the 2016 election, the data breach involving Cambridge Analytica and other scandals. And many of the women who once subscribed to Ms. Sandberg’s philosophy grew disillusioned as they discovered that “leaning in” did not bring about the raises and promotions she spoke of. Ms. Sandberg will remain on Meta’s board.
headline: The Week in Business: Meta Changes

abstract: The S&P 500 is trading at a three-month low as surging oil prices, rising bond yields and concerns about economic growth send investors to the exits.
lead_paragraph: Stocks are heading for their worst month of the year as a triple whammy of soaring bond yields, rising oil prices and slowing growth trigger a widespread sell-off, even in once-loved mega-cap tech companies.
headline: What’s Driving the September Stock Swoon

abstract: Andrew Bosworth, who will become Meta’s chief technology officer next year, laid out a vision for the social network to adopt and work with various blockchain or crypto technologies that have collectively become known as web3.
lead_paragraph: Meta, Facebook’s parent company, is aiming for “deep compatibility” with blockchain technology, according to an internal post on Tuesday from a top executive.
headline: Meta aims for ‘deep compatibility’ with blockchain, according to an internal post.

abstract: Kick off your week with Simon Marotte’s Monday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Today’s constructor is Simon Marotte, a name we encountered not even a month ago. Mr. Marotte must be busy indeed to be churning out publishable puzzles at this rate — after all, The New York Times receives around 150 crossword submissions per week, according to the senior puzzle editor, Joel Fagliano, so to have two “winners” in such a short period of time is quite the coup for Mr. Marotte.
headline: All the Clues That Are Fit to Print

abstract: Our columnist is searching for his own niche in a universe dominated by giants.
lead_paragraph: My friends, in these difficult and frightening times, humor is more essential than ever. So let’s talk about antitrust law and content monetization.
headline: Swimming With the Sharks in Facebook’s World

abstract: President Biden has signed the bill to force a sale of the video app or ban it. Now the law faces court challenges, a shortage of qualified buyers and Beijing’s hostility.
lead_paragraph: A bill that would force a sale of TikTok by its Chinese owner, ByteDance — or ban it outright — was passed by the Senate on Tuesday and signed into law Wednesday by President Biden.
headline: Congress Passed a Bill That Could Ban TikTok. Now Comes the Hard Part.

abstract: “Dave” and “Swarm” try to demystify extreme fandom but end up pledging fealty to celebrity.
lead_paragraph: The “stan,” a word that comes from Eminem’s seminal 2000 song about obsessive, sometimes violent superfans, has become a locus for celebrity anxiety in recent years. Popular fan bases can be malicious in defense of their idols — see Taylor’s Swifties, Nicki’s Barbz and Beyoncé’s BeyHive. (Selena Gomez recently had to chide her fans for sending death threats to Hailey Bieber because of a convoluted rivalry instigated in part by eyebrow lamination.) It can create an awkward dynamic for the famouses: Denounce your fan base’s zealotry, and you risk seeming ungrateful. And while obsessive fans have existed for as long as celebrity has, the internet, which is conducive to acts of anonymous virulence, has made stan fury particularly potent. It was only a matter of time before scripted TV tackled this subject.
headline: Why TV Can’t Quite Take a Stand on Stan Culture

abstract: Six people, all 35 or younger, talk about what they are doing to shake up politics on the continent, and what inspired them to step up.
lead_paragraph: “Not a lot of democracy happening at the moment,” the BBC journalist Will Ross said on the radio in August about the situation across West and Central Africa while reporting on a postelection coup in Gabon. He cited a litany of examples across the region — Guinea, Niger, Chad, Sudan, Burkina Faso and Mali — where there have been coups or armed rebellions in the last two years.
headline: Across Africa, Young Leaders Emerge to Push for Change

abstract: On TikTok, cringe comedy creators are gaining large followings and brand deals by impersonating terrible people.
lead_paragraph: During a three-part special examining the crimes of the serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer that aired last November on “Dr. Phil,” Phil McGraw, the host of the daytime talk show, played a TikTok video of a 27-year-old woman named Stanzi Potenza as evidence that true-crime fandom had gone too far. In the video, Ms. Potenza said she was so obsessed with Netflix’s “Monster: The Jeffrey Dahmer Story” that she stayed home from work in diapers to binge the series uninterrupted.
headline: Welcome to CringeTok, Where Being Insufferable Can Be Lucrative

abstract: If ever an issue cried out for some lawmaking guidance, this is it.
lead_paragraph: Facebook, oops, Meta — boy, this is going to take some getting used to — announced this week that it would end its decade-old facial recognition system and delete the face data of over a billion users, prompting the cybersecurity reporter Kashmir Hill of The New York Times to tweet, “My jaw dropped to the floor.”
headline: Is Meta’s Facial Recognition Retreat Another Head Fake?

abstract: Also, the 80th anniversary of D-Day.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Declan Walsh and the photographer Ivor Prickett spent three weeks in Sudan, where few foreign reporters have had access in the past year. Since the conflict erupted there in April 2023, millions of people have been displaced and a looming famine threatens the lives of hundreds of thousands of children.
headline: Thursday Briefing: A Special Report From Sudan

abstract: Ten people were killed at a dance hall in the San Gabriel Valley city.
lead_paragraph: Lunar New Year turned tragic over the weekend in Monterey Park, a city in the San Gabriel Valley in Southern California that is among the most predominantly Asian American in the country.
headline: What to Know About the Monterey Park Shooting

abstract: Remote work and rising interest rates are dealing a double blow to office landlords, with potentially grave consequences for the city and even national economy.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s biggest corporate landlords had it great for years — benefiting from a booming economy in a city where companies clamored to set up offices and from low interest rates that buoyed the economics of an industry built on debt.
headline: A Bleak Outlook for Manhattan’s Office Space May Signal a Bigger Problem

abstract: Preying on shoppers strapped for cash and time, scammers are setting up fake sites that claim to have deep discounts on premium brands.
lead_paragraph: The online retailer Bombas sells socks that are durable, popular and pricey. One pair of women’s ankle socks, for instance, can go for $15.
headline: With Many Retailers Offering Online Sales, Phony Sites Blend In

abstract: Creating a new A.I. system requires lots of money and lots of computing power, which is controlled by the industry’s giants.
lead_paragraph: The tech industry loves its garage start-up stories. From Hewlett-Packard to Google, the tales of bootstrapped companies that have turned into giants have inspired generations of entrepreneurs.
headline: In the Age of A.I., Tech’s Little Guys Need Big Friends

abstract: The F.T.C. chair shot to fame six years ago after publishing an academic article that the company needed to be contained. Legal experts wonder if that time has come.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, Lina Khan, then a 29-year-old law student, shot to fame with an academic article about why Amazon should be contained. Cutting against prevailing trends in antitrust law, Khan argued that the e-commerce giant was unfairly dominating huge swaths of the American economy.
headline: Lina Khan Raises the Heat on Amazon

abstract: Some of the jurors’ identities have been shared on social media, with suggestions that they be harassed or made “infamous.”
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Donald Trump’s expected surrender at a jail in Georgia.
headline: Officials Investigate Threats Against Trump Grand Jurors in Georgia

abstract: The messaging app stopped working for about two hours on Tuesday morning. WhatsApp did not provide a cause.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — WhatsApp, the popular messaging app, was inaccessible to users in several countries around the world for about two hours on Tuesday morning, including Britain, India and South Korea.
headline: WhatsApp Goes Down Briefly Around the World

abstract: Adam Neumann, the co-working company’s onetime chief, has sought for months to buy the now-bankrupt business, but accuses its current leaders of stonewalling him.
lead_paragraph: Adam Neumann shot to fame by turning WeWork into a cultural and business phenomenon, before being ousted from the work space operator in dramatic fashion.
headline: WeWork’s Co-Founder Is Trying to Buy the Company

abstract: The comedian devoted a segment of “The Daily Show” to West’s troubling online behavior, but said he didn’t ask for the rapper to lose his spot performing on the Grammys.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Noah, the comedian and face of “The Daily Show,” is returning to host the Grammy Awards for the second year in a row. For the 2021 show, Noah was front and center at an unconventional Grammys, with some performances pretaped and the bulk of the ceremony held outside the Staples Center (now known as the Crypto.com Arena) in Los Angeles. “On the whole, Noah made something that could have felt like several competing shows feel like one,” The New York Times pop music critic Jon Caramanica wrote.
headline: Trevor Noah returns as host, after a dust-up with Kanye West.

abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about even if you’re not planning to see them.
lead_paragraph: A group of bumbling criminals kidnap a young girl and hold her for ransom, but the titular 12-year-old ballerina turns out to have more than just tulle up her sleeve.
headline: 8 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week

abstract: The popular drug discount app deceptively shared details on users’ illnesses and medicines with ad firms, regulators said in a legal complaint.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans have used GoodRx, a drug discount app, to search for lower prices on prescriptions like antidepressants, H.I.V. medications and treatments for sexually transmitted diseases at their local drugstores. But U.S. regulators say the app’s coupons and convenience came at a high cost for users: wrongful disclosure of their intimate health information.
headline: GoodRx Leaked User Health Data to Facebook and Google, F.T.C. Says

abstract: Interest in the futuristic, immersive digital world is fading just as Apple plans to debut a virtual reality device.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg embraced a digital world known as the metaverse when he said in November 2021 that he was changing his company’s name from Facebook to Meta.
headline: Apple Is Stepping Into the Metaverse. Will Anyone Care?

abstract: The April 16 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Alison Gopnik. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Alison Gopnik

abstract: A presentation at the U.N., organized in part by Sheryl Sandberg, accused the body of ignoring the rape and mutilation of women in the Oct. 7 assault on Israel, and heard gruesome details from witnesses.
lead_paragraph: The body of one woman had “nails and different objects in her female organs.” In another house, a person’s genitals were so mutilated that “we couldn’t identify if it was a man or a woman.”
headline: Accounts of Sexual Violence by Hamas Are Aired Amid Criticism of U.N.

abstract: If you need an escape this weekend, try a British show, a zippy French drama or a documentary about Tiger Woods.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?

abstract: The troubled lender is working on a lifeline, but time is running out.
lead_paragraph: First Republic is limping into the weekend, days after reporting disastrous first-quarter results. The bank is still working on a lifeline, with some involved saying it is touch and go whether the federal government will assist in some way, DealBook hears.
headline: First Republic’s Troubles Reignite Fears of a Banking Crisis

abstract: Revelations about rivals’ plans may prompt the bank’s shareholders to ask about who will replace Jamie Dimon at an annual investor gathering on Monday.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase will hold its investor day on Monday after one of the busiest starts to a year that the bank has had in some time.
headline: JPMorgan May Face New Questions About Succession

abstract: Hear tracks by Maren Morris, Stromae, Robert Glasper and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
headline: FKA twigs Seeks Angelic Intervention, and 10 More New Songs

abstract: All of Facebook’s main products — Instagram, WhatsApp, Messenger and the “big blue app” of Facebook — were inaccessible to at least some users around 3 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook and its family of apps were inaccessible for about two hours on Friday afternoon, the second time in a week that the social network experienced widespread problems with its services.
headline: Facebook and its apps suffer another outage.

abstract: But how long can we wait for action against the social media company?
lead_paragraph: Would I like to write about anything else in tech except Facebook? I would. Can I write about anything else in tech but Facebook? I cannot.
headline: Brazen Is the Order of the Day at Facebook

abstract: In the first Broadway revival of the Monty Python musical, the old bits are verbatim but the clowns are running the circus.
lead_paragraph: Even the coconuts get entrance applause.
headline: ‘Spamalot’ Review: You’ll Laugh in Its General Direction

abstract: A Delaware court ruling on his $50 billion compensation plan at Tesla raises questions about corporate governance and more.
lead_paragraph: An unusual pay package that Tesla devised in 2018 helped make Elon Musk the world’s wealthiest individual.
headline: What Elon Musk Could Lose After His Big Pay Deal Is Blocked

abstract: Online chatter about holding rallies has grown, but sizable real-world gatherings on Thursday are unlikely to materialize.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the Jan. 6 Capitol Attack Anniversary.
headline: Right-Wing Calls to Celebrate Jan. 6 Anniversary Draw a Muted Response

abstract: The cult newsletter Perfectly Imperfect — known for tapping downtown scenesters, influencers and “it” girls for their personal recommendations — has a new platform where all can share their tastes.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to explain the way a certain kind of very online tastemaking works in 2024 to an alien, or a 45-year-old, you could do a lot worse than showing them Perfectly Imperfect.
headline: Can Everyone Be a Tastemaker?

abstract: More multilingual fact-checking groups are pushing back against misleading translations, manipulated images and outright lies that jump platforms and cross borders.
lead_paragraph: Unsubstantiated rumors and outright falsehoods spread widely in immigrant communities ahead of the presidential election in 2020. That is happening again in the run-up to this year’s midterm elections, researchers say, but with an insidious twist: The social media accounts pushing misinformation are now targeting audiences in more languages on more topics and across more digital platforms, with scant resistance from social media companies.
headline: Misinformation Swirls in Non-English Languages Ahead of Midterms

abstract: People have little protection or recourse when the technology creates and spreads falsehoods about them.
lead_paragraph: Marietje Schaake’s résumé is full of notable roles: Dutch politician who served for a decade in the European Parliament, international policy director at Stanford University’s Cyber Policy Center, adviser to several nonprofits and governments.
headline: What Can You Do When A.I. Lies About You?

abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 20, 2023.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on June 13 about NATO members conducting major air exercises in Germany as a signal of allied strength against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine misidentified a fighter jet. The jet shown is a Saab Gripen, not a Eurofighter Typhoon.
headline: Corrections: June 20, 2023

abstract: The tech giant has been accused of stifling competition by packaging its video conferencing app with other tools like Word and Excel.
lead_paragraph: European Union regulators on Tuesday charged Microsoft with breaking antitrust rules by bundling its Teams video conferencing and collaboration software with a suite of other productivity tools, giving it an unfair advantage over rivals.
headline: E.U. Charges Microsoft With Antitrust Violations Over Teams Bundling

abstract: Instagram’s choice to prioritize videos over photos creates unforeseen costs for small companies, leaving many owners disheartened.
lead_paragraph: Sana Javeri Kadri leaned heavily on Instagram for marketing when she started her spice company, Diaspora Company, in 2017. “I completely credit them for our growth — and then the algorithm changed and our sales dropped horrifyingly,” she said. “There was a point where I was having dreams that Instagram could go back to the way things were, and my nightmares were about all the reasons why that was impossible.”
headline: Food Businesses Lose Faith in Instagram After Algorithm Changes

abstract: Journalists and tech executives seem to be fighting each other to a draw in a battle that has no end in sight.
lead_paragraph: After Mark Zuckerberg announced, in a goofy video on Thursday, that he was changing his company’s name to Meta and shifting its focus to the creation of a digital space called the metaverse, he granted interviews to just four media outlets, including exactly zero of the great American legacy publications.
headline: Learning to Live With Mark Zuckerberg

abstract: Five days after Facebook changed its name to Meta, an Australian artist found herself blocked, with seemingly no recourse, from an account documenting nearly a decade of her life and work.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — In October, Thea-Mai Baumann, an Australian artist and technologist, found herself sitting on prime internet real estate.
headline: Her Instagram Handle Was ‘Metaverse.’ Last Month, It Vanished.

abstract: A large language model generates answers as gamers combine blocks of text. It can get as weird as “Farming Simulator 2013: Furry Shades of Grey” and “Osama Bin Donuts.”
lead_paragraph: Fuse “Water” and “Water” to get a “Lake.” Add “Fire” to “Mountain” to create “Volcano.” Combine “Titanic” and “Poison Ivy” to form something called “Poisonous Titanic.”
headline: Playing Infinite Craft Is Like Peering Into an A.I.’s Brain

abstract: DealBook is live and in person with our annual summit in New York.
lead_paragraph: DealBook is live and in person with our annual summit in New York.
headline: Here’s the agenda for this afternoon.

abstract: A return to in-person awards meant a return to fashion form for many celebrities. Have we learned nothing from the past year?
lead_paragraph: The 93rd annual Academy Awards were a night of historic firsts: first woman of color to win the directing Oscar; first Black women to win the makeup and hairstyling Oscar; oldest woman ever to win an Oscar; first Korean actor to win an Oscar. But in at least one area it was more like same-old, same-old: the red carpet.
headline: On the Oscars Red Carpet: A Lot of Style, Little Substance

abstract: For an outdoor residency at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the Bridge Production Group breathes fresh life into a 2004 musical.
lead_paragraph: The charm of the early internet era — before the web became an all-consuming necessity and was a seemingly innocent tool for promoting your work — survives in a new revival of “[title of show],” Jeff Bowen and Hunter Bell’s autobiographical one-act musical from 2004.
headline: Review: Revisiting Four Nobodies in ‘[title of show]’

abstract: V.R. treatments may provide relief similar to intravenous opioids — a tantalizing prospect for the millions of Americans living with chronic pain.
lead_paragraph: After an hour-and-a-half bus ride last November, Julia Monterroso arrived at a white Art Deco building in West Hollywood, just opposite a Chanel store and the Ivy, a restaurant famous for its celebrity sightings. Monterroso was there to see Brennan Spiegel, a gastroenterologist and researcher at Cedars-Sinai who runs one of the largest academic medical initiatives studying virtual reality as a health therapy. He started the program in 2015 after the hospital received a million-dollar donation from an investment banker on its board. Spiegel saw Monterroso in his clinic the week before and thought he might be able to help alleviate her symptoms.
headline: Can Virtual Reality Help Ease Chronic Pain?

abstract: In federal court, Satya Nadella and Bobby Kotick opposed an attempt by the F.T.C. to delay Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of a video game giant.
lead_paragraph: Satya Nadella, the chief executive of Microsoft, appeared in federal court on Wednesday to pledge his support for open platforms and consumer choice, underscoring the tech giant’s commitment to closing its $70 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard over regulators’ objections.
headline: Microsoft and Activision Chiefs Testify Merger Will Benefit Consumers

abstract: Legislation to force TikTok’s Chinese owner to sell the app or have it banned in the United States sailed through the House, but the Senate has no plans to move hastily.
lead_paragraph: After a bill that would force TikTok’s Chinese parent company to sell the app or face a nationwide ban sailed through the House at breakneck speed this week, its progress has slowed in the Senate.
headline: TikTok Bill’s Progress Slows in the Senate

abstract: Why Lina Khan and the F.T.C. must prevail in their long-awaited lawsuit against Amazon.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission’s chair, Lina Khan, has brought her long-awaited, audacious case against Amazon, signaling the Biden administration’s determination to restore an approach to competition law that has been in decline since the Carter administration. This will doubtless draw fresh criticism about her supposed overreach. But Amazon is precisely the kind of company that Congress had in mind in enacting America’s many antitrust laws.
headline: Amazon Is the Apex Predator of Our Platform Era

abstract: Advertisers are sticking with the social media platform, even as the House prepares to vote on a bill to force the company to cut its China ties this week.
lead_paragraph: The warnings against TikTok aren’t letting up, with U.S. security officials saying China is using the platform to meddle in elections and lawmakers calling the video app a global threat.
headline: The Clock Ticks for TikTok

abstract: A celebrity chef showed the meal in a TikTok video, now removed, that angered people in Vietnam. Facebook said it was investigating why the chef’s hashtag was blocked from its site.
lead_paragraph: A top Communist Party leader from Vietnam was in London last week visiting the grave of Karl Marx, the philosopher whose writing championed the proletariat fight to topple the ruling moneyed class.
headline: A Communist Leader Was Served Gold-Flecked Steak. The Video of It Has Vanished.

abstract: A talk with the directors Jennifer Tiexiera and Camilla Hall about their film that checks in on the subjects of high-profile documentaries.
lead_paragraph: Being a documentary subject can be a thankless kind of stardom, without much control over how your life story is told. In “Subject,” Jennifer Tiexiera and Camilla Hall went back to five famous documentaries and asked their stars about their experiences: “Hoop Dreams,” “The Staircase,” “Capturing the Friedmans,” “The Square” and “The Wolfpack.”
headline: With ‘Subject,’ Doc Stars Look Back

abstract: The sale is the first time Meta has been forced by regulators to sell a part of its business, a sign of increased antitrust scrutiny around the world.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Meta said on Tuesday that it would sell Giphy, the online repository for video clips of pets, facial expressions and other animated GIFs, a major defeat for the social media giant in a long-running dispute with British antitrust regulators.
headline: Meta Forced to Sell Giphy After British Antitrust Order

abstract: Facebook filters out political content, and India’s government clashes with Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Happy Valentine’s Day. Here’s your quick rundown of the top business and tech stories to know for the week ahead, so you can spend the rest of your day eating (sorry, reading) the candy you bought for your loved ones (or yourself). — Charlotte Cowles
headline: The Week in Business: Facebook Filters Politics

abstract: Prolific and widely-produced, Lauren Gunderson didn’t have to look far to create “The Catastrophist,” a play about risk that’s both timely and personal.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Confined by the pandemic to her three-story Victorian home, Lauren Gunderson did not have to go far to find inspiration for her latest play. He was one room away, in the home office next to hers on the top floor.
headline: A Playwright’s New Subject: Her Husband, the Pandemic Expert

abstract: Ilya Sutskever, a co-founder at the artificial intelligence start-up and one of the world’s leading researchers, is out, and Sam Altman’s control looks firmer than ever.
lead_paragraph: A day after OpenAI announced major updates to its ChatGPT chatbot, the company said its chief scientist and co-founder was leaving.
headline: A Big Plot Twist at OpenAI

abstract: Attorney General Maura Healey of Massachusetts weighs in on social media, the Sacklers and Florida’s “Don’t Say Gay” bill.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Maura Healey of Massachusetts has sued the Trump administration, Uber, Juul, Exxon Mobil, the Sacklers and more — and has made a national name for herself in the process. Now she’s investigating social media companies for the impact they have on teen mental health, and she’s not impressed. “The level of hubris and arrogance, particularly on the part of Facebook, has really astounded me,” she tells Kara Swisher.
headline: Why Facebook’s ‘Hubris and Arrogance’ Astound This Attorney General

abstract: A bipartisan group of lawmakers wants to fix the Electoral Count Act, the obscure law used to justify the Jan. 6 riot. Is it even possible?
lead_paragraph: The Electoral Count Act is both a legal monstrosity and a fascinating puzzle.
headline: The 1887 Law Putting American Democracy at Risk

abstract: There were surprises on-field and off — from Rihanna’s halftime performance to Disney’s controversial ad splash.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. fans are still buzzing about the Kansas City Chiefs’ down-to-the-wire Super Bowl LVII victory, and the questionable defensive holding call that extended the game-winning drive. From Rihanna to Elon Musk, there were plenty more headlines to emerge from the game.
headline: The Winners and Losers from Super Bowl LVII

abstract: In a first, a Colorado law extends privacy rights to the neural data increasingly coveted by technology companies.
lead_paragraph: Consumers have grown accustomed to the prospect that their personal data, such as email addresses, social contacts, browsing history and genetic ancestry, are being collected and often resold by the apps and the digital services they use.
headline: Your Brain Waves Are Up for Sale. A New Law Wants to Change That.

abstract: The company laid off more than 500 of its employees on Monday, or about 10 percent of its global work force.
lead_paragraph: Snap, the parent of the Snapchat messaging app, said on Monday that it would lay off more than 500 employees, joining other tech companies in a wave of new cost-cutting measures.
headline: Snap Becomes Latest Tech Company to Cut Jobs

abstract: The C.E.O. and his team drove Meta’s efforts to capture young users and misled the public about the risks, lawsuits by state attorneys general say.
lead_paragraph: In April 2019, David Ginsberg, a Meta executive, emailed his boss, Mark Zuckerberg, with a proposal to research and reduce loneliness and compulsive use on Instagram and Facebook.
headline: How Mark Zuckerberg’s Meta Failed Children on Safety, States Say

abstract: Consumers are splurging on expensive but fun experiences, from nights out to concerts — and that may force central banks to keep raising rates.
lead_paragraph: Uncomfortably high inflation appears set to linger, forcing central bankers to inflict further pain on consumers and businesses by raising borrowing costs again and again.
headline: Economists Warn a ‘Summer of Fun’ Could Lead to Autumn Pain

abstract: A new reality is setting in for students and recent graduates who spent years honing themselves for careers at the largest tech companies.
lead_paragraph: Ever since she was a 10th grader in Seattle, Annalice Ni wanted to develop software for a prominent tech company like Google. So she went to great lengths to meet the internship and other résumé criteria that make students attractive hires to the biggest tech firms.
headline: Computer Science Students Face a Shrinking Big Tech Job Market

abstract: Jobs rebounded in October. The government finally issued rules on requiring vaccinations at big employers. And we'll see how quickly inflation is rising.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve announced plans on Wednesday to slow its bond-buying program, a stimulus measure it introduced early in the pandemic. The central bank will reduce its monthly purchases of $120 billion in Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities by $15 billion a month, starting this month. The Fed’s policy committee did not give any indication it would raise interest rates anytime soon, despite persistently high inflation. But investors expect it will begin to do so midway through 2022.
headline: The Week in Business: Time to Slow the Economic Stimulus

abstract: Negotiations ran long into the night as Musk’s offer to buy Twitter and take it private looks increasingly likely to go ahead.
lead_paragraph: What seemed highly improbable a week and a half ago is now looking a lot more real: Twitter is in advanced talks to sell itself to Elon Musk. The company’s 11-member board was negotiating with Musk into the early hours of the morning over his offer to buy the social networking service and take it private, DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch and The Times’s Mike Isaac report.
headline: The Elon Musk-Twitter Endgame

abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 5, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Meta’s restriction of news content in Canada misstated the month the online news law will take effect. It is December, not January.
headline: Corrections: Aug. 5, 2023

abstract: Freddie Cheng strikes a chord.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — One of the most important personal qualities a new solver can have is stick-to-itiveness. Getting started in crossword puzzles is hard — it can feel like learning a new language as you figure out how to decipher the subtle hints in the clues that tell you what to look for in an entry. For example, a new solver may not know what “, say” means, or that an abbreviation in the clue means there will be an abbreviation in the entry. The more you solve, the more you begin to recognize these little flags, but getting over that initial hump of “why on earth is there a question mark in this clue?!” can feel insurmountable.
headline: Stick-to-itiveness

abstract: The metaverse doesn’t quite exist yet. But the hype still matters.
lead_paragraph: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
headline: Is the Metaverse Just Marketing?

abstract: Fueled by the conflict between Israel and Gaza and stoked by extremists, hate speech has spiked on social media platforms such as X, Facebook and Instagram, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 7, the day Hamas attacked Israel, the hashtag #HitlerWasRight appeared on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter. Over the next month, more than 46,000 posts featured the hashtag, often alongside language that called for violence against Jews.
headline: Antisemitic and Anti-Muslim Hate Speech Surges Across the Internet

abstract: The tech billionaire, who has been on the board of the company formerly known as Facebook since 2005, is backing numerous politicians in the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Peter Thiel, one of the longest-serving board members of Meta, the parent of Facebook, plans to step down, the company said on Monday.
headline: Peter Thiel to Exit Meta’s Board to Support Trump-Aligned Candidates

abstract: Plus, three video game adventures for the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried, who was convicted of stealing $8 billion from customers of his FTX cryptocurrency exchange, was sentenced to 25 years in prison. It was a significantly lighter sentence than the maximum penalty of 110 years that his charges carried, but was well above the six and a half years sought by his defense lawyers. Bankman-Fried was also ordered to forfeit $11.2 billion in assets.
headline: Friday Briefing: Sam Bankman-Fried Gets 25 Years

abstract: On any given weekend, there are dozens of parties happening on VRChat, a platform where users assume fantastical avatars of their own design.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday night, the street outside the nightclub Tube VR looked typical for East London: a boat moored on the canal, trendy retail spaces lining the waterfront, an underpass covered in graffiti. Inside, however, I found myself dancing next to a hedgehog wearing a top hat, an anime nun with an acid green halo and a humanoid fox in hot pants.
headline: Finding Community, and Freedom, on the Virtual Dance Floor

abstract: What movie, book, video game, album, show, restaurant or other work or experience disappointed you this year? Why?
lead_paragraph: Is there something you have read, watched, listened to, eaten, visited, played or otherwise experienced this year that you think is so bad that you want to discourage others from experiencing it? If so, what and why?
headline: What 2023 Work of Art or Culture Would You Warn Others to Avoid?

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing

abstract: Robert Iger, brought back as Disney’s C.E.O., unveiled his vision for more austere operations. New inflation data is coming out.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s often-overlooked search engine, Bing, is mounting a comeback with ChatGPT, the suddenly ubiquitous chatbot capable of composing song lyrics, writing academic essays and answering all manner of questions. The new version of Bing was released to a limited group of users on Tuesday. The revamped product is part of Microsoft’s $13 billion investment in OpenAI, the artificial intelligence lab behind ChatGPT that Microsoft is betting on to stay competitive with its big tech rivals like Google, Apple and Meta. But those companies are also racing to incorporate the new technology into their own software. A day before the unveiling of the new Bing, Google announced that it would soon release an experimental chatbot called Bard for its own search engine, which is much more widely used than Bing. And Meta is fast-tracking the development of chatbot technology for its products.
headline: The Week in Business: Microsoft’s Big Bet on A.I.

abstract: Mothers are running Instagram accounts for underage girls aspiring to stardom. Many encounter a dark underworld dominated by men, including pedophiles.
lead_paragraph: Instagram does not allow children under 13 to have accounts, but parents are allowed to run them — and many do so for daughters who aspire to be social media influencers.
headline: Five Takeaways From The Times’s Investigation Into Child Influencers

abstract: The White House laid the ground work for Microsoft’s $1.5 billion investment in an Emirati artificial intelligence start-up, a deal meant to box out Beijing.
lead_paragraph: A relatively small deal — by Microsoft’s standards, anyway — is leading to big geopolitical ripples on Tuesday.
headline: How Washington Played A.I. Matchmaker

abstract: Mosseri talks while Congress dithers.
lead_paragraph: I’ve not been shy about calling out social media companies like Meta — parent of Facebook — for amplifying and worsening a range of societal problems over the past decade or so. Much as the influence of cable news began the coarsening of all kinds of dialogue, particularly around politics, it’s hard to argue that the explosion of online discourse has had a dulcet influence on the world.
headline: We Need Less Talk and More Action From Congress on Tech

abstract: Provocative debuts from two exciting new female filmmakers lead off this month’s roundup of recommendations from your subscription streaming services.
lead_paragraph: The title is provocative, but this is no how-to manual; instead, the writer and director Molly Manning Walker tells a contemporary coming-of-age story that will reverberate with viewers of all ages and sexes. Her focus is on Tara (Mia McKenna-Bruce), a 16-year-old British girl on a post-exams holiday in Crete with her friends. They plan to party, drink and hook up, and the latter is of particular import to Tara, who is keen to lose her virginity — less out of desire or romanticism than to simply get it over with. Manning is a cinematographer making her feature directing debut, and she deftly uses compositions, color and sound to convey Tara’s isolation, desperation and disappointment. She gets a big assist from McKenna-Bruce, a charismatic and empathetic lead who can whisper, in a throwaway line or discreet gesture, everything you need to know about this young woman’s past and present.
headline: ‘How to Have Sex,’ ‘Miller’s Girl’ and More Streaming Gems

abstract: An E.U. law taking effect in March forced Apple to loosen its grip on the App Store, changes it had long resisted.
lead_paragraph: Since Apple introduced the App Store in 2008, it has tightly controlled the apps and services allowed on iPhones and iPads, giving the company an iron grip on one of the digital economy’s most valuable storefronts.
headline: Apple Overhauls App Store in Europe, in Response to New Digital Law

abstract: The festival opened with questions for the jury about Indigenous representation, #MeToo rumors and other timely topics.
lead_paragraph: Early on in the meta French comedy “The Second Act,” which was opening the 77th edition of the Cannes Film Festival on Tuesday night, a father (Vincent Lindon) and daughter (Léa Seydoux) are sitting in his car and chatting about her boyfriend. But just a few lines into the scene, Lindon cracks and refuses to perform it.
headline: Cannes: Greta Gerwig, Lily Gladstone and the Weight of Politics at the Fest

abstract: Millions of articles from The New York Times were used to train chatbots that now compete with it, the lawsuit said.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times sued OpenAI and Microsoft for copyright infringement on Wednesday, opening a new front in the increasingly intense legal battle over the unauthorized use of published work to train artificial intelligence technologies.
headline: The Times Sues OpenAI and Microsoft Over A.I. Use of Copyrighted Work

abstract: In the hands of anonymous internet users, A.I. tools can create waves of harassing and racist material. It’s already happening on the anonymous message board 4chan.
lead_paragraph: When the Louisiana parole board met in October to discuss the potential release of a convicted murderer, it called on a doctor with years of experience in mental health to talk about the inmate.
headline: Dark Corners of the Web Offer a Glimpse at A.I.’s Nefarious Future

abstract: Across the country, bars are serving jiggly, alcoholic concoctions that are nothing like the college party version.
lead_paragraph: At Ci Siamo, the Danny Meyer restaurant, you can order Jell-O shots made with Campari and French gin served individually in coupe glasses.
headline: The Jell-O Shot Renaissance

abstract: At a new website called Character.AI, you can chat with a reasonable facsimile of almost anyone, live or dead, real or (especially) imagined.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon Jonas Thiel, a socioeconomics major at a college in northern Germany, spent more than an hour chatting online with some of the left-wing political philosophers he had been studying. These were not the actual philosophers but virtual recreations, brought to conversation, if not quite life, by sophisticated chatbots on a website called Character.AI.
headline: A.I. Is Becoming More Conversational. But Will It Get More Honest?

abstract: The parent company of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp reaches 3.6 billion active users. But is its size actually against the public’s interest?
lead_paragraph: Facebook, Meta — whatever you want to call it, the tech titan has drawn a lot of ire, and not just from privacy advocates and people fighting misinformation. Antitrust regulators are sharpening their knives, too.
headline: Could Breaking Up Meta Make Things Worse?

abstract: Julia Whelan is one of the most in-demand audiobook narrators working today. With her novel, “Thank You for Listening,” she’s telling a story of her own.
lead_paragraph: Julia Whelan climbed into the double-walled, foam-insulated booth in her home office near Palm Springs, Calif. In preparation, she had refrained from alcohol the night before, had avoided dairy since waking at 6 a.m. and had run through the humming and vocalizing of her warm-up exercises.
headline: That Voice You’re Hearing? It Might Be Hers.

abstract: The Twitter owner’s latest fight is a big one: the market dominance of Apple’s App Store.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has been unafraid of picking fights, whether with prominent politicians, political whistle-blowers or his own employees. But in taking on Apple on Monday, the Twitter owner was trying to start a brawl that could have ramifications stretching from Silicon Valley to Washington.
headline: Elon Musk Takes on a Goliath

abstract: Dozens of states sue Meta, we get advice from a pro YouTuber and we examine impressive advancements in artificial intelligence image generators.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of state attorneys general have sued Meta, claiming the company knowingly created features that induce “extended, addictive and compulsive social media use” among teenagers and children. In a country without wide-reaching internet regulations, are lawsuits the way to reign in tech companies?
headline: The People v. Meta, Marques Brownlee on YouTube and Future Tech, and DALL-E 3 Arrives

abstract: The move by the commission signals an aggressive stance by federal regulators to thwart the expansion of the tech industry’s biggest companies.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission, in one of the most aggressive actions taken by federal regulators in decades to check the power of the tech industry’s giants, on Thursday sued to block Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of the video game maker Activision Blizzard.
headline: F.T.C. Sues to Block Microsoft’s $69 Billion Acquisition of Activision

abstract: The billionaire can amend his lawsuit to include claims from a Twitter whistle-blower, but lost an effort to delay a trial over whether he could drop his bid to buy the company.
lead_paragraph: Some potential major cracks are beginning to appear in Elon Musk’s suit to undo his $44 billion acquisition of Twitter, yesterday’s hearing in Delaware’s Court of Chancery revealed. But Musk has also scored a major victory.
headline: Judge Hands Elon Musk a Win in Court

abstract: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sam Altman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sam Altman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Sam Altman

abstract: Also, Israel intensified its airstrikes in Gaza. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans voted this afternoon to nominate Tom Emmer — a Representative from Minnesota who holds the No. 3 leadership post — to be the chamber’s next speaker. But within hours, he dropped his bid.
headline: A Third Speaker Nominee Failed to Unify Republicans

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing

abstract: The former president’s second-term agenda contains few policies that economists believe would reduce the rise in prices.
lead_paragraph: If there is a simple political truth, it’s that voters hate inflation. If there’s another, it’s that they also hate the policies that snuff it out.
headline: Trump and Inflation

abstract: The actor reflects on continuing the Off Broadway revival’s hot streak, and fighting against the stereotypes facing Asian American actors.
lead_paragraph: Since it opened in October 2019, Michael Mayer’s well-received “Little Shop of Horrors” revival has drawn quite the handsome string of leading men: Jonathan Groff was the first to step into Seymour Krelborn’s Converse sneakers, and he was followed by Gideon Glick and Jeremy Jordan. This reflects the casting evolution of the character, a painfully shy plant geek. Not many roles have been played by both Rick Moranis (in the show’s 1986 movie adaptation) and Jake Gyllenhaal (in a 2015 concert production).
headline: Conrad Ricamora on His Bumpy Road to ‘Little Shop of Horrors’

abstract: I asked what you want moderators to ask Biden and Trump at the debate. You had many thoughts.
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow night, Jake Tapper and Dana Bash of CNN have a big job: asking two unpopular men who have been president what they would do with a second term.
headline: Here’s the Debate People Want

abstract: For psychologists who study it, disgust is one of the primal emotions that define — and explain — humanity.
lead_paragraph: Two distinguished academics walk into a restaurant in Manhattan. It is their first meeting — their first date, in fact — and the year is 2015. The man wears a down jacket against the icy winter evening. The woman has a shock of glossy white hair. The restaurant is on a cozy corner of the West Village and has foie gras on the menu. What the man doesn’t know is that the interior of his down jacket has suffered a structural failure, and the filling has massed along the bottom hem, forming a conspicuous bulge at his waist. As they greet each other, the woman perceives the bulge and asks herself: Is my date wearing a colostomy bag?
headline: How Disgust Explains Everything

abstract: “When McKinsey Comes to Town,” by the Times reporters Walt Bogdanich and Michael Forsythe, argues that the legendary firm has accrued an inordinate amount of influence chasing profits at the expense of moral principle.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, Martin Elling, along with three colleagues at the global consulting firm McKinsey & Company, published an article in the firm’s quarterly journal intended to gin up more business from the pharmaceutical industry. Elling’s article argued that drug companies were missing an opportunity by not tracking how often individual physicians were prescribing certain drugs. By aggregating such data, pharmaceutical salespeople could target their marketing pitches to the doctors most likely to become heavy prescribers, and the sales reps themselves could also be better evaluated by their companies. Soon enough, a relatively unknown drug company called Purdue Pharma came calling, retaining McKinsey in 2004 to help increase sales of its opioid pain killer OxyContin — which had already topped $1 billion annually. In the face of a worsening national opioid addiction crisis and multiple state and federal investigations, prescriptions of higher-strength OxyContin pills had begun to level off. Among other recommendations, McKinsey, led by Elling and his team, suggested “turbocharging” sales through more innovative and aggressive marketing tactics. Between 2004 and 2019, Purdue paid McKinsey $83.7 million in fees.
headline: McKinsey Is a Consulting Powerhouse. But Is It a Force for Good?

abstract: Plus, what’s next for France.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled yesterday that Donald Trump was entitled to substantial immunity from prosecution, a major statement on presidential power that could have long-term repercussions.
headline: Tuesday Briefing: Top Court Gives Trump Significant Immunity

abstract: A five-day hearing over Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition, which the Federal Trade Commission hopes to block, began Thursday in federal court.
lead_paragraph: The first day of a weeklong hearing that could determine the outcome of Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of the video game giant Activision Blizzard opened Thursday with a promise from Microsoft: If a federal judge grants an injunction that would delay the deal’s closing, Microsoft could abandon the deal altogether.
headline: Microsoft Says It Could Abandon Activision Deal if Judge Delays It

abstract: The internet giant said it would begin testing its new chatbot, Bard, with a small, private group before releasing it to the public in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Monday that it would soon release an experimental chatbot called Bard as it races to respond to ChatGPT, which has wowed millions of people since it was unveiled at the end of November.
headline: Racing to Catch Up With ChatGPT, Google Plans Release of Its Own Chatbot

abstract: The N.Y.U. professor Jonathan Haidt became a favorite in Silicon Valley for his work on what he called the “coddling” of young people. Now, he has an idea for fixing Gen Z.
lead_paragraph: When James Comey became head of the F.B.I. in 2013, he sent reading recommendations to his staff, including “Letter From Birmingham Jail” by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., “Lean In” by Sheryl Sandberg and “The Righteous Mind” by a professor at New York University’s business school, Jonathan Haidt.
headline: First He Came for Cancel Culture. Now He Wants to Cancel Smartphones

abstract: The Florida governor’s plan to announce his presidential campaign on the social network is the latest sign of the company’s efforts to court conservatives.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is expected to finally announce his presidential campaign on Wednesday night — but not on a stalwart of conservative media, like Fox News. Instead, the Republican star will do so live on Twitter, in a conversation with Elon Musk. (Fox News will get the first television interview with Mr. DeSantis afterward.)
headline: DeSantis’s Big Event Underscores a Rightward Move for Twitter

abstract: Sam Altman sees the pros and cons of totally changing the world as we know it. And if he does make human intelligence useless, he has a plan to fix it.
lead_paragraph: I first met Sam Altman in the summer of 2019, days after Microsoft agreed to invest $1 billion in his three-year-old start-up, OpenAI. At his suggestion, we had dinner at a small, decidedly modern restaurant not far from his home in San Francisco.
headline: The ChatGPT King Isn’t Worried, but He Knows You Might Be

abstract: Facebook will temporarily stop showing ads that “promote weapon accessories and protective equipment in the U.S. at least through Jan. 22,” two days after Inauguration Day, according to a statement by the company.
lead_paragraph: Facebook will temporarily stop showing ads that “promote weapon accessories and protective equipment in the U.S. at least through Jan. 22,” two days after Inauguration Day, according to a statement by the company.
headline: Facebook will temporarily stop showing ads for gun accessories and military gear.

abstract: To land the House speaker position, the California Republican will have to win over opponents who question his ties to Silicon Valley and his commitment to right wing causes.
lead_paragraph: Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, is still working on landing the House speaker gig after six failed attempts. It’s the first such House floor showdown in a century, and business is at the heart of his woes.
headline: Kevin McCarthy’s Business Ties Complicate His Rise to Power

abstract: The musician and producer Ahmir Thompson, better known as Questlove, is starting his own imprint, with eye toward a mix of memoir, history and more.
lead_paragraph: On top of being a D.J., producer, filmmaker, drummer, Academy Award-winning director, culinary entrepreneur, member of the hip-hop band the Roots and scholar of Black musical history, Ahmir Thompson, also known as Questlove, is a prolific author. He’s written and co-authored seven books, including best sellers like “Mo’ Meta Blues,” “Creative Quest” and “Music is History,” and a forthcoming children’s book about time travel.
headline: Questlove Has a New Creative Pursuit: Publishing

abstract: Also, an industry-wide strike in Hollywood, floods in Delhi and Netflix’s Asia strategy.
lead_paragraph: After the military-backed Senate rejected Pita Limjaroenrat as prime minister, Thailand was staring down what could be another intense period of political unrest and nationwide protests.
headline: Your Friday Briefing: Thailand in Turmoil

abstract: A start-up called Perplexity shows what’s possible for a search engine built from scratch with artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: For my entire adult life, whenever I’ve had a question about the world or needed to track down something online, I’ve gone to Google for answers.
headline: Can This A.I.-Powered Search Engine Replace Google? It Has for Me.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing

abstract: The internet, according to the ruling, “affected her mental health in a negative way and contributed to her death in a more than minimal way.”
lead_paragraph: Sitting in the witness box of a small London courtroom this week, a Meta executive faced an uncomfortable question: Did her company contribute to the suicide of a 14-year-old named Molly Russell?
headline: British Ruling Pins Blame on Social Media for Teenager’s Suicide

abstract: Here are six steps for making amends, according to experts.
lead_paragraph: Most of us can remember receiving an unsatisfying apology. A friend of mine recently got a text message after a Bumble date stood her up: “Sry,” it read. (“He didn’t even spell out the whole word,” she told me.)
headline: How to Apologize Like You Mean It

abstract: The pop superstar’s latest album was preceded by a satellite radio channel, a word game, a return to TikTok and an actual library. For her fans, more is always welcome.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift was already the most ubiquitous pop star in the galaxy, her presence dominating the music charts, the concert calendar, the Super Bowl, the Grammys.
headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘Poets’ Arrives With a Promotional Blitz (and a Second LP)

abstract: Here’s what to know before adding a foam roller to your warm-up or cool down.
lead_paragraph: Like many people working from home during the pandemic, Veronika Javor, 39, swapped a supportive desk chair in her office for a soft sofa chair in her living room. It was comfortable at first, but the new seat soon took a toll, as Ms. Javor, a Houston-based content creator, developed a sharp, radiating pain in her left buttock. She tried to ignore it, but after a particularly tough glute-focused Pilates workout, the discomfort became unbearable.
headline: 5 Foam Rolling Exercises for Skeptics

abstract: The co-founder of CrowdTangle has been working with Congress on legislation to make tech companies disclose their inner workings.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Silverman’s last day at Facebook was Oct. 8, and like many others who have sold their companies to a Silicon Valley giant, had their shares vest and departed, he planned to take a year off to spend time with his children and figure out what to do next.
headline: A Former Facebook Executive Pushes to Open Social Media’s ‘Black Boxes’

abstract: For the first time, the chief executives of cryptocurrency companies faced questions from lawmakers about risk and regulation.
lead_paragraph: The chief executives of six cryptocurrency companies testified for nearly five hours on Wednesday before the House Financial Services Committee about the promises and perils of cryptocurrencies.
headline: Congress gets a crash course on cryptocurrency.

abstract: Several large studies have confirmed that vigorous exercise, walking and even doing household chores can greatly benefit the brain.
lead_paragraph: Experts had long believed that exercise could help protect against developing dementia. However, though they had observed a general pattern of reduced risk, studies on the subject had been small — and often conflicting — with little consensus on the type, frequency or intensity of exercise that might be best.
headline: What Types of Exercise Reduce Dementia Risk?

abstract: For University of Chicago graduates, I celebrated the need to profoundly disagree.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, I was the invited speaker for the Class Day Ceremony at the University of Chicago, my alma mater. Campus political groups issued a statement of protest and a few students walked out of the ceremony. Here’s the speech I gave.
headline: Go Forth and Argue

abstract: The “RuPaul’s Drag Race” alums Jinkx Monsoon and BenDeLaCreme put on a queer, clever and heartfelt Christmas show that keeps getting bigger.
lead_paragraph: It was half past 3 the day after the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree lighting, and a pair of America’s most famous drag queens strode up to the spruce’s formidable footprint, chatting about abundance.
headline: Holidays a Drag? Every Year, Thanks to Jinkx and DeLa.

abstract: A 120-year-old piece by Gustav Mahler is finding new life with unlikely listeners after a star turn in “Tár.”
lead_paragraph: For a 70-minute Austrian symphony first performed more than a century ago, Mahler’s Fifth makes a surprisingly strong case for itself as the song of the season.
headline: The Song of the Fall? It’s a Symphony, Actually.

abstract: Ahead of a presidential election in January, Taiwanese fact checkers and watchdogs say they are ready for Beijing. But they are still worried.
lead_paragraph: Suspicious videos that began circulating in Taiwan this month seemed to show the country’s leader advertising cryptocurrency investments.
headline: Can Taiwan Continue to Fight Off Chinese Disinformation?

abstract: Like Meta, the company opened access to its technology to outside programmers, but kept its most powerful system under wraps.
lead_paragraph: When Meta shared the raw computer code needed to build a chatbot last year, rival companies said Meta was releasing poorly understood and perhaps even dangerous technology into the world.
headline: Google Is Giving Away Some of the A.I. That Powers Chatbots

abstract: If you accept that you know very little, but hope to know a little more, discovering that you were wrong about something feels exciting rather than painful.
lead_paragraph: I don’t floss. This makes me, as my dentists always seem to imply, a naughty boy, a disgusting human willing to walk around with bits of food stuck between my teeth. Of all the dreaded parts of any dentist visit, the worst is receiving a condescending lecture on the merits of flossing.
headline: The Quest for Scientific Certainty Is Futile

abstract: Government data for October shows the labor market is still strong, though cooling slightly.
lead_paragraph: Employers continued to pull back in October on the number of jobs they were looking to fill, the latest sign that the labor market is strong but gradually cooling.
headline: Job Openings Ease, but Layoffs Are Little Changed

abstract: A small change to climate science could make a big difference for Americans.
lead_paragraph: The world’s top scientists released their latest report yesterday warning that the Earth is on pace for severe damage from climate change. But many Americans might have a hard time understanding the report because the analysis, like those before it, talks about temperatures exclusively in Celsius.
headline: A Translation Problem

abstract: The company said it would give outside programmers access to the latest version of its core artificial intelligence technology.
lead_paragraph: The largest companies in the tech industry have spent the year warning that development of artificial intelligence technology is outpacing their wildest expectations and that they need to limit who has access to it.
headline: Meta Unveils a More Powerful A.I. and Isn’t Fretting Over Who Uses It

abstract: Twitter’s new boss needs to boost the company’s value, or someone else will.
lead_paragraph: There’s been a whirlwind of commentary about all the changes at Twitter, and especially around its persistently quirky co-founder Jack Dorsey (whose world I am dubbing the Jackaverse). Besides suddenly stepping down as chief executive and chairman of Twitter, he made waves over at his other day job, leading the payments company he co-founded called Square, and changed its corporate name to Block. This is not just fun with shapes; the new name is meant to refer to the blockchain. (Do not make me explain what the blockchain is.)
headline: Squares, Blocks, Cubes — What Is Happening in Silicon Valley?

abstract: TikTok’s turn in geopolitical cross hairs highlights the narrowing paths to liquidity for investments in Chinese companies.
lead_paragraph: When investors talk about “zombie” companies, they’re usually referring to distressed start-ups that are hobbling along, unable to grow and unlikely to ever return the money they’ve raised.
headline: Americans Invested Billions in Chinese Companies. Now Their Money Is Stuck.

abstract: Also, Kim Jong-un presents a possible successor.
lead_paragraph: Russia said yesterday that their soldiers’ unauthorized use of cellphones in the Donetsk region was the “main reason” that Ukraine was able to launch a deadly attack on New Year’s Day. The Ministry of Defense said Ukraine used cellphone data to home in on their locations.
headline: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Blames its Dead Soldiers

abstract: Julian Kwan makes a debut with panache.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Julian Kwan is a software test engineer in telecommunications who is new to the vocation of crossword construction; this is his fourth published grid, and his first with us. I like a Sunday debut, and this is a fun endeavor: The theme is clean and deceptively simple, embedded in zippy fill.
headline: Mores

abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
headline: Today’s Top News: Florida Braces for Hurricane Idalia, and More

abstract: The inquiry is intended to pressure the tech giant to more aggressively police Facebook and Instagram ahead of the European Union’s closely watched elections in June.
lead_paragraph: Meta, the American tech giant, is being investigated by European Union regulators for the spread of disinformation on its platforms Facebook and Instagram, poor oversight of deceptive advertisements and potential failure to protect the integrity of elections.
headline: Meta Faces E.U. Investigation Over Election Disinformation

abstract: Meta’s stock prices plunged after the company reported that Apple’s privacy features would cost it billions this year. It’s not the only tech giant to take a hit.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s vision of a more private web is not necessarily a more profitable one for internet companies that depend on advertising revenue.
headline: A Change by Apple Is Tormenting Internet Companies, Especially Meta

abstract: Google has a zero-tolerance policy for child abuse content. The scanning process can sometimes go awry and tar innocent individuals as abusers.
lead_paragraph: When Jennifer Watkins got a message from YouTube saying her channel was being shut down, she wasn’t initially worried. She didn’t use YouTube, after all.
headline: How Your Child’s Online Mistake Can Ruin Your Digital Life

abstract: Companies shouldn’t need to build worker housing. Workers shouldn’t have to live in company towns.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, who inhabits the role of a gonzo captain of industry like no other figure in modern American life, has lately been dreaming aloud about building his own version of an old-fashioned company town.
headline: Welcome to Muskville, Texas

abstract: Almost all climate finance focuses on mitigating climate change. But money is increasingly pouring in to helping people adapt to the effects of global warming.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. In today’s newsletter: Extreme heat highlights the need for another kind of climate investment; A.I. puts shadow libraries in the spotlight; and Aly Wagner, a co-founder of a new women’s soccer team, talks about the money in women’s sports. (Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up here.)
headline: Extreme Heat Shows the Need for Another Kind of Climate Investment

abstract: The regulator’s move to block Kroger’s $25 billion bid for Albertsons could win the president points with voters squeezed by rising prices.
lead_paragraph: A paradox at the heart of the U.S. economy is that consumers are feeling squeezed even as growth indicators look strong — and are taking it out on President Biden’s approval ratings.
headline: The F.T.C. Boosts Biden’s Fight Against Inflation

abstract: For decades, tech companies heralded an approach that centered on making workers happy. That’s changing fast.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley as we know it — with its radically transparent company cultures, empowered employees, flat hierarchies and rarefied perks like nap pods and free food — is quickly disappearing. And it’s unlikely to return.
headline: The Era of Happy Tech Workers Is Over

abstract: Stocks on both sides of the Atlantic set records as investors foresee interest rates moving in one direction: down.
lead_paragraph: Stocks in Asia and parts of Europe rose on Thursday as investors bet that new data showing inflation easing would finally persuade central bankers to lower interest rates from multidecade highs. The rally has pushed stock indexes on both sides of the Atlantic into record territory.
headline: Markets Keep Rising Despite Inflation Concerns

abstract: Nations are accelerating efforts to control data produced within their perimeters, disrupting the flow of what has become a kind of digital currency.
lead_paragraph: Every time we send an email, tap an Instagram ad or swipe our credit cards, we create a piece of digital data.
headline: The Era of Borderless Data Is Ending

abstract: “‘Peanuts Vol. 3’ (I think) ... made it cool to be excited about Beethoven’s birthday.”
lead_paragraph: “‘Peanuts Vol. 3’ (I think) … made it cool to be excited about Beethoven’s birthday,” says the musician Jeremy Denk, whose new memoir is “Every Good Boy Does Fine.”
headline: Why a ‘Peanuts’ Collection Has Stuck With Jeremy Denk, Concert Pianist

abstract: “His abuse of democratic norms is more than enough to earn a permanent ban,” one reader says. Another worries about a “serious threat to the freedom that we all enjoy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
headline: Should Trump Be Permanently Barred From Facebook?

abstract: A series of surprising and serious events and trends that were unprecedented until now.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
headline: 22 Things That Happened for the First Time in 2022

abstract: The penalty, imposed by Irish data regulators, brings European fines against Facebook’s parent company to more than $900 million since last year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the latest penalty against Meta for violating European privacy rules, the tech giant was fined roughly $275 million on Monday for a data leak, discovered last year, that led to the personal information of more than 500 million Facebook users being published online.
headline: Meta Fined $275 Million for Breaking E.U. Data Privacy Law

abstract: The government can proceed with its claims that the company abused its monopoly power through acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday allowed the Federal Trade Commission’s antitrust lawsuit against Facebook to move forward, rejecting Facebook’s request to dismiss the case and handing the agency a major victory in its quest to curtail the power of the biggest tech companies.
headline: A Facebook antitrust suit can move forward, a judge says, in a win for the F.T.C.

abstract: People who upload images of children that Google flags as potentially illegal will be able to provide more context to appeal bans.
lead_paragraph: When Google informed a mother in Colorado that her account had been disabled, it felt as if her house had burned down, she said. In an instant, she lost access to her wedding photos, videos of her son growing up, her emails going back a decade, her tax documents and everything else she had kept in what she thought would be the safest place. She had no idea why.
headline: Her Child’s Naked Dance Killed Her Google Account. New Appeals Path Restored It.

abstract: Dawn Meyerriecks talks spy gear and why Hollywood and Silicon Valley play a critical role in national security.
lead_paragraph: The Central Intelligence Agency poaches puppeteers from Hollywood and partners with big tech firms from Silicon Valley. It has to, says the agency’s top technologist, Dawn Meyerriecks, if it wants cutting-edge drones, hidden cameras, and deep cover that can bypass biometric scans
headline: The C.I.A.’s Top Technologist Is Uncomfortable With Facebook

abstract: Executives at the social network have clashed over CrowdTangle, a Facebook-owned data tool that revealed users’ high engagement levels with right-wing media sources.
lead_paragraph: One day in April, the people behind CrowdTangle, a data analytics tool owned by Facebook, learned that transparency had limits.
headline: Inside Facebook’s Data Wars

abstract: Instagram Threads — it’s like Twitter, except it’s not run by Elon Musk.
lead_paragraph: Instagram is no stranger to taking product ideas from other companies and turning them into their own successes. Just ask Snapchat about Instagram Stories or TikTok about Instagram Reels. This time, the company is coming for Twitter with Instagram Threads.
headline: Special Episode: Meta’s Twitter Rival Arrives, with Adam Mosseri

abstract: Meta, Apple, Amazon and others will report their first-quarter earnings.
lead_paragraph: Tech company earnings: Technology giants including Microsoft, Alphabet, Meta, Amazon and Apple are set to publish their financial performance reports for the first three months of the year. Tech stocks have been losing their ground as investors respond to the Federal Reserve’s plans to raise interest rates this year.
headline: Big tech earnings and new data on economic growth: The week in Business.

abstract: The Rian Johnson mystery delighted Toronto audiences. There was only one problem: How do you talk about it — any of it — without giving anything away?
lead_paragraph: As a journalist, I’m supposed to tell you everything I can learn about a subject. But when it comes to the new movie “Glass Onion,” which premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival on Saturday night, I’d rather tread lightly instead.
headline: The No-Spoilers Guide to ‘Glass Onion,’ the ‘Knives Out’ Sequel

abstract: The billionaire owner of X has increasingly been using his social media platform to criticize President Biden for his health and immigration policies, according to a New York Times analysis.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Elon Musk posted on X that President Biden “obviously barely knows what’s going on.”
headline: Elon Musk Ramps Up Anti-Biden Posts on X

abstract: A crypto conversation with video essayist Dan Olson.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Dan Olson. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Dan Olson

abstract: Some of the biggest oil and gas producers and industry groups used Facebook ads to promote fossil fuels after Mr. Biden unveiled his climate change plan last year.
lead_paragraph: Soon after Joseph R. Biden Jr., then a presidential candidate, released his $2 trillion climate plan last year that promised to escalate the use of clean energy in the United States, the world’s major oil and gas dialed up their presence on Facebook.
headline: Oil producers used Facebook to counter President Biden’s clean energy message, a study shows.

abstract: The panel of about 20 people, including academics and political leaders, upheld the company’s ban of former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: An independent panel called the Facebook Oversight Board on Wednesday upheld Facebook’s ban on former President Donald J. Trump, but said the company must review its decision to impose an indefinite suspension.
headline: What Is the Facebook Oversight Board?

abstract: Voters in more than two dozen nations that make up the E.U. are heading to the polls this week to choose their representatives in the European Parliament.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of millions of voters in all the 27 countries that make up the European Union are heading to polls from Thursday through Sunday to choose their representatives in the European Parliament, the only directly elected institution of the alliance.
headline: European Union 2024 Election: What to Know

abstract: Reed Hastings’s move to become executive chairman may be a sign that the streaming giant thinks the worst may be behind it.
lead_paragraph: For 25 years, Reed Hastings was not only Netflix’s co-founder, but also its most visible cheerleader and advocate. Yesterday he announced that he would relinquish his co-C.E.O. title to a top deputy and become executive chairman.
headline: Why Netflix Is Changing the Guard

abstract: The social media giants removed a large number of accounts that promoted Covid-19 conspiracy theories and undermined reports of human rights abuses.
lead_paragraph: Twitter and Facebook said they have removed thousands of accounts connected to Chinese information campaigns, in the latest sign of Beijing’s ambitions to shape the global narrative around the country.
headline: Twitter and Facebook hit back at Chinese propaganda campaigns.

abstract: The iPhone maker said sales of its flagship product were down 8 percent as it dealt with a factory shutdown and worries about rising inflation.
lead_paragraph: When a Covid-19 outbreak in China forced a lockdown of Apple’s largest iPhone factory in November, the world’s most valuable company warned investors that it would lose sales. The question was: How much?
headline: Apple Revenue and Profit Down as iPhone Sales Slow

abstract: Nancy Dubuc is leaving the media company, which is exploring a sale of some or all of the business, after nearly five years there.
lead_paragraph: When Vice Media named Nancy Dubuc as its new chief executive in 2018, her contract hinted at one of her missions. Sell the company — at the time a darling of the media industry — and she could cash in on a big stock grant, according to a copy of the contract obtained by The New York Times.
headline: Vice C.E.O.’s Departure Signals Fallen Hopes for Digital Media

abstract: World leaders are in Glasgow.
lead_paragraph: The world has made more progress combating climate change than you may realize.
headline: How to Prevent Climate Disasters

abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: This crime drama follows the rise and fall of a fictional motorcycle club in the 1960s.
headline: 7 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week

abstract: Long after the death of Joseph Pilates, the exercise program’s magnetic founder, his disciples are battling over his legacy.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Pilates believed he had created an exercise program that would stand the test of time and contribute to the well-being of anyone who practiced it seriously. And while Pilates continues to grow in popularity 55 years after his death, many of its devotees are far from content, as they quarrel over his legacy.
headline: The Fight for the Soul of Pilates

abstract: The Justice Department’s lawsuit against Apple is the latest in a series of regulatory actions that are hitting the tech giant at the same time.
