lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Louisiana on Tuesday restricted the Biden administration from communicating with social media platforms about broad swaths of content online, a ruling that could curtail efforts to combat false and misleading narratives about the coronavirus pandemic and other issues.
headline: Federal Judge Limits Biden Officials’ Contacts With Social Media Sites

abstract: Federal privacy bills, security legislation and antitrust laws to address the power of the tech giants have all failed to advance in Congress, despite hand wringing and shows of bipartisan support.
lead_paragraph: In just the last few years, Europe has seen a sweeping law for online privacy take effect, approved far-reaching regulations to curb the dominance of the tech giants and on Saturday reached a deal on new legislation to protect its citizens from harmful online content.
headline: As Europe Approves New Tech Laws, the U.S. Falls Further Behind

abstract: Apple, a latecomer to artificial intelligence, has struck a deal with OpenAI and developed tools to improve its Siri voice assistant, which it is set to showcase on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Each June, Apple unveils its newest software features for the iPhone at its futuristic Silicon Valley campus. But at its annual developer conference on Monday, the company will shine a spotlight on a feature that isn’t new: Siri, its talking assistant, which has been around for more than a decade.
headline: Hey, Siri! Let’s Talk About How Apple Is Giving You an A.I. Makeover.

abstract: ‘Should I get rid of my gas stove’ isn’t the only question to ask. It may not even be the right one.
lead_paragraph: My grandmother in India cooked for many years with coal, then with a tank of liquid petroleum gas. As a child in California, I lived in an apartment with an electric stove, then in a house with a gas connection. In London, last summer, I stayed in an apartment with an induction stove that glowed red in an instant. In Kenya a few years before that, I spent hours talking to women cooking dinner in smoky kitchens, over charcoal.
headline: About That Gas Stove

abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Oct. 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about a lawsuit in which dozens of states accuse Meta of knowingly using addictive features to attract children misidentified one of the two states that led the legal action. It was Colorado and California, not Colorado and Tennessee.
headline: Corrections: Oct. 26, 2023

abstract: Representation for dramatic artists of color is improving, but few Black creators get to be their own bosses. Two recent productions show what France’s mainstream theater is missing.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent Sunday evening, Paris played host to a theater troupe that had come a long way. The Grand Théâtre Itinérant de Guyane traveled from French Guiana, nestled north of Brazil on the Atlantic coast of South America, with its latest production: “Bernarda Alba From Yana,” staged by the company’s director, Odile Pedro Leal.
headline: On Paris Stages, Black Directors Forge a New Course

abstract: Jamie Dimon tells the bank’s investors to prepare for an economic upswell.
lead_paragraph: The annual letter to shareholders by JPMorgan Chase’s chief Jamie Dimon was just published. The widely read letter is not just an overview of the bank’s business but also covers Mr. Dimon’s thoughts on everything from leadership lessons to public policy prescriptions.
headline: JPMorgan’s Chief Sees a Boom Coming

abstract: There is little agreement among regulators and lawmakers around the world on how artificial intelligence should — or even could — be controlled.
lead_paragraph: Though their attempts to keep up with developments in artificial intelligence have mostly fallen short, regulators around the world are taking vastly different approaches to policing the technology. The result is a highly fragmented and confusing global regulatory landscape for a borderless technology that promises to transform job markets, contribute to the spread of disinformation or even present a risk to humanity.
headline: Five Ways A.I. Could Be Regulated

abstract: These controls, which are buried inside products from Apple, Google, Meta and others, make us share more data than we need to.
lead_paragraph: There’s a catchy saying going around with a valuable lesson about our personal technology: The devil is in the defaults.
headline: The Default Tech Settings You Should Turn Off Right Away

abstract: Much of the advice about urinary tract infections isn’t rooted in science. Here are four misunderstood facts about this very common affliction.
lead_paragraph: Over half of women in the United States will get a urinary tract infection in their lifetime. (This is compared to an estimated 14 percent of men.) Despite being common, it is often an experience layered with frustration and stigma, said Dr. Kalpana Gupta, a professor at Boston University Chobanian & Avedisian School of Medicine who does research on U.T.I.s. Patients “feel some personal responsibility,” she said. “Like, ‘I’m doing something wrong.’”
headline: The Persistent Confusion Around the U.T.I.

abstract: David Marcus, the head of its financial services unit, described the social network as a “challenger in the payments industry” that faces unfair resistance.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s mission is to “bring the world closer together.” Increasingly, that’s about not just connecting friends and family to share messages, but also serving as a platform for people’s financial lives.
headline: Facebook says it wants a ‘fair shot’ in the crypto payments sphere.

abstract: Elevator Repair Service’s Chekhov revival has promising ideas about art, experimentation and truth, but the production inevitably falls flat, our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: If only I could find someone who loves me enough to gift me a dead bird in a brown paper bag.
headline: ‘Seagull’ Review: Blurring the Lines of Fiction

abstract: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has led to a new willingness for countries to pay for their own defense.
lead_paragraph: NATO countries have been promising to spend more money on defense for many years.
headline: A Turning Point for Military Spending

abstract: Is the $44 billion  Twitter deal actually for real this time? Our hosts disagree.
lead_paragraph: On the inaugural episode of Hard Fork, Kevin Roose and Casey Newton debate why Elon Musk may buy Twitter after all. Then, they step into Meta’s metaverse with New York Times reporter, Kashmir Hill. Plus: a bonus Hard Fork Transparency Report.
headline: Elon’s Hidden Motives + A Meetup in the Metaverse

abstract: HBO airs its documentary on the youth affected by the 2005 hurricane and MTV hosts its annual award show.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 22-28. Details and times are subject to change.
headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Katrina Babies’ and the MTV Video Music Awards

abstract: A conversation about one teen’s rapid ascent, and what the future might hold for a singer and sound evolving in real time.
lead_paragraph: The singer glaive, just 16 years old, has become the biggest breakout star from the world of hyperpop. An intuitive songwriter with a springy voice and a direct line to a wellspring of raw emotion, he’s a true talent looming in a scene that isn’t anti-pop so much as meta-pop, chaotic and a little indifferent.
headline: glaive and Hyperpop’s Breakthrough Moment

abstract: The singer, who has prioritized innovation over commercial domination, has opted for a more standard playbook ahead of her seventh solo album, “Renaissance,” out Friday.
lead_paragraph: An upbeat lead single ready for radio. An album title and release date with plenty of notice. A magazine cover story, followed by a personal mission statement, a fresh social media account, a detailed track list and a merchandise pre-sale.
headline: Is Beyoncé’s Latest Album Rollout (Gasp!) Conventional?

abstract: The hero vs. bully template made famous in the ’80s gets subverted in this indie comedy, as well as in Hulu’s “Miguel Wants to Fight.”
lead_paragraph: You know the setup: one boy, the underdog, is forced to face off with a boy with more social clout — and, likely, more muscles. They’re in the gym, the hallway, or the schoolyard, and by the time the last punch is thrown, the underdog, our hero, has taken his first steps into manhood.
headline: How the Bloody ‘Bottoms’ Reinvents the Coming-of-Age Fight

abstract: Hackers in Russia and Belarus are using Meta’s platform for cyberespionage and disinformation campaigns, executives said.
lead_paragraph: Hackers affiliated with the governments of Russia and Belarus have turned their attention to Ukraine since the Russian invasion began in February, attempting to use Facebook for cyberespionage and disinformation campaigns, the social network’s parent company, Meta, said on Thursday.
headline: Pro-Russian hackers have ramped up the use of Facebook in an information war, its parent company says.
Catch up: Apple and Facebook profits doubled last quarter.

abstract: Analysts bullish on 2023 were largely right and expect more of the same in 2024. Bears caution that the Fed’s impact is yet to be determined.
lead_paragraph: Twelve months ago, Tom Lee bet that 2023 was going to turn out just fine.
headline: Downturn or Not? At Year’s End, Wall St. Is Split on What’s Ahead.

abstract: Engineers at the tech giants built tools years ago that could put a name to any face but, for once, Silicon Valley did not want to move fast and break things.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in early 2017, at Facebook’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif., an engineer named Tommer Leyvand sat in a conference room with a smartphone standing on the brim of his baseball cap. Rubber bands helped anchor it in place with the camera facing out. The absurd hat-phone, a particularly uncool version of the future, contained a secret tool known only to a small group of employees. What it could do was remarkable.
headline: The Technology Facebook and Google Didn’t Dare Release

abstract: Tonics and tablets made with this ancient herb promise to calm you down and level you out. Do they actually work?
lead_paragraph: If you believe TikTok and pastel-colored ad campaigns, here is an incomplete list of what ashwagandha can do: reduce stress, “kill” emotions, focus a frantic mind, squelch social anxiety, fend off depression, give you a boost at the gym.
headline: All About Ashwagandha, the Stress Relief Supplement of the Moment

abstract: Mark Zuckerberg wants us thinking about visual art when we contemplate his company’s new venture. Artists should take the suggestion seriously.
lead_paragraph: In the opening pages of Ben Lerner’s debut novel, “Leaving the Atocha Station,” his narrator goes to Madrid’s Prado museum and observes a stranger breaking into sobs in front of Rogier van der Weyden’s “Descent From the Cross,” a votive portrait attributed to Paolo da San Leocadio, and Hieronymus Bosch’s “Garden of Earthly Delights.” He watches the man until he leaves and follows him out into the sunshine. The narrator has worried for a long time that he is incapable of having such a profound experience of art. Many of us, I imagine, have experienced the failure to be moved by a painting as we’d hoped to be. I thought of this passage as I watched the first major ad for Meta, Facebook’s rebranding as a metaverse company, which also takes place in a museum. But here the art is moving — quite literally.
headline: What Will Art Look Like in the Metaverse?

abstract: The meeting took place at a giant 20th-century estate built by a family that made its fortune in the gold rush.
lead_paragraph: Filoli, a grand house and garden on 654 acres of rolling green grounds near the California coast, has been a supporting character in the 1980s television drama “Dynasty” and the 2001 romantic comedy “The Wedding Planner.” It has been the venue for top-dollar nuptials of Facebook executives, and the public can tour the gardens.
headline: Biden and Xi Meet at a Backdrop for Hollywood and Tech-Titan Weddings

abstract: From flashlight-under-the-blanket page-turners and music-infused time travel to a campy book about camp, here are 11 summer novels for comics-hungry kids.
lead_paragraph: ‘Haylee and Comet: A Tale of Cosmic Friendship,’ by Deborah Marcero(Roaring Brook, June 1)
headline: 11 Summer Graphic Novels for Early and Middle-Grade Readers

abstract: Pro-Russian content presenting a distorted version of the war in Ukraine and promoting Russia’s interests in Africa is gaining an audience on the continent.
lead_paragraph: In South Africa, a social media influencer who added “Vladimir” to his Twitter name to convey his reverence for the Russian president transmits Russian-generated content over Twitter and Telegram to a growing audience that now numbers 148,000 followers.
headline: How Putin Became a Hero on African TV

abstract: The company’s revenue and profit beat Wall Street expectations, easing concerns that supply chain problems and the coronavirus were a drag on sales.
lead_paragraph: Apple weathered the supply chain snarls at the end of 2021 that tripped up the global electronics market and other industries, announcing on Thursday an 11 percent increase in revenue and a 20 percent jump in profit in its most recent quarter while offering optimism that the worst of the problems were behind it.
headline: Apple’s profit jumps to $34.6 billion in holiday quarter despite supply issues.

abstract: Both Musk, who once backed OpenAI, and Facebook’s parent company are set to unveil new services aimed at getting a piece of the artificial intelligence boom.
lead_paragraph: The rivalry between Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk won’t be confined to social media posts or a cage fight. The tech heavyweights are accelerating pushes into the artificial intelligence world to take on the Microsoft-backed OpenAI and Google, taking different approaches in the buzziest sector of the software industry.
headline: The A.I. Wars Heat Up as Elon Musk and Meta Enter the Ring

abstract: Chief executives in the U.S. have long pushed for closer ties between the two countries. Now they just hope a rocky situation won’t get worse.
lead_paragraph: In a meeting in Beijing on Friday, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, traded warm smiles with Bill Gates and praised Mr. Gates as “the first American friend” he had met this year.
headline: As U.S. and Chinese Officials Meet, Businesses Temper Their Hopes

abstract: A year ago, a rogue A.I. tried to break up my marriage. Did the backlash help make chatbots too boring?
lead_paragraph: A year ago, on Valentine’s Day, I said good night to my wife, went to my home office to answer some emails and accidentally had the strangest first date of my life.
headline: The Year Chatbots Were Tamed

abstract: The Swedish songwriter and producer behind smashes for Britney Spears, Katy Perry and the Weeknd is reluctantly emerging for “& Juliet,” a new Broadway show built on his music.
lead_paragraph: Once, not long ago, the Swedish songwriter and producer Max Martin met someone who had never heard one of his hits.
headline: Max Martin, Pop’s Low-Key Mastermind, Takes Center Stage (Sort Of)

abstract: The tech giant says it’s a “challenger” in finance.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s mission is to “bring the world closer together.” Increasingly, that’s not just about connecting friends and family to share messages, but also serving as a platform for people’s financial lives. Some $100 billion in payments have been enabled by Facebook over the past year, said David Marcus, who runs the company’s financial services unit. But that’s just the start of the social network’s ambitions in the finance industry, Marcus writes in a new memo about America’s “broken” payments system.
headline: Facebook Plays the Underdog

abstract: Microsoft, LinkedIn’s owner, had already pulled the flagship networking site from China in 2021, leaving only a stripped-down app that catered to job seekers.
lead_paragraph: LinkedIn, the networking platform used by millions of employees and companies, said on Monday it will pare down its operations in China, capping a multiyear pullback that exemplified the challenges of running a foreign business in China.
headline: LinkedIn Will Cut Over 700 Jobs Worldwide and Shut Its China App

abstract: This past week has been jam-packed with openings. Our reviewers think these new shows are worth knowing about even if you’re not planning to see them.
lead_paragraph: Rachel McAdams makes her Broadway debut in Amy Herzog’s play about an impossibly upbeat mother caring for a gravely ill child and navigating the byzantine health care system.
headline: 9 New Shows Our Theater Critics Are Talking About

abstract: Also, a legal victory for Imran Khan.
lead_paragraph: Gina Raimondo, the U.S. commerce secretary, told Chinese officials yesterday that the U.S. was not seeking to sever economic ties with China. But she raised a list of concerns that were prompting American businesses to describe China as “uninvestable” because it’s “too risky.”
headline: Wednesday Briefing: U.S. Businesses Say China Is ‘Uninvestable’

abstract: Or is it Styles-ish? Either way, when anthropologists look back on this year, they’ll be glad to have this list.
lead_paragraph: From the moment she revealed her pregnancy via a not-accidental “accidental” photo shoot, her growing belly — in all its bare, distended gloriousness — was impossible to ignore.
headline: Styles’s 93 Most Stylish ‘People’ of 2022

abstract: Russia is incubating a cottage industry of new digital surveillance tools to suppress domestic opposition to the war in Ukraine. The tech may also be sold overseas.
lead_paragraph: As the war in Ukraine unfolded last year, Russia’s best digital spies turned to new tools to fight an enemy on another front: those inside its own borders who opposed the war.
headline: Cracking Down on Dissent, Russia Seeds a Surveillance Supply Chain

abstract: Stanford researchers have ranked 10 major A.I. models on how openly they operate.
lead_paragraph: How much do we know about A.I.?
headline: Maybe We Will Finally Learn More About How A.I. Works

abstract: Ezra Klein and Kara Swisher join Jane Coaston to debate recent and ongoing mistakes dominating the news.
lead_paragraph: In a special Opinion Audio bonanza, Jane Coaston (The Argument), Ezra Klein (The Ezra Klein Show) and Kara Swisher (Sway) sit down to discuss what went wrong for the G.O.P. in the recall election of Gov. Gavin Newsom of California. “This was where the nationalization of politics really bit back for Republicans,” Jane says. The three hosts then debate whether the media industry’s criticism of itself does any good at all. “The media tweets like nobody’s watching,” Ezra says. Then the hosts turn to The Wall Street Journal’s revelations in “The Facebook Files” and discuss how to hold Facebook accountable. “We’re saying your tools in the hands of malevolent players are super dangerous,” Kara says, “but we have no power over them whatsoever.”
headline: How They Failed: California Republicans, Media Critics and Facebook

abstract: As regulatory scrutiny picks up, the tech giant says it is pleased with the progress OpenAI has made with governance and considers its oversight role unnecessary.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has given up its seat on OpenAI’s board, relinquishing a nonvoting position it gained late last year, as regulators intensify their scrutiny of the ties between the tech giant and the start-up behind the chatbot ChatGPT.
headline: Microsoft Surrenders OpenAI Board Position

abstract: Linwei Ding, a Chinese national, was arrested in California and accused of uploading hundreds of files to the cloud.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese citizen who recently quit his job as a software engineer for Google in California has been charged with trying to transfer artificial intelligence technology to a Beijing-based company that paid him secretly, according to a federal indictment unsealed on Wednesday.
headline: Ex-Google Engineer Charged With Stealing A.I. Secrets for Chinese Firm

abstract: It’s not just you — what you can buy on your phone makes less and less sense.
lead_paragraph: Apps have become a huge economy, but the rules that govern them are nearly impossible to understand.
headline: App Rules Are Twisted to Absurdity

abstract: Enormous numbers of kids follow social media influencers who boost addictive drugs to audiences who are too young to legally buy them.
lead_paragraph: Do you know what a Zynbabwe is? Or an upper-decky lip pillow? OK, here’s an easier one — how about just Zyn?
headline: Our Kids Are Living in a Different Digital World

abstract: The company faces accusations that it hid research showing the mental and emotional harm that Instagram, its photo-sharing app, has on teenagers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers took sharp aim at Facebook on Thursday, harshly questioning one of its executives about Instagram’s effect on teenagers, in a Senate hearing that illuminated the growing bipartisan frustrations and concerns with the social media giant.
headline: Facebook Grilled by Senators Over Its Effect on Children

abstract: An Australian man claimed a real estate agent did not pay its “employees” retirement funds. The lack of a punctuation mark may cost him thousands.
lead_paragraph: A missing apostrophe in a Facebook post could cost a real estate agent in Australia tens of thousands of dollars after a court ruled a defamation case against him could proceed.
headline: Missing Apostrophe in Facebook Post Lands a Man in Defamation Court

abstract: On the show “Platonic” and what research says about old straight married people and opposite-sex friends.
lead_paragraph: The show “Platonic” is about a pair of old friends, Sylvia and Will, who reconnect after years on the outs. Sylvia (Rose Byrne) is a stay-at-home mom of three kids, and Will (Seth Rogen) is recently divorced and child-free. In the first episode of the series, on Apple TV+, we learn that their close friendship had broken up in part because Will’s ex-wife didn’t get along with Sylvia. Sylvia reaches out when she discovers they are no longer together.
headline: Why Platonic Friendships Are So Hard to Keep

abstract: Young men are being tricked into sending naked pictures to scammers pretending to be women — who then demand money. The consequences can be devastating.
lead_paragraph: The Instagram message popped up from a girl named Chelsea: “Howdy.”
headline: ‘Chelsea’ Asked for Nude Pictures. Then the Sextortion Began.

abstract: Plus, floods and landslides batter northern India.
lead_paragraph: In a sudden reversal, Turkey agreed yesterday to clear the way for Sweden to join NATO. NATO’s secretary general announced the decision in Vilnius, Lithuania, where the alliance was preparing to open its annual summit today. Hours earlier, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had said that the E.U. should first advance Turkey’s bid to join the European bloc before Sweden could join the alliance.
headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Turkey backs Sweden’s NATO bid

abstract: With Elon Musk’s rebranding of the app, is Twitter’s name really retired? What about tweets? We unravel the terminology puzzle.
lead_paragraph: With a simple name change, Elon Musk has created confusion in social media.
headline: So What Do We Call Twitter Now Anyway?

abstract: The company’s quarterly revenue rose 25% as its costs fell after layoffs last year.
lead_paragraph: Meta on Thursday reported a 25 percent increase in quarterly revenue while profit more than tripled, a rise fueled by its ads business after a shaky 18 months of layoffs and a rocky digital advertising market.
headline: Meta Reports Profits More Than Tripled and Issues Its First Dividend

abstract: We’re seeing the limits of Facebook’s strategy to buy or copy other people’s best ideas.
lead_paragraph: There has been no shortage of explanations for the sudden, spectacular swoon in Facebook’s stock value last week. Meta, Facebook’s parent company, said in an earnings report that its user growth had stalled. Young people, its most valuable demographic, keep spending time on TikTok, the irresistible short-video app that has become Facebook’s most formidable competitor in years.
headline: Facebook Has an Innovation Problem

abstract: Ryan Reynolds and Will Ferrell star in this musical spin on “A Christmas Carol” from Apple TV+.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before rabid hordes of consumers descend upon department stores like the avian menace in a Hitchcock film, before neighborhood dogs daintily lift their legs to the stripped-down sidewalk pines left for dead in the cheerless days of January, I’ve had an early Christmas revelation: Scrooge was onto something. All his grinching doesn’t seem so far-fetched; ol’ Ebenezer probably lost out on a Black Friday sale or watched too many bad Christmas movies, because after viewing the Sean Anders film “Spirited,” I’m feeling plenty humbuggy myself.
headline: ‘Spirited’ Review: A Whole Lot of Humbug

abstract: In his new movie, “The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent,” the actor plays “himself” in all his meme-ified glory.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-two years ago, Nicolas Cage swaggered onto the set of a British talk show to promote his movie “Wild at Heart.” After performing a handspring and several kung fu-style moves, he whipped off his T-shirt, thrust it at the startled host, and put his leather jacket back on over his naked chest before proceeding with the interview.
headline: Nicolas Cage Is in on the Nicolas Cage Jokes

abstract: The venture capitalist Keith Rabois may have made his fortune in Silicon Valley, but he no longer thinks the Bay Area has much to offer tech.
lead_paragraph: Keith Rabois minted his wealth with Elon Musk, Peter Thiel and other members of the so-called “PayPal Mafia.” Now, though, he’s moved to Miami and become one of the city’s biggest hype men. He believes Florida — which has already seen an influx of tech bros, venture capital investments and cryptocurrency plays during the pandemic — offers a better home to tech than California can, largely because of the politics. He tells Kara Swisher: “The mayor of Miami, the governor of Florida treat citizens like customers. ‘What can we offer you? How can we help?’ That’s their goal, and that’s how they frame everything.”
headline: Is Tech’s Love Affair With Miami About Taxes, or Something Else?

abstract: How the Mexican military is using private data against civilians — and what that reveals about the country’s democracy.
lead_paragraph: Tech companies, like Meta and Apple, sell users the promise of privacy. They say the encryption on their smartphones and apps will keep user data safe.
headline: When a Military Spies on Citizens’ Phones

abstract: Meta announced that it would begin charging $11.99 a month for a blue badge on Facebook and Instagram.
lead_paragraph: Meta — the parent company of Facebook and Instagram — wants power users to start paying for some of its sites’ features, taking a page out of Twitter’s playbook in charging for verified blue check marks.
headline: Facebook Parent Plans to Sell ‘Meta Verified’ Accounts

abstract: The former president’s trials aren’t being aired. That isn’t stopping him from turning them into a political reality show.
lead_paragraph: The civil-fraud case against Donald J. Trump’s businesses in New York, in which he was ordered to pay a penalty of $355 million, was not televised. Neither was his civil trial for the defamation of E. Jean Carroll. Nor — barring an unlikely change in federal court policy — will be his looming federal election-interference trial.
headline: For Donald Trump, the Recriminations Will Be Televised

abstract: The U.S. economy shrinks, but still shows it’s still resilient. The Fed meets this week and is expected to approve a larger-than-usual rate increase.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk reached an agreement on Monday to buy Twitter for about $44 billion, a deal that was unanimously approved by Twitter’s board. The price works out to $54.20 a share, a 38 percent premium over the company’s share price in April, before Mr. Musk revealed he had purchased a 9 percent stake in Twitter. In a matter of weeks, Mr. Musk, the richest person in the world, took his bid from something that investors shrugged off to a serious proposal. The turning point came when he filed documents showing he had the financing to back up his offer. Now, it could be the largest deal to take a company private in at least 20 years, according to data from Dealogic. Still, much remains uncertain as to how the mercurial billionaire will carry out his vision for a platform with less moderation.
headline: The Week in Business: The Twitter Deal

abstract: Isaac Fellman’s new book, “Dead Collections,” explores identity, romance and sci-fi fandom, as seen through the eyes of a transgender vampire.
lead_paragraph: DEAD COLLECTIONSBy Isaac Fellman
headline: He’s a Transgender Archivist and a Vampire, and He’s in Love

abstract: The social network wants to promote standardized labels to help detect artificially created photo, video and audio material across its platforms.
lead_paragraph: Last month at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Nick Clegg, president of global affairs at Meta, called a nascent effort to detect artificially generated content “the most urgent task” facing the tech industry today.
headline: Meta Calls for Industry Effort to Label A.I.-Generated Content

abstract: Leaders from OpenAI, Google DeepMind, Anthropic and other A.I. labs warn that future systems could be as deadly as pandemics and nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: A group of industry leaders warned on Tuesday that the artificial intelligence technology they were building might one day pose an existential threat to humanity and should be considered a societal risk on a par with pandemics and nuclear wars.
headline: A.I. Poses ‘Risk of Extinction,’ Industry Leaders Warn

abstract: Books by Elvira Lindo, Blair Hurley, Ramona Ausubel and Nathacha Appanah take on crises of kinship.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t believe in God,” the Spanish writer Elvira Lindo concedes in her prayerful work of autofiction, OPEN HEART (Other Press, 359 pp., paperback, $18.99),“but I do believe in those memories that rain down on us endlessly, taking shape as ghosts that accompany us.” The ghosts, in this case, are the narrator’s father, Manuel, who in 1939, at 9 years old, is all but abandoned in a Madrid gutted by the Spanish Civil War, and her mother, who quails before the gregarious tyrant that Manuel grows into and who dies from a heart defect before the narrator is out of high school.
headline: New Novels About Family Ties (and Their Many Hazards)

abstract: The long-embattled property developer was finally ordered to liquidate. What comes next will test Western companies’ appetite to keep operating in China.
lead_paragraph: A Hong Kong court on Monday ordered the liquidation of Evergrande, the heavily indebted Chinese property giant. The decision comes two years after the company defaulted, setting off a financial crisis at other developers and adding to the challenges facing the world’s second-largest economy.
headline: What Evergrande’s Collapse Might Mean for Global Business

abstract: Tech and finance workers posted countless videos about the luxuries of their jobs — until the mood shifted.
lead_paragraph: “Here’s a day in the life working at Google,” the clip opens. We watch a woman in Los Angeles drive to the office, get valet parking, fetch some iced coffee and a banana and tend to some tasks on a blurred-out screen. She shows off but declines to eat drawers full of snacks, then describes her complimentary salad in detail. Highlights of the office space around her include a nap room and a Harry Potter-themed conference room filled with flickering lamps and house flags.
headline: What Does Workplace TikTok Look Like During Layoffs? It Gets Weird.

abstract: Elon Musk, in an early-morning post, said he planned to livestream the event on his own platform. Mark Zuckerberg called for a “more reliable” platform, adding, “I’m ready today.”
lead_paragraph: For months, the chatter in Silicon Valley has centered on whether Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk would actually participate in a “cage match” as they said they would. But after a flurry of activity and promises from both sides, it looked as if the momentum behind the mega-mogul face-off had fizzled out.
headline: With No Date Set, Musk and Zuckerberg Trade Barbs on ‘Cage Match’

abstract: The June 13, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Carlos Lozada. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Carlos Lozada

abstract: Plus a warning at COP27 and Kherson in distress.
lead_paragraph: Americans will finish voting in midterm elections today, which could change the balance of power in state and federal legislative bodies, influence foreign policy and foreshadow the 2024 presidential race.
headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: The U.S. Midterms Loom

abstract: Inflation, avian flu and war have made a food staple much more expensive.
lead_paragraph: Prices have risen for just about everything over the past couple of years. But anyone shopping for groceries recently has probably noticed the cost of one item in particular: eggs.
headline: Why Eggs Cost So Much

abstract: The prosecution of a prominent playwright and a director in Russia over their work is a chilling sign of increased repression, cultural figures say.
lead_paragraph: They wrote and staged their play as an indictment of terrorism, examining the deception and depravity of violent extremists and the people whose lives they ruin.
headline: 2 Russian Women Put on a Play. Then the State Came for Them.

abstract: Tom Gormican, the director of “The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent,” narrates a sequence featuring the star and Pedro Pascal.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
headline: How Nicolas Cage Parodies Himself in ‘Massive Talent’

abstract: Russian forces escalated attacks on Ukrainian cities.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
headline: Civilians Come Under Fire

abstract: Teachers across the country on how to support children’s social and emotional learning.
lead_paragraph: I have heard from many readers and friends that their kids are struggling to adjust to in-person schooling this year. For the little ones, there’s more separation anxiety, which means more tears at drop-off, and struggles to even get out the door. For older children and teens, I’m hearing that some previously motivated kids are less engaged. Perhaps they fell behind during remote learning and feel discouraged now that they’re back in the classroom. Others have anxiety about the virus and may still be reeling from grief if they’ve lost family members.
headline: Why Kids May Be Melting Down at School

abstract: Global markets edged higher as the prospect of the United States defaulting on its debt grows more remote.
lead_paragraph: The debt-ceiling deal is a step closer to becoming law after its breezy passage in the House last night, making the prospect of a U.S. default all the more remote. Investors expressed relief, sending global markets and U.S. stock futures higher this morning.
headline: Investors Exhale as Debt Limit Deal Clears a Big Hurdle

abstract: Despite concerns of a shaky ad market and growing competition in A.I., Google’s bounce forward in the second quarter was aided by accelerating revenue from its search engine and the video platform YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, gained ground in its most recent quarter against several of its lingering challenges, according to financial results released on Tuesday.
headline: Alphabet Steams Past Ad Worries, Fueled by Google’s Search Engine

abstract: Crypto, the economy, China, streaming wars, Elon Musk and other big topics dominated this year’s DealBook Summit.
lead_paragraph: DealBook held its annual conference in New York yesterday, a packed day of high-level discussions with leaders from the world of politics, business and culture. Speakers included:
headline: What We Learned From Sam Bankman-Fried, Mark Zuckerberg, Reed Hastings and More

abstract: In Stephanie Bishop’s psychological thriller, “The Anniversary,” tragedy strikes on a cruise.
lead_paragraph: In love, in art, in crime, what is done intentionally and what is done unintentionally? This is the question at the core of Stephanie Bishop’s fourth novel, “The Anniversary.”
headline: Water, Water, Everywhere, and Now Her Husband Is Gone

abstract: First it was college campuses. Now the corporate world is increasingly feeling pressure to find a balance in responding to the war.
lead_paragraph: As the Israel-Hamas war stretches on — with Israeli airstrikes hitting more targets in Gaza amid calls by the U.S. and others to delay a potential ground invasion — companies are finding themselves increasingly tangled in the conflict’s complex politics.
headline: Companies Are Caught in the Israel-Hamas War’s Crossfire

abstract: The former president’s social media company is finally set to go public. He could borrow against the value of his stake in the company.
lead_paragraph: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company could start trading on the stock market as early as Monday, immediately raising his net worth by around $3 billion — wealth that Mr. Trump may be able to tap to pay his mounting legal bills as he seeks a second presidential term.
headline: A Little-Known Way That Trump Could Raise Money to Pay His Legal Bills

abstract: In a mixed but audacious first season, AMC’s feminist deconstruction of marriage stories made two sets of TV clichés into something bigger.
lead_paragraph: In Disney+’s “WandaVision,” sitcoms were a prison and a haven. The Avengers’ Wanda Maximoff (Elizabeth Olsen), racked with grief over the death of her android husband, Vision (Paul Bettany), conjured him back to life on a sitcom set — a magical bubble constructed of made-for-TV happy memories.
headline: Welcome to His World. And Hers.

abstract: It was the company’s second consecutive quarterly decline, the first time that had happened in over a decade.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, has staked his company’s future on an immersive online world known as the metaverse. On Wednesday, the company showed it was still navigating that transformation.
headline: Meta, Facebook’s parent, reports a 21 percent drop in profits.

abstract: Moderators’ work on Reddit and Facebook is crucial but not paid. We should be creative in how we compensate them.
lead_paragraph: The volunteers who run our favorite groups on Facebook, Reddit, Nextdoor or Discord can make all the difference between our being part of a treasured community online or a gathering that descends into name-calling chaos.
headline: The Work of Online Volunteers

abstract: Instagram’s new app was downloaded more than 30 million times in 16 hours. Twitter threatened legal action against its rival.
lead_paragraph: Two hours after pressing the launch button on Wednesday on Threads, Instagram’s new app for real-time, public conversations, Mark Zuckerberg posted that more than two million people had downloaded his latest creation.
headline: Threads Becomes Most Rapidly Downloaded App, Raising Twitter’s Ire

abstract: A Kremlin-linked group known for online campaigns to sow falsehoods and distrust among Russia’s foes helped fuel the frenzy of conspiracy theories about Catherine and her health.
lead_paragraph: The whirl of conspiracy theories that enveloped Catherine, Princess of Wales, before she disclosed her cancer diagnosis last week probably didn’t need help from a foreign state. But researchers in Britain said Wednesday that a notorious Russian disinformation operation helped stir the pot.
headline: Russian Group Spread Disinformation About Princess of Wales, Experts Say

abstract: The Biden administration is suing to block Penguin Random House from buying Simon & Schuster. A United States District Court will decide if the sale can proceed.
lead_paragraph: When the largest publisher in the country, Penguin Random House, struck a deal in the fall of 2020 to acquire its rival Simon & Schuster, publishing executives and antitrust experts predicted that the merger would draw intense scrutiny from government regulators.
headline: Will the Biggest Publisher in the United States Get Even Bigger?

abstract: Joseph Earl Thomas’s new novel, “God Bless You, Otis Spunkmeyer,” follows a health care worker on a tumultuous shift where every other patient seems to be someone from his past.
lead_paragraph: Early one morning my husband asked me if I was enjoying “God Bless You, Otis Spunkmeyer,” the book I’d spent the last few days reading around the house, sometimes with a look of delight, sometimes laughing or on the verge of tears, sometimes with a look of extreme frustration. “Ask me later today,” I told him, unable to process if “enjoyment” was what I was feeling as I made my way through Joseph Earl Thomas’s debut novel.
headline: He’s an Emergency Medical Worker Fighting to Save People From His Own Life

abstract: OpenAI now lets outsiders tweak what its chatbot does. A new paper says that can lead to trouble.
lead_paragraph: Before it released the A.I. chatbot ChatGPT last year, the San Francisco start-up OpenAI added digital guardrails meant to prevent its system from doing things like generating hate speech and disinformation. Google did something similar with its Bard chatbot.
headline: Researchers Say Guardrails Built Around A.I. Systems Are Not So Sturdy

abstract: The results of the 2021 Puzzle Mania Super Mega crossword contest.
lead_paragraph: The “Super Mega” crossword by Jeff Chen in December’s Puzzle Mania section was, apparently, pretty challenging, because a lower percentage of solvers than usual got it right.
headline: And the Winners Are, Part 1: Super Mega

abstract: Democracies have to adjust to a changed world, but the challenge before them is to do so without losing their essential values.
lead_paragraph: Do we dare to hope? This was the question addressed to the 11th Athens Democracy Forum, against a backdrop of war in Europe, unchecked climate change, galloping inflation and the A.I. revolution with its specter of “robots with glaring red eyes,” as Nick Clegg, the president of global affairs for Meta, put it.
headline: Daring to Hope That Democracy Will Prevail

abstract: Broadcast television and talk radio are just as problematic as social media.
lead_paragraph: The plague of misinformation — false rumors about the legitimacy of the 2020 presidential election, the ineffectiveness of face masks and the safety of 5G, to name a few examples — is usually blamed on social media. But false and damaging information isn’t just available online. It’s also abundant in broadcast media, and as politicians debate whether or how to regulate technology companies, they should also consider creating systems to address the dangers implicit in allowing and enabling the spread of misinformation, wherever it’s published.
headline: Not on Facebook? You’re Still Likely Being Fed Misinformation.

abstract: Google’s parent company topped revenue and profit estimates and said that it would offer a stock dividend for the first time.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Alphabet, Google’s parent company, reported strong revenue growth in its latest quarter from its search engine and video platform, YouTube, as its market-leading position in online advertising continued to reap rewards despite recent fluctuations in the industry.
headline: Alphabet’s Revenue Jumps 15% to $80.5 Billion

abstract: How the former president’s legal troubles might affect his campaign.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has 10 days to come up with a $175 million bond in his New York civil fraud case. After that, he may be on the hook for the full penalty in the case: almost half a billion dollars.
headline: Trump’s Financial Squeeze

abstract: The District of Columbia case, which grew out of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, could expose the chief executive to financial and other penalties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The attorney general for the District of Columbia on Wednesday added Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, to a consumer protection lawsuit, in one of the first efforts by a regulator to expose him personally to potential financial and other penalties. The attorney general, Karl Racine, said that continuing interviews and reviews of internal documents for the case had revealed that Mr. Zuckerberg played a much more active role in key decisions than prosecutors had known.
headline: Mark Zuckerberg will be added to a Facebook privacy lawsuit.

abstract: Authorities in China have turned to sophisticated investigative software to track and silence obscure critics on overseas social media. Their targets include college students and non-Chinese nationals.
lead_paragraph: When Jennifer Chen traveled back to her hometown in central China last winter for Lunar New Year, she thought little about Twitter. She had around 100 followers on an account she believed to be anonymous.
headline: A Digital Manhunt: How Chinese Police Track Critics on Twitter and Facebook

abstract: Henri Bosco’s lyrical 1945 novella, “The Child and the River,” tells the story of two boys and a boat.
lead_paragraph: The life and literary career of Henri Bosco spanned two centuries, two world wars, two continents, an empire and its aftermath. Born in 1888 in Avignon, he trained as a composer, spent World War I on the Balkan front, then became a teacher in France’s “overseas departments” — notably in Rabat — until Moroccan independence in 1955.
headline: Called the French ‘Huck Finn,’ This Book Has Pleasures All Its Own

abstract: A lot happened last week. This week, pretty much all of it was put on hold.
lead_paragraph: And now for something completely different.
headline: ‘Ted Lasso’ Recap, Season 2 Episode 9: Beard Has a Late Night

abstract: Hear tracks by Dua Lipa, Nicky Jam and Romeo Santos, R+R=Now and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
headline: Taylor Swift’s New Old ‘Love Story,’ and 12 More Songs

abstract: Users of Instagram, Facebook, WhatsApp and Messenger will be able to turn to the new technology, powered by Meta’s latest artificial intelligence model, to obtain information and complete tasks.
lead_paragraph: On a call with investors last spring, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, said he believed that he had an opportunity to introduce artificially intelligent assistants “to billions of people in ways that will be useful and meaningful.”
headline: Meta, in Its Biggest A.I. Push, Places Smart Assistants Across Its Apps

abstract: In her new novel, “Leaving,” Roxana Robinson reunites a former couple. One of them is divorced; the other is still married. What now?
lead_paragraph: Every love story needs an obstacle, someone or something that threatens to keep the lovers apart. What obstacles are suitable for a contemporary American love story? The writer of such a story may wish to avoid the over-communication, the tolerance (real or performed) and the jadedness that dispel romantic tension. Can lovers still be “star-crossed,” doomed from the start to labor under a “malign star”?
headline: A Tale of Midlife Love With a Bombshell Ending

abstract: Marketing is consuming our culture to the point that the product seems almost irrelevant to its own success.
lead_paragraph: In today’s creative economy, the tail increasingly wags the dog. Marketing is driving culture as promotional campaigns overshadow the offerings they seek to elevate — in fashion, music, art and film. With fashion weeks taking place around the world and awards season well underway, the hype machine is operating at full throttle. But few products, if any, can compete with such fanfare. On the runway, the red carpet and beyond, culture is at risk of being subsumed by the sound and the fury, the hype and the buzz, of its own promotion.
headline: ‘Barbie,’ ‘Saltburn,’ Louis Vuitton: When Culture Becomes a TikTok Craze

abstract: The S&P 500 logged its first weekly decline since October, ending Wall Street’s longest winning streak in nearly 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s longest weekly winning streak in almost 20 years came to an end on Friday, as stock investors’ celebrations over slowing inflation and the potential for cuts to interest rates were replaced with caution over the lingering risks to the economy.
headline: Wall Street Sobers Up After December’s Rally

abstract: Natural gas prices soared in Europe and stocks fell, as officials  investigate the causes of the Nordstream 1 and 2 gas pipeline explosions.
lead_paragraph: There is still no official explanation for what caused the explosions that ruptured the Nord Stream 1 and 2 pipelines, sending natural gas gurgling to the surface of the Baltic Sea. But that hasn’t stopped some E.U. officials from calling the episode an “act of sabotage,” with Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki of Poland publicly blaming Russia. Then last night, the pipelines’ operator, Gazprom, threatened to shut down the only pipeline that’s still pumping Russian gas to Western Europe.
headline: ‘Act of Sabotage’ Hits Europe’s Energy and Stocks Markets

abstract: Facebook has reaffirmed its ban on Taliban-related accounts, as have the Facebook-owned WhatsApp and Instagram, even as the group engages in a publicity campaign to persuade Afghans and the rest of the world that they can be just and competent rulers.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has reaffirmed its ban on Taliban-related accounts, as have the Facebook-owned WhatsApp and Instagram, even as the group engages in a publicity campaign to persuade Afghans and the rest of the world that they can be just and competent rulers.
headline: Facebook reaffirms a ban on Taliban accounts even as the group looks to communicate a new message.

abstract: Moscow has ordered search engines in Russia to place a disclaimer on Wikipedia results and denounce the site as a violator of its restrictive information law, the latest effort by the country to manipulate how Russians view the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Moscow has ordered search engines in Russia to place a disclaimer on Wikipedia results and denounce the site as a violator of its restrictive information law, the latest effort by the country to manipulate how Russians view the war in Ukraine.
headline: Russia orders search engines to put a disclaimer on Wikipedia results it claims are ‘fakes.’

abstract: A new Florida law also requires apps like TikTok and Snapchat to obtain a parent’s consent before giving accounts to 14- and 15-year-olds.
lead_paragraph: Florida on Monday became the first state to effectively bar residents under the age of 14 from holding accounts on services like TikTok and Instagram, enacting a strict social media bill that is likely to upend the lives of many young people.
headline: DeSantis Signs Social Media Bill Barring Accounts for Children Under 14

abstract: Volodymyr Zelensky’s address to the U.N.
lead_paragraph: Addressing the U.N. Security Council yesterday via a video link, Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, accused Russia of a litany of horrors and questioned whether a world body that takes no action to stop a war serves any purpose. Follow the latest updates.
headline: Your Wednesday Briefing

abstract: Ms. Brown’s exit indicates how Meta’s priorities around news and its relationships with media companies have changed.
lead_paragraph: When Facebook was being battered in 2017 for distributing false and misleading news, the social network turned to Campbell Brown, a veteran journalist, to smooth over its relationships with the media.
headline: Campbell Brown, Who Led Facebook News, Leaves Meta

abstract: The company will assume the legal risk of businesses that use its A.I. systems and will publish the technology’s underlying data.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of excitement in corporate America for the new artificial intelligence that can produce everything from business reports to computer code with humanlike fluency.
headline: IBM Tries to Ease Customers’ Qualms About Using Generative A.I.

abstract: The site listed thousands of people and grouped them by their workplaces after they posted on the Israeli-Hamas conflict.
lead_paragraph: Online posts asking to “#PrayForPalestine.” Entreaties for peace. Pleas to “Free Gaza.”
headline: LinkedIn Issues Warning to Site Shaming Pro-Palestinian Sentiment

abstract: A second Republican commissioner has resigned as the agency gears up for a big showdown on noncompete agreements and the Microsoft-Activision merger.
lead_paragraph: The F.T.C.’s biggest internal critic won’t be hanging around to push back against the agency and its chair, Lina Khan, who’s come under repeated fire from the political right and big business for being too tough on mergers.
headline: A Big Breakup at the Federal Trade Commission

abstract: The former Facebook product manager handled democracy and misinformation issues and worked on counterespionage.
lead_paragraph: Just who is Frances Haugen?
headline: Who is Frances Haugen, the Facebook whistle-blower?

abstract: Facebook on Thursday said it will block President Trump on its platforms at least until the end of his term on Jan. 20, as the mainstream online world moved forcefully to limit the president after years of inaction.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Thursday said it will block President Trump on its platforms at least until the end of his term on Jan. 20, as the mainstream online world moved forcefully to limit the president after years of inaction.
headline: Facebook banned Trump from its platforms for the rest of his term for inciting violence.

abstract: With so many Christmas movies to stream this season, which ones are quality nuggets and which are lumps of coal?
lead_paragraph: Welcome back to the wonderful, self-contained world of holiday movies, where we do not smirk at the improbably high number of handsome widowed fathers; we accept the fact that every other person is a best-selling writer, a pop star, a princess or a baker; we applaud the frequent blizzards that force two hotties to spend time together; and we root for the big-city dweller discovering the joys of country life.
headline: A Very Streaming Christmas

abstract: Tom Wiscombe’s “chapel” on Sunset Boulevard lets passers-by immerse in a streaming world projected onto LED screens outside — and an architectural storm inside.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Those billboards that blight much of the American landscape are, along the Sunset Strip in West Hollywood, the landscape itself — a dense, linear forest of sizzling images advertising the hottest stars and the latest albums and movies. By the time motorists in rush hour have run the two-mile gantlet of these glamour tapestries, some of them digital, they have learned just who’s who and what’s what in America’s now culture.
headline: There’s a New Billboard in Town, and You Can Walk in

abstract: Social media is full of false and misleading posts. The rise in A.I. is making it worse. And the trust in traditional news sources has declined.
lead_paragraph: The major social media platforms, once heralded for their ability to document global events in real time, face a crisis of authenticity — one of their own making, critics say.
headline: Fact or Fiction? In This War, It Is Hard to Tell.

abstract: Tech innovations are again racing ahead of Washington’s ability to regulate them, lawmakers and A.I. experts said.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, two members of Congress have sounded the alarm over the dangers of artificial intelligence.
headline: As A.I. Booms, Lawmakers Struggle to Understand the Technology

abstract: Berkshire Hathaway shareholders will gather in Omaha for the conglomerate’s annual meeting on Saturday, with questions about the company’s future.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of investors are flocking to Omaha this weekend, which can mean only one thing: It’s time for Berkshire Hathaway’s annual shareholder meeting, dubbed the “Woodstock for capitalists.”
headline: What Will Warren Buffett Bet on Next?

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing

abstract: The company’s grip on ticket sales, and its move last year to cancel sales for Taylor Swift’s upcoming tour, will be a big focus of an antitrust-focused hearing.
lead_paragraph: Two months after Ticketmaster canceled sales for Taylor Swift’s upcoming Eras tour, a top executive from its parent company, Live Nation Entertainment, will appear at the Senate on Tuesday to defend the company. (Ms. Swift herself is not scheduled to show up.)
headline: Live Nation Faces a Skeptical Senate

abstract: Christopher Rufo helped make critical race theory a conservative rallying cry. Now he sees L.G.B.T.Q. issues as an even more potent line of attack.
lead_paragraph: GIG HARBOR, Wash. — Christopher Rufo appears on Fox News so often that he converted a room in his Pacific Northwest house to a television studio, complete with professional lighting, an uplink to Fox in New York and an “On Air” light in the hall so his wife and two children don’t barge in during broadcasts.
headline: He Fuels the Right’s Cultural Fires (and Spreads Them to Florida)

abstract: The July 7, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Robinson Meyer. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Robinson Meyer

abstract: DealBook asked experts in company culture, aviation, and leadership for actions the manufacturer could take to restore public trust.
lead_paragraph: As far as signs of trouble in a company go, a hole blowing through the wall of one of its airplanes at 16,000 feet is not subtle.
headline: What Should Boeing Do to Fix Its Longstanding Problems?

abstract: Here are two proposals for regulating the platform.
lead_paragraph: The Daily is powered, every day, by a big idea. Below, we go deeper on one from our show this week.
headline: How Should We Limit Facebook’s Power?

abstract: Stocks prospered in the first half of 2024 but national politics clouds the outlook.
lead_paragraph: Midyear is a good time to assess investing strategy, looking back at where the markets have been and ahead at prospects for the second half.
headline: The Election Muddle Aside, Investing Has Been a Snap Lately

abstract: South Korea pledged to protect its online platforms from marketplace giants, but lobbyists are crying foul play.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean government unleashed a wave of panic across the internet industry: The country’s antitrust regulator said it would enact the toughest competition law outside Europe, curbing the influence of major technology companies.
headline: The Antitrust Enforcers Aimed at Big Tech. Then Came the Backlash.

abstract: Jokes aside: Here’s what we really know about the 15th-century figure currently appearing (sort of) on Broadway in “Gutenberg! The Musical!,” starring Josh Gad and Andrew Rannells.
lead_paragraph: “Gutenberg! The Musical!,” a comic meta-musical about two talentless dolts pitching a show about the father of the printing press, wraps up its limited Broadway run on Jan. 28.
headline: ‘Gutenberg!’: A Guide to the Inventor Behind the Broadway Musical

abstract: Companies like Meta that could tout their work in the fast-growing field saw a benefit in their fourth-quarter results — and won praise from eager investors.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, Mark Zuckerberg of Meta endured a grilling on Capitol Hill and publicly apologized to relatives of victims of online abuse. Little more than a day later, he had a lot to crow about, as his business delivered some of its best quarterly earnings in years.
headline: A.I. Promises Give Tech Earnings a Jolt

abstract: Her new book, “You Could Make This Place Beautiful,” is an exploration of what happened to her marriage after she became a well-known poet.
lead_paragraph: The American poet and writer Maggie Smith exudes a beatific warmth, so it seemed apt — a felicitous pairing of author and venue — that her recent book tour included an evening at a Brooklyn church. The pews were crowded with admirers, many feverishly reading her new memoir even as they waited for her to speak.
headline: Maggie Smith Tries to Make the Divorce Memoir Beautiful

abstract: Four years of hard-core branding, soap opera chic and designer trolling are coming to an end. What have we learned? A look back in gilt.
lead_paragraph: Few presidents have exploited the theatrical grandeur of the job quite as enthusiastically or as cynically as Donald Trump, from his proliferating forests of flags to his gilding of the Oval Office. Few have been as strategic about the power of caricature, or had such a complicit wife and court to bolster the spectacle. As a group, they tapped into the dregs of “Dynasty” and “The Bonfire of the Vanities” past that sits nestled in our lizard brains. For four years, we parsed soap opera chic instead of “The West Wing.” The visuals demanded attention, just like the tweets.
headline: A Farewell to the Trump Aesthetic

abstract: The lo-fi “Tucker on Twitter” finds the former prime-time host at the intersection of Fox News and Fox Mulder.
lead_paragraph: Most of the time, it does not qualify as newsworthy to see a man in your social media feed staring into a camera, asking “What exactly happened on 9/11?” and demanding to know why the media isn’t digging for the truth about J.F.K.’s assassination. Usually, it’s just a sign that you should not have accepted so many friend requests from high school classmates you barely remember.
headline: The Paranoid Style in Tucker Carlson’s Home Office

abstract: The two men jostling to be the country’s next president are using artificial intelligence to create images and videos to promote themselves and attack each other.
lead_paragraph: The posters dotting the streets of Buenos Aires had a certain Soviet flair to them.
headline: Is Argentina the First A.I. Election?

abstract: The TikTok law undermines America’s moral authority on maintaining open internet platforms.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden signed a bill requiring that TikTok be divested from its Chinese owner, ByteDance, members of Congress hailed the law as a blow to Beijing. They shouldn’t be so quick to celebrate. The law would at best partially mitigate the hazards of misinformation or the risks to national security posed by China. The Communist Party, meanwhile, looks forward to a propaganda windfall, prizing off Washington’s mantle as champion of a free and open internet.
headline: The End of TikTok Is a Propaganda Win for Beijing

abstract: John Hawksley’s puzzle corrects some common misconceptions.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Happy Wednesday, Wordplay readers! Today we have a puzzle from John Hawksley, who is making his third appearance in the New York Times Crossword.
headline: Ooh, That Could Work!

abstract: China’s zero-Covid policy has kept deaths very low. Can it continue?
lead_paragraph: World leaders are increasingly deciding that their countries need to figure out how to live with Covid-19 rather than minimize the number of cases.
headline: Zero Covid in China

abstract: Influential and powerful users on Facebook and Instagram receive “unequal treatment,” an internal report said.
lead_paragraph: Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, was harshly criticized on Tuesday by a company-appointed oversight board for policies that give celebrities, politicians and business partners special treatment compared with the vast majority of its users.
headline: Oversight Board Criticizes Meta for Preferential Treatment

abstract: A court decision to delay a trial over the billionaire’s takeover bid for Twitter works in his favor as he plots his next steps.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk won a partial victory yesterday when Delaware’s Court of Chancery agreed to delay the trial over his Twitter takeover bid by a week and a half, until Oct. 28. That gives Musk some important tactical advantages in his monthslong battle with the social media company.
headline: ‘Plot Twist!’ as Elon Musk Wins Partial Victory

abstract: The spending that the industry’s giants expect artificial intelligence to require is starting to come into focus — and it is jarringly large.
lead_paragraph: If 2023 was the tech industry’s year of the A.I. chatbot, 2024 is turning out to be the year of A.I. plumbing. It may not sound as exciting, but tens of billions of dollars are quickly being spent on behind-the-scenes technology for the industry’s A.I. boom.
headline: In Race to Build A.I., Tech Plans a Big Plumbing Upgrade

abstract: Beijing stopped releasing youth unemployment figures in its latest attempt to play down negative trends as growth stalls, and global concerns grow.
lead_paragraph: China released more bad economic news on Tuesday, but it was the number that wasn’t included in the official data dump that stood out: Beijing said it would stop publishing figures for youth unemployment, weeks after it hit a record high of 21.3 percent in June.
headline: What China Isn’t Telling the World About Its Economy

abstract: On yet another issue, Trump sides with a foreign adversary over America.
lead_paragraph: When the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly last Wednesday to pass a bill that would require TikTok to divest its Chinese ownership or face an American ban, it provided a glimmer of hope in a dreary political time. This is exactly what a nation should do when it’s getting serious about the national security threat posed by the People’s Republic of China.
headline: What Trump’s TikTok Flip-Flop Tells America

abstract: Reeling from competing demands from stakeholders — including activists, clients, consumers, shareholders and elected officials — businesses are increasingly caught in the middle of the country’s bruising culture wars.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
headline: Businesses Are Bracing for the Political and Social Fight Post-Roe

abstract: The star and the creator of the Peacock crime thriller discussed its influences, including “Columbo,” “Murder, She Wrote” and “Magnum P.I.”
lead_paragraph: To make new television, it helps if you’ve watched a lot of old television. That’s a lesson evident in “Poker Face,” the crime-thriller series created by Rian Johnson and starring Natasha Lyonne, which makes its debut Jan. 26 on Peacock.
headline: Natasha Lyonne and Rian Johnson Trace the TV Origins of ‘Poker Face’

abstract: Roughly half of Californians with private insurance receive medical care through the Kaiser Permanente health care system.
lead_paragraph: Kaiser Permanente has an enormous footprint in California.
headline: What to Know About the Kaiser Permanente Strike

abstract: Both Florida and Texas passed laws regulating how social media companies moderate speech online. The laws, if upheld, could fundamentally alter how the platforms police their sites.
lead_paragraph: Social media companies are bracing for Supreme Court arguments on Monday that could fundamentally alter the way they police their sites.
headline: What to Know About the Supreme Court Arguments on Social Media Laws

abstract: Before chatbots exploded in popularity, a group of researchers, tech executives and venture capitalists had worked for more than a decade to fuel A.I.
lead_paragraph: While artificial intelligence has taken the limelight over the past year, technology that can appear to operate like human brains has been top of mind for researchers, investors and tech executives in Silicon Valley and beyond for more than a decade.
headline: Who’s Who Behind the Dawn of the Modern Artificial Intelligence Movement

abstract: The rally brings some relief to Wall Street after a brutal decline in September. The S&P 500’s 3.1 percent gain on Tuesday was its best showing since May 2020.
lead_paragraph: Stocks rose sharply again on Tuesday, extending gains from the previous day and rebounding from a painful decline in September, as some investors bet that the rapid pace of interest rate increases that have raised costs for companies may soon begin to moderate.
headline: Stocks Rally for a Second Day, Regaining Some Lost Ground

abstract: Activists said the designation could put L.G.B.T.Q. people and their organizations under threat of criminal prosecution for something as simple as displaying the rainbow flag.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s Supreme Court on Thursday declared the international gay rights movement an “extremist organization,” another chilling crackdown on gay and transgender people whose rights have been scaled back drastically since the start of the war in Ukraine.
headline: Russia Declares Gay Rights Movement as ‘Extremist’

abstract: Researchers have identified a series of Russian information operations to influence American elections and, perhaps, erode support for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 midterm elections for the latest news and updates.
headline: Russia Reactivates Its Trolls and Bots Ahead of Tuesday’s Midterms

abstract: What’s at stake for a 22-year-old trilingual rapper who became a TikTok sensation by talking dirty and who aspires to be the president of Palestine? A lot.
lead_paragraph: In the clip of “Very Few Friends” that went very viral on TikTok late last year, Marwan Abdelhamid — who records as Saint Levant — showed up as both a sex symbol and someone who understands that sex symbols are just a little bit ridiculous. A trilingual loverman wearing a white tank top and a shaggy, rakish mustache, he stares longingly at the camera in the 10-second video, rapping over spacious acoustic-soul production with deadpan erotic frankness and something much more alluring than confidence: nonchalance.
headline: For Saint Levant, Sexy Music Is Personal, and Political

abstract: Candid looks at the inner workings of influential tech companies shouldn’t be so rare.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Facebook, Show Us the Mess

abstract: A federal judge dismissed an inventor’s attempt to copyright artwork produced by an image generator he designed. But more legal challenges are on the way.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge rejected an attempt to copyright an artwork generated by artificial intelligence in a decision last week that provided insight into the broader legal war over authorship and intellectual property.
headline: As Fight Over A.I. Artwork Unfolds, Judge Rejects Copyright Claim

abstract: In “The Greatest Capitalist Who Ever Lived,” Ralph Watson McElvenny and Marc Wortman show how Oedipal battles fueled the company’s technological triumphs in the 1960s and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Thomas J. Watson Jr. seemed, from a young age, to be destined for failure. Born in 1914, he was an angry and often depressed young boy. Neighbors called him “Terrible Tommy.” He barely gained his high school diploma after attending three different schools. His father, Watson Sr., the head of IBM, was a domineering man who subjected his son to a classic combination of emotional distance and cruelty. Watson Jr. responded by becoming a rebel and wastrel.
headline: The Father-Son Struggle That Helped Ensure IBM’s Success

abstract: Tobacco companies must soon label individual cigarettes sold in the country with a health warning, in what Canada is calling a global first.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — “Poison in every puff.” “Cigarettes cause impotence.” “Tobacco smoke harms children.”
headline: ‘Poison in Every Puff’ Among Warnings to Be Printed on Canadian Cigarettes

abstract: In this collaboratively written novel, Lower East Side dwellers get through lockdown swapping colorful tales on the roof of their scruffy building.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers generally don’t talk to their neighbors. This is to preserve psychological boundaries while living stacked on top of one another like ice cubes in trays.
headline: 36 Authors Times ‘Fourteen Days’ Adds Up to a Mixed Literary Experiment

abstract: A rush to stock up on emergency contraception could mean huge profits for the investors behind the well-known morning-after pill.
lead_paragraph: Since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, many women have been rushing to stock up on emergency contraception pills, in hopes of exerting more control over their bodies, or because they’re worried that the products could be restricted. (Birth control remains legal across the United States.) Drugstores have found themselves in short supply of the pills, and some are limiting purchases.
headline: Who’s Profiting From Demand for Plan B?

abstract: The allegations by Twitter’s former security chief come after Elon Musk sued the company for more details on how it measures user numbers.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s former security chief sent a whistle-blower complaint to the S.E.C. and other agencies contending that the company’s spam- and hacker-fighting efforts were reckless and inadequate. The complaint, which was obtained by The New York Times, could strengthen Elon Musk’s hand in his efforts to walk away from his $44 billion deal to buy Twitter. The Washington Post and CNN first reported on the complaints.
headline: Whistle-Blower Spam Claims Pose Challenge for Twitter

abstract: A global response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. and its allies swiftly imposed economic sanctions on Russia for what President Biden denounced as the beginning of an “invasion of Ukraine.” Western officials have confirmed that Russian forces have crossed the Ukrainian border into two separatist enclaves in eastern Ukraine.
headline: Your Wednesday Briefing

abstract: The agency said it made the decision after Meta promised Mr. Zuckerberg would not try to personally purchase the start-up his company wants to acquire.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has said it will remove Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, from a lawsuit to block the company’s acquisition of Within Unlimited, an artificial intelligence start-up.
headline: F.T.C. agrees to remove Mark Zuckerberg as defendant in antitrust suit.

abstract: Hundreds of workers decided to leave the troubled social network, after Elon Musk demanded employees commit to a new “hard core” work environment.
lead_paragraph: No, Twitter is not dead this morning, despite #RIPTwitter trending on the social network last night. But its future looks more turbulent than at any point since Elon Musk took over three weeks ago, as a huge number of workers decided to quit rather than agree to the billionaire’s loyalty pledge, which involved committing to a “hard core” work routine to grow the platform.
headline: Twitter’s Nest Gets a Little Emptier

abstract: A new paper suggests that it takes far less exercise than was previously thought to lower blood sugar after eating.
lead_paragraph: Walking after a meal, conventional wisdom says, helps clear your mind and aids in digestion. Scientists have also found that going for a 15-minute walk after a meal can reduce blood sugar levels, which can help ward off complications such as Type 2 diabetes. But, as it turns out, even just a few minutes of walking can activate these benefits.
headline: Just 2 Minutes of Walking After a Meal Is Surprisingly Good for You

abstract: The social network and the Biden administration have engaged in an increasingly rancorous war of words over the issue of vaccine misinformation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facebook and the Biden administration engaged in an increasingly rancorous back and forth over the weekend after the administration denounced the social media giant for spreading misinformation about the Covid-19 vaccines.
headline: Facebook Tells Biden: ‘Facebook Is Not the Reason’ Vaccination Goal Was Missed

abstract: Readers are appalled by mothers who profit from images that attract pedophiles. Also: Haley and Trump; lives lost in Gaza; exclusionary zoning.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
headline: Moms Marketing Their Daughters on Social Media

abstract: Frances Haugen, who left the social network in May and leaked internal documents, gave senators rare insight into its inner workings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former Facebook product manager who turned into a whistle-blower gave lawmakers an unvarnished look into the inner workings of the world’s largest social network on Tuesday and detailed how the company was deliberate in its efforts to keep people — including children — hooked to its service.
headline: Facebook Whistle-Blower Urges Lawmakers to Regulate the Company

abstract: Fueled by the pandemic’s convergence of endless scrolling, supply chain woes and the thrill of quick cash, furniture flipping has become D.I.Y. that, for many, is worth a try.
lead_paragraph: In July 2019, Elle Woodworth was raising three children with her husband in Fort Myers, Fla. when she had an idea to generate income that would change the course of their lives.
headline: Furniture Flippers Will Take That Dresser You’re Done With, Thank You

abstract: A consistent booster of far-right and antisemitic accounts on Twitter, Elon Musk is now melding a sense of victimhood with the most toxic elements of the right.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, one of the world’s richest men who is now most famous for running the website X, formerly known as Twitter, has a new excuse for the company’s shaky performance since he bought it last year. The problem, according to Mr. Musk, is the Jews.
headline: Elon Musk Has Crossed a Line

abstract: The Oct. 31, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Zack Beauchamp. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Zack Beauchamp

abstract: The University of Virginia senior charged with killing three classmates had appeared in a video with a gun, rapping about murder and his own mental troubles.
lead_paragraph: More than a year before he was charged with shooting and killing three fellow University of Virginia students, Christopher Darnell Jones Jr. appeared in a music video holding a gun and rapping about murder and his own mental troubles.
