abstract: Users reported widespread issues with the platforms from around 10 a.m. Eastern to about noon, according to Down Detector, a website that tracks user reports of internet disruptions.
lead_paragraph: Meta said it had resolved a technical issue with its platforms, including Facebook, Facebook Messenger and Instagram, after what appeared to be an hourslong outage on Tuesday.
headline: Meta Says Access Is Restored After Facebook and Instagram Outage

abstract: Hubert Humphrey’s 1948 triumph resonates today.
lead_paragraph: On the torrid afternoon of July 6, 1948, Hubert Humphrey departed one kind of inferno to plunge into another. Humphrey, the brash young mayor of Minneapolis, was leaving a city reeling under a 100-degree heat wave that had taken two lives that very day. He was bound for Philadelphia, the site of the impending Democratic National Convention, where the sweltering weather provided a fitting backdrop for a heated convention.
headline: What We Can Learn From the Young Democratic Mayor Who Sent a Wing of His Own Party Into Exile

abstract: The prize recognized important work explaining when and why financial markets implode.
lead_paragraph: Do people still read Rudyard Kipling’s “If”? Even if you haven’t, you probably know how it begins: “If you can keep your head when all about you are losing theirs …” Refusing to panic, Kipling asserted, was a great virtue.
headline: A Nobel Prize for the Economics of Panic

abstract: New regulations in Indonesia show that strict online controls are no longer confined to autocratic countries like China.
lead_paragraph: I want us to consider the implications of this new reality: In three of the four most populous countries in the world, governments have now given themselves the power to order that the internet be wiped of citizens’ posts that the authorities don’t like.
headline: Classic Internet Censorship

abstract: When the present is divisive and the future is scary, pop culture’s biggest event plays “remember when.”
lead_paragraph: “This is the millennium of Aftermath.” When Dr. Dre rapped that line on “Forgot About Dre,” from his 1999 album “2001,” he was referring to his record label. But from the vantage point of the 2022 Super Bowl, where he headlined the halftime show, it was also a pretty accurate forward-looking statement.
headline: At the Super Bowl, Nostalgia’s the Only Game

abstract: Allies of the former president are said to be devising plans to reduce the central bank’s independence if he is re-elected, a move that would have big consequences for monetary policy.
lead_paragraph: This week, investors had planned to examine the latest inflation data, due out at 8:30 a.m. Eastern on Friday, for clues about when the Fed would start cutting interest rates. But they now have something potentially bigger to digest.
headline: Would Trump Move to Control the Fed?

abstract: Leading A.I. firms, including Microsoft, Google and OpenAI, will agree to voluntary guidelines that may be a first step to wider regulations.
lead_paragraph: In a potentially significant victory for the Biden administration, top players in artificial intelligence, including Microsoft, Google and OpenAI, are to meet at the White House on Friday to pledge to build safeguards into their development of a technology that has captivated Wall Street and rattled many world leaders.
headline: The White House Pushes Tech Leaders To Get Tough on A.I. Safety

abstract: Anthropic, a safety-focused A.I. start-up, is trying to compete with ChatGPT while preventing an A.I. apocalypse. It’s been a little stressful.
lead_paragraph: It’s a few weeks before the release of Claude, a new A.I. chatbot from the artificial intelligence start-up Anthropic, and the nervous energy inside the company’s San Francisco headquarters could power a rocket.
headline: Inside the White-Hot Center of A.I. Doomerism

abstract: Romantic love is a beautiful thing, but it is not the only way to feel connected, to feel seen, to feel loved.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — By now, whatever time of day you read this essay, your Facebook and Instagram feeds are most likely filled with hothouse flowers and lovely hand-dipped chocolates and stories of the funny way two people met, how lucky they are to have found each other, how grateful they feel, on this day of love especially, to be moving through the world together. Such stories can be incredibly sweet, but their cumulative effect is … not.
headline: A Valentine’s P.S.A.: Instagram Is Not Your Friend Today

abstract: With Australia moving to make the tech companies pay for news, Facebook took a hard line, while Google has struck deals to pay publishers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, Facebook and Google have been locked in a stare-down with news publishers and lawmakers in Australia.
headline: Facebook Blocks News in Australia, Diverging With Google on Proposed Law

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Chicago, Capitol Riot, ‘Scream’: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing

abstract: The video app is spending millions on ads as Congress considers a bill that could lead to a U.S. ban.
lead_paragraph: In a TV commercial, Sister Monica Clare, a nun in northern New Jersey, walks through a church that’s bathed in sunlight and sits in a pew, crossing herself. Her message: TikTok is a force for good.
headline: TikTok Turns to Nuns, Veterans and Ranchers in Marketing Blitz

abstract: The people who were most afraid of the risks of artificial intelligence decided they should be the ones to build it. Then distrust fueled a spiraling competition.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk celebrated his 44th birthday in July 2015 at a three-day party thrown by his wife at a California wine country resort dotted with cabins. It was family and friends only, with children racing around the upscale property in Napa Valley.
headline: Ego, Fear and Money: How the A.I. Fuse Was Lit

abstract: This isn’t the first time Apple has introduced a bulky piece of hardware that nobody is sure people will want to buy. Can Apple pull off another wearable revolution?
lead_paragraph: Apple kicked off the week with the announcement of a mixed-reality headset: the Apple Vision Pro. Putting a computer on your face may seem weird, but if there’s one company that knows how to make nerdy stuff into the thing that everyone wants, it’s Apple. Will these fancy goggles be the next Apple revolution?
headline: Apple’s Face Computer, Crypto Chaos and How Teens Really Feel About Social Media

abstract: Sony’s new $550 headset offers best-in-class virtual reality gaming, but it’s still hard to see why we need V.R. goggles at all.
lead_paragraph: Ah, the “metaverse.” Will a fantasy where our office meetings and social gatherings take place mostly in virtual reality ever come true?
headline: The PlayStation Goggles Are a Win for Gamers. Not for the Metaverse.

abstract: Every hour of the day and night with the gamers, parents, insomniacs, preteens and aspiring comedians who are the earliest adopters of the immersive, three-dimensional internet that Mark Zuckerberg has bet the future of his company on.
lead_paragraph: My two young daughters are both crying as I tell my husband that he’s on his own because I’m going to the metaverse. Shutting myself in my home office at 7 p.m. on a Friday, I put on Meta’s $399 virtual-reality headset: the Quest 2, a bulky, white visor loaded with all manner of cameras, microphones, speakers, eye displays and sensors.
headline: This Is Life in the Metaverse

abstract: Several states run by Democrats are pushing for stiffer rules on the spread of false information, while Republican-run states are pushing for fewer rules.
lead_paragraph: To fight disinformation, California lawmakers are advancing a bill that would force social media companies to divulge their process for removing false, hateful or extremist material from their platforms. Texas lawmakers, by contrast, want to ban the largest of the companies — Facebook, Twitter and YouTube — from removing posts because of political points of view.
headline: The Fight Over Truth Also Has a Red State, Blue State Divide

abstract: After two wry country albums and a Grammy-sweeping breakthrough, pop stardom is calling for Kacey Musgraves. Will she answer?
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Kacey Musgraves made her new album in a garage studio buzzing with domestic chaos. On an August afternoon, the 33-year-old singer and songwriter arrived there to find a basketball rolled into the driveway, tiny swimsuits drying on the porch and a spaniel, Bean, rooting around the percussion section for a stick. “I don’t feel self-conscious out here,” Musgraves said, leaning into a snug couch next to a Himalayan salt lamp. “You can try stuff and if it sucks, it’s fine.”
headline: Kacey Musgraves’s Expanding Universe

abstract: The Mar. 21, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kelsey Piper. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kelsey Piper

abstract: Could a better understanding of how infants acquire language help us build smarter A.I. models?
lead_paragraph: We ask a lot of ourselves as babies. Somehow we must grow from sensory blobs into mobile, rational, attentive communicators in just a few years. Here you are, a baby without a vocabulary, in a room cluttered with toys and stuffed animals. You pick up a Lincoln Log and your caretaker tells you, “This is a ‘log.’” Eventually you come to understand that “log” does not refer strictly to this particular brown plastic cylinder or to brown plastic cylinders in general, but to brown plastic cylinders that embody the characteristics of felled, denuded tree parts, which are also, of course, “logs.”
headline: From Baby Talk to Baby A.I.

abstract: This thriller, about a teenage girl whose mother disappears, plays out on a computer screen.
lead_paragraph: The gimmick behind “Missing,” a strenuous techno-thriller about a teen girl named June (Storm Reid) who takes to the internet to track down her mother (Nia Long), is that the directors and screenwriters, Will Merrick and Nick Johnson, frame the action on computer screens. All of June’s sleuthing is cloistered to apps which she opens in increasing panic. She’s a web-weaned child who barely bothered to speak to her mom even before the parent’s disappearance. Initially, June celebrates having the house to herself by Googling “How to throw a rager.” Her friends dutifully post her drunkenness to Instagram so that we, the viewer, can witness it.
headline: ‘Missing’ Review: Mom’s Lost in the Matrix

abstract: “Civilizations,” by Laurent Binet, imagines a counterhistory of the Spanish conquests.
lead_paragraph: CIVILIZATIONSBy Laurent BinetTranslated by Sam Taylor
headline: What if the Inca Conquered Europe? A Novel Rewrites History.

abstract: Adenrele Sonariwo has brought her Nigerian sensibility to Melrose Avenue, with a show focusing on women.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It certainly didn’t feel like a gallery opening. There was no crowd. No wine and cheese. Only a few people were allowed in at a time because of Covid-19 restrictions.
headline: From Lagos to Los Angeles, an African Art Gallery Arrives

abstract: A  damning expose depicts a company with all the information it needs to fix the egregious oversights and mistakes of the past.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, The Wall Street Journal published “The Facebook Files,” a damning series based on a cache of leaked internal documents that revealed how much the company knew about the harms it was causing and how little it did to stop it.
headline: Clearly, Facebook Is Very Flawed. What Will We Do About It?

abstract: Snap’s announcement comes amid a slowdown for tech start-ups, as venture capital funding has fallen and young companies have been cutting costs and laying off employees.
lead_paragraph: Snap, the maker of the messaging app Snapchat, said on Monday that it expected to miss its quarterly financial goals as it dealt with toughening economic conditions.
headline: Snap warns it will miss earnings goals because of economic challenges.

abstract: A covert war to determine the regulatory future of A.I. is being waged by deeply divided camps with divergent motivations.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of researchers and industry titans willing to warn us about the potential destructive power of artificial intelligence. Reading the headlines, one would hope that the rapid gains in A.I. technology have also brought forth a unifying realization of the risks — and the steps we need to take to mitigate them.
headline: The A.I. Wars Have Three Factions, and They All Crave Power

abstract: A wave of parents has been radicalized by Covid-era misinformation to reject ordinary childhood immunizations — with potentially lethal consequences.
lead_paragraph: The mother of four brought her children, ranging in age from grade school to high school, to the doctor’s office last summer for their annual checkup. When their pediatrician, Robert Froehlke, said that it was time for shots and several boosters and then mentioned the Covid vaccine, her reaction stunned him. “I’m not going to kill my children,” Froehlke recalls her saying, as she began to shake and weep. He ushered her out of the examination room, away from her children, and tried to calm her. “We’re just trying to help your kids be healthy,” he told her. But he didn’t press the issue; he sensed that she wasn’t persuadable at that moment. And he didn’t want to drive her away from his practice altogether. “That really shook me up,” he says.
headline: The Anti-Vaccine Movement’s New Frontier

abstract: For more than two years, soccer officials pushed the social network to limit the invective. As a new season begins, the hate continues.
lead_paragraph: In May 2019, Facebook asked the organizing bodies of English soccer to its London offices off Regent’s Park. On the agenda: what to do about the growing racist abuse on the social network against Black soccer players.
headline: How Facebook Failed to Stem Racist Abuse of England’s Soccer Players

abstract: Americans kept shopping last month. China’s sunny version of the Olympics. And the potential impact on energy markets of a  Ukraine invasion.
lead_paragraph: Google announced on Wednesday that it planned to change its Android smartphone software to limit the sharing of data across apps and with third parties. The other major smartphone software provider, Apple, which has made privacy a selling point, announced new measures last year. But the two companies have taken different approaches. Apple allows customers to choose whether to block tracking, which has had a significant impact on companies that rely on customer data to target ads. Meta said this month that the changes would cost it $10 billion in ad revenue this year. Google, which unlike Apple makes most of its money from selling digital ads rather than devices, promised that its changes would not be as disruptive. It plans to support its existing technologies for at least two more years to give advertisers a chance to prepare.
headline: The Week in Business: A Step Toward Data Privacy

abstract: The robotic nerd depicted in “The Social Network” has turned into the kinder, more accessible face of Silicon Valley. What’s going on?
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to Meta’s first-quarter earnings report this week, a video image of Mark Zuckerberg suddenly started going viral.
headline: The Meta-morphosis of Mark Zuckerberg

abstract: The statute, passed by the Florida Legislature last week, would have required sites like TikTok and Instagram to deny accounts to underage users, even if their parents permitted them to do so.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis on Friday vetoed a sweeping social media bill that would have effectively barred Florida residents under the age of 16 from opening accounts on services like TikTok and Instagram, even if their parents permitted them to do so.
headline: DeSantis Vetoes Blanket Social Media Ban for Youths Under 16

abstract: We surveyed voters ahead of this year’s ceremony on Sunday. They are strikingly split in the races for leading musical performers.
lead_paragraph: After a strange year on Broadway, it looks as if it could be a “Strange” night at the Tony Awards.
headline: A ‘Strange’ Wind Blowing: Tony Voters Like ‘Loop’ and ‘Lehman’

abstract: Ifeoma Ozoma, who accused Pinterest of discrimination, has become a key figure in helping tech employees disclose, and fight, mistreatment at work.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California signed a bill to expand protections for people who speak up about discrimination in the workplace.
headline: A Tech Whistle-Blower Helps Others Speak Out

abstract: The S&P 500 rose 2.4 percent, its biggest one-day jump since June 2020. But some analysts cautioned against reading too much into a single day’s bounce.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street finally found a foothold on Friday, rebounding from days of back-to-back declines with its biggest gain in 18 months as investors grabbed on to glimmers of good news: a strong earnings report from Apple and data on wage growth that came in lower than expected.
headline: Stocks rally, erasing losses from a turbulent week.

abstract: The company has ambitious targets for growth in the next two years.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Twitter executives set ambitious goals for their company, with hopes of attracting more than 100 million new users and doubling revenue by 2023. The last three months of 2021, however, showed the challenges the company must overcome before it can hit its objectives.
headline: Twitter’s mixed fourth quarter shows its challenges ahead.

abstract: Citing privacy failings by the tech giant, regulators proposed to stop sites like Instagram and Facebook from profiting off the data of users under 18.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission escalated its fight with the tech industry’s biggest companies on Wednesday as it moved to impose what it called a “blanket prohibition” on the collection of young people’s personal data by Meta, Facebook’s parent company.
headline: F.T.C. Seeks ‘Blanket’ Ban on Meta’s Use of Young Users’ Data

abstract: New studies on social media’s influence tell a complicated story.
lead_paragraph: It was the social-science equivalent of Barbenheimer weekend: four blockbuster academic papers, published in two of the world’s leading journals on the same day. Written by elite researchers from universities across the United States, the papers in Nature and Science each examined different aspects of one of the most compelling public-policy issues of our time: how social media is shaping our knowledge, beliefs and behaviors.
headline: Does Information Affect Our Beliefs?

abstract: Internet companies are making it harder for those with big followings to spread misinformation. Finally!
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Facebook Takes on Superspreaders

abstract: The drummer, D.J. and producer is everywhere and loved by everyone. But few understand what drives him: an obsession with spreading the joys of Black music.
lead_paragraph: Most Saturday nights from age 5 to 10, Ahmir Thompson would go to bed at 8 p.m., only to be woken up a few hours later. When he was 3, he had taken a fruit-drink commercial too literally — “Hey, how about a nice Hawaiian punch?” ended with a fist to his mother’s face — so his parents decided to limit his television consumption. But on the weekends, they bent the rules and, around 12:45 a.m., nudged him awake. He would grab his crocheted-by-Grandma blanket and head downstairs, where he would switch on the television, wait for it to warm up and then crank the dial to Channel 48 as quietly as he could. Right at 1 a.m., he was greeted by a magical locomotive — chugging along so rhythmically that it almost seemed to dance, flipping gray buildings it passed into psychedelic colors — for his regular dose of peace, love and “Soul Train.”
headline: The Passion of Questlove

abstract: How to take something that has flaws — and break it completely.
lead_paragraph: If you spend much time online, you witnessed something remarkable last week. Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, introduced a competitor to Twitter called Threads, and the public response was astonishing. As my colleague Mike Isaac detailed in The Times, Threads had two million users in its first two hours. Two hours later, it had five million users. The next day, Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, said it had 30 million. Isaac wrote that Threads “appears to have taken the crown as the most rapidly downloaded app ever.” An independent tracker purports to show that the app is still adding about a million users per day.
headline: Twitter Shows, Again, the Failure of the New Right’s Theory of Power

abstract: The mini-series, based on the star’s experiences, has viewers wondering how much of it is real. Here’s the back story.
lead_paragraph: Some spoilers follow.
headline: ‘Baby Reindeer’: What to Know About the True-ish Netflix Hit

abstract: A new kind of exchange-traded fund linked to the cryptocurrency could begin trading as soon as Thursday, and the investment world is buzzing.
lead_paragraph: A new era of crypto trading is expected to begin as soon as today, after the S.E.C. finally approved the creation of new exchange-traded funds that would allow investors to more easily buy and sell Bitcoin.
headline: Bitcoin Heads to Wall Street. Now What?

abstract: Olivia Mitra Framke’s puzzle strikes a chord.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor Olivia Mitra Framke, who is making her 10th appearance in the New York Times Crossword! At 1A, Ms. Framke urges us all to get in the game, a suggestion that I took to heart during my solve.
headline: Get in the Game

abstract: The deal, which values Spirit at $3.8 billion, was announced a day after Frontier’s bid for Spirit fell apart. It is likely to face antitrust scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: JetBlue Airways reached a deal to buy Spirit Airlines on Thursday, a merger that could reshape the airline industry by putting pressure on the nation’s four dominant carriers.
headline: JetBlue and Spirit announce plan to merge, creating fifth-largest U.S. airline.

abstract: If the Supreme Court sides with social media platforms in NetChoice v. Paxton, that will jeopardize our ability to control our own future.
lead_paragraph: On the average day, some 95 million pictures are posted on Instagram, along with 34 million videos on TikTok and hundreds of millions of tweets. Some go viral, most don’t. And some percentage — the numbers are unclear — are taken down for violating the content rules set by the platforms. Given the volume of posts and videos, it is no exaggeration to say that the rules for social media have become the most important speech regulations on the planet, policing what can and cannot be said online.
headline: Texas Is Right. The Tech Giants Need to Be Regulated.

abstract: The company warned that the inauthentic accounts underscored the threat of foreign election interference in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Meta announced on Thursday that it had removed thousands of Facebook accounts based in China that were impersonating Americans debating political issues in the United States. The company warned that the campaign presaged coordinated international efforts to influence the 2024 presidential election.
headline: 4,789 Facebook Accounts in China Impersonated Americans, Meta Says

abstract: A spokesman for the Facebook founder said the money sent to election offices in 2020 was a “one-time donation.” The grants prompted Republicans to push for bans on private donations for elections.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, who donated nearly half a billion dollars to election offices across the nation in 2020 and drew criticism from conservatives suspicious of his influence on the presidential election, won’t be making additional grants this year, a spokesman for the Facebook founder confirmed on Tuesday.
headline: Mark Zuckerberg Ends Election Grants

abstract: The tech giant has publicly released its latest A.I. technology so people can build their own chatbots. Rivals like Google say that approach can be dangerous.
lead_paragraph: In February, Meta made an unusual move in the rapidly evolving world of artificial intelligence: It decided to give away its A.I. crown jewels.
headline: In Battle Over A.I., Meta Decides to Give Away Its Crown Jewels

abstract: In the absence of federal privacy legislation, the state’s law is considered among the nation’s strongest.
lead_paragraph: The facial recognition company Clearview AI agreed in a settlement this month to stop selling its massive database of photographs culled from the internet to private firms across the United States. That decision is a direct result of a lawsuit in Illinois, a demonstration that strong privacy laws in a single state can have nationwide ramifications.
headline: How Illinois Is Winning in the Fight Against Big Tech

abstract: Facebook’s business rose even as it dealt with controversies around the proliferation of misinformation across its platform and as it has come under increased scrutiny by regulators.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Wednesday reported surging profits and revenue driven by soaring ad sales, but cautioned that it might face “headwinds” in the future from regulation and technology changes.
headline: Facebook posts a 33 percent increase in revenue and a 53 percent jump in profit.

abstract: Some of the biggest tech companies have announced tens of thousands of job cuts. But even after the layoffs, their work forces are still behemoths.
lead_paragraph: For a stretch of the pandemic, tech companies couldn’t hire fast enough. Talent wars broke out in Silicon Valley, with firms vying for software engineers, often lavishing extravagant perks on their new and would-be hires. As profits soared, executives acted as if the party would never end.
headline: Layoffs at Tech Giants Reverse Small Part of Pandemic Hiring Spree

abstract: The show’s creative team talks about revamping the immersive Off Broadway hit so that it moves “around the audience” at Circle in the Square Theater.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2017, the musical “KPOP” had the kind of Off Broadway premiere that showbiz dreams are made of. The buzz around the production — which had the rare distinction of being about a specifically Asian pop-music style and having a largely Asian creative team — was so intense that desperate New Yorkers were pleading for tickets to its sold-out run at the small A.R.T./New York Theaters in Midtown Manhattan.
headline: For ‘KPOP,’ a Broadway Transfer Is More Like a Reinvention

abstract: Britain’s antitrust regulator said the companies had addressed its main concerns about the $69 billion deal, though final approval is yet to come.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft came one step closer on Friday to completing its $69 billion purchase of the video game maker Activision Blizzard, in a deal that has become an example of how a company can successfully ride out stricter regulatory scrutiny of the power of tech giants.
headline: Microsoft Closes In on Activision Deal After Britain Signals Approval

abstract: The real beginning of the fashion-technology love affair and its legacy lies with Issey Miyake, who died last week.
lead_paragraph: Little wonder, really, that Issey Miyake was Steve Jobs’s favorite designer.
headline: Why Steve Jobs Chose This Designer’s Turtlenecks

abstract: It’s only a matter of time before the poster-board and markers come out …
lead_paragraph: Houston? We have a Christmas Episode.
headline: ‘Ted Lasso’ Season 2 Episode 4 Recap: A Very Special Christmas Episode

abstract: The ad, a sleek 30-minute production, was blocked for several hours on Friday and Saturday. Meta, which owns both platforms, said the link had been incorrectly flagged as spam.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has made censorship — specifically, claims that the government, news media and tech platforms have tried to stifle his message — a cornerstone of his independent presidential campaign.
headline: R.F.K. Jr. Claims Censorship After Facebook and Instagram Briefly Block New Ad

abstract: After the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol by supporters of President Donald J. Trump, social media sites including Twitter and Facebook were urged to limit hate speech and the glorification of violence on their platforms.
lead_paragraph: After the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol by supporters of President Donald J. Trump, social media sites including Twitter and Facebook were urged to limit hate speech and the glorification of violence on their platforms.
headline: Trump’s banishment from Facebook and Twitter: A timeline.

abstract: The market for commercial spyware — which allows governments to invade mobile phones and vacuum up data — is booming. Even the U.S. government is using it.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration took a public stand last year against the abuse of spyware to target human rights activists, dissidents and journalists: It blacklisted the most notorious maker of the hacking tools, the Israeli firm NSO Group.
headline: How the Global Spyware Industry Spiraled Out of Control

abstract: Montana is at the forefront of a wave of new tech laws passed by Republican-led states. Some give parents control over their children’s social media accounts.
lead_paragraph: Many of the world’s largest consumer technology companies will be closely monitoring a federal court hearing in Montana on Thursday that could decide whether TikTok will have to stop operating in the state next year.
headline: As Red States Curb Social Media, Did Montana’s TikTok Ban Go Too Far?

abstract: Brands find that some of their customers’ pandemic-era buying habits are here to stay.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than a year since Covid-19 restrictions faded away in most parts of the world, but some fine jewelry brands are finding that their customers’ pandemic shopping habits are here to stay.
headline: Digital Interactions Are Just Part of a Jewelry Sale Now

abstract: Our readers tell us about the surprising ways in which tech has helped them discover new worlds.
lead_paragraph: Last week, our On Tech editor, Hanna Ingber, shared a story of her kiddo stumbling upon a design app that unlocked his amazing taste for interiors. We asked for your own tales of surprising ways in which technology helped you unleash creativity or discover new joys.
headline: The Tech Magic That Unleashed Your Best

abstract: Also, Scotland’s leader resigns and Air India orders a record 470 planes.
lead_paragraph: After China relaxed the world’s most stringent Covid-19 restrictions in December, the virus exploded there. Four separate academic teams have come up with broadly similar estimates suggesting that one million to 1.5 million people died during the surge, far more than China’s official count.
headline: Your Thursday Briefing: 1.5 Million Covid Deaths in China?

abstract: Psychiatry too often ignores how a patient’s perspective can depend on culture, race, ethnicity and faith.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, when I was reporting on clinics for people in the earliest stages of psychosis, I met many young patients who were struggling to express what was happening to their minds. They described their condition as disabling, but it was still so new that it had not remade their identities or social worlds. When I asked one woman to describe her symptoms, she told me there was no language. She said, “It’s like trying to explain what a bark sounds like to someone who’s never heard of a dog.”
headline: Do You Need a ‘Correct Attitude’ to Understand Your Mind?

abstract: The American tech giant’s platforms, Facebook and Instagram, may “exploit the weaknesses and inexperience of minors,” the European Commission said.
lead_paragraph: European Union regulators on Thursday opened investigations into the American tech giant Meta for the potentially addictive effects Instagram and Facebook have on children, an action with far-reaching implications because it cuts to the core of how the company’s products are designed.
headline: E.U. Investigates Meta Over Addictive Social Media Effects on Children

abstract: The practice in which tech workers use their own product consistently to see how well it works and where improvements can be made.
lead_paragraph: Software engineers are hungry for excellence. Dogs are hungry for dog food. And software engineers at many companies are hungry to “dogfood.”
headline: What Is ‘Dogfooding’?

abstract: Employers love to talk about “authenticity.” But psychologists say nearly everyone uses some form of deception to get a job.
lead_paragraph: It was as if a “Seinfeld” plot met John le Carré.
headline: Do You Know Who That Worker You Just Hired Really Is?

abstract: As the technology’s rapid rise sets off alarms about the risks to society, these shows will help put the boom into context.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, artificial intelligence has advanced so rapidly that it feels dizzying, and a growing chorus of industry insiders, academics and politicians are sounding the alarm about risks to society. The effects have already been wide-ranging — colleges are struggling to weed out A.I.-generated essays, disinformation researchers are contending with a whole new category of deepfakes, and the threat of A.I. screenwriting is central to the current Hollywood writers’ strike.
headline: 6 Podcasts to Make Sense of A.I.

abstract: The unusual lawsuits filed on Friday are among the most far-reaching to be filed in response to the escalating number of mass shootings in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The families of schoolchildren who were shot at Robb Elementary School in 2022 filed two lawsuits on Friday accusing Instagram, the publisher of the popular “Call of Duty” video game and a manufacturer of semiautomatic rifles of helping to train and equip the teenage gunman who committed the massacre.
headline: Uvalde Families Accuse Instagram, ‘Call of Duty’ and Rifle Maker of ‘Grooming’ Gunman

abstract: This Disney reboot combines animation and live-action comedy with an irreverent, self-referential attitude.
lead_paragraph: As a general rule, movie reboots proceed from a basic assumption about interest and familiarity — that audiences adore some bygone franchise, and will be eager to see it resuscitated.
headline: ‘Chip ’n Dale: Rescue Rangers’ Review: Remember Them? (No?)

abstract: A.I. is set to advance at a rapid rate, becoming more powerful and spreading into the physical world.
lead_paragraph: At an event in San Francisco in November, Sam Altman, the chief executive of the artificial intelligence company OpenAI, was asked what surprises the field would bring in 2024.
headline: Robots Learn, Chatbots Visualize: How 2024 Will Be A.I.’s ‘Leap Forward’

abstract: The government, seeking a broad order to stop the internet distribution of “Glory to Hong Kong,” will return to court next month to address a judge’s questions.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Hong Kong on Monday postponed deciding on a petition to ban the online distribution of a popular pro-democracy protest song in a case that could further challenge how technology companies operate in the Chinese territory.
headline: Judge Delays Decision on Hong Kong’s Request to Ban Protest Song Online

abstract: The billionaire posted a note to advertisers saying he wanted the service to be “the most respected advertising platform.”
lead_paragraph: A day before Elon Musk’s court-imposed deadline to complete his $44 billion acquisition of Twitter, he posted a message to advertisers in an apparent attempt to soothe nerves as concerns circulate about how he intends to run the platform.
headline: Elon Musk Reaches Out to Advertisers Ahead of Deadline for Twitter Deal

abstract: For the first time, A.I.-generated personas, often used for corporate trainings, were detected in a state-aligned information campaign — opening a new chapter in online manipulation.
lead_paragraph: In one video, a news anchor with perfectly combed dark hair and a stubbly beard outlined what he saw as the United States’ shameful lack of action against gun violence.
headline: The People Onscreen Are Fake. The Disinformation Is Real.

abstract: The Meta C.O.O. leaves a legacy of stunning financial success — and a company still in denial about its toxic impact.
lead_paragraph: When exactly is the right time to exit the limelight?
headline: Sheryl Sandberg’s Long (Overdue) Goodbye

abstract: Barbie springs to life, Indy swings into action and Spidey slings new webs. Here are 107 films for movie lovers of all tastes.
lead_paragraph: Here is a list of noteworthy movies heading to theaters and living rooms this summer — everything from blockbusters to small indies from the festival circuit. Release dates and platforms are subject to change.
headline: Summer Movies 2023: Here’s What’s Coming to Theaters and Streaming

abstract: The electric vehicle maker has announced price cuts and a Cybertruck recall ahead of Tuesday’s pivotal earnings report.
lead_paragraph: Tesla has hardly been keeping quiet as it prepares to announce earnings on Tuesday.
headline: How Can Elon Musk Reassure Tesla Investors?

abstract: TikTok accounts are spreading falsehoods with help from A.I.-generated voices.
lead_paragraph: In a slickly produced TikTok video, former President Barack Obama — or a voice eerily like his — can be heard defending himself against an explosive new conspiracy theory about the sudden death of his former chef.
headline: ‘A.I. Obama’ and Fake Newscasters: How A.I. Audio Is Swarming TikTok

abstract: We still don’t understand why so many girls suffer from anorexia.
lead_paragraph: She was exposed to toxic substances as a baby. She was too mature for her age. She was too smart for her school. She was not smart enough for her school. Her school was too rigid. Her school was too flexible. She did ballet as a child. She had a hormonal imbalance. She was just unbalanced. She was painfully immature. She wanted attention. She wanted to disappear. She was obsessed with sex. She had an aversion to sex. She wanted to be a boy. She wanted to be Kate Moss. She was part of the zeitgeist.
headline: Girls Are Taking Their Pain Out on Themselves

abstract: Dogecoin. WeWork. The Metaverse. It was an era of illusory and ridiculous promises.
lead_paragraph: At a guest lecture at a military academy when the price of a single Bitcoin neared $60,000, I was asked, as finance professors often are, what I thought about cryptocurrencies. Rather than respond with my usual skepticism, I polled the students. More than half of attendees had traded cryptocurrencies, often financed by loans.
headline: The Crypto Collapse and the End of the Magical Thinking That Infected Capitalism

abstract: Twitter’s would-be owner brings a slew of financiers into the fold — and a wide range of views.
lead_paragraph: While doubters still think Elon Musk may not carry through with his plan to buy out Twitter, the world’s richest man has garnered a new vote of confidence. Seven billion votes of confidence, to be more precise.
headline: Elon Musk’s Growing Grab Bag of Investors

abstract: When “The Bachelor” squeezes widows and widowers through its melodrama machine, the franchise finally finds true heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: The third episode of “The Golden Bachelor” begins with a shot of a 72-year-old man crying outside of a California mansion. “The Golden Bachelor” is a dating competition for people over 60, and the man is Gerry Turner, a kindly retiree with a hearing aid and a full head of hair. Just three weeks ago, Gerry — he pronounces it “Gary” — moved into the mansion with 22 women and started dating every single one of them. Already, he is overcome with emotion.
headline: ‘Golden Bachelor’ Brings Something New to the Mansion: Grief

abstract: The tech company’s plan is similar to one announced two days earlier by Meta, another Silicon Valley giant.
lead_paragraph: Google, whose work in artificial intelligence helped make A.I.-generated content far easier to create and spread, now wants to ensure that such content is traceable as well.
headline: Google Joins Effort to Help Spot Content Made With A.I.

abstract: Apple said it removed WhatsApp and Threads from its China app offerings Friday on Beijing’s orders, amid technological tensions between the U.S. and China.
lead_paragraph: Apple said it pulled the Meta-owned apps WhatsApp and Threads from its app store in China on Friday on government orders, potentially escalating the war over technology between the United States and China.
headline: Apple Says It Was Ordered to Pull WhatsApp From China App Store

abstract: “It has been five months since Trump was indefinitely suspended from Facebook for the minor infraction of trying to overthrow the government. I mean, who hasn’t done that?” Trevor Noah said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
headline: Late Night Rallies Behind Facebook’s Extended Trump Ban

abstract: Although some employees might decide to stick with their jobs when the market appears uncertain, work force reductions can, conversely, spur more quitting.
lead_paragraph: Reports of layoffs have cast a shadow over the recent surge in quitting. Tech behemoths like Amazon and Meta and, most recently, Dell and Microsoft have led the way in cutting jobs, along with companies like BlackRock and Goldman Sachs; layoffs are planned at McDonald’s, as well.
headline: In an Uncertain Job Market, How Can Companies Retain Workers?

abstract: The owner of X broke with tradition at other social media companies to support the former president, as he drives political conversation on his site.
lead_paragraph: Roughly 30 minutes after former President Donald J. Trump was shot at a rally in Pennsylvania on Saturday, Elon Musk backed his bid for the White House.
headline: Elon Musk Enters Uncharted Territory With Trump Endorsement

abstract: The accusations reflect worry in Washington that China’s information operations pose a growing security challenge to the United States.
lead_paragraph: The State Department accused China on Thursday of using “deceptive and coercive methods” to shape the global information environment, by acquiring stakes in foreign newspapers and television networks, using major social media platforms to promote its views and exerting pressure on international organizations and media outlets to silence critics of Beijing.
headline: China Uses ‘Deceptive’ Methods to Sow Disinformation, U.S. Says

abstract: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has spent his political career trying to rehabilitate the family name. As the front-runner in the upcoming election, he may finally succeed.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — They bopped along to the beat of a martial law anthem updated into a pop tune. They cheered when an A-list celebrity proclaimed that the spirit of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former dictator, was alive. And when Mr. Marcos’s son and namesake held up the peace sign made popular by his father a generation ago, the shrieking crowds mirrored it in return.
headline: The Philippines Toppled One Marcos. Now His Son May Become President.

abstract: The company said on Friday that its users should be able to hear from all presidential candidates “on the same basis.”
lead_paragraph: Meta on Friday said it was rolling back some restrictions to former President Donald J. Trump’s Facebook and Instagram accounts so people on its services could hear from those running for the presidency “on the same basis.”
headline: Meta Rolls Back Restrictions on Trump’s Instagram and Facebook Accounts

abstract: Also, a group of regulators put together after the financial crisis weighs on how risky digital currencies are to the economy.
lead_paragraph: Kim Kardashian’s $1.26 million crypto-related settlement yesterday with the S.E.C. was designed to get maximum exposure. Instead of just a dry press release, though the agency released one of those, Chair Gary Gensler announced the settlement on social media and even posted an influencer-style video warning the public about crypto investment schemes and scams. One of the many questions raised by the settlement that Gensler didn’t address in the video: Was it fair?
headline: Keeping Up With the Crypto Influencers

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Omicron, Instagram, Great Performers: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing

abstract: Facebook on Friday became the first American tech giant to be blocked by the Russian government, as part of the Kremlin’s broadening campaign to tighten control of the internet and limit spaces for dissent about the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Friday became the first American tech giant to be blocked by the Russian government, as part of the Kremlin’s broadening campaign to tighten control of the internet and limit spaces for dissent about the war in Ukraine.
headline: Russia blocks Facebook inside the country, as the Kremlin moves to stifle dissent.

abstract: For years, federal lawmakers have tried to pass legislation to rein in the tech giants. The TikTok law was their first success.
lead_paragraph: The swift passage this week of legislation to force the sale or ban of TikTok was the first time a federal tech law has been approved in years.
headline: TikTok Broke the Tech Law Logjam. Can That Success Be Repeated?

abstract: The lawsuit caps years of regulatory scrutiny of Apple’s wildly popular suite of devices and services, which have fueled its growth into a nearly $3 trillion public company.
lead_paragraph: The federal government’s aggressive crackdown on Big Tech expanded on Thursday to include an antitrust lawsuit by the Justice Department against Apple, one of the world’s best-known and most valuable companies.
headline: U.S. Sues Apple, Accusing It of Maintaining an iPhone Monopoly

abstract: Why the development of artificial intelligence might result in greater pollution of our digital public spaces.
lead_paragraph: Greg Marston, a British voice actor, recently came across “Connor” online — an A.I.-generated clone of his voice, trained on a recording Mr. Marston had made in 2003. It was his voice uttering things he had never said.
headline: The Internet Is About to Get Much Worse

abstract: The chief executives of JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup are among the Wall Street leaders set to testify in Washington.
lead_paragraph: This morning, the heads of the nation’s seven largest banks are in Washington for two days of testimony, starting in the House. More than a decade after bank C.E.O.s were in the hot seat during the financial crisis, many of the same issues remain.
headline: Banking C.E.O.s Face a Grilling on Capitol Hill

abstract: Meta “routinely documented” children under 13 on Instagram and collected their data, according to a newly unsealed complaint.
lead_paragraph: Meta has received more than 1.1 million reports of users under the age of 13 on its Instagram platform since early 2019 yet it “disabled only a fraction” of those accounts, according to a newly unsealed legal complaint against the company brought by the attorneys general of 33 states.
headline: At Meta, Millions of Underage Users Were an ‘Open Secret,’ States Say

abstract: Facebook said on Wednesday that it planned to lift its ban on political advertising across its network, resuming a form of digital promotion that has been criticized for spreading misinformation, falsehoods and inflaming voters.
lead_paragraph: Facebook said on Wednesday that it planned to lift its ban on political advertising across its network, resuming a form of digital promotion that has been criticized for spreading misinformation, falsehoods and inflaming voters.
headline: Facebook is lifting its ban on political advertising, with caveats.

abstract: Don’t underestimate the tech that makes your eyes glaze over. It holds us all up.
lead_paragraph: This week, a company I never think about scooped up another one I had forgotten existed. It was a reminder that we shouldn’t underestimate the boring.
headline: Hugs to Boring

abstract: The major restructuring, a possible precursor to I.P.O.s, was announced after Jack Ma, its founder, returned to mainland China after a yearlong absence.
lead_paragraph: China’s Alibaba Group said on Tuesday that it would become a holding company with six different business groups, in a major reshuffle that signaled the potential breakup of the country’s biggest e-commerce firm.
headline: Alibaba, China’s E-Commerce Giant, Will Split Into 6 Units

abstract: After weeks of setbacks on the battlefield, Russia struck civilian targets in Ukraine. But Vladimir Putin’s missiles may not accomplish much.
lead_paragraph: When Russia invaded Ukraine in February, many Ukrainians took shelter underground for days and even weeks from constant bombardments and fighting.
headline: Russia’s Revenge

abstract: The billionaire moved SpaceX’s incorporation out of the state. Wall Street is wondering if Tesla will follow suit.
lead_paragraph: Another Elon Musk-led company has moved its home base from Delaware as the tech billionaire continues to criticize the state after a judge there voided his nearly $56 billion payday at Tesla.
headline: Elon Musk Extends His Anywhere-but-Delaware Campaign

abstract: Even before the pandemic, there was an “epidemic of loneliness,” and it was affecting physical health and life expectancy.
lead_paragraph: For two years you didn’t see friends like you used to. You missed your colleagues from work, even the barista on the way there.
headline: How Loneliness Is Damaging Our Health

abstract: The federal government isn’t banning them anytime soon, but they may still be on the way out.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays. Debatable will be off on Feb. 1.
headline: Is the Era of Gas Stoves Burning Out?

abstract: The virtual pinboard service will remove content that denies climate change after also blocking ads about politics, weight loss and anti-vaccine sentiment.
lead_paragraph: Pinterest will prohibit ads and posts that feature climate misinformation in its latest attempt to block harmful content on its virtual pinboard service, the company said on Wednesday.
headline: Pinterest bans climate misinformation from posts and ads.

abstract: Flush with cash, Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and Google are positioned to emerge from a downturn stronger and more powerful. As usual.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and the parent companies of Facebook and Google have lost $2.7 trillion in value so far this year, about the annual gross domestic product of Britain.
headline: Big Tech Is Getting Clobbered on Wall Street. It’s a Good Time for Them.

abstract: The congressional news start-up is doubling down on information for its audience of Capitol Hill obsessives.
lead_paragraph: Since leaving Politico three years ago, the founders of the Washington news start-up Punchbowl News have made their mark with aggressive inside-the-Beltway coverage, breaking news on the Capitol riot, the messy ouster of Speaker Kevin McCarthy and the death of Senator Dianne Feinstein of California.
headline: Punchbowl News Strikes Deal to Buy Data Start-Up

abstract: A series of potential problems, including rising oil prices and labor strikes, have prompted a much warier mood among investors.
lead_paragraph: The stock market staggered to the end of its worst month of the year so far, dragged down by fears of a looming government shutdown, striking autoworkers, surging oil prices and the prospect of interest rates remaining high for longer than previously thought. Combined, they are darkening the outlook for the economy.
headline: Wall Street on Edge After Worst Month of the Year

abstract: As the Justice Department’s case against Google nears an end, the federal government has more suits in the pipeline trying to rein in Big Tech.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government’s landmark antitrust trial against Google’s search business is nearing its conclusion. But the parade of major federal cases challenging Big Tech’s power is just getting going.
headline: U.S. Antitrust Case Against Google Is Just the Start

abstract: Streetwear’s Black history raconteur survived Kanye, Supreme and a near-death experience. But can he survive the internet?
lead_paragraph: Not long after Tremaine Emory resigned his position as Supreme’s creative director last summer, he came across an image of an old hoodie from the brand emblazoned with one of its familiar biting slogans: “Illegal business controls America.”
headline: Tremaine Emory Refuses to Hide the Scars

abstract: Some supplements have been shown to modestly lower cholesterol, but cardiologists say they’re no match for statins.
lead_paragraph: Q: My doctor recently recommended that I take a statin to lower my cholesterol, but I’d rather not start the drug unless I absolutely have to. A friend said he takes an over-the-counter supplement for his cholesterol — does that really work?
headline: Can I Skip Statins and Just Take Supplements?

abstract: A three-day pre-wedding ceremony for the son of one of India’s richest men raises the bar for extravagant festivity.
lead_paragraph: When a member of one of India’s wealthiest families gets married, big-name guests and showstopping pomp and circumstance are nothing unusual. But it’s not every day that the invitees include royalty, business titans, Bollywood luminaries and Rihanna, for three days of a pre-wedding spectacular, months ahead of the actual ceremony.
headline: In a Land of Lavish Weddings, This Prenuptial Party Takes the Cake

abstract: The mosquitoes that transmit the disease dramatically increased their range over the last century as temperatures warmed, scientists reported.
lead_paragraph: Warming temperatures are chasing animals and plants to new habitats, sometimes with devastating consequences to ecosystems. But there is little evidence regarding how far and how fast the invaders might be moving.
headline: How Climate Change Is Spreading Malaria in Africa

abstract: Tech reporter Casey Newton takes us inside the Facebook Papers consortium, the company’s failure to be held to account and why the problem is bigger than any one company.
lead_paragraph: The Facebook Papers and whistle-blower testimony have given us yet more insight into the company’s impact on polarization and mental health, but if you could wave a magic wand and “pull the plug on Facebook,” would these problems go away? Casey Newton, the journalist behind the newsletter Platformer, says no. Imagining a universe where “Mark Zuckerberg is not the C.E.O., the company doesn’t exist — I actually don’t think you would improve the internet that much,” he says. He caveats that Facebook has never been held accountable “in any meaningful way,” but the problems are much bigger than any one platform.
headline: Is the Problem Facebook? Or the Internet?

abstract: Lina Khan faced more than three hours of questioning from the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee.
lead_paragraph: Lina Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, faced more than three hours of criticism and ridicule from Republicans in a House hearing on Thursday, as emboldened critics increasingly put pressure on the agency for its crackdown on the growing power of tech giants.
headline: F.T.C. Chair Faces Criticism in Congressional Hearing

abstract: Amid endless agonizing over the State of Cinema, the actual releases proved a bounty for film lovers, whether fans of the art house or the multiplex.
lead_paragraph: In 1985, The New York Times’s longtime film critic Vincent Canby wrote an inspired, admirably cranky essay about the future of cinema. The spark for his ruminations was “Room 666,” a documentary from Wim Wenders that had just opened in New York. Shot during the 1982 Cannes Film Festival, the movie consists of different directors alone in a hotel room where they respond to a question that Wenders had written on a piece of paper: “Is cinema a language that is about to get lost, an art that is about to die?”
headline: Best Movies of 2022

abstract: A discothèque, a shrine to Dolly Parton, an ode to Iranian films: These are just a few of the eye-popping, eccentric restaurant restrooms giving diners a different kind of thrill.
lead_paragraph: Behind an unmarked door at Wenwen, a homey Taiwanese restaurant in Brooklyn, a discothèque awaits: Speakers pump out pop songs in Mandarin, Cantonese and Taiwanese. Strobe lights dance across the walls. A disco ball twirls above. A framed poster of the Taiwanese pop star Feng Fei-fei hangs directly opposite the toilet.
headline: The Most Exciting Part of Dining Out Is … the Bathroom?

abstract: Strikes by actors and screenwriters have ground movie and TV productions to a halt, with consequences likely to be felt across the entertainment industry.
lead_paragraph: It’s happening: America’s $134 billion movie and TV industry has ground to a halt after the Hollywood actors’ union voted to strike, joining screenwriters and shutting down virtually all productions.
headline: The Economic Stakes in the Hollywood Shutdown

abstract: Twitter permanently banned her account on Sunday after what the company said was her fifth “strike.”
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Monday suspended for 24 hours the account of Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene for spreading misinformation about the coronavirus, a day after Twitter permanently banned one of her accounts for posting a similar message.
headline: Facebook suspends Marjorie Taylor Greene’s account for 24 hours.

abstract: In professional football, danger is at the root of any given play.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, millions of people watched a terrifying scene unfold in real time. Damar Hamlin, a 24-year-old safety for the Buffalo Bills, collapsed and went into cardiac arrest after making what appeared to be a routine tackle in a nationally televised N.F.L. game against the Cincinnati Bengals.
headline: Violence in the N.F.L.

abstract: The 2023 Emmys were meant to be a celebration of television’s best. Instead, they’ll serve as a funeral for the era dominated by landmark shows.
lead_paragraph: In a normal year we’d be talking about the 75th Emmy Awards telecast this week: who wore what, whose speech went too long and which of the lauded shows took home the night’s biggest haul. But the awards telecast was postponed to January, in hopes that the writers’ and actors’ strikes will be resolved by then, so we’ll have to wait a few more months to celebrate what was a remarkable year in TV. Twenty-seven nominations for the final season of “Succession” alone, including 14 nominated acting performances. Prestige heavyweights like “Better Call Saul,” “The White Lotus,” “The Last of Us” and “The Crown” all duking it out — and that’s just in the outstanding drama category. What a lineup! What a year!
headline: The Era of Prestige TV Is Ending. We’re Going to Miss It When It’s Gone.

abstract: Larry David’s HBO series never aimed at grand statements. But its reflection of modern grievances was pretty, pretty good.
lead_paragraph: At the end of his 1999 HBO special, “Larry David: Curb Your Enthusiasm,” David wraps up a stand-up comedy set by telling his audience he has no more material for them. “This is what happens when you run out of nothing,” he says.
headline: ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ Made Something Out of Nothing

abstract: How did modern feminism lose Roe v. Wade? An answer lies in Depp v. Heard.
lead_paragraph: One month almost to the day after Americans learned of Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito’s draft opinion that would eviscerate the constitutional right of women to control their bodies and so their lives, millions sat glued to their screens to witness the verdict in the Johnny Depp-Amber Heard defamation trial, in which the jury awarded more than $10 million to Mr. Depp. In a statement afterward, Ms. Heard said she was “disappointed with what this verdict means for women.” “It sets back the clock,” she said, “to a time when a woman who spoke up and spoke out could be publicly shamed and humiliated.”
headline: Feminism Made a Faustian Bargain With Celebrity Culture. Now It’s Paying the Price.

abstract: D.C.’s attorney general had waited too long to add Mark Zuckerberg as a defendant in the suit against Meta, the judge said.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Tuesday threw out motions by the attorney general of the District of Columbia to name Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, as a defendant in a privacy lawsuit.
headline: A judge throws out D.C.’s attempt to name Zuckerberg in a privacy lawsuit.

abstract: Regulators looking to block JetBlue’s $3.8 billion bid to buy Spirit Airways think there’s no other way to address their competition concerns.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department plans to sue to block JetBlue’s deal to buy the low-cost airline Spirit Airways for $3.8 billion, JetBlue acknowledged on Monday. Word of the suit — which could come as soon as Tuesday — sent shares in Spirit down nearly 9 percent.
headline: A Mega Airline Merger Hits Turbulence

abstract: Katie Hale and Scott Hogan’s ingenious collaboration will possess you.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
headline: Punctuation Matters

abstract: The Anti-Defamation League says the social media company has failed to rein in hate speech and extremist views. Also: Afghanistan’s lessons; solar power production in China.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
headline: From the ADL: Facebook Must Be Held Accountable

abstract: Between 1920 and 2020, the average human life span doubled. How did we do it? Science mattered — but so did activism.
lead_paragraph: In September 1918, a flu virus began spreading through Camp Devens, an overcrowded military base just outside Boston. By the end of the second week of the outbreak, one in five soldiers at the base had come down with the illness. But the speed with which it spread through the camp was not nearly as shocking as the lethality. “It is only a matter of a few hours then until death comes,” a camp physician wrote. “It is horrible. One can stand it to see one, two or 20 men die, but to see these poor devils dropping like flies sort of gets on your nerves. We have been averaging about 100 deaths per day.”
headline: How Humanity Gave Itself an Extra Life

abstract: The job cuts of approximately 10,000, which would start as soon as this week, would focus on the company’s devices organization, retail division and human resources.
lead_paragraph: Amazon plans to lay off approximately 10,000 people in corporate and technology jobs starting as soon as this week, people with knowledge of the matter said, in what would be the largest job cuts in the company’s history.
headline: Amazon Is Said to Plan to Lay Off Thousands of Employees

abstract: The Chinese-owned video app is dealing with a flood of war videos and the question of whether it is spreading unverified information.
lead_paragraph: Bre Hernandez used to scan TikTok for videos of makeup tutorials and taco truck reviews. Since Russia invaded Ukraine, the 19-year-old has spent hours each day scrolling the app for war videos, watching graphic footage of Ukrainian tanks firing on Russian troops and civilians running away from enemy gunfire.
headline: TikTok Is Gripped by the Violence and Misinformation of Ukraine War

abstract: This month’s picks include an Argentine psychological thriller, a charming Korean drama and an elliptical Galician war film.
lead_paragraph: In the age of streaming, the earth is flat — screen-size — with travel to faraway destinations only a monthly subscription and a click away. We’ve journeyed through the world of options and chosen the best new international movies for you to watch.
headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now

abstract: New voting rules made for sharper attacks, while a bold defense kept the activist investor at bay. But pressure remains on the company’s chief, Bob Iger.
lead_paragraph: It’s over. Disney fended off the activist investor Nelson Peltz for the second time in two years, as its shareholders rejected his effort to win two seats on its board.
headline: The Takeaways From Disney’s Board Fight with Nelson Peltz

abstract: Mark Zuckerberg has used Meta’s might to push Threads to a fast start — but that may only work up to a point.
lead_paragraph: A big tech company with billions of users introduces a new social network. Leveraging the popularity and scale of its existing products, the company intends to make the new social platform a success. In doing so, it also plans to squash a leading competitor’s app.
headline: Why the Early Success of Threads May Crash Into Reality

abstract: Some crypto insiders say they saw the implosion of TerraUSD coming. Other stablecoins could also run into trouble.
lead_paragraph: This week’s implosion of TerraUSD is once again shaking confidence in crypto markets, and raising alarms about investor protection.
headline: A Stablecoin ‘Death Spiral’

abstract: Support for Ukraine wavers.
lead_paragraph: The White House said yesterday that it saw no current prospects for negotiations to end the war in Ukraine, even as President Biden faces new obstacles to keeping together the bipartisan, multinational coalition supporting the effort to drive out Russian invaders, as American midterm elections and a cold European winter loom.
headline: Your Thursday Briefing

abstract: The company formerly known as Facebook has hit major turbulence as it suffered its biggest one-day wipeout ever.
lead_paragraph: Meta, the company formerly known as Facebook, suffered its biggest one-day wipeout ever on Thursday as its stock plummeted 26 percent and its market value plunged by more than $230 billion.
headline: 6 Reasons Meta Is in Trouble

abstract: Cease-fire talks stall.
lead_paragraph: Negotiations between Israel and Hamas stalled again, meaning more uncertainty for the families of Israeli hostages and no quick reprieve for Palestinians in Gaza. Mediators struggled to bridge the remaining gaps, and a Hamas delegation left the talks, officials said.
headline: Monday Briefing

abstract: A Times project explores the daily lives of people experiencing homelessness.
lead_paragraph: Yvonne Soy had to move out of her apartment in Contra Costa County because she couldn’t pay her rent. She began living in her car, with her two cats, and tried to get work as a secretary or a legal administrator.
headline: What’s Homelessness Really Like?

abstract: Battling far-right extremism, Germany has gone further than any other Western democracy to prosecute individuals for what they say online, testing the limits of free speech on the internet.
lead_paragraph: When the police pounded the door before dawn at a home in northwest Germany, a bleary-eyed young man in his boxer shorts answered. The officers asked for his father, who was at work.
headline: Where Online Hate Speech Can Bring the Police to Your Door

abstract: Research shows they can indeed deliver fitness benefits while you work — but only if you use them wisely.
lead_paragraph: Experts have long known that extended inactivity can be bad for your body, increasing your risk for heart disease, Type 2 diabetes and other illnesses. As the saying goes, “sitting is the new smoking.” At the same time, decades of studies have shown that walking — even just 4,000 steps a day — is good for the mind and body.
headline: The Treadmill Desk Might Really Be Worth It

abstract: With Art Basel Hong Kong fully open, visitors also can use the occasion to explore the contemporary art museum M+, which has a show that looks at who controls what we see online.
lead_paragraph: Many international visitors to this week’s Art Basel Hong Kong will finally get a chance to see the museum M+, located just across Victoria Harbor from the fair’s home in the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center. The museum was completed in 2021, when local quarantine restrictions were still in force.
headline: A Different Kind of Museum in Hong Kong

abstract: The tech giant moved quickly to hire Sam Altman and others after their abrupt departures from OpenAI, a key Microsoft partner.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft, the technology giant that ranks as one of the world’s most valuable companies, was shaken by the upheaval at OpenAI, the small but influential artificial intelligence start-up that developed the ChatGPT chatbot, before it found a way out of the turmoil that propelled its shares to a new high.
headline: Microsoft’s Stock Hits Record High After Hiring OpenAI Outcasts

abstract: Companies are wrestling with an array of state rules that makes designing pandemic policies tricky.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Biden administration’s nationwide coronavirus vaccine mandate for large companies has been overturned by the Supreme Court, employers are left to navigate a thicket of state and local rules. In New York, that means private employers have to require vaccines. In Florida and Texas, laws limit the pandemic protocols they can put in place.
headline: States Are Complicating Corporate Pandemic Planning

abstract: Riddles are as old as the English language and, as Adrienne Raphel explains, can tell us a lot about Anglo-Saxon culture — as long as we are able to solve them.
lead_paragraph: There’s a certain state of mind I call crossword brain: It’s both intuitive and counterintuitive, knowing when to turn away from the seemingly obvious solution, but also knowing when to trust your instincts and go with the answer that feels good. Crossword brain requires you to bend and sometimes entirely break the way you think you should make connections. Crosswords tug all sides of your mind, requiring you to dart from straightforward definitions to narrative logic to free association to bad dad puns, all in the same space.
headline: What Has One Eye and 1,200 Heads? An Old English Riddle, That’s What!

abstract: Adam Mosseri, the head of the company, is expected to face questions from lawmakers this week about whether social media harms children.
lead_paragraph: Instagram will introduce its first parental controls in March as it faces pressure to do more to shield its young users from harmful content and keep them from overusing the product.
headline: Instagram says parental controls will arrive in March.

abstract: There are so many film experiences to choose from on Netflix, let us help you narrow down your choices.
lead_paragraph: Sign up for our Watching newsletter to get recommendations on the best films and TV shows to stream and watch, delivered to your inbox.
headline: The 50 Best Movies on Netflix Right Now

abstract: The labor market showed continued resilience. President Biden signed legislation averting a rail strike. And a near-total embargo on Russian oil takes effect.
lead_paragraph: China appeared to ease off some of its Covid protocol on Thursday after residents — frustrated by the “zero Covid” approach of the Chinese leader Xi Jinping — began protesting on a scale that is rare for the country. Chinese people flocked to the streets, and videos of marches and rallies surfaced on social media platforms, apparently overwhelming the censors who would otherwise swiftly suppress them. The demonstrations erupted amid a new Covid outbreak that prompted the Chinese government to invoke some of its most stringent measures, which include mandatory lockdowns and quarantining. These policies have affected people’s livelihoods and life prospects — many small businesses have struggled to survive, and youth unemployment reached a record 20 percent. It’s not yet clear to what extent the Chinese government will roll back its mandates, particularly as Mr. Xi has trumpeted the strict management of Covid in China.
headline: The Week in Business: Upheaval in China

abstract: One of the most prominent women in Silicon Valley, she was an early Google employee and a key member of the inner circle of the company’s founders.
lead_paragraph: Susan Wojcicki, YouTube’s chief executive and one of the most prominent women in Silicon Valley, said on Thursday that she was stepping down from her longtime role leading the internet’s most popular video service.
headline: Susan Wojcicki, YouTube’s Longtime C.E.O., Says She Will Step Down

abstract: Don’t delete your account just yet. Elon Musk’s takeover can teach us valuable lessons about our relationship with social networks.
lead_paragraph: Sheer chaos has surrounded Elon Musk’s takeover of Twitter over the past few weeks. More than half of Twitter’s employees have been fired or have resigned. The verification system no longer means much. And some users have reported problems with security features. So if you have an account on the social network, what do you do?
headline: How to Prepare for Life After Twitter

abstract: Anthropic, OpenAI, Google, Meta and other key developers are acting to prevent the technology from threatening democracies, even as their tools become more powerful.
lead_paragraph: Artificial intelligence companies have been at the vanguard of developing the transformative technology. Now they are also racing to set limits on how A.I. is used in a year stacked with major elections around the world.
headline: In Big Election Year, A.I.’s Architects Move Against Its Misuse

abstract: Facebook is using  privacy as a pretext to squelch inconvenient research about the political ads it delivers.
lead_paragraph: We learned last week that Facebook had disabled our Facebook accounts and our access to data that we have been using to study how misinformation spreads on the company’s platform.
headline: We Research Misinformation on Facebook. It Just Disabled Our Accounts.

abstract: These prosecutions typically spark innovation in unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: The Google antitrust trial, which began last week, is ostensibly focused on the past — on a series of deals that Google made with other companies over the past two decades. The prosecution in the case, U.S. et al. v. Google, contends that Google illegally spent billions of dollars paying off Samsung and Apple to prevent anyone else from gaining a foothold in the market for online search.
headline: The Google Trial Is Going to Rewrite Our Future

abstract: Warning: Neither Hermès nor Birkenstock has approved this product.
lead_paragraph: On the second Monday in February, the Banksys of consumer culture struck again.
headline: $76,000 Birkinstocks Made From Actual Birkin Bags?

abstract: Keeping a promise from when her master recordings were sold, Swift has faithfully rerecorded her 2008 album. Our critics and reporters explore its sound, and purpose.
lead_paragraph: JON PARELES When the master recordings for Taylor Swift’s first six albums were sold along with her first label, Big Machine, to the manager Scooter Braun’s company, she announced she would remake them on her own terms (and for her own reward). “Fearless (Taylor’s Version)” is the first album of her reclamation project: a newly recorded version of the entire “platinum edition” of her second album, which was released in 2008. She was 18 at the time.
headline: Taylor Swift Remade ‘Fearless’ as ‘Taylor’s Version.’ Let’s Discuss.

abstract: The S&P 500 has been buoyant mainly because of A.I. fever, while bonds are having another mediocre year. But as an investor, our columnist is staying the course.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve has disappointed investors this year, but no matter. The markets have adjusted.
headline: Why the Stock Market Has Risen Even With No Fed Rate Cuts

abstract: Jean-Luc Godard’s hard-boiled sci-fi movie from 1965 returns in a restored version at IFC Center.
lead_paragraph: Cinephiles of a certain age have a Jean-Luc Godard film that when first seen, blew their minds. Mine was Godard’s low-budget foray into dystopian science fiction, “Alphaville.”
headline: ‘Alphaville’: A Film That Feels Brand-New

abstract: How Prime Minister Hun Sen is leveraging his people’s dependence on Facebook to quash opposition as elections approach.
lead_paragraph: The Cambodian People’s Party created its Cyber War Room about a decade ago. The goal was to support Prime Minister Hun Sen’s regime through social media propagandizing. Led by the prime minister’s son Hun Manet, a troll army used Facebook and other digital platforms to attack his father’s opposition with disinformation and even, allegedly, wield death threats.
headline: Some of the Worst Troll Armies Are Gaining Ground. Just Look at Cambodia.

abstract: Seven years ago, I showed that Facebook sold discriminatory ads. Its system is still broken.
lead_paragraph: I still remember the shock I felt when I was able to buy a Facebook ad aimed only at white house hunters — something the Fair Housing Act was designed to prevent — in just minutes. But even more shocking is that it took six years after my test for Meta, Facebook’s parent company, to comply with the act. As of today, the company still has not fully fixed its discriminatory ad system.
headline: It’s Time to Tear Up Big Tech’s Get-Out-of-Jail-Free Card

abstract: The company has poured billions into the construction of the metaverse, which has been slow to take off.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg wants people to know that his company is still focused on social media. He made those remarks moments after appearing in a hiccup-interrupted recorded exchange with Andrew Ross Sorkin, founder of DealBook, that took place in the metaverse.
headline: Mark Zuckerberg defends company’s push into the metaverse, where he appeared with a bout of hiccups.

abstract: Also, the Supreme Court ruled against Andy Warhol. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The tech industry’s race to develop artificial intelligence has been upended by a decision to give away a powerful system for free. In February Meta released LLaMA, an A.I. technology similar to the one powering ChatGPT, as open-source software that anyone can use to build their own chatbot.
headline: Meta Gave Away Its A.I. Crown Jewels

abstract: The conference on Nov. 29 will bring together the biggest newsmakers in business, politics and culture.
lead_paragraph: We’re excited to announce the lineup for the DealBook Summit, to be held at Jazz at Lincoln Center in New York City on Nov. 29. Andrew will host a series of conversations with the biggest newsmakers in the worlds of business, politics and culture. We hope you will join us.
headline: Elon Musk, Kamala Harris, Jamie Dimon Will Speak at the DealBook Summit

abstract: A selection of recent poetry books of note; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: INDEX OF WOMEN, by Amy Gerstler. (Penguin Poets, paper, $20.) Gerstler’s witty collection channels various characters — the tooth fairy, a lost doll — to celebrate “shrewd, / ingenious, difficult women, prodigal daughters / and wisecracking wives.”
headline: New & Noteworthy Poetry, From Sign Language to Robot Saints

abstract: Investors weighed mixed economic reports and company earnings.
