lead_paragraph: Global stocks fell on Tuesday, giving back some of Monday’s gains and returning to the downward drift in recent weeks, as investors weighed mixed economic reports and company earnings.
headline: Stocks fall and are again headed toward bear market territory.

abstract: The Feb. 19 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with George Saunders. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews George Saunders

abstract: European Union regulators filed new antitrust charges against Google, which could lead to fines and orders for the company to change its business practices.
lead_paragraph: Google was charged on Wednesday with violating European Union antitrust laws by using its dominance in online advertising to undercut rivals, the latest in a string of cases around the world that strike at the core of the internet giant’s business model.
headline: Google’s Online Advertising Practices Violate Antitrust Laws, E.U. Says

abstract: A letter from moms whose children have a life-threatening illness. Also: Regulating social media; sanctions; politics and I.V.F.; a house full of memories.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
headline: Three Mothers’ Plea to the F.D.A.: Save Our Children

abstract: Meta announced changes to its ad-targeting policies, but they will do little to stop campaigns from reaching specific voters.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
headline: Political Campaigns Can Still Target You on Facebook

abstract: A conversation with Reihan Salam.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Reihan Salam. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Reihan Salam

abstract: The retailer, which had closed all its U.S. stores, has resurfaced at the American Dream mall in New Jersey, just in time for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was 11 a.m. six days before Christmas, and a security guard in a bulletproof vest eyed 120 masked customers standing in line at the entrance to the newest retailer at the American Dream mall: Toys “R” Us.
headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Tries to Come Back, Four Years After Bankruptcy

abstract: What happens on Facebook has such big consequences, its quasi-independent Oversight Board can only do so much.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: The Limits of Facebook’s ‘Supreme Court’

abstract: To make social media less toxic, the United States needs to commit to making digital platforms more transparent.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s deal to take Twitter private, which has spurred questions about power, censorship and safety for the future of the platform, happened just days after the European Union reached a landmark agreement to make social media less toxic for users. The new E.U. standards, and the ethic of transparency on which they are based, will for the first time pull back the curtain on the algorithms that choose what we see and when we see it in our feeds.
headline: Europe Is Making Social Media Better Without Curtailing Free Speech. The U.S. Should, Too.

abstract: The social network's owner  talks about bots, blue checks and why he went ahead with the $44 billion acquisition.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk gave one his most extensive interviews since promising a series of big changes to Twitter that he hopes will return the money-losing social media platform to profitability. In a wide-ranging discussion with the BBC that was also broadcast on Twitter, and was at times full of contradictions, regrets and dog jokes, Musk defended his management of the company and gave an update on layoffs, cash flow, the status of the blue checks and who might succeed him as C.E.O.
headline: Elon Musk Addresses the ‘Painful’ Side of Running Twitter

abstract: Kate Schutzengel makes her New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Kate Schutzengel on her New York Times Crossword debut. This is our fifth debut of the year, and boy is it a silly one (in the best possible way)! Before we get to the theme, though, I want to discuss one clue convention that can be particularly confusing to new solvers.
headline: It’s the Word

abstract: Google’s parent company returned to sales growth, even as an advertising slowdown continued to crimp YouTube.
lead_paragraph: After years of easy financial growth and booming popularity, Alphabet, Google’s parent company, has in recent months faced mounting questions about its future. It has been under the gun to deliver artificial intelligence technology, its sales growth has decelerated, and it is laying off 12,000 employees to cut costs.
headline: Alphabet Shrugs Off Advertising Slump, Thanks to Search Engine

abstract: A new proposal casts an even bigger shadow over the once-booming market for blank-check firms.
lead_paragraph: The S.E.C. voted yesterday to propose new rules for special purpose acquisition companies, casting an even bigger shadow over the once-booming market. If adopted, these public shell companies — formed to acquire a business and take it public without the fuss of the traditional I.P.O. process — would have to provide more investor disclosures, especially about their ownership and performance forecasts. In some cases, SPACs may have to register as investment companies, subjecting them to stricter rules.
headline: The S.E.C. Takes Aim at SPACs

abstract: Apple, Amazon and Alphabet all reported disappointing quarterly results, as they emphasized efforts to cut costs in the face of an economic slowdown.
lead_paragraph: Shares in tech companies are in retreat after investors got sobering news on Thursday about three of the industry’s giants — Alphabet, Amazon and Apple — including slowing demand for everything from iPhones to digital ads to cloud services.
headline: Tech Earnings Give a Wake-Up Call to Investors

abstract: Three theaters are exploring “Swingin’ the Dream,” which tanked on Broadway in 1939, but opens a window on the racial and artistic dynamics of its time.
lead_paragraph: “It’s almost like a kind of murder mystery,” Kwame Kwei-Armah said with obvious relish. “The play was butchered by the press, and somehow the body has disappeared.”
headline: Shakespeare, Swing and Louis Armstrong. So What Went Wrong?

abstract: Gorman’s reading of her poem “The Hill We Climb” on Wednesday combined the personal and political.
lead_paragraph: The sun came out intermittently at President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration in Washington on Wednesday, but Amanda Gorman was her own source of illumination. With her canary-yellow Prada coat, her regal red headband, her thrice-scrubbed innocence and her exacting delivery, she was a one-person reminder that if winter is here, then spring cannot be far behind.
headline: At the Inauguration, Amanda Gorman Wove History and the Future Into a Stirring Melody

abstract: For years, the director puzzled over an adaptation of “The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar.” Then he let the characters say things they weren’t meant to.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, while the director Wes Anderson was adapting Roald Dahl’s “Fantastic Mr. Fox” into a stop-motion animated film, the author’s widow, Felicity, asked whether he saw cinematic potential in any of Dahl’s other tales. One came immediately to Anderson’s mind: “The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar,” a short Dahl published in 1977 about a wealthy gambler who learns a secret meditation technique that allows him to see through playing cards.
headline: Wes Anderson Finally Found a Way Into His New Roald Dahl Film

abstract: Dressing for a virtual world is going to be both enormously liberating and potentially very, very messy.
lead_paragraph: Late in October, when Mark Zuckerberg unveiled the rebranding of Facebook as Meta, he did so in an immersive video designed to reveal his vision of the future in which virtual he, Mark Z., gave a virtual tour of all of the exciting things we will able to do in the new virtual world otherwise known as the metaverse.
headline: What to Wear in the Metaverse

abstract: As legislation moves ahead that could eventually mandate a sale by the Chinese parent company ByteDance, hurdles include finding buyers.
lead_paragraph: Legislation that could eventually mandate a sale of TikTok is moving forward. But any kind of divestiture by its Chinese parent company, ByteDance, is likely to prove challenging.
headline: Why a Sale of TikTok Would Not Be Easy

abstract: The Justice Department’s recommendation that restrictions on marijuana be lifted have revived expectations for a business that has waited years for such a change.
lead_paragraph: For years, the dreams of the cannabis industry looked like they might go up in smoke, with the U.S. government classifying marijuana as a drug as dangerous as heroin. But the multibillion-dollar industry now has some hope that could change.
headline: The Cannabis Industry Hopes for New Highs

abstract: Leslie Rogers takes us aloft on a Saturday.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today’s grid has one of the most disarming set of misdirects that I’ve seen in a while. As a paper solver I would have left a couple of incorrect letters in the grid and went on with my day if it weren’t for having to write this write-up, and I imagine that plenty of online solvers had to run through the alphabet a couple of times, on entries with four and five letters, no less. Leslie Rogers is fairly new; her last puzzle was the clever one on daylight saving time in March, and this is only her second themeless. I think it’s a good one — lively and original, with seven debuts tucked in throughout.
headline: Something Opened With a Click

abstract: Addison Snell’s Sunday debut requires us to crack the code.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Addison Snell lives in Mountain View, Calif., and is the chief executive of Intersect360 Research, a consulting firm in high-performance computing. This is his second Times crossword after an existential Wednesday debut in July.
headline: Sending a Message

abstract: Facebook keeps dabbling in new things. Is it now an overstuffed mess, or a genius idea factory?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: What Is Facebook?

abstract: TikTok shut down the “legging legs” hashtag, but experts said they’re more worried about other content surfaced by social media algorithms.
lead_paragraph: In late January, a volunteer at the help line for the National Alliance for Eating Disorders fielded a call from someone who had seen an alarming trend on TikTok. The hashtag #legginglegs had started taking off as users posted about the slim bodies seemingly deemed the most desirable for leggings.
headline: Why Eating Disorder Content Keeps Spreading

abstract: A new generation of chatbots doesn’t have many of the guardrails put in place by companies like Google and OpenAI, presenting new possibilities — and risks.
lead_paragraph: A.I. chatbots have lied about notable figures, pushed partisan messages, spewed misinformation or even advised users on how to commit suicide.
headline: Uncensored Chatbots Provoke a Fracas Over Free Speech

abstract: For once, a presidential Q. and A. was must-see TV. But it didn’t put an end to the summer’s biggest drama.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest Biden news and election updates.
headline: Biden’s News Conference Answered Many Questions. But Not the Big One.

abstract: Also, the South is facing dangerous heat. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Coast Guard said today that a remote-controlled vehicle found debris from the Titan, the vessel that carried five people on a deep-sea exploration of the Titanic wreckage over the weekend, indicating a “catastrophic implosion.” Everyone aboard the submersible was believed to be dead, the Coast Guard said. The discovery effectively ended the international search that began on Sunday after the submersible lost contact.
headline: The Titan Submersible Suffered a ‘Catastrophic Implosion’

abstract: Enrique Henestroza Anguiano’s puzzle may enlighten you.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Enrique Henestroza Anguiano, who is making his fourth appearance in the New York Times Crossword with today’s puzzle.
headline: Are You Sure About That?

abstract: “Squid Game: The Challenge” keeps the slick design of the dystopian drama but loses the point.
lead_paragraph: Late in the first season of Netflix’s “Squid Game” — two-year-old spoiler alert, I guess — an elaborate, deadly contest among 456 needy contestants is revealed to be an entertainment for the viewing pleasure of a handful of crass, wealthy “VIPs,” who watch the gruesome proceedings wearing golden animal masks.
headline: The ‘Squid Game’ Reality Show Is More Depressing Than the Original

abstract: Ukrainian military officials say Russia is planning more strikes on infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian military officials say that Moscow is preparing a new wave of strikes on energy plants. A military spokeswoman said Ukraine had received intelligence reports suggesting that more strikes might come this week, perhaps using missiles launched from a Russian naval vessel in the Black Sea.
headline: Your Tuesday Briefing

abstract: The New York Post has complained that Facebook is blocking and downplaying its stories. But the platform doesn’t pay any special deference to journalists.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, I learned a new way to get a news article erased from much of the internet.
headline: Is an Activist’s Pricey House News? Facebook Alone Decides.

abstract: Introducing DJ TaskRabbit.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s Vision Pro headset is now for sale in stores. Will it live up to the hype? Kevin Roose and Casey Newton tried it out to see. Then, in a high-profile congressional hearing on child safety and social media, Mark Zuckerberg, the Meta chief executive, made an apology to families of victims of online child abuse. Is new legislation on the horizon? And finally, what the collapse of Cruise, the autonomous vehicle company, means for the future of self-driving cars.
headline: We Tried the Apple Vision Pro + Can Congress Protect Kids Online? + Cruise’s Crash

abstract: Joshua Kosman and Henri Picciotto, two professionals, knock a cryptic puzzle out of the park.
lead_paragraph: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — This has been a great year for variety puzzles, in my opinion, with some great new entries to the genre and some excellent guest appearances. Today, we have a cryptic puzzle constructed by Joshua Kosman and Henri Picciotto, the creators of a weekly online subscription puzzle called “Out of Left Field,” as well as the authors of “Word Salad,” a guide to cryptic puzzles that looks stuffed with interesting information.
headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword

abstract: Its campaign is part of a global wave of actions by governments that are testing how far they can go to control online speech.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Russia is increasingly pressuring Google, Twitter and Facebook to fall in line with Kremlin internet crackdown orders or risk restrictions inside the country, as more governments around the world challenge the companies’ principles on online freedom.
headline: Russia Raises Heat on Twitter, Google and Facebook in Online Crackdown

abstract: Research suggests there may be an ideal number of close friends we should have. What is that number for you?
lead_paragraph: Today, you will read about studies that try to identify the optimal number of close friends a person should have in order to feel connected and happy. If you had to choose such a number, what would it be, and why?
headline: How Many Close Friends Do You Need?

abstract: Boris Johnson plans to resign.
lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson, Britain’s beleaguered leader, said that he would step down as prime minister after a dizzying 48 hours that included a wholesale rebellion of his cabinet, a wave of government resignations and a devastating loss of party support prompted by his handling of the latest scandal to engulf his leadership.
headline: Your Thursday Briefing

abstract: How should that affect your behavior?
lead_paragraph: The details of the Omicron variant are becoming clearer, and they are encouraging.
headline: Omicron Is Milder

abstract: The inquiries signal the bloc’s intention to tightly enforce sweeping new competition rules that took effect this month.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Apple and Meta were told by European Union regulators on Monday that they were under investigation for a range of potential violations of the region’s new competition law.
headline: E.U. Takes Aim at Alphabet, Apple and Meta in Wide-Ranging Investigations

abstract: Plus Japan seeks to boost its own military and TikTok surges forward with ad revenue.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, met for nearly three hours yesterday.
headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Biden and Xi Discuss Taiwan

abstract: Employees are divided over Frances Haugen, a former product manager who testified that the company was putting profit before safety.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At a question-and-answer session with employees last week, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, was asked about Frances Haugen, a former product manager turned whistle-blower who had testified to Congress about the company’s harms.
headline: After Whistle-Blower Goes Public, Facebook Tries Calming Employees

abstract: The attitude of many Americans toward their jobs appears to have changed during the long pandemic — and not for the better.
lead_paragraph: Quiet quitting. Working from home. The Great Resignation.
headline: Is Working From Home Really Working?

abstract: President Biden’s struggling social policy bill.
lead_paragraph: President Biden pleaded with House Democrats to embrace his “framework” for a $1.85 trillion economic and environmental bill, saying that its fate would help determine that of his presidency and his party’s hold on Congress, and that its success would restore the nation’s standing on the world stage.
headline: Your Friday Briefing

abstract: Virtuosity and creativity with language are “everyone’s birthright” in the Irish capital, says Tana French, an award-winning mystery writer who has made it her home.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite things about Dublin is its relationship with words. History is embedded deep in language here. A lot of Dublin communities are tight-knit, with roots that go back centuries, so the dialect is sprinkled with words and phrases that have been passed down over the generations, even after they’ve vanished everywhere else. In Dublin, “my girlfriend” is still “me mot,” from the Victorian English “mort” for “woman” — long gone out of use in England, but still alive here. And back in the 16th century, “child” meant specifically a girl child; it’s been gender-neutral almost everywhere for hundreds of years, but within the last decade, when I had my second baby, older Dublin people still asked me “Is it a boy or a child?”
headline: Read Your Way Through Dublin

abstract: After the success of “I Am Not Your Negro,” HBO gave Peck carte blanche for his next big project. What resulted is a sweeping meditation on colonialism and the nature of truth itself.
lead_paragraph: After completing his 2016 documentary “I Am Not Your Negro,” the director Raoul Peck felt he’d had his say on the topic of U.S. race relations. Or at least his subject, the writer James Baldwin, had.
headline: In ‘Exterminate All the Brutes,’ Raoul Peck Takes Aim at White Supremacy

abstract: The video-sharing app has received unfair treatment in Washington. But the company’s biggest wounds are self-inflicted.
lead_paragraph: I was really rooting for TikTok.
headline: TikTok Is Its Own Worst Enemy

abstract: Dubious claims in product marketing are everywhere. Don’t fall for them.
lead_paragraph: You can’t browse a grocery store or pharmacy without being subject to flashy labels that promote health benefits. In the beverage aisle, for example, you might find “prebiotic” sodas that supposedly support “gut health.” In the beauty department, you’ll see “medical-grade” serums, “probiotic” facial creams and “skin detoxing” treatments. Go to the supplements section for promises of “immunity support,” “hormone balance” and “energy enhancement,” among other things.
headline: How Fake Science Sells Wellness

abstract: Default settings on devices allow the tech industry to keep collecting and using data as it wants.
lead_paragraph: A report in The Guardian in August that lawyers who had had business before the Supreme Court gave money to an aide to Justice Clarence Thomas for a Christmas party was surprising. Just as surprising was the way the publication learned about it: from the aide’s public Venmo records. Brian X. Chen, the consumer technology writer for The Times, wrote that even he was surprised that such records of money transfers could be public.
headline: This Is Why Google Paid Billions for Apple to Change a Single Setting

abstract: After more than eight months of research and development, Google has unveiled its most powerful A.I. so far. But only parts of it are widely available.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, Google has raced to build technology that could match ChatGPT, the eye-opening chatbot offered by the San Francisco artificial intelligence start-up OpenAI.
headline: Google Updates Bard Chatbot With ‘Gemini’ A.I. as It Chases ChatGPT

abstract: A union would represent an about-face for both companies, which told investors nearly a decade ago that they were better off apart.
lead_paragraph: The two parts of Rupert Murdoch’s media business, News Corp and Fox Corporation, are considering a proposal to reunite nearly 10 years after they split up, the companies announced on Friday.
headline: Fox and News Corp, After Years Apart, Explore Merger

abstract: A proposed union of budget airlines could test competition policy.
lead_paragraph: Frontier Airlines said today it plans to buy a rival budget airline, Spirit, for $2.9 billion in stock and cash. The companies pledged that merging would create jobs and save consumers money, but the deal is almost sure to draw tough scrutiny from the Biden administration’s emboldened antitrust enforcers.
headline: The New Frontier in Antitrust Fights?

abstract: As Facebook has become more active at moderating political speech, it has had trouble dealing with satire.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Since 2013, Matt Bors has made a living as a left-leaning cartoonist on the internet. His site, The Nib, runs cartoons from him and other contributors that regularly skewer right-wing movements and conservatives with political commentary steeped in irony.
headline: For Political Cartoonists, the Irony Was That Facebook Didn’t Recognize Irony

abstract: The playwright Michael R. Jackson describes his musical as “a big, Black and queer-ass American Broadway show.”
lead_paragraph: “A Strange Loop,” Michael R. Jackson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning meta-musical, is coming to Broadway this spring.
headline: ‘A Strange Loop’ Won the Pulitzer. Now It’s Coming to Broadway.

abstract: The covert and coordinated campaign was disclosed in a new report that also addressed misinformation, fake accounts and moderation struggles.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, 1,704 TikTok accounts made a coordinated and covert effort to influence public discourse about the war in Ukraine, the company said on Thursday.
headline: Influence Networks in Russia Misled European Users, TikTok Says

abstract: The group is looking into the Chinese-owned video site for the harms it may pose to younger users.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of state attorneys general announced on Wednesday that it had opened an investigation into TikTok and potential harms that the popular social media app may pose to younger users.
headline: A coalition of state attorneys general opens an investigation into TikTok.

abstract: Recreating the human face could give virtual interactions the sense of intimacy they’re missing.
lead_paragraph: Decades ago, Steve Perlman’s technology helped kick-start an era in which figments of Hollywood imagination feel increasingly authentic.
headline: Metaverse Lessons From Hollywood

abstract: Shou Zi Chew is testifying for
lead_paragraph: Shou Chew, TikTok’s chief executive, is appearing for the first time on Thursday before Congress, as the solo witness in a hearing about the dangers of the video app. TikTok is owned by the Chinese internet giant ByteDance, which has prompted concerns that the app could share sensitive data from American users with the Chinese government.
headline: Who Is Shou Chew, TikTok’s Chief Executive?

abstract: Social media worsened a migrant crisis on the border of Belarus and Poland and helped smugglers profit off desperate people trying to reach Europe.
lead_paragraph: BRUZGI, Belarus — After more than a week sleeping in a frigid encampment on the border between Belarus and Poland, and an abortive foray across the frontier repelled by pepper spray and police batons, Mohammad Faraj gave up this month and retreated to a warm hotel in Minsk, the capital of Belarus.
headline: How Fake News on Facebook Helped Fuel a Border Crisis in Europe

abstract: Despair in the winter months can point to a serious condition. Experts recommend light boxes, earlier wake-up times and therapy.
lead_paragraph: Seeing friends was normally the highlight of Kendra Sands’ week. One night in January 2018, she had plans to meet two for dinner, but instead, Ms. Sands, who lives in Charlotte, N.C., crawled into bed. She wanted to go out, but she was stuck in a dark room, sobbing.
headline: How to Recognize and Address Seasonal Depression

abstract: The suit, filed by the now defunct photo start-up Phhhoto, accused the social network of stalling on a deal and then putting it out of business.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, downloaded a popular new app, Phhhoto, on Aug. 8, 2014, and took a selfie. Other Facebook executives and product managers soon followed suit. The social network then made overtures to integrate Phhhoto.
headline: Facebook Faces New Antitrust Lawsuit

abstract: His protean “Assembly,” at the Park Avenue Armory, bridges art, technology, performance, workshops — and offers an A.I. Being who will teach you how to vogue.
lead_paragraph: One of Rashaad Newsome’s greatest contributions to contemporary art has been to highlight and champion vogueing — a stylized form of dance invented by pioneers of Black and trans culture whose ideas have gone mainstream in America.
headline: Rashaad Newsome Pulls Out All the Stops

abstract: Mr. Musk has not been a responsible caretaker for the companies he already oversees.
lead_paragraph: Twitter has never been a place for rational, nuanced speech. Expect it to get much, much worse.
headline: Twitter Under Elon Musk Will Be a Scary Place

abstract: Culture, including music and social media, can be an important medium for financial education.
lead_paragraph: Flau’jae, the 20-year-old star of basketball and hip-hop, does not manage $1.3 trillion in assets for clients. She also does not have an army of financial advisers and economists at her disposal. But when an organization that does have all of that — the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, known as TIAA — needed to reach young people and minorities, it was Flau’jae and some of her fellow celebrities that it turned to for help.
headline: Flau’jae and Wyclef Jean Are Rapping About Personal Finance. Good.

abstract: Devastated at the height of the pandemic, cruise lines have become top performers.
lead_paragraph: Many top performers in the stock market for the first half of this year were exactly what you would expect, if you’ve been following the news.
headline: Look at the Stocks Leading the Market Now

abstract: Mark Zuckerberg’s company recorded its biggest daily market gain in nearly a decade, as the mood brightens among tech investors.
lead_paragraph: Meta’s stock surged on Thursday after the company reported better-than-expected earnings, said it would buy back billions of dollars in its stock, and overcame a court challenge to its ambitions in the so-called metaverse.
headline: Meta Soars by Most in Decade, Adding $100 Billion in Value

abstract: The Outer Sunset’s success reflects how some cities have evolved during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The succulent-adorned parklet outside of Hook Fish was filled on a recent Friday afternoon with customers enjoying a late lunch of $17 burritos with carrot hot sauce. Shoppers perused the racks at Mollusk Surf Shop and enjoyed coffee in the newly renovated backyard of the Black Bird Bookstore. Others wandered farther down Irving Street, littered with children’s scooters and discarded helmets, to walk along the shoreline.
headline: While Downtown Flounders, This San Francisco Neighborhood Is Thriving

abstract: The losses in tech stocks and bonds is wrecking investor portfolios, and analysts warn of more sell-offs.
lead_paragraph: Technology stocks have long been seen as the market’s most rewarding but riskiest investments. Bonds have the opposite reputation. This year, both have ended up in the same place — deep in the red.
headline: The Markets Face a Rare Double Decline

abstract: Our critic recommends old and new books
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,
headline: Monkeys, Mysteries and Murder

abstract: Plus, China bans some U.S. chips.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has tacitly acknowledged that Russia has seized Bakhmut: A Ukrainian official said today that Russian forces are engaged in “mopping up” operations to clear the remaining Ukrainian soldiers in the city — even as Kyiv seeks to shift the focus from the apparent loss to the battle for the city’s outskirts.
headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Bakhmut in Ruins

abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced cryptocurrency executive, pleads not guilty to an array of charges. A bumpy road ahead for Tesla. And the latest inflation figures are coming out.
lead_paragraph: After many consecutive months of jobs reports showing strong gains, new jobs data on Friday appeared to begin breaking the mold. The economy gained 223,000 jobs last month, a slight decline from the November total of 263,000, which was similar to the September and October numbers. The gradual slowdown is good news for officials at the Federal Reserve, who have long been waiting for a sign that their efforts to cool off the economy are having an effect on the labor market as they fight rapid price increases. But 223,000 is still a comfortable pace of growth, and the central bank has its eye on a much lower target of 100,000 jobs a month.
headline: The Week in Business: Slowing Job Growth

abstract: Plus the future of salmon farming.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is considering a trip to Israel in the coming days to demonstrate American solidarity. The trip would be a remarkable gamble and could tie Biden and the U.S. to bloodshed in Gaza.
headline: Tuesday Briefing: Biden Weighs a Visit to Israel

abstract: He isn’t rapping on his new LP. But he showed his skills on these tracks.
lead_paragraph: After announcing a new album just a few days ago, André 3000 has released his solo debut, “New Blue Sun.” Coming nearly two decades into his rap duo Outkast’s long hiatus, the album’s mere existence is surprising enough. But here’s an understatement: It is not what most people were expecting from the man behind hits as disparately brilliant as “Ms. Jackson,” “B.O.B.” and “Hey Ya!,” who is arguably one of the most skilled and beloved rappers of his generation. It’s actually not a rap album at all. It is, in fact, an 88-minute instrumental album of ambient woodwind compositions.
headline: 7 Great André 3000 Guest Verses

abstract: The company said its financial results in the most recent quarter were about in line with the expectations of investors.
lead_paragraph: Uber said on Tuesday that its revenue grew 29 percent in its most recent quarter as the company benefited from a series of investments in new services, as well as the continued return of drivers to its ride-hailing business.
headline: Uber’s Revenue Up 29% as U.S. Ride-Hailing Business Improves

abstract: Alex Bajcz schemes up a rhythmic Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Alex Bajcz, roughly pronounced “badges,” is one of those constructors who pops up with a gem, then vanishes for too long; this is his sixth construction since 2014, and his second Sunday. He’s a busy guy, an assistant professor of biology and environmental science at Drew University, in New Jersey, who’s currently researching fruiting plants.
headline: Oh, Fourpeat’s Sake!

abstract: The Super Bowl will feature commercial breaks that embrace the usual jokes and celebrities plus a whole lot of blockchain.
lead_paragraph: [Read how the Los Angeles Rams won the Super Bowl.]
headline: Prepare Yourself for This Weekend’s ‘Crypto Bowl’

abstract: Hear tracks by Soccer Mommy, Tems, Floating Points and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
headline: Plant and Krauss Cover a Led Zeppelin Classic, and 12 More New Songs

abstract: The implications of Israel’s attack on Iran.
lead_paragraph: After a week of tense internal deliberation and international appeals for calm, Israel struck an air defense system in Iran on Friday, according to Western and Iranian officials. Israel’s airstrike was the latest in an exchange of attacks between the countries.
headline: Monday Briefing

abstract: Election losses leave U.S. Democrats reeling.
lead_paragraph: Virginia has a Republican governor for the first time in more than a decade after an election on Tuesday, dimming U.S. Democrats’ hopes for midterm elections.
headline: Your Thursday Briefing

abstract: The June 20, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Leslie Kean. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Leslie Kean

abstract: ConocoPhillips has agreed to buy Marathon Oil for $22.5 billion, as consolidation in the U.S. energy sector shows little sign of slowing down.
lead_paragraph: Bullish predictions for $100 crude oil may not have come to fruition, but that hasn’t stopped the deal frenzy in the fossil fuel sector.
headline: Another Big Oil Deal Despite Regulatory Pushback and Market Volatility

abstract: The sheer amount of tech tools and knowledge required to discreetly seek an abortion underlines how wide open we are to surveillance.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the post-Roe era of digital privacy, a moment that underscores how the use of technology has made it practically impossible for Americans to evade ubiquitous tracking.
headline: In a Post-Roe World, the Future of Digital Privacy Looks Even Grimmer

abstract: Companies like the celebrity-endorsed Prenuvo claim they can revolutionize preventive health care. Experts warn this might not be the right approach.
lead_paragraph: For $2,499, Prenuvo will try to predict your future. The company offers a roughly hourlong session of magnetic resonance imaging, or M.R.I., that scans your entire body, searching for early signs of cancer, aneurysms, liver diseases and even multiple sclerosis.
headline: The New Status Symbol Is a Full-Body M.R.I.

abstract: The Center for Countering Digital Hate said it had received a letter from X, Twitter’s parent company, accusing it of trying to hurt the social platform with its research.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has over the last year threatened legal action against tech competitors, employees and people who use Twitter, which he owns. Now he is also taking aim at an organization that studies hate speech and misinformation on social media.
headline: Twitter Sues Nonprofit That Tracks Hate Speech

abstract: Car manufacturers must now raise labor costs as they confront slower-than-expected demand for electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: In reaching a tentative contract with the U.A.W., Ford has moved to make peace with restive employees, one of the most costly problems it has faced in recent years.
headline: What Ford’s Labor Deal Might Mean for the Auto Industry

abstract: In his haunting new play, Branden Jacobs-Jenkins updates the reunion genre with too much jungle juice and an otherworldly visitor.
lead_paragraph: School reunions, like work and family ones, are fertile ground for dramatists, offering an excuse to gather disparate characters with a catalog of ready-made conflicts. (There’s always someone who got dumped, dissed or disowned x years ago.) Add alcohol or pot to fuel the resurgence of old feelings and loosen the tongue, then let the heavy compression of the timeline, just a weekend or even a night, do the rest.
headline: Review: In ‘The Comeuppance,’ a Bigger, Chillier Big Chill

abstract: The chief executive of OpenAI, which makes ChatGPT, has met with at least 100 U.S. lawmakers in recent months. He has also taken his show abroad.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after OpenAI released its ChatGPT chatbot last year, Sam Altman, the chief executive of the artificial intelligence start-up, launched a lobbying blitz in Washington.
headline: How Sam Altman Stormed Washington to Set the A.I. Agenda

abstract: The move comes after Twitter and Facebook shut down misleading accounts that they determined were sending messages to promote U.S. foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials told the military that they were concerned about its efforts to spread pro-American messaging on social media, prompting the Pentagon to order a review of secretive operations to influence populations overseas, U.S. officials said.
headline: Pentagon Orders Review of Its Overseas Social Media Campaigns

abstract: Need a Covid rapid test? One solution is to work for the right big company.
lead_paragraph: As the Omicron variant of the coronavirus surges across the country, tests are in short supply. But for a select group of employees at corporate America’s largest firms, tests are free and often readily available. These companies have been buying tests in bulk, some as part of their return-to-office protocols and others as a perk to offer workers peace of mind — even for those not yet coming into the office.
headline: The Newest Corporate Perk

abstract: The suit, filed with the Authors Guild, accuses the A.I. company of infringing on authors’ copyrights, claiming it used their books to train its ChatGPT chatbot.
lead_paragraph: A group of prominent novelists, including John Grisham, Jonathan Franzen and Elin Hilderbrand, are joining the legal battle against OpenAI over its chatbot technology, as fears about the encroachment of artificial intelligence on creative industries continue to grow.
headline: Franzen, Grisham and Other Prominent Authors Sue OpenAI

abstract: After I’ve struggled with anorexia and bulimia for more than 20 years, the last thing I want is technology that further estranges me from my body.
lead_paragraph: When Mark Zuckerberg announced the rebranding of Facebook to Meta late last month in a “founder’s letter,” I was on a video call with my writing group, discussing the tactile joys of our craft — the benefits of writing by hand, our love of beautiful Rhodia writing pads, our favorite examples of manuscript pages (mine: David Foster Wallace’s, reeking of chew). Among the three of us, we owned five typewriters and no social media accounts. There we were in the metaverse, longing for the one thing it can’t provide: the experience of touch.
headline: We’re Longing for the One Thing the Metaverse Can’t Give Us

abstract: Mr. Hanks and the CBS anchor Gayle King both said their likenesses were used in unauthorized advertisements, as worries have grown over the unregulated use of artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Tom Hanks and Gayle King, a co-host of “CBS Mornings,” have separately warned their followers on social media that videos using artificial intelligence likenesses of them were being used for fraudulent advertisements.
headline: Tom Hanks Warns of Dental Ad Using A.I. Version of Him

abstract: Aerobic exercise is hugely beneficial for health. But research increasingly shows you also need some resistance training. Here’s how to work it in.
lead_paragraph: Anh Bui’s main focus as a physical therapist is to treat and prevent running injuries. Her most common prescription for patients? Lifting weights.
headline: Your Workout Routine Isn’t Complete Without Strength Training

abstract: The actor narrates Ann Patchett’s sentimental new novel, “Tom Lake,” about a Midwestern family.
lead_paragraph: Deciding what audiobook to listen to requires its own special calculus, related to but distinct from the factors we consider when picking a book off a shelf. From the Book Review’s own endless listening, we will select and review a different title each week, from a range of genres, to help you decide. See you next Friday.
headline: Audiobook of the Week: Meryl Streep Would Like to Tell You a Story

abstract: The company has publicly released its latest technology so people can build their own chatbots. Rivals like OpenAI and Google argue that approach can be dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Mistral AI, a Paris start-up founded seven months ago by researchers from Meta and Google, has raised 385 million euros, or about $415 million, in yet another sign of feverish interest in a new kind of artificial intelligence that drives online chatbots.
headline: Mistral, French A.I. Start-Up, Is Valued at $2 Billion in Funding Round

abstract: Tech companies really want their employees to be happy — or at least less annoyed — about returning. So they’re providing concerts, food trucks and other perks.
lead_paragraph: When Google employees returned to their mostly empty offices this month, they were told to relax. Office time should be “not only productive but also fun.” Explore the place a little. Don’t book back-to-back meetings.
headline: Welcome Back to the Office. Isn’t This Fun?

abstract: With a little help from celebrities and influencers, the health food store became the place to see and be seen.
lead_paragraph: Angelenos have long known that health is wealth, and the healthiest and wealthiest among them shop at Erewhon, the upscale organic grocery store with six locations throughout Los Angeles County.
headline: How Erewhon Became L.A.’s Hottest Hangout

abstract: Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, wrote on his Threads platform that Elon Musk did not seem “serious” about the much-ballyhooed match.
lead_paragraph: The will-they-or-won’t-they drama between Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg over a potential “cage fight” appeared on Sunday to end with a whimper, as Mr. Zuckerberg said that Mr. Musk’s delays and excuses had rendered the discussion moot.
headline: Zuckerberg Says It’s ‘Time to Move On’ From ‘Cage Fight’ With Musk

abstract: The effort by Senators Richard Blumenthal and Josh Hawley is the latest move by lawmakers to catch up with the rapidly evolving technology.
lead_paragraph: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, and Senator Josh Hawley, Republican of Missouri, plan to announce a sweeping framework to regulate artificial intelligence, in the latest effort by Congress to catch up with the technology.
headline: 2 Senators Propose Bipartisan Framework for A.I. Laws

abstract: Meta’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, called 2023 the “year of efficiency,” a pronouncement that is reassuring investors and sparking a wider rally in tech stocks.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of a mammoth day for tech earnings, investors already like what they see.
headline: Investors Cheer Meta’s Slimmed-Down Ambitions

abstract: Alphabet, Exxon Mobil, UPS and others gave shareholders reasons to stay optimistic.
lead_paragraph: We are almost at the halfway point for earnings season, and jittery investors are looking to corporate financial reports for direction after inflation, geopolitics and other worries dragged down markets last month. It’s been a different story in the past few days, though, as robust earnings reports steadied nerves.
headline: Investors See Hope in Big Corporate Profits

abstract: Experts say the pandemic and resulting changes in the working world may be encouraging people to rethink how essential passion for your job really is.
lead_paragraph: Follow your passion. It’s perhaps the most common advice given to job seekers. The implication: You can only be your best at work when you’re doing something you truly love.
headline: Is Following Your Work Passion Overrated?

abstract: Data shows that the U.S. economy has been largely resilient. The Fed may slow its rate increases. And the jobs report is expected to show solid gains.
lead_paragraph: What began as a wave of ominous job cuts by technology companies is rippling through other industries, most recently media and retail. In the last week alone, layoffs, or reports of coming layoffs, have swept The Washington Post, Vox and Saks.com. Adding to the tens of thousands of unemployed tech workers, Spotify said on Monday that it was cutting 6 percent of its work force, or about 600 employees, and IBM announced on Wednesday that it would shed 3,900. Tech’s challenges may be somewhat particular to the sector — employers have largely pointed to overhiring during the pandemic as a reason for the recent cuts — but its upheaval can be an indicator of where the economy is heading. Yet even as layoffs appear to creep across the job market, unemployment claims overall remain low, and millions of jobs are open across the country.
headline: The Week in Business: Creeping Layoffs

abstract: New start-ups and other social platforms sense opportunity as Twitter grapples with changes from Elon Musk, its new owner.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last month, employees at Meta, which owns Facebook and Instagram, joined a virtual brainstorming session to discuss how to build the next Twitter.
headline: Twitter’s Rivals Try to Capitalize on Musk-Induced Chaos

abstract: Scrolling past ads has rarely been enjoyable. But in recent months, people say the experience seems so much worse.
lead_paragraph: Portia Kapraun has always seen unwelcome ads on Twitter, usually from major brands pitching her luxury jewelry or vehicles that she, as a librarian in Indiana, could not afford.
headline: Why Are You Seeing So Many Bad Digital Ads Now?

abstract: Matthew Stock and Finn Vigeland put on a cinematic spectacle, with a little something extra.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is the first collaboration between two makers of memorable Sunday puzzles, although they’ve been in touch since meeting at a crossword competition in 2018. Finn Vigeland is a transportation planner in Washington, D.C.; Matthew Stock works for a math education nonprofit in East St. Louis, Ill., and is moving to Florida next month to teach eighth-grade math.
headline: Bonus Features

abstract: The New York Times is sharing its current choices, including world-class Korean barbecue, Mission-style burritos and quintessential California cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Where’s the best place to eat?
headline: Our Favorite Restaurants in San Francisco

abstract: Sean Baker prefers a cast with a mix of experience levels. That was never more true than on “Red Rocket,” where many of the performers had never worked on a movie.
lead_paragraph: The leading man in “Red Rocket” made his name as a comic rapper and an MTV video jockey. His character’s wife is played by a longtime theater actress with almost no film experience. And the supporting players include the ex-proprietor of a New Orleans bar and a downsized refinery worker. One woman won a role after her car broke down and she needed a jump.
headline: In His Films, Big Roles Go to Passers-by and Professionals Alike

abstract: Apple says its new Vision Pro headset will “shift the way we look at technology.” How about how we look?
lead_paragraph: They talked about the optics. They talked about the computer specs. They talked about the “lenticular glass” and the “new spatial computing platform” and the “aluminum alloy” used in the “primary structural element.”
headline: But Would You Wear It?

abstract: Here we go again: Virtual reality, now called “the metaverse,” will be a thing. So will the smart home.
lead_paragraph: Each year, I look ahead at what’s new in consumer technology to guide you through what you might expect to buy — and what will most likely be a fad.
headline: The Tech That Will Invade Our Lives in 2022

abstract: Ask the founders of Roman and Williams, who for two decades have designed homes, hotels, restaurants, clubs, galleries, stores, furniture — even birdhouses — bathed in a luxe patina.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Ace Hotel New York. The Chicago Athletic Association. The NoMad hotel in London. Goop’s store in Los Angeles. The Reykjavik Edition hotel, in Iceland. The Boom Boom Room.
headline: What Makes a Room Unforgettable?

abstract: The agency plans to scrutinize Microsoft, Amazon and Google for their investments in the A.I. start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission opened an inquiry on Thursday into the multibillion-dollar investments by Microsoft, Amazon and Google in the artificial intelligence start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic, broadening the regulator’s efforts to corral the power the tech giants can have over A.I.
headline: Federal Trade Commission Launches Inquiry Into A.I. Deals by Tech Giants

abstract: A sell-off in Meta’s stock after the company disclosed huge investments in the technology may be a sign of investor fears about tech giants’ spending.
lead_paragraph: Meta just reported its best-ever first-quarter earnings. But for investors, that’s not enough — and that’s a warning to other tech giants set to announce their own financial results in the coming days.
headline: Wall Street’s Patience for a Costly A.I. Arms Race Is Waning

abstract: As part of a broader campaign against anticompetitive practices, the Biden administration has taken on the chicken industry. Why have the results been so paltry?
lead_paragraph: At Kentucky Fried Chicken, sales tend to peak at the same time every year: Mother’s Day. This has been the case since the 1960s, when the chain began to experiment with TV advertising. In a spot from that era, a man in an office answers a phone call from an anonymous male narrator who asks, “Sir, do you have any idea what your wife has to do to run your house?” Cut to a sped-up montage of an impeccably dressed 30-something as she dusts, irons, vacuums and balances the checkbook. Newly enlightened, the husband shows his appreciation by stopping at Kentucky Fried Chicken on his way home. Cut to a close-up of a happy wife biting into a drumstick. “Colonel Sanders fixes Sunday dinner seven days a week, and it’s finger-lickin’ good.”
headline: The Chicken Tycoons vs. the Antitrust Hawks

abstract: This is a good time to think more broadly about Big Tech’s business models.
lead_paragraph: When is free not free?
headline: You Know the Saying: You Are the Product

abstract: Companies partially pulling out of the country are under pressure to make a cleaner break.
lead_paragraph: As Western governments ratchet up their economic punishments against Russia after it invaded Ukraine, the corporate world has paused or pulled out of operations there. But as the list of companies quitting Russia grows by the day, differences in the degree of disconnection are spurring debate.
headline: Are Big Businesses In or Out of Russia?

abstract: Worries of higher-for-longer interest rates have grown since Tuesday’s Consumer Price Index report.
lead_paragraph: Markets are still on edge after Tuesday’s hot inflation report, as Wall Street suddenly and sharply discounted the odds of imminent interest rate cuts.
headline: Rethinking the Prospects of a ‘Soft Landing’

abstract: Also, the U.N. passed a resolution for an immediate cease-fire. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump was handed a lifeline today when a panel of judges in New York ruled that he no longer had to post a nearly half-billion-dollar bond in order to appeal his civil fraud case. The judges gave Trump 10 days to secure a much smaller $175 million bond.
headline: Trump Dodged Financial Ruin, but Failed to Delay His Trial

abstract: Wall Street’s most closely watched succession saga ended with the selection of Ted Pick as the bank’s next leader. But he now must keep the momentum going.
lead_paragraph: One of Wall Street’s most closely watched succession races is over as Ted Pick prepares to become Morgan Stanley’s next chief executive. He will take the baton in January from James Gorman, who since 2010 has transformed the firm from an investment bank into an asset-management behemoth.
headline: Morgan Stanley’s Post-Gorman Era Begins

abstract: More Americans than ever are buying fancy phones and laptops. Will it last?
lead_paragraph: By choice or necessity, Americans have fallen for fancier smartphones, televisions, laptops and cars. The companies that make this stuff are trying to assess whether the shift to luxury is a temporary phenomenon or a new normal.
headline: Want a Value-Priced Gadget? Good Luck.

abstract: In a series of tweets on Monday, Mr. Musk accused Apple of threatening to pull Twitter from its App Store and of trying to censor.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — “What’s going on here @tim_cook?” Elon Musk tweeted on Monday to Tim Cook, the chief executive of Apple, igniting a spat between the world’s richest man and the world’s most valuable public company.
headline: Elon Musk Takes On Apple’s Power, Setting Up a Clash

abstract: Mark Zuckerberg delivered bad news for shareholders of Facebook’s parent company.
lead_paragraph: Lately, Mark Zuckerberg has been redirecting investors’ attention away from Facebook’s existing social media platforms and toward the exciting future of virtual worlds in the metaverse. (The company is now called Meta, after all.)
headline: Meta’s ‘Unmitigated Disaster’ of a Quarter

abstract: Plus Ukraine updates, a U.S.-Iran World Cup preview and a “She Said” interview.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, protesters gathered in the cold in Beijing, calling for an end to coronavirus restrictions. “We don’t want lockdowns, we want freedom!” they shouted.
headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Anxiety in China

abstract: Opening arguments in a case tied to the 1MDB bribery scandal will begin today.
lead_paragraph: Today, the onetime banker Roger Ng is set to stand trial in a Brooklyn courtroom over allegations that he abetted the looting of the huge Malaysian state fund known as 1MDB. The legal proceedings will resurrect a scandal that saw $4 billion stolen from the Malaysian government and tarnished the reputation of Ng’s former employer, Goldman Sachs.
headline: A Dark Moment for Goldman Sachs Goes to Trial

abstract: Alina Abidi paints the town red (and blue).
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — This is just to sayI have solvedAlina Abidi’s debutthat was inThe New York Times
headline: This Is Just to Say

abstract: Mr. Musk, the owner of Twitter, is the latest Silicon Valley mogul to pursue an all-in-one app, the kind that has thrived in Asia but not elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, a billionaire tech executive leading one of the world’s pre-eminent social platforms laid out a vision to transform it into an app that could do it all. In an online manifesto, he wrote that the app would not only be central to written communications but have audio, video, payments, commerce and more.
headline: Elon Musk’s Quixotic Quest to Turn X Into an ‘Everything App’

abstract: Shares in the Swiss banking giant tumbled after its executive team laid out the details of a long-awaited restructuring plan.
lead_paragraph: After months of anticipation, Credit Suisse’s plan to revamp itself — with an eye toward making its long-troubled businesses smaller and less risky — is here. What has emerged from a strategic review is a drastic downsizing and a retreat from high finance.
headline: Credit Suisse Plans a Big Retreat From Wall Street

abstract: The Supreme Court will hear arguments in April on a question it once ducked: whether intent counts in criminal cases based on online threats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time the Supreme Court considered what the First Amendment has to say about threats, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. found himself reciting lyrics from the rapper Eminem.
headline: When Do Creepy Facebook Messages Cross a Constitutional Line?

abstract: The Supreme Court heard oral arguments yesterday on one of the biggest cases of the current term.
lead_paragraph: Now that abortion is restricted and affirmative action is hobbled, the conservative legal movement has set its sights on a third precedent: Chevron v. Natural Resources Defense Council.
headline: How Much Power Should Government Experts Have?

abstract: Google’s parent company reported that sales climbed 13 percent to $86.3 billion while profit jumped 52 percent.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, on Tuesday reported search revenue and a profit margin for its latest quarter that fell short of Wall Street’s expectations, in a sign that growth in its flagship business and recent layoffs, intended to cut costs, were not enough to offset its growing investment in artificial intelligence.
headline: Alphabet’s Search Revenue Disappoints in Fourth Quarter

abstract: Step 1: Connect to Wi-Fi.
lead_paragraph: Your cell network is down. Maybe it’s AT&T, which went down for many users on Thursday. Or maybe it’s another service a week, a month or a year from now.
headline: How to Make a Call When Your Cell Network Is Down

abstract: For a fee, the app will allow businesses to build a custom dashboard so they can chat with customers and offer customer services more easily.
lead_paragraph: More than eight years after agreeing to buy one of the world’s largest messaging apps, the company formerly known as Facebook has decided to start making money from it.
headline: WhatsApp introduces commercial services as Meta, its parent, seeks fresh revenue.

abstract: The social network has contacted academics to create a group to advise it on thorny election-related decisions, said people with knowledge of the matter.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has approached academics and policy experts about forming a commission to advise it on global election-related matters, said five people with knowledge of the discussions, a move that would allow the social network to shift some of its political decision-making to an advisory body.
headline: Facebook Said to Consider Forming an Election Commission

abstract: Two shows with Broadway aspirations, “Once Upon a One More Time” and “A Strange Loop,” represent opposite extremes of what a big, mainstream production can be.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sidney Harman Hall was bustling before a recent matinee of “Once Upon a One More Time,” a revisionist fairy tale mash-up scored with Britney Spears songs at Shakespeare Theater Company here. People were taking group selfies at one of two step-and-repeats. A few girls — and women — tittered in tiaras. Purple T-shirts and tote bags with the show’s title and the names of storybook princesses were being sold. And the theater, which has a capacity of about 700, had no empty seats in sight. At least from the outside, “Once Upon a One More Time” looked like the kind of splashy show you might find on Broadway.
headline: In Washington, a Princess Party and a Carnival of Self-Loathing

abstract: The law, aimed at forcing social media giants to adopt new policies to curb harmful content, is expected to face blowback from Elon Musk, who owns X.
lead_paragraph: The Facebook page in Slovakia called Som z dediny, which means “I’m from the village,” trumpeted a debunked Russian claim last month that Ukraine’s president had secretly purchased a vacation home in Egypt under his mother-in-law’s name.
headline: E.U. Law Sets the Stage for a Clash Over Disinformation

abstract: Shop Talk examines the business jargon used by executives to elevate ordinary functions and conceal ugly truths.
lead_paragraph: Perusing LinkedIn might not seem like the typical way to spend your downtime. But for Lora Kelley, a New York Times business reporting fellow interested in the ways business shapes culture, the platform is a gold mine for reporting ideas.
headline: A Column That Listens for What’s Not Being Said

abstract: For the 29th time, the Swatch Group brand will be timing the events — and introducing some new technology — at the Tokyo Games.
lead_paragraph: It may be a year late, but the Olympic flame was scheduled to be lit in Tokyo last night, heralding a season of elite sport — and intense marketing activity. It is expected that more than half the world’s 7.9 billion people will follow the Games, making it one of the world’s most powerful marketing platforms.
headline: Omega Returns to the Olympics

abstract: It has long had technology to rival chatbots like ChatGPT, but can’t afford to back artificial intelligence that can spread misinformation and toxic content.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Two weeks before a chatbot called ChatGPT appeared on the internet in November and wowed the world, Meta, the owner of Facebook, WhatsApp and Instagram, unveiled a chatbot of its own.
headline: Meta, Long an A.I. Leader, Tries Not to Be Left Out of the Boom

abstract: Experts say Americans are taking more walks than before the pandemic. Here are some ways to turn your neighborhood stroll in to an exciting workout.
lead_paragraph: At 76 years old, Judy Fog is one of the fittest people her daughter knows. Take, for instance, her VO2 max — a common fitness metric that measures how much oxygen one can absorb while exercising.
headline: 6 Ways to Level Up Your Daily Walk

abstract: A tricky challenge for Black playwrights: offering deliverance, even hope, while staying truthful about real-life tragedy.
lead_paragraph: In “Soft,” Donja R. Love’s affecting new play at MCC Theater, a teenager wonders where Black boys go when they die. By the end the audience gets the answer: a haven overgrown with flowers where Black boys can truly be themselves.
headline: Onstage, Paradise for Black Characters Often Comes With a Price

abstract: With the deal, the largest in the software maker’s history, Microsoft will acquire Activision’s huge pool of users and access to some of the world’s most popular games.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft plans to buy the powerhouse but troubled video game company Activision Blizzard for nearly $70 billion, its biggest deal ever and one that places a major bet that people will be spending more and more time in the digital world.
headline: Microsoft will buy Activision Blizzard, betting $70 billion on the future of games.

abstract: We have the latest chapter on the C.D.C.’s description of outdoor Covid risks.
lead_paragraph: This morning, I am going to tell you another story about the C.D.C. and its approach to Covid-19 behavioral guidelines. It’s a story that highlights the costs of extreme caution.
headline: A New C.D.C. Story

abstract: Jeff Horwitz’s “Broken Code” draws on 25,000 pages of internal documents to reveal the company’s tumultuous inner workings — and their devastating impact on humanity.
lead_paragraph: In a welcome departure from the subgenre of stories about Facebook, Jeff Horwitz’s “Broken Code” doesn’t open in a Harvard dorm room. Expanding on the revelations of his blockbuster “Facebook Files” series of articles in The Wall Street Journal, the book focuses squarely on the past decade. It begins when Facebook is already a global behemoth with a user count in the billions — and a company ethos that has yet to account for its capacity to effect enormous social and political change.
headline: Inside Facebook’s Dangerous Battle Between Integrity and Engagement

abstract: Basketball and tennis are the subjects of two top titles written by stars in their own fields.
lead_paragraph: SLAM DUNK This week’s batch of new best sellers includes two very different titles involving athletics. On the nonfiction side at No. 7, we have “Where Tomorrows Aren’t Promised,” a memoir by Carmelo Anthony, who plays as No. 7 for the Los Angeles Lakers. Written with D. Watkins, author of several books of his own, including “We Speak for Ourselves: How Woke Culture Prohibits Progress,” the account is dedicated “to every child who knows there is more to this life than people tell them is possible.” It begins in Brooklyn, where Anthony was born, with the view from his family’s apartment: “After pushing our old speaker against the wall and climbing my small body on top of it, I could peer through the black iron bars.” Anthony describes “hoopers, dreamers, rappers,” older kids “trading dope for cash,” girls playing jacks and his sister, Michelle, doing double Dutch “with ballerina footwork.” As his view widens, readers get to see the rest of his family, their move to Baltimore, their losses and challenges and Anthony’s road to the N.B.A. Fun fact: Anthony isn’t the only best-selling Laker right now. LeBron James’s book, “We Are Family,” is No. 4 on the middle grade hardcover list. Perhaps No. 7 and No. 6 will have a reading together?
headline: Readers Aren’t Into Sports? The Best-Seller List Says Otherwise.

abstract: OpenAI’s GPT-3 and other neural nets can now write original prose with mind-boggling fluency — a development that could have profound implications for the future.
lead_paragraph: You are sitting in a comfortable chair by the fire, on a cold winter’s night. Perhaps you have a mug of tea in hand, perhaps something stronger. You open a magazine to an article you’ve been meaning to read. The title suggested a story about a promising — but also potentially dangerous — new technology on the cusp of becoming mainstream, and after reading only a few sentences, you find yourself pulled into the story. A revolution is coming in machine intelligence, the author argues, and we need, as a society, to get better at anticipating its consequences. But then the strangest thing happens: You notice that the writer has, seemingly deliberately, omitted the very last word of the first                   .
headline: A.I. Is Mastering Language. Should We Trust What It Says?

abstract: A lot hinges on the answer.
lead_paragraph: As Trump rose to the presidency, one explanation that swept political science was the power of polarization, specifically a phenomenon known as affective polarization, but a keen group of scholars now suggests that this approach is inadequate.
headline: How Much Does How Much We Hate Each Other Matter?

abstract: Two studies are giving us insight into the roots of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Two studies published yesterday in Science magazine are giving us insight into the roots of the pandemic.
headline: Where the Covid Outbreak Began

abstract: “Stop using Facebook!” one reader urges. Another admits to a possible addiction but finds it useful. Readers offer varied opinions about the company.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
headline: Just What Is Happening With Facebook?

abstract: The social media giant is making bonkers money. But it aims to turn itself inside out to get more young people.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Facebook Wants the Young People Back

abstract: What happens when a columnist and a reporter use A.I. glasses to scan groceries, monuments and zoo animals? Hilarity, wonder and lots of mistakes ensued.
lead_paragraph: In a sign that the tech industry keeps getting weirder, Meta soon plans to release a big update that transforms the Ray-Ban Meta, its camera glasses that shoot videos, into a gadget seen only in sci-fi movies.
headline: Meta’s Smart Glasses Are Becoming Artificially Intelligent. We Took Them for a Spin.

abstract: The tech giant has changed its playbook this year to rebut criticism, using its algorithm to promote positive stories about itself.
lead_paragraph: Whether on privacy, misinformation, hate speech or changes to its News Feed, Facebook has been embroiled in controversy for most of its existence. Its playbook, no matter the perceived misstep, has remained relatively consistent: Apologize and promise to do better.
headline: Facebook’s Good News

abstract: Adrian Lyne used to make deranged romps animated by conservative masculine anxieties. By the time of “Deep Water,” his muse — the all-powerful white man — had lost his grip.
lead_paragraph: Recently I rented a house upstate for the weekend with a group of friends, all new parents with children under 2. After putting the children to bed, we decided to stage a group viewing of “Deep Water” on Hulu — then spent the next 15 minutes in a state of escalating madness, frantically tossing baby books and upending couch cushions in search of the house’s lost remote control. This was how desperate we were to feel like adults, and to experience a now-rare form of grown-up entertainment: an erotic thriller directed by the master of the genre, Adrian Lyne.
headline: When the Master of the Erotic Thriller Fails to Thrill

abstract: One of the most lasting and influential artistic movements of the 20th century was created with and for Black artists. Why has their contribution been so overlooked?
lead_paragraph: IN DECEMBER OF 1968, the TV show host Ed Sullivan introduced the group Sly and the Family Stone onto his stage. An ensemble of seven Black and white men and women in sequined blazers, platinum wigs and vinyl vests, they played a rapid-fire medley of their most affirming hits: “Everyday People,” “Dance to the Music,” “Sing a Simple Song,” “I Want to Take You Higher.” They had just released their third studio album, “Life” (1968), and everyone looks excited, although Sly Stone alone appears confident that the whole thing will come off. We see why when he leaves the organ and heads out into the studio audience with his sister Rose: After her solo, he performs a dance routine drawn from Africa, patting juba. “We look like we just landed in a spaceship from Venus,” the group’s original drummer, Greg Errico, tells me of the clip. Men in the audience are wearing suits that “weren’t even cool suits — they look like accountants.” Before heading back to the stage, Stone finds what may have been the one Black man in the crowd and slaps him five. If the group couldn’t make any more time for themselves (hence their pack-it-all-in medley), they could make a little more space and, for a moment, paint it Black.
headline: The Radical Experimentation of Black Psychedelia

abstract: Biodiversity loss, global warming, pollution and the spread of invasive species are making infectious diseases more dangerous to organisms around the world.
lead_paragraph: Several large-scale, human-driven changes to the planet — including climate change, the loss of biodiversity and the spread of invasive species — are making infectious diseases more dangerous to people, animals and plants, according to a new study.
headline: Environmental Changes Are Fueling Human, Animal and Plant Diseases, Study Finds

abstract: ‘One Italian Summer’ was inspired by a meaningful encounter during an intergenerational pilgrimage to Positano and Rome.
lead_paragraph: MAMMA MIA What would you give to be able to spend time with your mother as a young woman, before life’s obligations and turning points landed with a thud on her shoulders? In “One Italian Summer,” now in its fourth week on the hardcover fiction list, Rebecca Serle immerses her protagonist in this fantasy. The circumstances are bittersweet for Katy Silver, who proceeds with a long-planned vacation to the Amalfi Coast after Carol, her mother and intended traveling companion, dies of cancer. There, in the lobby of her hotel in Positano, she runs into a 30-year-old incarnation of Carol.
headline: Rebecca Serle Met Her Mom’s Old Boyfriend, Then Wrote a Best Seller

abstract: Meta’s earnings led to a wild swing in stocks. The latest jobs numbers might trigger another.
lead_paragraph: Last week, markets swung wildly on economic news, as investors tried to interpret signals from the Fed about inflation and interest rates. This week, corporate earnings took the spotlight, and things looked steadier — for a while.
headline: What Will Move Markets Now?

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing

abstract: Analysts see Brent crude climbing to levels last seen in the first months of the Ukraine war after Saudi Arabia and Russia extended production cuts.
lead_paragraph: Brent crude oil was trading on Wednesday morning at around $90 a barrel for the second straight day, and is up 25 percent since June thanks to the prospect of more production cuts by leading oil exporters.
headline: $100 Oil? What a Price Spike Could Mean for Markets and Geopolitics

abstract: Andy Parker, the father of a journalist killed in 2015, filed a complaint with the F.T.C. urging it to increase regulation on the tech giant, saying it failed to remove videos of his daughter’s killing.
lead_paragraph: The father of a slain journalist urged federal regulators in a complaint filed Tuesday to make Facebook change how it polices content, accusing it of failing to remove footage of his daughter’s killing from its platforms.
headline: Father of Killed Reporter Asks Regulators to Investigate Facebook

abstract: Sandberg transformed digital advertising and was a voice on big issues, but she also denied problems and deflected blame.
lead_paragraph: It’s not clear how history will judge Sheryl Sandberg.
headline: Sheryl Sandberg’s Legacy

abstract: Plus, small town U.S.A. in “Asteroid City”
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Prigozhin accused the Russian military of attacking his private forces, shortly after he released a scathing video that described the invasion of Ukraine as a “racket” meant to enrich Russia’s corrupt elite.
headline: Wagner’s leader said the Kremlin attacked his forces

abstract: Online hoax allegations are an insult to family members and should be taken down.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost impossible to comprehend what to do in the wake of mass shootings like the one that killed 19 schoolchildren and two teachers in Uvalde, Texas, this week. While there are lots of words — you can listen to my discussion on “Sway” with Nicholas Kristof and Frank Smyth on where we go next on gun control — it can leave an empty feeling, as the sense of hopelessness overwhelms our ability to understand how we got here. The problem is exacerbated by the perpetrators’ use of online tools, which some have used to float phony conspiracy theories.
headline: In the Texas Rampage’s Wake, Social Media Can Reform Itself

abstract: “One minute you get scammed, another minute you’re having the best time of your life, making billions of dollars.”
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of people, I have been scrambling to get a grasp of the metaverse since Mark Zuckerberg made his move to colonize it by rebranding Facebook as Meta last week.
headline: An 8-Year-Old Explains the Metaverse

abstract: Outdoor venues in and around the city are reliable resources for scary movies this summer. Here are our picks, for the squeamish and slasher-lover alike.
lead_paragraph: The outdoors is a terrible place to be if you’re in a horror movie being pursued by a knife-wielding maniac. He’ll always know the woods better than you.
headline: Summer Movies That Deliver Chills and Skyline Views

abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, May 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about an all-women heavy metal band in Indonesia misstated the surname of the band’s bassist. She is Widi Rahmawati, not Rahmati. The article also erroneously attributed a distinction to the group’s tour last year. It was its first in the United States, not its first in the West; the group performed in some European countries earlier.
headline: Corrections: May 2, 2024

abstract: Peter Thiel, one of Donald J. Trump’s biggest donors in 2016, has re-emerged as a prime financier of the Make America Great Again movement.
lead_paragraph: The wine flowed. Donald Trump Jr. mingled with the guests. And Peter Thiel, the tech billionaire and host of the event, had a message for the well-heeled crowd: It was time to clean house.
headline: The Right’s Would-Be Kingmaker

abstract: For all their accomplishments in the past two years, Democrats face a far tougher environment to see most of their priorities through.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats began the year with an ambitious to-do list that included providing billions of dollars in pandemic aid, reviving lapsed expanded payments to most families with children and giving Afghan refugees a pathway to citizenship.
headline: For Democrats, Spending Package Marked One Final Opportunity

abstract: Investors, who have been closely watching company earnings reports for signs of economic headwinds, appeared to zero in on better-than-expected results from Apple.
lead_paragraph: Stocks rallied on Friday, finishing a second consecutive week of gains and adding to a recovery that has come as investors hope the Federal Reserve might indicate next week that it is preparing to slow down on interest rate increases next week.
headline: S&P 500 Rebounds After a Week of Mixed Messages From Big Tech

abstract: Also, a deal to protect the Colorado River. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: The eastern city of Bakhmut, site of the longest and bloodiest battle of the war in Ukraine, is almost entirely obliterated.
headline: With Bakhmut in Ruins, Ukraine Shifts Focus

abstract: A murder mystery on a London houseboat, a 16th-century Pacific voyage, and a deep dive into humans’ relationships with animals.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve found that audiobooks are keeping me up at night. It’s not because I’m devouring them in nocturnal binges, unable to tear myself away. No, I’m losing sleep because I’m thinking about certain audiobooks too much. Like a movie watched just before bed, or a video game played too many times, a good audiobook peppered throughout the day can reverberate long after you have pressed pause. Who’s the murderer? What would I do if I came face to face with a leopard? What must it have been like to be floating in the middle of the Pacific in the 16th century, scurvy-ridden and months from home? These three new audiobooks may provide some answers — but expect a fair share of mental somersaults along the way.
headline: Rosamund Pike Reads Paula Hawkins; and Other Audiobooks to Make Your Head Spin

abstract: In an internal meeting this week, Mr. Zuckerberg said the tech giant was facing one of the “worst downturns that we’ve seen in recent history.”
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg has a message for Meta employees: Buckle up for tough times ahead.
headline: Mark Zuckerberg Prepares Meta Employees for a Tougher 2022

abstract: Wild swings in stocks haven’t shown up in other assets.
