lead_paragraph: Stock markets took investors on another wild ride yesterday, plunging, recovering and then dropping again. Futures are looking up today, but what does that mean after a week of such swings in stocks?
headline: In Some Markets, Cooler Heads Are Prevailing

abstract: “The Headlines,” a show by The New York Times, promises to bring listeners the most noteworthy news of the day in about 10 minutes.
lead_paragraph: What do a Republican presidential debate, Meta’s foray into artificial intelligence and a new musical by the composer Stephen Sondheim, who died in 2021, all have in common?
headline: Need News Fast? Try Listening to Your Headlines.

abstract: Tom Cruise takes to the air once more in a long-awaited sequel to a much-loved ’80s action blockbuster.
lead_paragraph: Every so often in “Top Gun: Maverick,” Pete Mitchell (that’s Maverick) is summoned to a face-to-face with an admiral. Pete, after all these years in the Navy — more than 35, but who’s counting — has stalled at the rank of captain. He’s one of the best fighter pilots ever to take wing, but the U.S. military hierarchy can be a treacherous political business, and Maverick is anything but a politician. In the presence of a superior officer he is apt to salute, smirk and push his career into the middle of the table like a stack of poker chips. He’s all in. Always.
headline: ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ Review: Will This Stuff Still Fly?

abstract: Layoffs and hiring freezes at companies like Amazon and Meta are changing the job market for recent grads and college students. Tell us about your experiences.
lead_paragraph: November was a bleak month for tech workers. Meta, Amazon, Lyft, Stripe and Twitter laid off thousands of employees. Microsoft and Google announced hiring slowdowns.
headline: Are You Applying for Tech Jobs or Internships? We Want to Hear About It.

abstract: The broad nature of Thursday’s decline pointed to more than one reason. Oil prices and yields on government bonds also fell.
lead_paragraph: Stocks slid on Thursday, extending a volatile stretch of trading brought on by uncertainty about inflation, rising interest rates and the potential for war in Europe.
headline: Sell-off of stocks deepens as Ukraine adds to investors’ worries.

abstract: Some lawyers say the changes could make it more difficult to bring legal action against the company.
lead_paragraph: Parents, schools and even attorneys general have increasingly been raising concerns about how TikTok may be hooking children to the app and serving them inappropriate content. But some lawyers say bringing legal action against the company could be more difficult after TikTok quietly changed its U.S. terms of service this summer.
headline: TikTok Quietly Changes User Terms Amid Growing Legal Scrutiny

abstract: Wall Street will closely watch Friday’s nonfarm payrolls report, which could influence the Federal Reserve’s next move on borrowing costs.
lead_paragraph: Bonds have been on an impressive monthlong rally fueled by investors’ hopes that the Fed will begin cutting interest rates next year. That bet may be tested as soon as Friday with the release of new payroll data that Wall Street expects will show the labor market cooling further.
headline: What a Slowing Jobs Market Might Mean for Interest Rates

abstract: Big Tech is reeling from the ouster of Sam Altman at a leading A.I. start-up and his subsequent jump to Microsoft, moves that reset the power dynamic underpinning the sector.
lead_paragraph: Over just three days, the landscape for artificial intelligence has been reshaped drastically. On Friday morning, Sam Altman was the C.E.O. of OpenAI, the leader in commercializing generative A.I. through ChatGPT. By Monday, he had not only been fired by his board — he had also joined Microsoft, the start-up’s biggest backer.
headline: The Shake-up at OpenAI Reshapes the Industry’s Global Order

abstract: Elections have consequences that go beyond the results.
lead_paragraph: Americans casting their ballots in tomorrow’s midterm elections might be voting in their 30th or 40th contest in four years. In the same amount of time, a German citizen might vote in six to eight races.
headline: Does America Vote Too Much?

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing

abstract: Neck pain is common, but working on your posture and strengthening your spine can help.
lead_paragraph: Experts estimate that up to 80 percent of people will experience some form of neck pain in their lives, and as much as half of Americans will suffer from it this year alone.
headline: The Best Exercises to Prevent Neck Pain

abstract: With each Facebook crisis, we become savvier about the influence of tech companies on our lives.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: We’re Smarter About Facebook Now

abstract: Irish regulators said Instagram violated European data protection rules. It was the latest move by authorities in Europe and the U.S. related to child protection online.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Meta was fined roughly $400 million for breaking European Union data privacy laws for its treatment of children’s data on Instagram, the latest in a series of steps by authorities in Europe and the United States to crack down on what information is collected and shared by companies about young people online.
headline: Meta Fined $400 Million for Treatment of Children’s Data on Instagram

abstract: The states argue that Google reached a deal with Facebook to have the social network join its effort in an effort to “kill” a competing ad network.
lead_paragraph: Google’s chief executive approved an agreement with Facebook at the heart of an antitrust lawsuit that 16 states and Puerto Rico have lodged against the search giant, according to a portion of the complaint revealed on Friday.
headline: Google’s chief executive signed off on deal at center of antitrust case, states say.

abstract: Frances Haugen, a former product manager for Facebook, will argue to protect consumers from a profits-over-safety culture.
lead_paragraph: A Facebook whistle-blower is taking her campaign to Washington.
headline: What to watch: Whistle-blower to detail need to regulate Facebook.

abstract: The chipmaker’s high “price to sales” ratio reflects investor enthusiasm around its growth prospects. But relying on that metric created trouble during the dot-com boom.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, after the dot-com bubble burst and Sun Microsystems swooned, the company’s co-founder Scott McNealy highlighted the folly of Wall Street analysts who favored one particular financial metric to gauge a stock’s worth: its price relative to the company’s sales.
headline: Nvidia Is a Must-Buy. Or Is It?

abstract: The A.I. chip maker’s revenue more than tripled, and profits rose ninefold. It also projected that its revenue would more than triple again.
lead_paragraph: Nvidia, the kingpin of chips powering artificial intelligence, on Wednesday released quarterly financial results that reinforced how the company has become one of the biggest winners of the artificial intelligence boom, and it said demand for its products would fuel continued sales growth.
headline: Nvidia Says Growth Will Continue as A.I. Hits ‘Tipping Point’

abstract: Demand for the company’s A.I. chips remains high, but it said new U.S. export restrictions would hurt it sales to countries like China.
lead_paragraph: A start-up driving the artificial intelligence revolution may be in turmoil, but the semiconductor supplier propelling its innovations seems to be getting only stronger.
headline: Nvidia Triples Quarterly Revenue, but Sales in China Are a Concern

abstract: Chafing at their dependence, Amazon, Google, Meta and Microsoft are racing to cut into Nvidia’s dominant share of the market.
lead_paragraph: In September, Amazon said it would invest up to $4 billion in Anthropic, a San Francisco start-up working on artificial intelligence.
headline: Nvidia’s Big Tech Rivals Put Their Own A.I. Chips on the Table

abstract: A.I. fervor has rocketed the chip company’s share price upward. Our columnist asked A.I. chatbots how big Nvidia would become if it kept growing as fast as it had over the past year.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a household name quite yet, but anyone who follows the stock market knows at least a little about Nvidia.
headline: If Nvidia Keeps Rising Like This, It Will Be Bigger Than the Global Economy

abstract: “It’s like if you were told that there’s going to be a world-conquering dictator and it’s Mr. Bean.”
lead_paragraph: A few days after a lawyer used ChatGPT to write a brief filled with made-up cases, a group of A.I. experts released a letter warning of the “risk of extinction” from the technology. But will A.I. ever be good enough to pose such a threat?
headline: A.I.’s Inner Conflict, Nvidia Joins the Trillion-Dollar Club, and Hard Questions

abstract: The chipmaker unveiled a new high-speed processor at its developer conference to power an “industrial revolution,” but its sky-high valuation is coming under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Nvidia’s stock has soared more than fivefold since ChatGPT debuted in November 2022, a rally that has vaulted the chipmaker into the trillion-dollar market cap club on the back of investor fervor for artificial intelligence — and the high-end processors that power these models.
headline: Investors Shrug Off Nvidia’s ‘A.I. Woodstock’

abstract: The chipmaker’s stock has tumbled in recent days, a reminder that the artificial intelligence stock boom could be tough to sustain.
lead_paragraph: It looks like another volatile day for Nvidia shareholders. And given the company’s enormous influence on the entire S&P 500, they may not be the only investors facing big swings.
headline: Inside Nvidia’s $500 Billion Wipeout

abstract: Wall Street is closely watching the semiconductor giant’s earnings report, as questions swirl over its massive stock market valuation on the back of the boom in artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: The stock price of the chip giant Nvidia has marched steadily higher over the past year and a half, propelled by investors’ hopes that artificial intelligence is truly transformative technology — and by their hope that the company’s high-end semiconductors will continue to power that technology.
headline: The Chips Riding on Nvidia

abstract: The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission agreed to divide responsibility for investigating three major players in the artificial intelligence industry.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators have reached a deal that allows them to proceed with antitrust investigations into the dominant roles that Microsoft, OpenAI and Nvidia play in the artificial intelligence industry, in the strongest sign of how regulatory scrutiny into the powerful technology has escalated.
headline: U.S. Clears Way for Antitrust Inquiries of Nvidia, Microsoft and OpenAI

abstract: Jensen Huang said that the chips giant enjoys a decadelong lead over rivals because it didn’t just make chips. It reinvented computers.
lead_paragraph: In the year since OpenAI sparked an artificial intelligence boom with its popular ChatGPT chatbot, start-ups and tech giants have been scrambling to develop semiconductors to power the buzzy technology, hoping to muscle in on Nvidia’s market dominance.
headline: Nvidia C.E.O. Is Not Worried About Rising A.I. Industry Competition

abstract: The deal, which was initially valued at $40 billion, encountered regulatory scrutiny, including an F.T.C. lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Nvidia, the Silicon Valley chip maker, has ended its nearly 18-month effort to buy Arm, which licenses chip technology used in most smartphones.
headline: Nvidia Deal to Buy Arm From SoftBank Is Off After Setbacks

abstract: The proposed deal would give Nvidia control over computing technology and designs that rival firms rely on.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday sued to block Nvidia’s $40 billion acquisition of a fellow chip company, Arm, halting what would be the biggest semiconductor industry deal in history, as federal regulators push to rein in corporate consolidation.
headline: F.T.C. Sues to Stop Blockbuster Chip Deal Between Nvidia and Arm

abstract: The chip maker’s stock price has jumped over the last year thanks to its stranglehold on the market for the chips needed to build A.I. systems.
lead_paragraph: Move over, Microsoft and Apple. The stock market has a new king.
headline: Nvidia Becomes Most Valuable Public Company, Topping Microsoft

abstract: It was the S&P 500’s best day in more than a year, and the tech-heavy Nasdaq composite rose 3 percent.
lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street recorded their biggest gain in more than a year on Thursday, a day after Nvidia, which has become an emblem of the growth potential offered by artificial intelligence, reported record profits.
headline: Stocks Jump as Nvidia Sets Off Tech Rally

abstract: The company delivered a robust sales forecast, powered by demand for the processors that run artificial intelligence systems.
lead_paragraph: Shares in the chip maker Nvidia soared more than 24 percent on Thursday, after the company delivered a knockout quarterly sales outlook powered by demand for the processors that run artificial intelligence systems.
headline: A.I. Demand Lifts Nvidia Toward Trillion-Dollar Valuation

abstract: The Silicon Valley company was again lifted by sales of its artificial intelligence chips, but it faces growing competition and heightened expectations.
lead_paragraph: Nvidia, which makes microchips that power most artificial intelligence applications, began an extraordinary run a year ago.
headline: Nvidia, Powered by A.I. Boom, Reports Soaring Revenue and Profits

abstract: Sales for the current quarter will nearly triple their total a year ago, said the company, which makes chips essential to the development of A.I. systems.
lead_paragraph: In a sign that the tech industry’s next big boom is picking up steam, Nvidia on Wednesday predicted rapid growth in the already rabid demand for the chips it makes to build artificial intelligence systems.
headline: Nvidia Revenue Doubles on Demand for A.I. Chips, and Could Go Higher

abstract: The most visible winner of the artificial intelligence boom achieved its dominance by becoming a one-stop shop for A.I. development, from chips to software to other services.
lead_paragraph: Naveen Rao, a neuroscientist turned tech entrepreneur, once tried to compete with Nvidia, the world’s leading maker of chips tailored for artificial intelligence.
headline: How Nvidia Built a Competitive Moat Around A.I. Chips

abstract: Meet the schemers and savers obsessed with ending their careers as early as possible.
lead_paragraph: Even before he really knew what it meant, Allen Wong wanted to be rich. As a kid, he didn’t yet equate the word with “luxury” or “status” or “expensive things.” He didn’t think wealth would bring him 85-inch televisions and Jacuzzis, a one-of-a-kind rose-gold Lamborghini in the garage, a wearable Iron Man suit that shoots lasers — though he does, actually, have all of that now. What “rich” seemed to dangle was something simpler, more elementary, more a feeling than anything else: freedom from pain.
headline: Your Neighbors Are Retiring in Their 30s. Why Can’t You?

abstract: Expectations are sky-high for the chipmaker’s latest earnings report. The company is at the center of Wall Street’s focus on artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Despite concerns about stubbornly high inflation, elevated interest rates and ballooning U.S. debt, the S&P 500 is trading at a record on Wednesday, having soared 27 percent over the past year.
headline: Testing the Nvidia Boom

abstract: Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, said that he believed the United States was at least a decade away from breaking its dependence on chips created overseas.
lead_paragraph: Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, said that he believed the United States was at least a decade away from breaking its dependence on chips created overseas.
headline: U.S. Will Take Years to Reach Chip Independence, Nvidia C.E.O. Says
